webTitle: Charities need leaders to be effective

fields.headline: Charities need leaders to be effective
fields.standfirst: A leadership academy for the voluntary sector would contribute to its growing professionalism, writes Stephen Bubb
fields.trailText: A leadership academy for the voluntary sector would contribute to its growing professionalism, writes Stephen Bubb
fields.body:
Leadership is currently very fashionable. But is it just a trend? Or is it a term that truly defines the role of a chief executive? Probably the key role of a chief executive is leading change and developing the organisation and this applies whether it is a multi-million pound company or a small voluntary organisation.

Other sectors in the economy are promoting leadership. The civil service is developing a programme to provide stronger leadership. The recently published NHS plan promotes leadership and the establishment of a leadership centre. And there are plenty of expensive management courses for private sector executives learning to be leaders.

Cabinet secretary Sir Richard Wilson writes: "All studies of successful organisations show that strong leadership is essential to achieve change. We need leaders at all levels, but particularly at the top, who are actively committed to transforming their organisations, have a clear sense of direction, purpose and values, and inspire and motivate those they work with."

But is there some distrust of the concept of leadership in voluntary organisations? Many charities and membership organisations may dispute the need for the chief executive to be a leader. Perhaps they see the role more as that of a senior civil servant or administrator serving the trustees or board. The reality is that in an effective organisation there are leaders at many levels, but this is particularly true at the top where there needs to be a partnership, particularly between the chair and the chief executive. But it is the chief executive who leads the staff.

Yet, while the private sector, local government, civil service and the health authorities are now developing extensive leadership courses (and in some cases, leadership colleges) there is very little work, or visible support, for leadership in charities. This must be a major task for the sector. Indeed the concept of leadership sums up the drive for a greater professionalism in the sector as a whole. Should we not be looking at creating a leadership academy for the voluntary sector?

The idea is not about some grand stately home and long residential courses. Such an academy would be largely virtual. It would act as a resource base and centre for sharing good practice and for organising chief executive leadership development, learning from other sectors, drawing in international experience, advocacy and promotion of good professional practices and fostering talent.

At the National Lottery Charities Board I was able to pioneer a top managers leadership programme. This consisted of a short residential leadership course (the Industrial Society's Runge leadership programme) together with 360-degree appraisal, mentoring and individual learning support. Such a programme recognises that while there are core leadership values, development needs will vary.

The key mission of the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations is to promote and support leadership of chief executives. It is a role I want to promote but the task is larger than any one organisation. If the concept is worth supporting, then I believe we can find partners and supporters who can translate such an idea into action.

One American academic, John Kotter, defined leadership as creating a sense of purpose and direction in generating support for that vision. Perhaps a leadership academy is one such vision? Any supporters?

 Stephen Bubb is the new chief executive of the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations. Stephen will join www.SocietyGuardian.co.uk at 2.30pm on Thursday November 30 for an online chat with visitors to the site. Tell him what you think about his idea of establishing a leadership academy in the voluntary sector, discuss how charities evaluate their work, the Charity Commission's role, charity mergers, diversity in the sector, social investment or any other charity management issue. webTitle: Worthington Cup final on way to Wales

fields.headline: Worthington Cup final on way to Wales
fields.trailText: The Millennium Stadium is expected to be named as the venue for the Worthington Cup final next week.
fields.body:
The Millennium Stadium is expected to be named as the venue for the Worthington Cup final next week.

Representatives of the Football League were at the rugby international between Wales and South Africa on Sunday when the state of the pitch generated almost as much debate as who the Wales outside-half should have been. A league spokesman said: "We have no problems with the pitch which we have been assured will be conducive to quality football come February."

The Wales Rugby Union has asked for help from turf experts in New York and Amsterdam. Glanmor Griffiths, chairman of the WRU and Millennium Stadium plc, said: "We are addressing the problem and I'm confident that it will be sorted out in time for the soccer finals."

fields.headline: Pires clashes with O'Leary
fields.trailText: Details have emerged of a spat involving Robert Pires and David O'Leary after Sunday's match between Leeds and Arsenal, when O'Leary reportedly blew a kiss at Pires and the Frenchman responded by calling the Leeds manager a whore.
fields.body:
Arsenal's chances of wrenching the title from Manchester United's grasp may look increasingly bleak, but no one could ever accuse them of going down without a fight.

As the Football Association meted out a £25,000 fine for the lack of discipline from Arsène Wenger's players in Sunday's bad-tempered encounter at Leeds, details emerged last night of a clash between Robert Pires and David O'Leary.

Two local radio reporters had been interviewing O'Leary in the players' entrance, more than an hour after the match, when Pires walked past with Thierry Henry and muttered something in French. O'Leary responded by blowing a kiss in their direction and saying "au revoir". And with that all hell broke loose.

Pires had to be restrained by Henry as he attempted to confront O'Leary, with witnesses claiming he was repeatedly screaming " putain " - French slang for whore. O'Leary, in turn, was heard shouting to Henry: "Get him out of here, get him out of here." The Leeds manager then turned to his interviewers: "You're the proof. What have I done? What have I done?"

Henry eventually led his compatriot to Arsenal's team coach but not before turning to O'Leary and rebuking him for his behaviour: "It is not a nice way for a coach to behave."

O'Leary opted for a dignified silence yesterday but, according to an informed source, the Leeds manager is believed to have instigated the incident by blowing a kiss at Pires from the dug-out during his side's 1-0 win. The Arsenal winger was said to have tried to confront O'Leary in the tunnel after the final whistle.

As part of regulations introduced at the start of the season, the FA will fine Arsenal for having seven players cautioned. The club could face further action if Dermot Gallagher's match report refers to an incident in the tunnel in which several Arsenal players angrily remonstrated with him. The FA will also look at a video replay of a second-half challenge when the Gunners midfielder Patrick Vieira appeared to kick Olivier Dacourt in the jaw.

Wenger is awaiting a date for an appeal hearing into his 12-match touchline ban for allegedly manhandling the fourth official after Arsenal's defeat at Sunderland on the opening day of the season.

Newcastle United's French defender Alain Goma has joined his fellow centre-half Marcelino by asking for a transfer from St James' Park.

The 28-year-old Goma has impressed after initially struggling following his £4.5m arrival from Paris St-Germain in the summer of 1999. "We cannot tolerate any players who do not want to play for us," said the Newcastle chairman Freddie Shepherd. "If players don't shape up then we must ship them out."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Boro look to the usual suspects as Venables thinks again

fields.headline: Boro look to the usual suspects as Venables thinks again
fields.standfirst:
El Tel a staple of the shortlist
Harry Peasron: Boro beware cockney messiahs
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough intend to appoint a new manager at the Riverside, even if Terry Venables declines the offer to take up the reins of the struggling Premiership club.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough intend to appoint a new manager at the Riverside, even if Terry Venables declines the offer to take up the reins of the struggling Premiership club.

The Boro chairman Steve Gibson is still hopeful that Venables will accept the role of first-team manager but, preparing for the worst, the club have drawn up a short-list of alternative candidates should the 57-year-old turn them down.

The current manager Bryan Robson, who worked with Venables at Euro 96, has been earmarked to become the club's chief coach and Gibson is hopeful he will stay on in that capacity even if the former England coach declines the offer.

That scenario looks increasingly likely, despite the fact that Venables continued talks with Robson and the Boro chief executive Keith Lamb yesterday. He is apparently keen to manage Middlesbrough, currently 18th in the Premiership, after 22 months out of the game.

But Venables is also reluctant to relinquish his media commitments and business interests - particularly a hotel complex in Spain, similar to that at La Manga, designed for touring football teams - and does not believe he can do the Middlesbrough job justice on a part-time basis.

Given that the club's offer is dependent upon the Londoner moving to the north-east, relinquishing any business commitments in the capital and working for the Teesside club seven days a week, any possible deal appears likely to be scuppered.

The former England coach has promised Gibson an answer within the next 24 hours and, should he decline the role, the Boro chairman will turn his attention to his contingency list.

Possible candidates for the post include Ron Atkinson, who managed Robson at West Bromwich Albion and Manchester United, and the former Liverpool and Newcastle manager Kenny Dalglish. Kevin Keegan, another former England coach, is not thought to be in contention.

The speculation has done little for the frustrated Boro players. "You could have Venables, you could have Johan Cruyff but, if you go on the pitch and commit schoolboy errors, there's nothing he can do," said the Boro captain Paul Ince, who played under Venables with England.

Middlesbrough's supporters, clamouring for change after their side's miserable slide towards the foot of the table, had warmed to the prospect of Venables accepting the job but may now be forced to take more disappointment on the chin.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Boro beware cockney messiahs
fields.trailText: The experience of Malcolm Allison should make Boro fans think twice about hankering after the services of Terry Venables.
fields.body:
There has been talk among Middlesbrough fans for some time about the perceived inadequacies of Bryan Robson's coaching staff, particularly the former Old Trafford pairing of Gordon McQueen and Viv Anderson.

Striding out of a pub in Middlesbrough half-an-hour before Saturday's match with Bradford came three of Teesside's finest - burly blokes who spoke in the loud, deep, rumbling tones of cement mixers.

One expressed the desire for defeat followed by Robson's departure. "You say that," his mate responded, "but what if he goes and they put Anderson and McQueen in charge?"

"I'll go up the Transporter Bridge and jump off," came the swift response.

"You'll have to join the queue," the third member of the trio said.

"Hey, I tell you what," the first man replied, brightening, "McQueen and Anderson get the job, we'll bomb over to the Trannie, charge £1 entrance and we'll have our season-ticket money back in five minutes."

Unhappily for this triumvirate, their brilliant entrepreneurial scheme was scotched by a combination of a late Paul Ince equaliser and the rumours of the impending arrival of the coaching guru Terry Venables.

Admittedly, on a rain-swept Cleveland Saturday that had passed from dawn to dusk without anything so pretentious as morning and afternoon in between, the prospect of the irredeemably West End Venables making the trek north seemed an unlikely one. There is a precedent, however - Malcom Allison.

In October 1982 when the Dartford-born Allison took charge at Ayresome Park he was pretty much the apotheosis of cockney swank. Fedora hats, big cigars, champagne and snaps of him wallowing in the communal baths at Selhurst Park with the Crystal Palace team and soft-porn star Fiona Richmond had established Big Mal as an internationally renowned flash wideboy. El Tel, a Palace player at the time of the Richmond incident (he sensibly ducked out of that particular photo opportunity), looks thin and etiolated when set beside him.

In an interview in the Middlesbrough Supporters South newsletter last year Allison revealed that it was he who suggested to Venables that he take on Bryan Robson as part of the England coaching staff, a piece of matchmaking that did much to fuel the weekend rumours.

Eighteen years ago the arrival of Allison, who had recently won the Portuguese double with Sporting Lisbon, caused a greater stir in Middlesbrough than that of Venables would today. Back then the club was in even greater difficulties.

Bottom of the Second Division drop zone with crowds rarely breaking five figures they had moved from flirting with financial ruin to groping with it in the coat pile. In such desperate times Allison was hailed as the Messiah and toured round town on an open-topped bus. He averted relegation.

That summer the public responded to Big Mal's appeal and turned up by the hundred to help re-decorate Ayresome Park. They were joined by a number of players. How times have changed.

Whatever his motivational qualities it is hard to imagine Terry Venables managing to persuade Alen Boksic to pick up a paintbrush and a pot of Dulux and set to work on the Riverside stadium. Maybe this is just as well. Given the Croatian's luck with injuries he'd probably faint from the fumes and fall off the ladder.

Allison's response to all this excitement was suitably mysterious. He employed a body-movement coach and ordered badges bearing the motto "I was there at the beginning" to be distributed with season tickets at the start of his first term. Later he suggested that the Ayresome Park pitch be dyed orange. He was sacked after 18 months.

Despite that experience Allison still lives in the area. For a while he worked in the commentary box for local radio as an expert summariser. Unfortunately his language was sometimes too salty for comfort. It is alleged that his co-commentator was told to switch off Big Mal's microphone whenever it appeared he was about to swear.

Since this was the sort of job that would have taxed the reflexes of Michael Schumacher the inevitable happened. During a fraught derby with Newcastle Allison squeezed in an expletive before anyone could hit the button. And that was the end of that.

All in all then Allison is perhaps not the happiest of examples to set before El Tel. Then again, Venables recent record is hardly inspiring either.

Indeed, many Crystal Palace fans would suggest that anyone hoping to make a profit from a mass-suicide leap among supporters should take their former manager's arrival as a signal to start printing the tickets.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Case that left homeless out in the cold

fields.headline: Case that left homeless out in the cold
fields.standfirst: Care industry waits on appeal of Cambridge Two as fear drives needy away from shelters
fields.trailText: Care industry waits on appeal of Cambridge Two as fear drives needy away from shelters
fields.body:
A chilly day in Cambridge and a group of homeless people huddle in a car park, arguing and drinking. When the police move them on they will grumpily shuffle toward another gloomy corner in which to congregate.

Close by, on the other side of Midsummer Common is The Bus drop-in centre. A few years ago some 120 homeless people came and went freely, enjoying warmth, company and a hot meal. And then two of the centre's managers were arrested for "knowingly permitting" heroin dealing.

On Friday Ruth Wyner and John Brock - the Cambridge Two as they came to be known - will hear whether their appeal against their controversial conviction is to be overturned.

But no matter what the result, the case has caused great damage to the many organisations up and down the country who work with homeless people and drug users.

Some centres have seen a reduction in volunteers, worried that they too could also be accused of not doing enough to tackle drug dealing. Others have found fundraising ever more difficult. Many - The Bus included - have been forced to scrap "open door" policies and now monitor comings and goings with CCTV cameras and registers.

Inevitably this has led to suspicion between clients and staff at centres. One field worker said that some clients now saw hostels as another law enforcement agency. Some of the most vulnerable stay away, and this at a time when the government is urging the sector to be more inclusive.

The Bus, for example, continues to do invaluable work but now caters for a maximum of 80 visitors daily and, on one day this week, was down to the 50 mark. The rest are still out there but now loiter in parks, streets and the car parks.

At the heart of the case and of the ongoing insecurity in the sector is the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971. There was never any suggestion that Wyner and Brock, who were jailed in December last year for five and four years respectively, were involved in the dealing. The accusation was that they had not done enough to halt the trade.

Section eight of the act states that a person commits an offence if "being the occupier or concerned in the management of any premises he knowingly permits or suffers" a series of illegal activities including the supply of controlled drugs. It is also forbidden to allow the smoking of cannabis.

Following the conviction of the Cambridge Two, there was debate in the Commons over the original intentions of the act. Some MPs argued that it was intended to target the organisers of druggie nightclub parties. Many, including Cambridge Labour MP Anne Campbell, have argued that a simple modification of the wording of the section - perhaps by replacing the word "knowingly" with "wilfully" - could be enough to clarify the problem.

Thus far, however, the government has set its face against tinkering with the act.

There is real anger and frustration that in the 30 months since the arrest of Wyner and Brock there has been no firm guidance from ministers even though they have been keen for charities and organisations to work more inclusively with homeless people including those who use drugs.

Of course, it is impossible to work with homeless people without working with drug users. New statistics claim that 86% of homeless people take drugs and 57% are regarded as "problem drug users".

Sharon O'Hara, head of supported housing for the English Churches Housing Group - which has 2,500 beds for homeless people - said: "The case lessened our ability to work with drug users.

"Staff in some organisations have become much more wary about housing users in the first place. They want more information about someone before taking them in. And then if they discover drug taking, they are more likely to exclude the user forever. In the past they might have given them more chances. There has been little information from the government.

"There seems to be a conflict between it wanting us to be more inclusive and the concerns from staff over what will happen to them if they do work with people working with drugs."

Those who work with the homeless have been left in limbo. Martin Blakebrough, of the Kaleidoscope drop-in centre in Kingston-upon-Thames, Surrey, which takes in up to 500 addicts every day, said: "How far do you have to go to protect yourself? Do you have to search everyone who comes in?"

A judge suggested to Mr Blakebrough that Kaleidoscope should use sniffer dogs to help banish drugs.

But Mr Blakebrough said: "It is vital for street work that you retain the confidence of clients. Dogs sniffing around the centre would hardly engender mutual trust."

A few years ago some 120 homeless people came and went freely, enjoying warmth, company and a hot meal. And then two of the centre's managers were arrested for "knowingly permitting" heroin dealing. On Friday Ruth Wyner and John Brock - the Cambridge Two as they came to be known - will hear whether their appeal against their controversial conviction is to be overturned. But no matter what the result, the case has caused great damage to the many organisations up and down the country who work with homeless people and drug users. Some centres have seen a reduction in volunteers, worried that they too could also be accused of not doing enough to tackle drug dealing. Others have found fundraising ever more difficult. Many - The Bus included - have been forced to scrap "open door" policies and now monitor comings and goings with CCTV cameras and registers. Inevitably this has led to suspicion between clients and staff at centres. One field worker said that some clients now saw hostels as another law enforcement agency. Some of the most vulnerable stay away, and this at a time when the government is urging the sector to be more inclusive. The Bus, for example, continues to do invaluable work but now caters for a maximum of 80 visitors daily and, on one day this week, was down to the 50 mark. The rest are still out there but now loiter in parks, streets and the car parks. At the heart of the case and of the ongoing insecurity in the sector is the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971. There was never any suggestion that Wyner and Brock, who were jailed in December last year for five and four years respectively, were involved in the dealing. The accusation was that they had not done enough to halt the trade. Section eight of the act states that a person commits an offence if "being the occupier or concerned in the management of any premises he knowingly permits or suffers" a series of illegal activities including the supply of controlled drugs. It is also forbidden to allow the smoking of cannabis. Following the conviction of the Cambridge Two, there was debate in the Commons over the original intentions of the act. Some MPs argued that it was intended to target the organisers of druggie nightclub parties. Many, including Cambridge Labour MP Anne Campbell, have argued that a simple modification of the wording of the section - perhaps by replacing the word "knowingly" with "wilfully" - could be enough to clarify the problem. Thus far, however, the government has set its face against tinkering with the act. There is real anger and frustration that in the 30 months since the arrest of Wyner and Brock there has been no firm guidance from ministers even though they have been keen for charities and organisations to work more inclusively with homeless people including those who use drugs. Of course, it is impossible to work with homeless people without working with drug users. New statistics claim that 86% of homeless people take drugs and 57% are regarded as "problem drug users". Sharon O'Hara, head of supported housing for the English Churches Housing Group - which has 2,500 beds for homeless people - said: "The case lessened our ability to work with drug users. "Staff in some organisations have become much more wary about housing users in the first place. They want more information about someone before taking them in. And then if they discover drug taking, they are more likely to exclude the user forever. In the past they might have given them more chances. There has been little information from the government. "There seems to be a conflict between it wanting us to be more inclusive and the concerns from staff over what will happen to them if they do work with people working with drugs." Those who work with the homeless have been left in limbo. Martin Blakebrough, of the Kaleidoscope drop-in centre in Kingston-upon-Thames, Surrey, which takes in up to 500 addicts every day, said: "How far do you have to go to protect yourself? Do you have to search everyone who comes in?" A judge suggested to Mr Blakebrough that Kaleidoscope should use sniffer dogs to help banish drugs. But Mr Blakebrough said: "It is vital for street work that you retain the confidence of clients. Dogs sniffing around the centre would hardly engender mutual trust."

webTitle: Local government finances fluctuate despite drive for stability

fields.headline: Local government finances fluctuate despite drive for stability
fields.standfirst: Local authorities still face plenty of instability in central grant support arrangements despite the government's aim of introducing stability, writes Tony Travers
fields.trailText: Local authorities still face plenty of instability in central grant support arrangements despite the government's aim of introducing stability, writes Tony Travers
fields.body:
The revenue support grant settlement never loses its importance for local government.

The allocation of £44.4bn of external support to local authorities is the single most important event in their year. Such is the level of interest that many councils send an official to pick up the papers from the glassy offices of the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) near Buckingham Palace. The sight of so many local government representatives standing in a long queue, waiting patiently for their brown envelopes stuffed with facts and figures, resembles nothing so much as Oliver Twist.

In fact, deputy prime minister John Prescott was trying hard to avoid the image of Scrooge that has haunted the government in the past. Overall total standard spending (TSS - the government's aggregate figure of revenue spending by local authorities) is to rise by over 6% on a settlement-to-settlement basis. Because 2000-01 budgets exceeded the government's forecasts, the actual rise may be lower. In real terms, TSS is likely to increase by perhaps 2 to 3%, which is certainly more generous than in a number of previous years, though not quite the jackpot some ministers have previously suggested.

Aggregate external finance (revenue support grant, business rates, specific grants and other government funding) will also rise, in total, by over 6%. There should not, therefore, be any significant increase in the proportion of local government financed from council tax. The government's own figures suggest that the council tax for standard spending (for a Band D property) will go up 5%.

Ministers have made it clear on many occasions that they will not change the standard spending assessment (SSA) method of distributing central grant support during the period of the current review of the grant system. However, new data about population and earnings levels have been fed into the SSA system, despite a long wrangle within government about whether or not to do so. The use of new earnings figures was particularly controversial, as it impacted on the much-disputed area cost adjustment. To education secretary David Blunkett's dismay, the use of new data would, in general, shift resources into London and the south-east.

In order to dampen the impact of the new earnings and population data, DETR has reintroduced some old friends: "floors" and "ceilings". No authority with education and social services responsibilities will receive less than a 3.2% increase in the (total) central support they receive in 2001-02 as compared with 2000-01, while none will receive more than a 6.5% increase. For other authorities, it is proposed to adopt similar rules for protection as for 2000-01: no authority will receive less central support in 2001-02 than in 2000-01. The government has also outlined an "alternative proposal" without floors and ceilings.

As ever, the real problem for local government will be to make sense of the complex packages of information that have been published. Even when the government is seeking to achieve "more stability", there is still plenty of instability. Many authorities will once again find it hard to understand how a "no change" settlement can lead to so much redistribution. As always, next year's council budgets and tax levels will depend primarily on Mr Prescott's early Christmas present.

webTitle: White paper promotes 'market town without a market'

fields.headline: White paper promotes 'market town without a market'
fields.standfirst: The government's new white paper on the countryside fails to address fundamentals of rural decline, argues Derek Brown
fields.trailText: The government's new white paper on the countryside fails to address fundamentals of rural decline, argues Derek Brown
fields.body:
The government's new white paper on the countryside is full of good intentions about reinvigorating the rural economy. There will be measures to provide affordable housing, develop better public transport and encourage commercial development and diversification. That's all fine, but it is built on a flawed premise: that the needs of country folk are somehow different from those of townies. They aren't.

Of course, there is a need for affordable housing: ask anyone in Middle Wallop, or in Bermondsey. Naturally, the countryside needs better public transport - so how was it this morning on the Tube? And it goes without saying that new jobs must be created: anyone in Sunderland or Paisley knows that.

There is something essentially condescending about the government assumption that the rural lives are any different from urban ones. And even if they were, how could a set of new measures be applied evenly to the Lincolnshire Wolds, the Somerset Levels, the Romney Marshes, and the Cumbrian hills? When it comes to regional variations, one size most definitely does not fit all.

The very concept of "countryside" is blurred by sentiment. We like to think that our landscapes are as old as time, and that human encroachment is at best a necessary evil. That's rubbish. Virtually every square inch of our island has been moulded and shaped by us. We made the fields, drained the meadows, sent our sheep to graze the hills, diverted the rivers and built the walls. The hedgerows being ripped out, to universal lamentation, mark the historically recent enclosure of old common lands - one of the most dramatic human assaults on the landscape.

Of course, the countryside is changing fast. It always has. A century ago or more, Flora Thompson wrote about the fast-vanishing lifestyle of rural north Oxfordshire, in Lark Rise. Scarcely a generation later Laurie Lee wrote about about the same thing happening in Gloucestershire, in Cider With Rosie. Their worlds were utterly different from each other. Now, again, we have the sentimentalists droning on about the pace of change, and the irreversible damage being done to our green and pleasant heritage.

The very people who are most garrulous about rural problems are those who contribute to them. They are the weekenders, the second home-owners, the four-wheel drivers and the "green-welly" class in general. And the answers they have come up with, exactly reflect their own interests.

The white paper talks of relaxing the planning regime - already in tatters - to encourage the conversion of farm buildings, for example, into high-tech offices. What a boon that will be for the Jeremies and Fionas who want to move out of the city and work from home.

There is also talk of reviving the fortunes of old market towns, many of which have been blighted by the closure of shops and pubs and other businesses. An excellent idea, but how exactly is it to be done? New rural bus services would be grand, but why exactly would people come into a market town, if there is no market?

Nothing in the white paper addresses the fundamentals of rural decline, which are more or less exactly the same as those of urban decline: to take an obvious example, the remorseless grip of the giant supermarket companies on the consumer economy. They drive small traders out of business, force down farm prices, and clog the national road network with their juggernauts. A community bus service is unlikely to make much of a dent in their monopolistic ambition, except by delivering even more customers to the out-of-town Asdawaytescobury's.

fields.headline: Barak calls early elections
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, has called a general election.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, has called a general election.

The announcement came in the middle of a parliamentary debate brought by five opposition members calling for an early poll.

Mr Barak's minority government has been in peril since parliament returned from recess four weeks ago.

Many hardliners in the opposition would like to see his government fall for what they believe is its reluctance to take severe action against the Palestinians.

The date of the new elections will be set in the coming days through negotiations with the opposition, which recommended May. Mr Barak was elected to a 4-year term in May 1999.

The agreement could bring down his government, but it also gives him time before the election for a last-ditch effort to forge an agreement with the Palestinians.

Mr Barak's minority government has been steadily losing support as violence has persisted in Gaza and the West Bank, and it has been in peril since parliament returned from recess a month ago.

webTitle: Comment: France's rural life a model for UK

fields.headline: Rural life better across the ditch
fields.standfirst: Britain could learn a lesson from France when it comes to managing its countryside, says political editor Michael White
fields.trailText:
Britain could learn a lesson from France when it comes to managing its countryside, says political editor
Michael White
fields.body:
As a creature of habit I usually take two holidays a year, one week in St Ives, Cornwall, at Easter and two or three weeks in a village in southwest France in the summer. And I do not need today's rural white paper from the government to tell me which country conducts its rural life better.

France wins every time. The contrasts are painful. It may be argued, rightly, that Cornwall, where I grew up, is the poorest county in England, hammered by successive disasters in agriculture, fishing, defence cuts and tourism. Tin, like pilchards, went west a long time ago.

Neither Tony Blair nor William Hague is to blame for the fact that affordable package tours to hotter seasides have hurt St Ives and its rival southwest resorts. But cooler climates can fight back, just as post-industrial economies can diversify. The best model looks for fewer visitors but ones which spend more.

Despite everything (as I often put it) celtic Cornwall remains as good as the novelists and travel writers say. The Penwith peninsular is impressive: steeped in history, rugged landscape, fabulous beaches and remnants of pre-history too. All this and it has a thriving artistic life which fills galleries in St Ives, Penzance and Newlyn.

Cornwall has been slow to learn this lesson, though the creation of the Tate of the west on the site of the bombed gasworks above Porthmeor Beach has overcome local scepticism by boosting the till take at local hotels and restaurants by over 20%.

The county has been improving its wet weather tourist facilities for years and Truro - which I visited last weekend - is as good a town as you will find in all but the wealthiest shires, though it seems to have drained the life blood from some of its nearby commercial rivals in the process.

The Eden project, the brainchild of John Smit of Lost Gardens of Heligan fame, which is gouged out of a south-facing china clay pit outside St Austell, also has huge potential as a world class tourist attraction - the millennium dome that worked. Plants from around the world are now arriving at the huge biodomes we stared down on at the weekend.

There are already concerns about the size of carparks, roads, hotels and B&Bs if the project becomes a runaway success. The badly-needed posh visitors can't all stay at the nearby Carlyon Bay hotel, though it was good enough for Tony Blair's recent visit.

But Cornwall needs its own university. There are plans to create a greenfield campus at Penryrn next to the distinguished Falmouth School of Art, with £300m worth of EU funds provided under ''objective one'' programmes for poor regions.

But £30m of matching funds must be found from business, government or philanthropists. The higher education funding council, Whitehall's arms-length manager of university cash, has no capital fund. Meetings are under way but it is tricky.

Yet a knowledge economy where unskilled jobs are in dwindling supply needs educated people to stay in Cornwall. I left. So did my brothers and sisters. So did my father, his siblings and his father - a St Just in Penwith mining captain - though they all came home to die. If I do the same I will unavoidably price someone out of a home they might otherwise have afforded.

Rural France - "la France profonde" - has many problems like this. But it is managing them better.

This is partly because France is twice the size of Britain with the same population. And unlike Britain, France was a rural economy for over a century until 1945. It retains a vast network of villages. Modernisation and the flight to better paid jobs in the cities came late. Most French people have personal or parental experience of rural life in a way that most English people do not, though the flight back to the country is changing that.

But the part of France we go to in summer - on the borders of the Lot and Aveyron departments north of Toulouse - has taken a beating. Most of the land is poor and EU farm subsidies have been taken away. Villages which once supported 800 people now have 150 in the winter and 250 in the summer.

Yet each village has a mayor. The roads are well maintained. The main roads are improved every year, three lane nightmares becoming four or even six lane highways of motorway standard. Even more curious to the incoming British, Belgians, Dutch and Germans, the villages are not rotting.

Every summer there is a new tabac selling foreign newspapers, a new tourist centre, an upgraded mini-market which stays open sensible hours, a second café with touristy food, a new tennis court to attract people to rent the local gite - that chain of older houses done up with state subsidies to protect the rural heritage and draw in even more visitors.

Rural poverty is as bad as the urban kind. I know that where I come from. But you do not feel it in France in the way you do at home. Small towns and villages retain a civic life which seems to nurture rural values - good and bad - which seem harder to sustain at home.

Townies and foreigners are regarded with suspicious distain in France too, though I know a Sunday morning market where an English couple have been selling homemade marmalade and Dundee cake for years. And BBC TV recently described how an English farmer had given up but started again in the Ardeche.

The key is our old friend, state subsidy, only it is not focused exclusively on agriculture (the expat farmer got a £60,000 loan) but the whole community and its infrastructure. That too is a trick we have yet to learn properly though the rural white paper will help.

It is not true that foreigners do everything better. French city dwellers flock to London or Ashford in Kent to set up businesses because it is cheaper and quicker to do so than at home. But foreigners do fare better in the countryside. More's the pity since ours is every bit as good as theirs.

fields.headline: Rural white paper: main points
fields.trailText: The government's rural white paper is intended to be a blueprint for the rejuvenation of the countryside. Here are its main proposals.
fields.body:
The government's rural white paper is intended to be a blueprint for the rejuvenation of the countryside. Here are its main proposals.

 A 50% rate cut for village shops, pubs and garages which offer a benefit to the community

 Giving local councils discretion to end the 50% council tax discounts for second homes, with the money going to providing cheaper homes

 Putting £100m towards one-stop healthcare centres in 100 communities

 Revitalising rural post offices with £270m of investment

 Putting £240m into rural transport schemes with a new £15m special transport fund to support car clubs, taxi services, and community transport

 Giving extra rate relief to farmers who diversify into new businesses

 Strengthening the role of parish councils to give local people more say in how local services are provided

 Increasing the number of farmers' markets from 250 to 400

 Building 9,000 affordable homes each year across rural districts

 Giving £37m extra regeneration money to market towns to bring in new business

 Using information technology to connect people in rural areas to good and services

 Revitalising rural post offices with £270m of investment

 Putting £240m into rural transport schemes with a new £15m special transport fund to support car clubs, taxi services, and community transport

 Giving extra rate relief to farmers who diversify into new businesses

 Strengthening the role of parish councils to give local people more say in how local services are provided

 Increasing the number of farmers' markets from 250 to 400

 Building 9,000 affordable new homes each year across rural districts

 Giving £37m extra regeneration money to market towns to bring in new business

webTitle: The end of an Ofsted era

fields.headline: Exit chief inspector
fields.standfirst: Chris Woodhead leaves Ofsted on Thursday. On the same day, a 'failed' London school will be the first to challenge an inspection in court.  Ted Wragg on the end of an era
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead leaves Ofsted on Thursday. On the same day, a 'failed' London school will be the first to challenge an inspection in court. Ted Wragg on the end of an era
fields.body:
One day the Office for Standards in Education sent a team of inspectors into a primary school. Nothing unusual about that. On this occasion, however, there was a teeny problem. The school had just one pupil, and he was part-time. Nonetheless, the ponderous inspection machinery clanked into action.

The inspectors duly reported that 100% of parents/pupils/teachers did this, while 0% did the other. As David Hart of the National Association of Head Teachers observed at the time, once the Ofsted juggernaut had started rolling, nothing could stop it, least of all common sense.

In September 1994, a day after Chris Woodhead took up the post, press accounts were full of threats from the newly appointed chief inspector. "Schools watchdog attacks classroom failures who betray our children: Sack the useless teachers" was just one headline.

On Thursday this week, as most of the nation's teachers cartwheel round the playground in celebration of his last day, Woodhead faces a legal challenge from Crown Woods Comprehensive School in Eltham, south London. The school is objecting to the conduct of its re-inspection, saying that draconian conclusions were reached on the basis of too slender evidence.

This is symptomatic of the adversarial relationship schools have with Woodhead, but it is also an extremely important test case. Schools believe there is no appeal against Ofsted judgments.But if Crown Woods wins, others could challenge the monopolists.

A teacher wrote to me recently asking if I could explain her inspection feedback. Though fully bilingual in both English and Ofsted, I was baffled. One inspector described a lesson as being "on the sound side of satisfactory". Later in the week a different inspector summarised a session as "on the satisfactory side of sound". Another teacher, with 25 years' teaching experience, told me that her feedback stated, "Your lessons are generally good and never less than sound". A quarter of a century in a nutshell.

What on earth do words such as "sound" and "satisfactory" do to improve someone's performance? As a researcher and teacher trainer, I watch dozens of lessons in primary and secondary schools. Ofsted-speak never features. Nor does it figure in any aspect of daily life: "These frozen peas are generally sound"; "Beethoven's Fifth Symphony is well above the national average"; "This car needs to go into special measures". I think not.

Such episodes from Ofsted inspections explain exactly what is wrong with the empire over which Woodhead presided. Set up so it could be sustained by armies of private profit-making firms, it had to be formulaic. All of them would, in theory, apply the same dreary procedures. The many good inspectors have tried to humanise the process, often apologising in advance for turning into the speaking clock at the final debriefing.

But why should they have to do this? Teaching is supposed to be a creative activity, carried out by professional people, not by robots. It is not surprising that they see such formulae, detached from intelligent dialogue and advice, as insensitive and professionally demeaning.

The saddest feature about Ofsted during the last six years has been its low credibility. Few people working in education feel they can take its pronouncements seriously. Too many of them seemed to reflect Woodhead's own prejudices. What is often a mixed picture in research studies, like the efficacy of "traditional" teaching, was presented as much more certain in his pronouncements. The many drafts of the report on Birmingham local education authority showed inconsistencies. In one section it would say there were real improvements, not mere rhetoric, while in a later one it would attack rhetoric.

There are exceptions. He drew attention to the lower achievement of boys before it became a fashionable topic. This is precisely what a chief inspector should do. He talked, quite rightly, about schools that were failing their pupils. This should certainly not be a taboo subject, but nor should it be used to flagellate the mass of teachers.

Of course schools gain something from inspection. People who say they learned nothing at all are either arrogant or unwilling to listen. The question is: would head governors, given a choice, pay such a substantial sum of money for a limited product and a high degree of stress?

Inspection is far too important to be done mechanically. Reform of Ofsted is long overdue. The departure of Woodhead, and other senior people close to retirement, offers an opportunity to fashion something that suits the needs of 21st-century schools better than the current 19th-century model of scourging.

First, politicians must not panic and enmesh the next chief inspector in a strait-jacket of committees and ministerial approval. There were good reasons why, for most of two centuries, it was the monarch's inspectorate. We need an independentservice, where the chief inspector is free to praise and criticise, provided judgment is based on evidence.

Second, there should be a combined local and national inspection service, bringing together the objectivity and overview of national inspectors with the local knowledge of those in the region. There could thus be proper follow-up of reports to make sure that action followed, rather than relief or inertia.

Third, schools that are succeeding should be left in peace for longer, with interim mini-inspections to make sure all is well and the option to mount a full-scale inspection if there is just cause.

Fourth, the dictionary of Ofstedspeak should be buried at the foot of a deep mine and left to rot, so that normal intelligent dialogue could take place when schools are inspected.

When the retiring chief inspector enters the House of Lords, the myths will resurface. Apparently he drove up standards (inspected schools actually improved more slowly than non-inspected schools). He fought a lone battle (no one else in education wanted to improve things?). He managed a huge inspection programme (senior inspectors Mike Tomlinson, Anthea Millett and Jim Rose ran their socks off). The best thing about Woodhead's departure is that there is no "ism": "Woodheadism" simply does not exist. A new era can begin.

I think Tomlinson will do a good job and restore credibility as chief inspector. His remark about not giving "a monkey's toss about teachers" was unfortunate, but in the same breath he said children should come first - not a bad sentiment. As for Screaming Lord Woodhead, future rightwing aristocrat, journalist and PR man, I hope he and the Conservatives will be very happy together.

webTitle: White paper promotes 'market town without a market'

fields.headline: White paper promotes 'market town without a market'
fields.standfirst:
The government's new white paper on the countryside fails to address fundamentals of rural decline, argues Derek Brown

Government white paper: a fair deal for rural England
fields.trailText: The government's new white paper on the countryside fails to address fundamentals of rural decline, argues Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The government's new white paper on the countryside is full of good intentions about reinvigorating the rural economy. There will be measures to provide affordable housing, develop better public transport and encourage commercial development and diversification. That's all fine, but it is built on a flawed premise: that the needs of country folk are somehow different from those of townies. They aren't.

Of course, there is a need for affordable housing: ask anyone in Middle Wallop, or in Bermondsey. Naturally, the countryside needs better public transport - so how was it this morning on the Tube? And it goes without saying that new jobs must be created: anyone in Sunderland or Paisley knows that.

There is something essentially condescending about the government assumption that the rural lives are any different from urban ones. And even if they were, how could a set of new measures be applied evenly to the Lincolnshire Wolds, the Somerset Levels, the Romney Marshes, and the Cumbrian hills? When it comes to regional variations, one size most definitely does not fit all.

The very concept of "countryside" is blurred by sentiment. We like to think that our landscapes are as old as time, and that human encroachment is at best a necessary evil. That's rubbish. Virtually every square inch of our island has been moulded and shaped by us. We made the fields, drained the meadows, sent our sheep to graze the hills, diverted the rivers and built the walls. The hedgerows being ripped out, to universal lamentation, mark the historically recent enclosure of old common lands - one of the most dramatic human assaults on the landscape.

Of course, the countryside is changing fast. It always has. A century ago or more, Flora Thompson wrote about the fast-vanishing lifestyle of rural north Oxfordshire, in Lark Rise. Scarcely a generation later Laurie Lee wrote about about the same thing happening in Gloucestershire, in Cider With Rosie. Their worlds were utterly different from each other. Now, again, we have the sentimentalists droning on about the pace of change, and the irreversible damage being done to our green and pleasant heritage.

The very people who are most garrulous about rural problems are those who contribute to them. They are the weekenders, the second home-owners, the four-wheel drivers and the "green-welly" class in general. And the answers they have come up with, exactly reflect their own interests.

The white paper talks of relaxing the planning regime - already in tatters - to encourage the conversion of farm buildings, for example, into high-tech offices. What a boon that will be for the Jeremies and Fionas who want to move out of the city and work from home.

There is also talk of reviving the fortunes of old market towns, many of which have been blighted by the closure of shops and pubs and other businesses. An excellent idea, but how exactly is it to be done? New rural bus services would be grand, but why exactly would people come into a market town, if there is no market?

Nothing in the white paper addresses the fundamentals of rural decline, which are more or less exactly the same as those of urban decline: to take an obvious example, the remorseless grip of the giant supermarket companies on the consumer economy. They drive small traders out of business, force down farm prices, and clog the national road network with their juggernauts. A community bus service is unlikely to make much of a dent in their monopolistic ambition, except by delivering even more customers to the out-of-town Asdawaytescobury's.

webTitle: Comment: France's rural life a model for UK

fields.headline: Rural life better across the ditch
fields.standfirst:
Britain could learn a lesson from France when it comes to managing its countryside, says political editor Michael White

Government white paper: A fair deal for rural England
fields.trailText:
Britain could learn a lesson from France when it comes to managing its countryside, says political editor Michael White.

Government white paper: A fair deal for rural England
fields.body:
As a creature of habit I usually take two holidays a year, one week in St Ives, Cornwall, at Easter and two or three weeks in a village in southwest France in the summer. And I do not need today's rural white paper from the government to tell me which country conducts its rural life better.

France wins every time. The contrasts are painful. It may be argued, rightly, that Cornwall, where I grew up, is the poorest county in England, hammered by successive disasters in agriculture, fishing, defence cuts and tourism. Tin, like pilchards, went west a long time ago.

Neither Tony Blair nor William Hague is to blame for the fact that affordable package tours to hotter seasides have hurt St Ives and its rival southwest resorts. But cooler climates can fight back, just as post-industrial economies can diversify. The best model looks for fewer visitors but ones which spend more.

Despite everything (as I often put it) celtic Cornwall remains as good as the novelists and travel writers say. The Penwith peninsular is impressive: steeped in history, rugged landscape, fabulous beaches and remnants of pre-history too. All this and it has a thriving artistic life which fills galleries in St Ives, Penzance and Newlyn.

Cornwall has been slow to learn this lesson, though the creation of the Tate of the west on the site of the bombed gasworks above Porthmeor Beach has overcome local scepticism by boosting the till take at local hotels and restaurants by over 20%.

The county has been improving its wet weather tourist facilities for years and Truro - which I visited last weekend - is as good a town as you will find in all but the wealthiest shires, though it seems to have drained the life blood from some of its nearby commercial rivals in the process.

The Eden project, the brainchild of John Smit of Lost Gardens of Heligan fame, which is gouged out of a south-facing china clay pit outside St Austell, also has huge potential as a world class tourist attraction - the millennium dome that worked. Plants from around the world are now arriving at the huge biodomes we stared down on at the weekend.

There are already concerns about the size of carparks, roads, hotels and B&Bs if the project becomes a runaway success. The badly-needed posh visitors can't all stay at the nearby Carlyon Bay hotel, though it was good enough for Tony Blair's recent visit.

But Cornwall needs its own university. There are plans to create a greenfield campus at Penryrn next to the distinguished Falmouth School of Art, with £300m worth of EU funds provided under ''objective one'' programmes for poor regions.

But £30m of matching funds must be found from business, government or philanthropists. The higher education funding council, Whitehall's arms-length manager of university cash, has no capital fund. Meetings are under way but it is tricky.

Yet a knowledge economy where unskilled jobs are in dwindling supply needs educated people to stay in Cornwall. I left. So did my brothers and sisters. So did my father, his siblings and his father - a St Just in Penwith mining captain - though they all came home to die. If I do the same I will unavoidably price someone out of a home they might otherwise have afforded.

Rural France - "la France profonde" - has many problems like this. But it is managing them better.

This is partly because France is twice the size of Britain with the same population. And unlike Britain, France was a rural economy for over a century until 1945. It retains a vast network of villages. Modernisation and the flight to better paid jobs in the cities came late. Most French people have personal or parental experience of rural life in a way that most English people do not, though the flight back to the country is changing that.

But the part of France we go to in summer - on the borders of the Lot and Aveyron departments north of Toulouse - has taken a beating. Most of the land is poor and EU farm subsidies have been taken away. Villages which once supported 800 people now have 150 in the winter and 250 in the summer.

Yet each village has a mayor. The roads are well maintained. The main roads are improved every year, three lane nightmares becoming four or even six lane highways of motorway standard. Even more curious to the incoming British, Belgians, Dutch and Germans, the villages are not rotting.

Every summer there is a new tabac selling foreign newspapers, a new tourist centre, an upgraded mini-market which stays open sensible hours, a second café with touristy food, a new tennis court to attract people to rent the local gite - that chain of older houses done up with state subsidies to protect the rural heritage and draw in even more visitors.

Rural poverty is as bad as the urban kind. I know that where I come from. But you do not feel it in France in the way you do at home. Small towns and villages retain a civic life which seems to nurture rural values - good and bad - which seem harder to sustain at home.

Townies and foreigners are regarded with suspicious distain in France too, though I know a Sunday morning market where an English couple have been selling homemade marmalade and Dundee cake for years. And BBC TV recently described how an English farmer had given up but started again in the Ardeche.

The key is our old friend, state subsidy, only it is not focused exclusively on agriculture (the expat farmer got a £60,000 loan) but the whole community and its infrastructure. That too is a trick we have yet to learn properly though the rural white paper will help.

It is not true that foreigners do everything better. French city dwellers flock to London or Ashford in Kent to set up businesses because it is cheaper and quicker to do so than at home. But foreigners do fare better in the countryside. More's the pity since ours is every bit as good as theirs.

But the part of France we go to in summer - on the borders of the Lot and Aveyron departments north of Toulouse - has taken a beating. Most of the land is poor and EU farm subsidies have been taken away. Villages which once supported 800 people now have 150 in the winter and 250 in the summer. Yet each village has a mayor. The roads are well maintained. The main roads are improved every year, three lane nightmares becoming four or even six lane highways of motorway standard. Even more curious to the incoming British, Belgians, Dutch and Germans, the villages are not rotting. Every summer there is a new tabac selling foreign newspapers, a new tourist centre, an upgraded mini-market which stays open sensible hours, a second café with touristy food, a new tennis court to attract people to rent the local gite - that chain of older houses done up with state subsidies to protect the rural heritage and draw in even more visitors. Rural poverty is as bad as the urban kind. I know that where I come from. But you do not feel it in France in the way you do at home. Small towns and villages retain a civic life which seems to nurture rural values - good and bad - which seem harder to sustain at home. Townies and foreigners are regarded with suspicious distain in France too, though I know a Sunday morning market where an English couple have been selling homemade marmalade and Dundee cake for years. And BBC TV recently described how an English farmer had given up but started again in the Ardeche. The key is our old friend, state subsidy, only it is not focused exclusively on agriculture (the expat farmer got a £60,000 loan) but the whole community and its infrastructure. That too is a trick we have yet to learn properly though the rural white paper will help. It is not true that foreigners do everything better. French city dwellers flock to London or Ashford in Kent to set up businesses because it is cheaper and quicker to do so than at home. But foreigners do fare better in the countryside. More's the pity since ours is every bit as good as theirs. webTitle: Batistuta breaks Florentine hearts, and his own

fields.headline: Batistuta breaks Florentine hearts, and his own
fields.trailText: Before Roma's match against Fiorentina on Sunday night, Gabriel Batistuta walked over to the Viola fans and saluted them. Then, eight minutes from time, he buried them - with a goal that Fabio Capello later hailed as a "masterpiece."
fields.body:
Before Roma's match against Fiorentina on Sunday night, Gabriel Batistuta walked over to the Viola fans and saluted them. Then, eight minutes from time, he buried them - with a goal that Fabio Capello later hailed as a "masterpiece."

At that stage the game looked to be petering out into a scoreless draw: Fiorentina coach Fatih Terim's disciplined 4-5-1 had smothered Capello's usually fluent 3-4-1-2 formation, and Batistuta appeared out of sorts. Then - suddenly - Guigou's header dropped to him 25-yards out, and a moment later Toldo was clawing in thin air as a thunderous volley flew high into the net. The Giallorossi were 1-0 ahead, and everyone in the Stadio d'Olimpico went wild.

Well, not quite everyone. Because rather than celebrate with his team-mates, who hugged and grabbed and kissed him, Batistuta was lost in his own private world. He shut his eyes, as if to holding back tears and when he eventually walked back to the half-way line, his head was bowed, like a sinner looking for penance.

During the post-match interviews, Batistuta - who spent nine years in Florence - admitted he was still emotionally torn. "At the end of the game I felt real joy because we gained three important points but soon after I couldn't help but feel really sad either, thinking back at all those years spent with Fiorentina," he confessed. "My family grew up in Florence, There I became what I am now, and those are things that cannot be forgotten."

"I hope that the Viola fans understand that. I think I paid my respects to them. The rest is for me to judge. Certainly I cannot say that I am happy to have scored against my former team-mates, but Roma wanted the win."

"I did not want to punish Fiorentina. Sometimes, though, we have to do things that we don't want to. Now and again I think that certain games should not be played," he added.

Maybe Batistuta will feel a little better when he looks at the Serie A table. Roma are now on 21 points, three ahead of Atlanta, five ahead of Udinese and Bologna and, perhaps crucially, six ahead of Juventus and nine ahead of Lazio.

Another Argentinean striker facing his old club this weekend was Hernan Crespo. But the £35m man - who has been out of form all season - had another day to forget as Lazio crumbled to a 2-0 defeat away at Parma.

Sergio Conceicao - who moved to Parma as part of the Crespo transfer - opened the scoring in the tenth minute, and Sabri Lamouchi sealed the win in injury time. Parma dominated the game and deserved their victory, while Lazio were again lifeless, and allowed Mattias Almeyda - another makeweight in the Crespo deal - to boss the midfield. No wonder the increasingly irate Lazio supporters unfurled a 'Eriksson must go' banner during the game.

Juventus have also been struggling of late, but Carlo Ancelotti's side proved too strong for Verona on Sunday, powering to a 2-1 victory that was more comfortable than the scoreline suggests.

Ancelotti dropped Alessandro Del Piero for the first time in five years and replaced him with French international David Trezeguet. The decision paid dividends after 38 minutes when the French striker put Juventus 1-0 ahead. Fellow countryman Zinedine Zidane then doubled the lead 17 minutes from time before Martins Adailton snatched a late equaliser.

After the game Ancelotti denied he had dropped Del Piero. Instead, he insisted, the move was part of a new 'squad rotation' policy. "I'm sure Del Piero is capable of performing as well as Trezeguet," claimed Ancelotti. "We have four good strikers and I intend to play them according to what the conditions dictate."

Meanwhile Zidane - who has been criticised by his own supporters in recent weeks - was happy with Juventus's performance. "We badly needed the victory today," he admitted. "We are rebuilding the team spirit and today we saw some of the fruits of that effort.

"After being knocked out of the Champions League, the Italian Cup and failing to qualify for the Uefa Cup, all we have left is the Serie A championship. So this is our objective and we have to put everything into it."

Despite the result Juventus are still only fifth - behind Atalanta, who beat Lecce 1-0, Udinese, who lost 2-0 away at Bari, and Bologna, who beat Perugia 3-1. But don't be surprised if Roma are looking anxiously over their shoulder. The Old Lady might just have some life in her after all.

fields.headline: Bush prepares for power
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush sought to tighten his grip on the presidency today by moving key operatives to Washington and seeking private financing for what he believes will be his transition to power.
fields.body:
George W Bush sought to tighten his grip on the presidency today by moving key operatives to Washington and seeking private financing for what he believes will be his transition to power.

As the Democrats continued to make court challenges against the certification of Mr Bush as winner of Florida's contested presidential balloting, the Texas governor was pressing ahead with plans to form a new government.

Meanwhile, the vice president, Al Gore, is contunuing his attempts to rally a sceptical public behind an unprecedented legal challenge to Mr Bush's pivotal victory in Florida, which was controversially declared on Sunday.

Mr Gore claims ballots have not been fully counted and that "ignoring votes means ignoring democracy itself."

Today, the Democrat vice-presidential running mate, Joseph Lieberman, made the rounds on this morning's television programmes, fighting for the initiative in the PR battle following Mr Gore's televised address last night.

But public opinion polls point to an uphill climb for the vice president. A CNN-USA Today-Gallup survey, released just before Mr Gore spoke, showed 56% of those polled believe the vice president should concede, and 38% believed he should not.

Mr Bush's vice presidential running mate, Dick Cheney, who is overseeing transition planning, said: "We can move fairly rapidly in a couple of areas, but he has to decide the timing."

He added there was a "good possibility" that a Bush cabinet would include some Democrats, although overall the Republicans plan to take of the 3,000 top positions from them.

Mr Cheney said: "The governor has given me instructions to look in those areas  we clearly will."

However, while Mr Bush wants the keys to the transition office, the general services administration in Washington is refusing to open it or release the allotted $5.3m for the next president-elect until the contest is unequivocally settled.

Mr Cheney said: "This is regrettable, because we believe the government has an obligation to honour the certified results of the election. Despite the decision, we feel it is our obligation to the American people to honour their votes by moving forward and assembling the administration that they've chosen in this election."

Mr Cheney said Mr Bush was reaching out to people with experience, including some from his father's and Ronald Reagan's administrations, but he added: "We're also going to want new talent. We're going to want to emphasise diversity. We're going to want a broad cabinet."

There has been no letup in the legal skirmishing between the two sides.

Mr Bush's legal team had written arguments to submit to the US supreme court in Washington in support of the governor's lawsuit challenging the validity of manual recounts conducted in Florida.

At the same time, members of Mr Gore's legal team said they were hoping to provide Mr Bush's lawyers with their evidence and witness lists by tomorrow in their state court challenge to the Texas governor's 537-vote victory in Florida.

Mr Gore's challenge to the results in Palm Beach, Nassau and Miami-Dade counties is before circuit judge N Sanders Sauls, a jurist known for swift action.

The candidate who has the support of the state's electors before the December 12 deadline stands to become the 43rd president, since without Florida, neither can command a 270-vote electoral college majority.

webTitle: Watchdog suspects BT Surf masks subsidy

fields.headline: Watchdog suspects BT Surf masks subsidy
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Oftel yesterday announced an investigation into the pricing of British Telecom's unmetered internet access, invoking for the first time the powers it won under the 1998 Competition Act.
fields.body:
Oftel yesterday announced an investigation into the pricing of British Telecom's unmetered internet access, invoking for the first time the powers it won under the 1998 Competition Act.

The investigation centres on two new packages which BT had lined up for launch at the end of this week. Oftel's inquiry will focus on whether the packages are anti-competitive. The regulator has the power to fine BT up to 10% of its annual turnover.

The packages are BT Surf Together and BT Talk & Surf Together. The first offers unlimited weekend and evening internet calls for £14.99 a month while the second also bundles in unlimited weekend and evening local voice calls for £19.99. The second package had already been lifted from £17.99 a month following discussions between BT and Oftel.

The watchdog said it welcomed lower prices but needed to ensure that BT was not undermining competition. Director general David Edmonds, it noted, suspected that BT was subsidising its unmetered internet access by the voice call element of the packages.

BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield said: "We strongly resist the suggestion that we are acting anti-competitively. All we are trying to do it give our customers value for money."

A BT spokeswoman said that the company was bemused by Oftel's decision to investigate. "We believe this is the kind of package that consumers, the government and Oftel have been telling us they want. They have known about this pricing since October and known of our intent for longer than that."

She said that the company intended to push ahead with the launch on Friday. The investigation marks a new low in relations between BT and the watchdog. Mr Edmonds said last week that dealing with the monopoly was akin to trench warfare.

Oftel yesterday published the procedure to decide how space in the most popular BT exchanges will be allocated to rival suppliers when its local network is opened for competition next year.

Competing operators will be asked to list the exchanges in which they wish to install equipment in order of priority. The higher a named exchange is on the operator's list, the more likely it will be to gain entry.

BT meanwhile signalled its intent to press ahead with the £5bn flotation of its directories and e-commerce business Yell when it named the chief financial officer who will lead the company to market. John Davis is joining Yell from internet portal business Yahoo! Europe where he was group financial officer.

The partial flotation of Yell will be the first stage of a broad restructuring of BT designed to restore investor confidence and reduce debts of £30bn.

The appointment of Mr Davis suggests that BT is undaunted by the volatility of the markets and, more particularly, the sharp change in sentiment toward internet-related new issues. The company is aiming at flotation before the end of March.

The share price closed 9.5p higher yesterday at 660p but are still lower than the 749p on the day the restructuring was announced. At the beginning of the year, BT shares were worth £15.13.

fields.headline: The rise of the Little Englanders
fields.standfirst:
Xenophobic views are increasing, says survey, as figures reveal widening gap on nationality, race and foreign affairs

Class divide centres on sex issues more than spending
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: A sharp increase in the number of Little Englanders who do not identify themselves as British and tend towards racist and xenophobic views is disclosed today by the National Centre for Social Research in its annual survey of social attitudes.
fields.body:
A sharp increase in the number of Little Englanders who do not identify themselves as British and tend towards racist and xenophobic views is disclosed today by the National Centre for Social Research in its annual survey of social attitudes.

As power devolved to Scotland and Wales over the first two years of Tony Blair's government, the proportion of English people saying they owed allegiance to England, not Britain, grew from 7% to 17%.

The researchers discovered no evidence of resentment in England about power passing to the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly, but the figures suggested that 6m adults in England no longer subscribed to a British national identity.

More than a third of this group (37%) freely admitted to being racially prejudiced, compared with 17% of those who continued to assert their Britishness.

They were also much more likely to think that immigrants take jobs away from people who were born in Britain (70%), that it was "bad" that people from ethnic minorities were getting ahead (26%), and that attempts to give equal opportunities to blacks and Asians in Britain had "gone too far" (46%).

The Little Englanders were also more likely to say it mattered a great deal to being English that people were white and born in England, with English parents.

Nearly threequarters (73%) wanted to keep the pound as Britain's only currency and 22% thought Britain should quit the EU altogether - a much more strongly Eurosceptic stance than among those acknowledging British nationhood.

The survey by John Curtice, of Strathclyde University, and Anthony Heath, of Oxford University, concluded: "We have found that those who feel English are indeed different from those who feel British, being consistently more inclined to want to shut out the outside world. Indeed 'Little Englanders' appear to be alive and well, if not yet very thick on the ground."

By contrast 6% of those who described their ethnic origin as black and 7% of those who said they were Asian classified themselves as English, not British. More than a third said they were British, not English.

The survey found a quarter of people living in England thought Scotland should become completely independent, but the most common response to Scotland's status was indifference. More than half would be "neither pleased nor sorry" if Scotland were to become completely independent.

A fifth of English people wanted independence for Wales, either inside or outside the EU. And a majority (54%) thought Northern Ireland's long-term interests would be with the rest of Ireland rather than as part of Britain.

But these reformist views did not lead to any great appetite for devolution within England, where 15% favoured regional assemblies and 18% wanted an English parliament.

"This is probably why the somewhat muted attempts by the Conservative party to identify itself as the party of English interests have met with an even more muted response," the study said.

One reason why English nationalism might struggle to assert itself was a lack of potent symbols belonging to exclusively England after centuries of intertwined British culture.

More than half thought fox hunting and Guy Fawkes night were English rather than British institutions. Paradoxically, a third thought the same about the Houses of Parliament, the centre of the British democratic state.

The survey, based on more than 3,000 interviews with a representative random sample of people in England, Scotland and Wales, was the 17th in the British social attitudes series.
