webTitle: Law Society in the dock over 'racism and sexism'

fields.headline: Law Society in the dock over 'racism and sexism'
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Lawyers for Kamlesh Bahl, the former Law Society vice-president, yesterday accused the solicitors' professional body of breaching natural justice and denying her a fair hearing by forcing her out within days of a report which found her guilty of bullying staff.
fields.body:
Lawyers for Kamlesh Bahl, the former Law Society vice-president, yesterday accused the solicitors' professional body of breaching natural justice and denying her a fair hearing by forcing her out within days of a report which found her guilty of bullying staff.

Ms Bahl, 44, took her claim for sex and race discrimination, victimisation and constructive dismissal to the Watford employment tribunal, which is expected to hear a stream of witnesses over the next four weeks.

Her supporters, including the Society of Black Lawyers, claim the case exposes institutional discrimination in the legal profession. Well-wishers demonstrating outside the tribunal waved placards reading "Ethnic cleansing at the Law Society". Om Prakash Sharma, president of the National Council of Hindu Temples, said: "The unjust, racist and sexist excesses of the Law Society need to be challenged".

The saga has proved highly expensive and embarrassing for the body which regulates and represents the 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales. "I don't think there will be much change from £2m by the time the tribunal finishes," said one member of the society's 75-strong council.

Witnesses for the Law Society include two district judges. Ms Bahl, who is expected to give evidence today, was in line last summer to become the first Asian solicitor and first woman to head the 175-year-old organisation, but was forced to resign in March after findings that she had bullied and harassed five staff members.

An inquiry headed by Lord Griffiths, a former law lord, found all the allegations could be proved. He said her behaviour had been "at times demeaning and humiliating and at other times offensively ag gressive." One victim underwent counselling for stress.

Ms Bahl, a former chairwoman of the Equal Opportunities Commission, is not challenging the Griffiths inquiry, although she does not accept its findings and denies that her behaviour amounted to bullying.

Her claims centre on the way the society dealt with complaints against her and her exclusion so quickly in the inquiry's aftermath.

webTitle: Fresh delay to AOL/Time Warner deal

fields.headline: AOL/Time Warner mega-merger waits on US regulator
fields.trailText: Tuesday 5pm: AOL and Time Warner face further uncertainty over their planned £70bn merger, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
AOL and Time Warner face another agonising wait to find out if their £70bn merger will get the go-ahead, after watchdogs delayed a key ruling that is potentially deal-breaking.

The US Federal Trade Commission is threatening to scupper the deal over concerns that AOL would offer its internet service through Time Warner's cable network, locking out competitors.

Regulators have prepared a court action to block the merger, but are waiting for further concessions from both parties.

The FTC was due to make a ruling yesterday, but believes there is still time to save the deal.

Time Warner went some way to dealing with regulatory concerns last week, when it allowed internet company EarthLink Network to use its cable lines.

However, the FTC wants AOL and Time Warner to sign up two more firms if the merger is approved.

If the FTC agrees to the deal, which was cleared by EU regulators last month, it must then be passed by the Federal Communications Commission.

The merger has met with far greater opposition in the US owing to AOL's dominant position in the internet market and Time Warner's extensive cable network.

The £12bn joint venture between UK music group EMI and Time Warner subsidiary Warner Music broke down earlier this year because EU regulators feared AOL would use it to dominate the market for music downloads over the web.

The prolonged wrangling over the world's largest media merger has damaged both parties' share prices and cut the value of the deal from £115bn to £70bn since January.

fields.headline: Song,  Film, and Speech
fields.trailText: GOING FOR A SONG/SING A SONG OF £2.5m etc
fields.body:
GOING FOR A SONG/SING A SONG OF £2.5m etc

Last Thursday, when rumours that Rigobert Song was about to join West Ham for £2.5m sped down Fleet Street faster than a hack who's heard the words "free" and "booze", the ever-eager Fiver travelled down to Appy Arry's Ammers to see what was going down. But when we arrived the place was deserted, except for West Ham official Paul Aldridge, who told us: "I can assure you that nothing like that is going to happen here today, and maybe never." And we believed him - until today at least - when we heard that Song had joined West Ham for £2.5m!

Talk about Saddam Hussein-like levels of cunning! But no sooner had we got over that shock, than another one arrived with Song himself insisting that he does not want to be compared with Rio Ferdinand. At all! "You can't compare us," he claimed. "I am different from Rio but I will offer the same hard work and desire to improve. I will be bringing my own experience and character to the club." And your mistakes and poor positioning too, we bet.

Not that Appy Arry Redknapp is bothered: "He makes the odd ricket, but he is a whole-hearted player," he joked, while aiming a playful punch at Song's arm. "I am buying him for a song [gedditt??!!]. It's not taking up much of the Rio money," he larked. It's amazing what £18m can do for a man's disposition, an infection Song appears to have caught too. "I played four times for Liverpool this season, and I certainly don't think it didn't work out there", he said. "West Ham's squad is as good. And you could say they are more ambitious because they want to improve." It's not national self-delusion day today is it, by any chance?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SPANKS FOR THE MEMORY

It's been a while since the FA's swinging disciplinary committee has got a mention in the Fiver. And it's been even longer since their under-the-counter pals at the video review panel got their hands dirty, the naughty boys. But retribution and punishment is back on the agenda again today, thank God, and the FA haven't refrained from cracking the whip.

Except they have, which is a bit disappointing, really. Particularly since they were dealing with Sunday's juicy events at Elland Road where referee Dermot Gallagher was surrounded by butch men, players got slapped around, Robert Pires called David O'Leary a whore allegedly followed by a big explosion in a tunnel - activities you'd usually have to pay £15 cash-in-hand-no-questions-asked to see. However, these antics failed to make it into Mr Gallagher's post-match report, and neither team complained, so the FA can take no action, however much they want to. And boy do they want to.

No such problem exists for those fans of amateur video however. They can sit and watch Patrick Vieira's foot slam into Olivier Dacourt's neck as often as they like, perhaps pausing on the point of contact for some seconds, before making a decision on what to do. The FA today confirmed that the panel will be looking at footage of Vieira in red hot action "this week", which is quite a long period of time really. They will decide on a verdict shortly afterwards, and if there's a punishment don't bet against it be being hard.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

STEVEN CARR'S QUOTES OF THE DAY

The shaven-headed fullback gives considered opinion on his teammates to his own personal website.

Chris Perry: "He thinks he's funny, but he's very, very unfunny."

Ben Thatcher: "He's a bit of a madman. He's really mouthy, he's a cocky Londoner."

Steffen Iversen: "Tramp! He wears the same couple of suits every day and they're always creased. He just doesn't know how to iron!"

And there's more where they came from

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CIAO IL MIO NOME È DENNIS

Those of you who no longer subscribe to the official magazine of fashionable west London boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea may be interested to hear that Dennis Wise has exclusively opened his heart to the publication. Sadly this does not mean an personal tour around his chest cavity, rather a few pages about how much he loves Chelsea and how Ken Bates is a lovely man. For all the waffle, however, the article does reveal some interesting things - like the fact he's going to learn Italian, for a start.

"Obviously you need to understand each other verbally," Wise revealed verbally. "The majority of the lads speak Italian but there are a few who don't. Me and Jody [Morris - trombone player] have spoken about it and we've decided we might well go for Italian lessons. Seriously." Now, why Dennis had to tack the seriously on there is anyone's guess, but he did. "We've got to do it for politeness," he went on "because the English are very rude. They're not bothered about any languages because everyone around the world speaks English."

Expect Dennis to be addressing the EU on the importance of cultural rapprochement any time soon, but for now he's just doing his bit to help Claudio Ranieri out. The new Chelsea coach has - how shall we put it - looked a right pillock since his arrival in England having to communicate through a variety of comedy translators. According to the mag, however, this problem won't remain for long as Ranieri has three different English teachers - one purely to school him in footy speak. Apparently the teacher gives Claudio a word and then makes an appropriate drawing on a whiteboard to illustrate it. Which makes it quite tricky to explain "bottle" if you think about it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea have set their sights on Internazionale's Ivan Zamorano, after having a tentative enquiry for Lazio's Marcelo Salas rejected, reports Teamtalk. The club have also been linked with a £6m move for Anderlecht's Walter Baseggio.

Aston Villa have added Lee Hughes to their strikers wish-list after continuing difficulties in tempting Celta Vigo into selling Benni McCarthy.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Len Shackleton died today aged 78 after being taken ill last night. The former England international, who scored 101 times in 348 appearances for Sunderland passed away in hospital at around midday. Shackleton, known as the "Clown Prince of Soccer" because of his entertaining skills, suffered a heart attack in August and never fully recovered. There will be a minute's silence at Sunderland's Worthington Cup tie with Manchester United tonight.

Martin Palermo scored twice in the opening six minutes as Boca Juniors beat Real Madrid 2-1 to lift the Toyota Cup in front of 50,000 fans at Tokyo's Olympic Stadium. Roberto Carlos pulled a goal back for the European champions.

BBC Radio 5 Live has secured the rights to broadcast live commentary of the Premiership matches until the end of the 2003/2004 season. Under the terms of the new three-year contract, the BBC will be able to cover up to 180 matches each season as well as continue test commentaries on their digital service.

Alen Boksic will be out of action for up to three weeks after tearing a hamstring during Middlesbrough's draw against Bradford at the weekend.

Meanwhile Aston Villa's Julian Joachim could be out of action until the new year after breaking a toe against Southampton.

Manchester United reserve striker Alex Notman is talking over move to Norwich.

Leicester City have applied for planning permission for their proposed new 32,000-seater stadium at Freeman's Wharf in the city.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm) Similar to Nationwide Football League Extra, only it's only repeated twice.

Gillette Soccer Special (7.30pm) Jeff Stelling gives another "How to handle three drunk ex-footballers" masterclass.

Sky Sports 2: Live Worthington Cup Football: Sunderland v Manchester United (7.30pm) Surely you're better off watching this, rather than hearing George Best slurring about it?

Sky Sports 1: You're on Sky Sports (10pm) Is McCaff hot or not? Hats off to Alex Bell, who has decided to let the world decide. Click here to have your say.

Channel 4: Football Italia (1.55am) Trust us: Batigol's brilliant strike against Fiorentina is worth staying up for.

ITV: Football Extra (3.10am) Extra only in the sense that it's a repeat of yesterday's Nationwide League highlights.

Channel 5: Argentine Football (4.15am) Christian Bozzo - is he the Shakespeare of our age? Why not stay up till tomorrow and find out?

fields.headline: TalkSport makes Premier League debut
fields.trailText: 4pm: TalkSport has secured its first top flight football with BBC Radio 5 Live holding onto live Premier League coverage, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC Radio 5 Live has held onto its exclusive contract for live Premier League coverage, but its commercial arch-rival, TalkSport, has also secured its first top flight football rights.

In a groundbreaking deal, from next season TalkSport, which is owned by Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group, will provide score flashes from top games.

Richard Scudamore, chief executive of the Premier League, said this evening: "We are delighted to have this agreement with TalkSport.

"The station has over 2m listeners. It's a growing audience, it's a great franchise and we are keen to consolidate and standardise our relationship."

5 Live's new three-year deal will see the station increase its coverage of live matches from 120 to 180 matches per season.

The BBC station will continue to be the only national radio outlet for full live Premier League action.

The new deal takes effect from August 2001.

fields.headline: Russia offering arms to Tehran
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russia announced yesterday that it wants to sell conventional arms to Iran, reneging on a secret deal signed with the US and risking the prospect of American sanctions.
fields.body:
Russia announced yesterday that it wants to sell conventional arms to Iran, reneging on a secret deal signed with the US and risking the prospect of American sanctions.

The deputy prime minister responsible for the arms industry, Ilya Klebanov, said Moscow was prepared to open talks with Tehran on arms supplies.

"We are ready to supply Iran with everything that does not contradict our country's international obligations in this area," he said.

The decision, agreed by President Vladimir Putin after close analysis of the benefits, amounts to a calculated snub to America and confronts the incoming US administration with the challenge of how to respond.

As other influential figures in Moscow spoke of Iran becoming a "strategic partner" of Russia, the foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, and the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, had a frosty encounter in the Austrian capital, Vienna.

Mrs Albright criticised Moscow's activities in Chechnya and accused it of backsliding on promises to reduce conventional arms and forces in Europe. Mr Ivanov warned the west against preaching to Russia and interfering in human rights issues.

Under a secret deal signed by the US vice-president, Al Gore, and the then Russian prime minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin, in 1995, Moscow committed itself to ending arms supplies to Iran by last December. When the deadline passed Moscow continued to sell weaponry under 10-year-old supply agreements with Iran.

The US turned a blind eye to the continued sales, but earlier this month the Kremlin enraged the White House by brusquely telling it that it regarded the secret agreement as void.

In Vienna yesterday Mr Ivanov and Mrs Albright agreed to convene a meeting of experts on the arms trade.

fields.headline: Oyster expands into offline marketing
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: The company behind websites for Barclaycard and Sky is to expand into offline marketing, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The company that has created websites for household names including Barclaycard and Sky is to expand into offline marketing with the launch of a new branding consultancy.

Oyster Partners today announced the formation of a brand strategy group to be headed by co-founder and chief creative officer Hugo Manassei.

The company is already working on a project for mobile firm company Orange and has been appointed to create new brands for two unnamed clients, one a major newspaper group and the other a wireless company.

Mr Manassei said: "Until now we have been mainly focused around the internet but as a company we are moving towards an environment in which digital is no longer an issue.

"At some point the internet is not going to be such a specialist thing. As a channel of communication it will become as big as TV."

Oyster was set up in 1995 and now has around 180 employees. Current clients include BA, Channel 4, Unilever and Virgin.

fields.headline: Prescott unveils rural white paper
fields.standfirst: Government white paper: a fair deal for rural England
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, today spelled out the government's five-point plan to assist rural areas in a white paper called A fair deal for rural England.
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, today spelled out the government's five-point plan to assist rural areas in a white paper called A Fair Deal For Rural England.

He said ministers would act to improve services; tackle poverty; help the rural economy; protect the countryside and wildlife and give more choice to local people.

Mr Prescott told MPs in a Commons statement that the government would invest a further £192m over the next three years on rural transport on top of an existing investment of £170m.

He said concern about speeding traffic would be met by allowing local communities to "make villages and rural roads safer by reducing speed limits and investing more in traffic calming".

A further £1bn over the next ten years would be spent on rural bypasses.

Mr Prescott also announced a doubling of the existing Housing Corporation programme to see 3,000 "affordable homes a year in small rural settlements and a total of 9,000 homes a year across all rural districts".

There would also be a new starter homes initiative to help key workers buy their homes in areas of high prices and high demand, said Mr Prescott.

webTitle: Health: Definitive guide to fertility treatments

fields.headline: The definitive guide to treating common ailments
fields.standfirst: No 30: Fertility treatments
fields.trailText: No 30: Fertility treatments.
fields.body:
About 6% of couples have difficulties conceiving within two years of trying. Around one in seven couples seeks medical help and - as treatment options increase - demand is rising.

Causes

To find the right treatment it is vital to establish the cause of difficulties. About 27% have ovulation problems, 19% low or poor quality sperm, 14% fallopian tube damage and 5% endometriosis. Nearly a third of problems have no apparent explanation.

Treatment

A review this year for the clinical effectiveness compendium Clinical Evidence assessed all trials of fertility treatments. It concluded that hormone therapy - to stimulate egg production - works well for ovulation problems. The most commonly used drug, clomiphene, triples pregnancy rates.

Research is less conclusive for other hormone therapies. Where tube damage is the problem, surgery can help if damage is slight but is little use in more severe cases. In-vitro fertilisation (IVF) works better, with 15% becoming pregnant after one attempt and up to 77% after three to five cycles.

IVF works equally well where endometriosis is the problem. Surgery may also help - increasing pregnancy rates normally around 2% by about 40% - but drug treatment is not effective, trials show. For male fertility problems, intrauterine insemination, where sperm is injected directly into the womb, is twice as successful - about 6% become pregnant - as intracervical insemination, where sperm is inserted into the cervix.

Other options, including IVF, ICSI - where a single sperm is injected into an egg - and GIFT - where eggs are mixed with sperm and transferred to the fallopian tubes - appear to help but success rates are unclear. Donor insemination works in 1 in 10 cases. With unexplained infertility, clomiphene is no help. Intrauterine insemination combined with hormone therapy more than doubles pregnancy chances. IVF and GIFT also seem effective but success rates are unclear.

Drawbacks

Drugs to stimulate the ovaries increase the chances of multiple birth. Tubal surgery increases risk of ectopic pregnancy. IVF treatment leads to multiple births in 1 in 4 pregnancies. Success varies between clinics and with the woman's age. Only about a quarter of IVF attempts are NHS funded.

 What works? is based on reviews of the most up-to-date and reliable evidence available. It is written in collaboration with the NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination at York university (01904 433 634) and verified by experts.

fields.headline: The official start of middle age
fields.standfirst: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.body:
Tuesday: Four days from now is my birthday, and although (apart from a middle ear infection, otitis media, in the right ear) my general health is no worse than usual, at this time of year it is a struggle to keep my thoughts off death and decay.

Wednesday: On Saturday I reach 37, the official start of middle age, as I point out to my wife over what passes here for breakfast (three mouldy grapes and a glass of slightly rancid grapefruit juice: sometimes I wonder what Ivan Denisovitch found so bleak about his labour camp). "Is that what you really think?" asks Rebecca. "Well it certainly was 10 seconds ago when I last spoke on the point. But perhaps I've changed my mind." A fermenting muscat splatters into my left ear, filling it with rancid juice, and I take this as a sign that the debate has reached a natural hiatus.

Thursday: My mind is diverted when a friend calls for advice. For four years, he says, he has had stomach pain and heartburn recurring every few months, and he is in a state about an appointment in Harley Street later today. I explain that you can't have anything nasty in that region for long without suffering weight loss, rectal bleeding, altered blood and, after four years, rigor mortis and decomposition. My diagnosis is an ulcer or one of those hard-to-diagnose recurrent bacterial infections. He sounds relieved and grateful, although when I ask to see his medical notes the line goes dead.

Friday: My friend calls to say that a latex-gloved examination and an ultrasound were clear, a blood test has been taken, and that the specialist suspects either a "pseudo ulcer" or one of those bacterial infections that are so tough to diagnose. "What's a pseudo-ulcer?" asks Rebecca when I boast about it. "It's an ulcer that goes to modern art shows and whines about finding the artist's work 'a little jejune'," I say. "So you've no idea at all," says Rebecca.

Saturday: In the Bayswater Turkish baths, where I spend my birthday morning, the spirits lift. I may be plump and balding, but I still have some hair and am not as grotesquely fat as I have been. In this heavy steam I could still pass for 35, I am reflecting, when a man with whom I often exchange grunted hellos asks how I am.

"Oh," I hear myself reply, "mustn't grumble." He nods morosely. "Yes," he says, "at our age you can't expect perfect health, can you?" Eventually, I recover the power of speech. "If you don't mind my asking," I say, "how old are you?" "I'm 74," he replies, sighing sadly.

Sunday: I awake in the midst of what was an untroubled night, and am baffled when a run through the usual check-list for wakingness yields nothing. No nightmare and no drink-induced dehydration, while Rebecca has not yet confiscated my third of the duvet. And then it hits me. I have been awoken at 3.47 am by the need to void my bladder. My cousin, who is 40 next May, warned me of this. And now it's happened. At 37 and one day, I can no longer make it through the night.

Monday: The urinary earthquake is followed by an ocular aftershock. Famously, shortsightedness can reverse itself in middle age, I remember, when in the sitting room I am struck by the clearest vision of the magnolia in the front garden ... a tree I haven't seen through this window for years. I am about to inform Rebecca of the miracle when a man enters the kitchen with a ladder and a sponge.

"This is Peter," she says, but very, very faintly. "He's here to cream the widows." I ask her to explain (Rebecca isn't a widow yet; and if she was, she'd hardly have inherited anything from me worth creaming off), but I cannot make out a word of the reply. So this is the third leg of the inevitable three in which calamity presents itself: first the dodgy bladder, then the restored sight, now the deafness.

How long now, I wonder before the short term memory goes and I start repeating myself? And how much longer before I can't remember as well as I used to, and start saying everything twice? Not long enough. Not nearly long enough.

fields.headline: Me and my bad ear
fields.standfirst: Doctors say Oscar Wilde was probably killed by a chronic ear infection (rather than syphilis, as has often been claimed). A century on, treatment is still far from simple, says Patrick Viner, who has just had surgery for the same problem
fields.trailText: Doctors say Oscar Wilde was probably killed by a chronic ear infection (rather than syphilis, as has often been claimed). A century on, treatment is still far from simple, says Patrick Viner, who has just had surgery for the same problem.
fields.body:
"P'don? What did you say?" was the soundtrack to my childhood, usually followed by a reponse of: "Cloth-ears!" From the age of two I was plagued with ear infections. Four, five, six times a year I'd complain of pain at school. After being sat down with my ear pressed against a warm radiator for the afternoon, I'd be marched to the doctor for yet another course of antibiotics.

Continually diagnosed as having a "weak ear", I'd grown used to the pain and deafness, never questioning why I was continually affected. I remember, aged eight, returning from playing Oliver in the school play (not a dry eye in the house) and rapidly falling ill with yet another infection. Packed quickly off to bed, I woke the next morning with what can only be described as a three-inch, blood-and-wax worm attaching my ear to the pillow. More antiobiotics for Cloth-ears. These infections continued throughout my adolesence, and by my early 20s they had become more occasional but much more severe.

One or two painful infections every two years became the norm, then, at 25, they stopped. An untroubled couple of years passed, until last April. Almost excited at the prospect of a week in bed, I went to my doctor for the quickest consultation I have ever had. I took the prescribed antibiotics but didn't get any better.

This had never happened before, so I went to see another doctor to ask for a different antibiotic. After a little condescension he prescribed a new course. During this second week, I would wake every morning with dried pus and blood caked to the outside of my ear.

Worried, and averse to shelling out for pills that did nothing, I returned to the original doctor. He took one look and referred me to the emergency ward of London's ear, nose and throat hospital. Several painful consultations later, where a microscopic vacuum cleaner was used to break off and suck out all the festering debris, I was diagnosed with cholosteotoma - apparently I'd had it for years.

Cholosteotoma is a creeping, corroding disease which eats away the mastoid bone around the ear and anything else, including the three hearing bones, the ear-drum and, most dangerously, the lining of the brain, causing increased susceptibility to infections such as meningitis.

The problem is that the disease can start in any part of the ear and thus cannot always be detected early on. It is only revealed once the debris is visible in the middle ear, which means its extent cannot be determined without an operation. You can only hope that visible debris is the start of the cholosteotoma and not its last push.

The purpose of the operation is to cut away all infected areas, save the ear from further corrosion, and prevent the lining of the brain being exposed. It was this very op, according to new evidence released in last week's Lancet, which Oscar Wilde underwent, in a hotel bedroom in Paris, seven weeks before his death in November 1900. The surgery failed to save him, and may even have hastened his death.

So I was given a date for early October - as chance would have it, almost exactly 100 years after Oscar's op. Now totally deaf in the affected ear, I went back to work. Optimistically, this meant that the debris in the middle ear was preventing sound getting in. Pessimistically, it meant that the hearing bones had already been consumed by the disease.

Socialising became a bizarre experience - in pubs the background noise was deafening in the good ear, while conversation two feet away was inaudible. This feeling of having my head "bubble-wrapped" led me to assume that I was far more drunk than two pints could possibly make me. Also, not being able to catch what was being said prior to outbursts of laughter can lead to strange, paranoid assumptions if you're sick and tired of asking people to repeat themselves.

As the operation date approached, those close to me became increasingly worried, while I adopted an attitude of, "well, it needs to be done, it's usually not life-threatening, it's a routine procedure". I went into hospital, becoming more and more nervous with each meal.

I came round at 12pm the day after the procedure, with the left side of my face swollen and a tight ban dage wrapped around my head. Thick red blood was all over my pillow, and still leaking out of my ear sporadically. After a few hours of recovery, the surgeon visited with the post-match analysis. The operation had been a success, but the extent of the disease had been severe.

First, two of the three hearing bones had been so corroded that their remains had been removed. Second, the lining of the brain was already exposed, necessitating a graft of healthy mastoid bone to plug the gap. Third, the operation, which normally takes one hour, had taken three and a half. The ear canal had been filled with surgical packing to aid healing from the inside out, and I'd only discover the extent of the deafness when it was removed three weeks later.

During those anxious three weeks in bed, I encountered some strange side effects. I had been told that two important nerves run over or near the eardrum. Severing the first would cause one side of the face to droop permanently, which thankfully did not happen.

However, the second had to be severed, which caused a loss of taste and feeling down one side of my tongue, meaning that chips, or anything else cooked in fat, actually felt like raw lard; a most unpleasant sensation. And I've lost half a stone.

Chewing caused nasty headaches, but they diminished as the ear healed. The blood eventually stopped discharging and I began to sleep all through the night. Then, on Hallowe'en, I returned to hospital to have the packing removed.

I had been warned to take my strongest painkiller beforehand, as it was going to be agony. I had feared this moment; excrutiating pain followed by possible deafness. As things turned out, the warm and sloppy removal of the packing was disturbingly pleasurable.

Then I sat up, put my hand over my good ear, and realised the extent of my hearing loss. It felt like I had my hand over both ears: vague and muffled sounds trying to get in, but no hearing bones to help them onto the eardrum.

A later operation to insert plastic hearing bones could help, but this promises no more than a 20% hearing increase. And all that pain and recovery to make the muffled sounds slightly less muffled does not appeal.

Of course the operation was necessary, but the permanent loss of hearing will take some getting used to. After all the attention and worry, I feel a bit like a kid again. Or maybe that's because I'm back to saying, "P'don? What did you say?"

fields.headline: Desperately seeking sympathy
fields.standfirst: On Munchausen by internet
fields.trailText: Dr Theodore Dalrymple on Munchausen by internet.
fields.body:
The more we know, the wiser we grow. The principal source of medical enlightenment these days, therefore, is the internet: for by its use, we can all become expert on almost anything within a short time. Knowledge that has taken years of strenuous effort to accumulate is available to us in minutes.

Alas, history demonstrates that any technology that is used for good can also be used for ill. I was looking something up on Medline last week when I came across a paper entitled Munchausen by Internet, in the Southern Medical Journal, by a psychiatrist in Birmingham, Alabama, called Dr Feldman.

In the paper, Dr Feldman describes four of the 21 cases that have already come to his attention. Typically, an internet support group for people suffering from a certain disease is suddenly joined by a newcomer, who claims to be suffering from the disease. He has the most dramatic manifestations of the condition, or even claims to be dying, though life-threatening complications do not prevent him from writing long bulletins about himself. If interest in his case wanes among the other participants, he simply invents new crises to rekindle it.

For example, a person who called herself Barbara and claimed to be suffering from the terminal stages of cystic fibrosis, wrote to a cystic fibrosis internet support group. She (if indeed it was a she) was looked after by her older sister, Amy, and wrote that her dream was to die on the beach. She received a great deal of sympathy from other sufferers. Prayers were offered up for her. A short time afterwards, a message was posted by Amy, to the effect that, sadly, her sister Barbara had died, though fortunately she had been transported to the beach just in time to die there.

Members of the group, however, noticed that the very same spelling errors that had appeared in Barbara's communications, which they had generously attributed to the lack of oxygen reaching her brain, now appeared in Amy's communications. On being questioned, Barbara/Amy admitted that she had made the whole story up, and taunted the other members of the group for being so gullible.

In another case, this time of a mother claiming to have a baby with cystic fibrosis, the support group was divided for a time as to the truth of her story. Some soon spotted the fake, but others took longer to do so. When the baby was alleged to have died, some members offered to send flowers to the hospital, but discovered that no such baby had ever been treated there. Only then was the entire group convinced the original story was nothing but a lie: some were left with feelings of anger, disgust and shame at having been duped in this fashion.

What kind of people mimic suffering in the hope of attracting sympathy and attention, if only temporarily (their eventual exposure as fraudulent being inevitable)? It doesn't take much imagination to understand that they must be rather sad individuals, whose life is lacking in more conventional rewards.

No doubt some people have always sought sympathy by subterfuge, but there seems something more urgent and unscrupulous about our modern thirst for victimhood. Not long after the problem of stalking (in my belief, a real enough and probably growing problem) was given wide publicity in the press and reports emerged in the medical literature of people who falsely claimed to have been stalked. The false claimants wanted the sympathy and attention that the truly stalked had received, but without having gone through the unpleasant experience itself.

Perhaps we are seeing the survival into a secular and materialist age of the old religious idea that true sanctity cannot be achieved except through the voluntary acceptance of suffering. If life itself refuses to send you such suffering, you simply make it up.

Of course, I was in two minds whether to write about Munchausen by internet, because you have only to mention such undesirable conduct nowadays for it to spread. How long can it be, indeed, before there are false claims to have been the victim of someone with Munchausen by internet? What would such a condition be called? Munchausen by Munchausen by internet? The alarming prospect of an infinite regress of false claims opens up.

 Sarah Boseley is away

Typically, an internet support group for people suffering from a certain disease is suddenly joined by a newcomer, who claims to be suffering from the disease. He has the most dramatic manifestations of the condition, or even claims to be dying, though life-threatening complications do not prevent him from writing long bulletins about himself. If interest in his case wanes among the other participants, he simply invents new crises to rekindle it. For example, a person who called herself Barbara and claimed to be suffering from the terminal stages of cystic fibrosis, wrote to a cystic fibrosis internet support group. She (if indeed it was a she) was looked after by her older sister, Amy, and wrote that her dream was to die on the beach. She received a great deal of sympathy from other sufferers. Prayers were offered up for her. A short time afterwards, a message was posted by Amy, to the effect that, sadly, her sister Barbara had died, though fortunately she had been transported to the beach just in time to die there. Members of the group, however, noticed that the very same spelling errors that had appeared in Barbara's communications, which they had generously attributed to the lack of oxygen reaching her brain, now appeared in Amy's communications. On being questioned, Barbara/Amy admitted that she had made the whole story up, and taunted the other members of the group for being so gullible. In another case, this time of a mother claiming to have a baby with cystic fibrosis, the support group was divided for a time as to the truth of her story. Some soon spotted the fake, but others took longer to do so. When the baby was alleged to have died, some members offered to send flowers to the hospital, but discovered that no such baby had ever been treated there. Only then was the entire group convinced the original story was nothing but a lie: some were left with feelings of anger, disgust and shame at having been duped in this fashion. What kind of people mimic suffering in the hope of attracting sympathy and attention, if only temporarily (their eventual exposure as fraudulent being inevitable)? It doesn't take much imagination to understand that they must be rather sad individuals, whose life is lacking in more conventional rewards. No doubt some people have always sought sympathy by subterfuge, but there seems something more urgent and unscrupulous about our modern thirst for victimhood. Not long after the problem of stalking (in my belief, a real enough and probably growing problem) was given wide publicity in the press and reports emerged in the medical literature of people who falsely claimed to have been stalked. The false claimants wanted the sympathy and attention that the truly stalked had received, but without having gone through the unpleasant experience itself. Perhaps we are seeing the survival into a secular and materialist age of the old religious idea that true sanctity cannot be achieved except through the voluntary acceptance of suffering. If life itself refuses to send you such suffering, you simply make it up. Of course, I was in two minds whether to write about Munchausen by internet, because you have only to mention such undesirable conduct nowadays for it to spread. How long can it be, indeed, before there are false claims to have been the victim of someone with Munchausen by internet? What would such a condition be called? Munchausen by Munchausen by internet? The alarming prospect of an infinite regress of false claims opens up.  Sarah Boseley is away

webTitle: Health: Are our wards dangerous places?

fields.headline: Dishing the dirt
fields.standfirst: Infections picked up in hospital kill 5,000 patients a year, it was claimed last week. So why are our wards such a dangerous place to be? And what's the best way to survive them? Junior doctor Michael Foxton reports
fields.trailText: Infections picked up in hospital kill 5,000 patients a year, it was claimed last week. So why are our wards such a dangerous place to be? And what's the best way to survive them? Junior doctor Michael Foxton reports.
fields.body:
The story of hospital acquired infections is one of shirked responsibility amongst people who are rarely identifiable and who are never brought to task. First of all, let me put my hands up: as a junior doctor in a busy London hospital, I should probably be washing my hands at least 50 times a day, not just after I see patients (which is what my mum tells me to do), but before.

Of course there are times when I don't do it. And of course it's not acceptable. It's been drilled into me from an early age. I was marked on hand-washing in my finals. There is even a Handwashing Taskforce in my hospital whose sole purpose is to cajole me. I am a murderer by omission. What do I have to say in my defence? And what can you do to defend yourself from my poisonous mitts?

Firstly, antibiotic resistant infections (the nasty ones I give you in hospital) are something we all share responsibility for. Every time you bully your GP into giving amoxycillin syrup to your children for their viral earache (or rather, every time the GP gives in just to get rid of you) you are contributing to the pool of resistant infections in the community.

Every time you stop taking antibiotics before the course is finished, just because your symptoms have cleared up, you allow all the remaining bacteria in your body (the ones that were most resistant to the drug) to live on to fight another day, with someone else's immune system.

Farmers, who, like doctors, alternate between saint and sinner in the popular press, routinely use animal feed containing low levels of antibiotics, because (and no one knows how) they increase the body mass of livestock by a lucrative 10%. In some parts of the world, farmers even use antibiotic spray to reduce the rate of bacterial infections on their crops.

Bacteria are clever little things. Once one of them has evolved a trick to make it resistant to antibiotics, it tells all its friends, by sharing little blobs of DNA around so that the others can make copies and share in the secret. The more we use antibiotics, the more we send them into battle, the more chance bacteria have to see what we've got, and to develop new tricks for resistance.

So now I've got that off my chest, how does it get me off the hook with not washing my hands in hospital? Of course it doesn't. But there are things that could be done to make things easier for doctors and nurses.

Firstly, I don't see little pots of moisturising cream being handed out on morning ward rounds. There is a little patch of skin on my left hand which has been red, cracked and dry ever since I began working. There are (ahem) marginally more expensive brands of hospital handwashing product that come with moisturiser already in them.

There are also (more expensive) alcohol-based handwashing solutions which take 10 seconds, rather than 90, to use. The infection control guidelines in my last hospital stated that these should be at the foot of the bed of every patient who was a high risk for infection: the ward managers, who run their own budgets like the ward was a franchise, have their own ideas.

But smaller initiatives like these make much more of a difference to whether or not we give you nasty infections in hospital than punitive measures or nagging posters, because there are serious workforce implications to washing your hands.

Studies have shown that if nurses on intensive care washed their hands every time it was appropriate, it would take up a fifth of their working day. I already work an unholy number of hours a week, much of it unpaid overtime, so do I add handwashing to my list of things worth ruining my social life for?

Where is the initiative to increase staffing levels by 20% to fund our way out of this scourge of unwashed hands? Where is the evidence to demonstrate that the problem warrants that expenditure? Should I wash my hands after I shake a patient's hand? After I place a concerned hand on their relative's shoulder?

And it's not just hands. There are numerous "humourous" articles in the Christmas editions of medical journals about the disgusting bacteria that reside on the white coat sleeves of junior doctors. My hospital laundry is only open four hours a day. And what about my stethoscope?

So all of this fuss about handwashing guidelines and dirty hospitals (more cleaners, please) was a missed opportunity to promote real initiatives. Which is all very well, but you want to know how to stay alive once you find yourself trapped in my apparently filthy hospital.

The first thing to remember is to get out as soon as you can. I fight a never-ending battle with certain social workers who give old people stuck in hospital a low priority for services in the community, because they labour under the mistaken impression that hospital is a safe place to be if you're medically stable. Of course it's not.

Old people - or rather, people who are run down and weak - are vulnerable wherever they are. You won't catch me going down with one of those nasty infections I carry around under my fingernails: sometimes I don't even wash my hands before I go to the hospital sandwich bar. You could inject me with 10ml of pus from their festering bed-sores and I'd still be back for more. If you're in hospital and there is any chance you could get home, you should be campaigning tirelessly for your release.

But what if you're stuck? The first thing to remember is that just because someone's in hospital, it doesn't mean that all responsibility for their existence is passed over to the state. If your elderly mother needs food to keep her strength up, then the best I can honestly suggest is that you bring her some, because all the jokes about hospital food are true (a prison meal is said to cost 50% more than a hospital one).

If you think someone has been given a catheter for convenience's sake, ask the doctors about it. It's a route of entry for bacteria, and the same goes for cannulae, and both can sometimes get overlooked.

And if you think that the state of hygiene of a patient or a part of the ward really is poor, then mention it to someone, tactfully, referring to specific events and choosing your target - a doctor, a friendly nurse - or even write to the infection control team. It's easy to get labelled a "difficult patient", of course, but most people work in hospitals for the best motives, and in every hospital the majority, however busy they might be, want to be aware of the problem.

webTitle: Ministers to announce rural checklist for policy formulation

fields.headline: Ministers to announce rural checklist for policy formulation
fields.trailText: The government is today expected to announce plans to put rural issues at the heart of the policy-making process.
fields.body:
The government is today expected to announce plans to put rural issues at the heart of the policy-making process.

So-called "rural proofing" measures expected in the rural white paper could mean new legislation being tested against a checklist of rural concerns before it hits the statute book.

Ministers may have to ensure that changes in policy do not cut people living in sparsely populated areas off from essential services. They may also be forced to consider the effect that cutbacks would have on rural communities.

The Local Government Association (LGA) has been pushing for such measures to be included in the paper, and policy officer Crispin Moore believes it has been successful. "We are expecting to see some rural proofing measures," he says.

The white paper is a high-profile attempt by Labour to counter claims from groups such as the Countryside Alliance that the government does not understand the problems faced by rural communities.

It will introduce a focus on the social problems faced by rural communities, moving away from the traditional emphasis that rural policy has placed on agriculture.

As part of this shift, ministers are expected to set out a range of proposals to strengthen the role of parish and town councils as the tier of government closest to rural people.

Ministers are keen to lay to rest accusations by the media and the Conservative party that they want to abolish parishes and replace with them with area committees set up by councils. The government has always hotly denied the allegations.

Sources familiar with negotiations over the white paper expect it to suggest extra funding for parishes as well as closer joint-working with district councils, including more devolution of district responsibilities to the parish level.

Parishes may, however, have to prove that they are open, accountable and democratic before they can benefit from these proposals.

John Findlay, chief executive of the parish lobbying group, the National Association of Local Councils, said: "We welcome what the government is planning to do. It's about a new approach to community democracy. The rural white paper is expected to reflect the changing role of town and parish councils."

webTitle: Prescott proposes minimum service standards for the countryside

fields.headline: Prescott proposes minimum service standards for the countryside
fields.trailText: A wide-ranging package of measures to reverse the decline in rural services was announced today by Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott.
fields.body:
A wide-ranging package of measures to reverse the decline in rural services was announced today by Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott.

Unveiling the long awaited rural white paper, Mr Prescott said the aim was to promote "a living countryside with thriving rural communities and access to high-quality services".

At the heart of the plans is a new rural service standard, setting minimum standards for education, health, childcare and other services in towns and villages. A £15m transport fund is being set up to tackle local transport problems and develop new services.

Mr Prescott also announced that English local authorities will be allowed to end the 50% council tax discount for second homes and use the proceeds to develop affordable housing for local people.

A new "Rural Advocate", Ewen Cameron, the chairman of the Countryside Agency, will argue the case for the countryside "at the highest levels in government and outside".

fields.headline: 2000 places on two-year practical degrees
fields.standfirst: E-business,  music and multimedia, photography, and land-based industry are some of the first foundation degrees to be provided by partnerships of universities, FE colleges and employers.
fields.trailText: Two-year degrees in practical subjects from e-business to land-based industry, from photography to becoming a teaching assistant, were launched today in the government's £10m foundation degree initiative.
fields.body:
Two-year degrees in practical subjects from e-business to land-based industry, from photography to becoming a teaching assistant, were launched today in the government's £10m foundation degree initiative.

Universities, further education colleges and employers have come together to mount 40 pilot courses and are hoping to recruit 2,000 students from next September. Students, who can be full- or part-time, will receive much of their teaching at local colleges or via the internet, and will be guaranteed the chance to convert their qualification into a full degree with another year's (or 1.3 years) study. There will be a strong work-based element and it is a condition of the scheme that employers are involved in designing and providing the courses.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said: "By linking higher education to the world of work we have responded to employers' demands for highly qualified people who know their subject and can apply it in the workplace." His department is to mount a campaign to attract students next year.

The plan involves 35 higher education institutions, 70 further education colleges and a range of employers, national training organisations and other organisations in England and Wales. Sir Brian Fender, Chief Executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, said the innovative nature of the programmes would attract students who had not previously considered higher education, or whose needs were not met by a traditional three or four year course.

A full list of foundation degrees is on www.hefce.ac.uk/news/

webTitle: Scotland could break with England by introducing free personal care

fields.headline: Scotland could break with England by introducing free personal care
fields.trailText: Scotland's first minister faces pressure to offer free personal care for the elderly and chronically ill, following a unanimous parliamentary committee decision. Linda Steele reports.
fields.body:
Scotland's parliament could decide to introduce free personal care for the elderly and chronically ill, following a unanimous committee recommendation today.

The health and community care committee, which scrutinises the Scottish executive, today agreed that the recommendations of Sir Stewart Sutherland's royal commission on long-term care should be implemented, at an estimated extra cost of £110m.

The decision will put extra pressure on first minister Henry McLeish and flies in the face of the message from Whitehall. The UK government has decided that personal care, in residential units or people's own homes in England, should be means-tested. Only nursing care will be free of charge. Ministers would be unhappy with free personal care in Scotland, which would lead in effect to a two-tier system in Britain.

The committee's report calls for fairness and equality in service delivery, and an end to means-testing. Committee convenor Margaret Smith said: "A civilised society is judged upon how well it looks after its most vulnerable citizens and it is clear that many of Scotland's most vulnerable people are not getting the support services they need or deserve.

"Throughout our 10-month inquiry, the overwhelming message we received from stakeholders in community care was that personal care services should be free at the point of use. While we recognise that such a commitment could have an effect on other aspects of community care spending, we received strong indications that this is an important issue of principle for the people of Scotland."

The committee report said that community care for older people and those with learning disabilities or mental health problems needs to draw on evidence-based good practice. It also called for a commitment to raising NHS and local authority expenditure on community care services in real terms.

The Scottish Executive welcomed the health and community care committee's report. A spokesperson said: "We have made community care a priority in our policies and in our spending. We are now taking forward a range of measures which will benefit tens of thousands of old and vulnerable people.

"We are pleased that community care - an important and sometimes complex area of provision - is now high on the political agenda. We will examine the report in detail and respond fully in due course."

The executive has eight weeks to respond to the committee's report. The findings are likely to be debated by the full parliament early in the new year.

fields.headline: Insights into Aids
fields.standfirst: Jerome Monahan asks why two million people in Africa are dying each year from it and what can be done
fields.trailText: Jerome Monahan asks why two million people in Africa are dying each year from it and what can be done
fields.body:
Friday, December 1 is World Aids Day. In many countries people will be wearing red ribbons to show their support for those with the disease. As many as 34.4 million people on the planet are infected with HIV (human immunodeficiency virus). Twenty-four million of them live in Africa, where two million are dying from it every year.

What is Aids?

Aids, or Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome, is a devastating and incurable condition which is carried by HIV in body fluids such as blood, semen (a man's reproductive fluid) or mother's milk. It spreads mainly through people having sexual relations but women with HIV can give it to babies during pregnancy and birth and through breastfeeding them.

The virus attacks the body's natural defences - the immune system. People can have HIV for several years without knowing it, but in many cases eventually their protection cells stop working and they develop other illnesses which are fatal. From the time someone is infected with HIV it is possible to pass it on to somebody else. One of the many reasons why Aids has hit developing countries so hard is because often they do not have the equipment or systems needed to test people for the disease. People remain unaware that they are infectious and so put others they have sex with at risk.

How did it originate?

No one knows. It is similar to viruses that affect monkeys and apes. One idea is that HIV first got into humans in Africa when someone killed an infected chimpanzee and its blood went into an open wound on the hunter's body. It has also been linked to a Polio vaccine that was developed using chimpanzees.

What makes it particularly bad in Africa?

There are drugs that can delay HIV developing into Aids and there are others that can stop the virus passing from mothers to their children in breast milk. However, the companies in America and Europe that make these drugs charge a lot for them. Even when they reduce the price of their products they are still too costly for ordinary Africans.

Education is essential. But safe-sex messages about using condoms have been slow to reach people in African countries, where some leaders have not done enough to fight ignorance and superstition about the disease. Traditional attitudes to sex do not help either - many men refuse to use condoms and African women often have little or no say in the matter.

There have been many wars in Africa's recent history, and the armies fighting them may have spread Aids. The continent's poverty has also assisted the spread of Aids by forcing women into prostitution or weakening people through other illnesses and poor diet.

What impact is Aids having?

Usually it is the young and the old who are at risk of disease, but Aids has been killing people in their 30s and 40s when they have families to support. There are over 13m Aids orphans in Africa. They are growing up neglected and uneducated. Many African countries are getting poorer as improvements in agriculture and industry made over the last 20 years are wiped out. One of Africa's greatest resources is its people and they are dying. A third of people in Botswana aged 15-49 are HIV positive.

What should be done to help?

Western countries are finally realising the threat that Aids represents to peace and stability in Africa. Their governments and charities are funding education and health work. African countries want to be given the right to make the HIV drugs for themselves at prices they can better afford, but the big drugs companies are unwilling to allow this. Campaigners also say it is a scandal that African countries are paying over $15bn a year to Western countries because of huge bank debts built up in the past. They think the richer nations can afford to cancel the $230bn they are owed.

Is it all bad news?

The red ribbon worn on World Aids Day is meant to be a sign of hope. One success story is Uganda, where President Yoweri Museveni has been very public in his support of safe-sex campaigns aimed at young people and new Aids cases have dropped by 75% in 10 years.

 For a history of Aids and an Aids quiz: www.avert.org

fields.bodyText: Friday, December 1 is World Aids Day. In many countries people will be wearing red ribbons to show their support for those with the disease. As many as 34.4 million people on the planet are infected with HIV (human immunodeficiency virus). Twenty-four million of them live in Africa, where two million are dying from it every year. What is Aids? Aids, or Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome, is a devastating and incurable condition which is carried by HIV in body fluids such as blood, semen (a man's reproductive fluid) or mother's milk. It spreads mainly through people having sexual relations but women with HIV can give it to babies during pregnancy and birth and through breastfeeding them. The virus attacks the body's natural defences - the immune system. People can have HIV for several years without knowing it, but in many cases eventually their protection cells stop working and they develop other illnesses which are fatal. From the time someone is infected with HIV it is possible to pass it on to somebody else. One of the many reasons why Aids has hit developing countries so hard is because often they do not have the equipment or systems needed to test people for the disease. People remain unaware that they are infectious and so put others they have sex with at risk. How did it originate? No one knows. It is similar to viruses that affect monkeys and apes. One idea is that HIV first got into humans in Africa when someone killed an infected chimpanzee and its blood went into an open wound on the hunter's body. It has also been linked to a Polio vaccine that was developed using chimpanzees. What makes it particularly bad in Africa? There are drugs that can delay HIV developing into Aids and there are others that can stop the virus passing from mothers to their children in breast milk. However, the companies in America and Europe that make these drugs charge a lot for them. Even when they reduce the price of their products they are still too costly for ordinary Africans. Education is essential. But safe-sex messages about using condoms have been slow to reach people in African countries, where some leaders have not done enough to fight ignorance and superstition about the disease. Traditional attitudes to sex do not help either - many men refuse to use condoms and African women often have little or no say in the matter. There have been many wars in Africa's recent history, and the armies fighting them may have spread Aids. The continent's poverty has also assisted the spread of Aids by forcing women into prostitution or weakening people through other illnesses and poor diet. What impact is Aids having? Usually it is the young and the old who are at risk of disease, but Aids has been killing people in their 30s and 40s when they have families to support. There are over 13m Aids orphans in Africa. They are growing up neglected and uneducated. Many African countries are getting poorer as improvements in agriculture and industry made over the last 20 years are wiped out. One of Africa's greatest resources is its people and they are dying. A third of people in Botswana aged 15-49 are HIV positive. What should be done to help? Western countries are finally realising the threat that Aids represents to peace and stability in Africa. Their governments and charities are funding education and health work. African countries want to be given the right to make the HIV drugs for themselves at prices they can better afford, but the big drugs companies are unwilling to allow this. Campaigners also say it is a scandal that African countries are paying over $15bn a year to Western countries because of huge bank debts built up in the past. They think the richer nations can afford to cancel the $230bn they are owed. Is it all bad news? The red ribbon worn on World Aids Day is meant to be a sign of hope. One success story is Uganda, where President Yoweri Museveni has been very public in his support of safe-sex campaigns aimed at young people and new Aids cases have dropped by 75% in 10 years. webTitle: London councils get limited increases in central grant support

fields.headline: London councils get limited increases in central grant support
fields.trailText: The government is proposing to limit funding increases for local authorities with education and social services responsibilities in a bid to even out "unacceptably wide" fluctuations in council grants.
fields.body:
The government is proposing to limit funding increases for local authorities with education and social services responsibilities in a bid to even out "unacceptably wide" fluctuations in council grants.

Local government minister Hilary Armstrong announced the move today as part of a consultation paper on next year's local government finance settlement, money supplied by the government which makes up the bulk of individual council budgets. The government has boosted overall council funding by £2.8bn, or 6.7%, bringing the total amount of money paid to local authorities to £44bn.

The paper suggests limiting funding increases to 6.5% of an authority's current grant. This will cap large increases due to 12 councils in the south-east, nine of which are in London, because of rising wages and populations in the region. London councils say the funding settlement will still mean an extra £349m for the capital.

Association of London Government chairman Sir Robin Wales welcomed the government's decision to use the most up-to-date information on wages to calculate council grants. Ministers had suggested not updating the information in a bid to maintain funding levels for northern authorities.

Sir Robin said: "Factors such as higher wages and increases in the number of school children in London will be at least partially taken into account when considering how much money each borough is to get."

The money saved on large increases will help provide a 3.2% minimum funding increase for councils that provide education and social services. While many of the 35 authorities that will benefit are in the north of England, including Liverpool and Hull, southern councils such as Islington, Plymouth and Bath and North East Somerset will also receive a boost.

Launching the financial package, local government minister Hilary Armstrong said she did not expect to have to use her powers to cap council tax increases next year, but added: "Council tax increases should continue on a downward trend. Of course, increases in council taxes are a matter for individual authorities and last year the vast majority acted sensibly and with restraint. I urge councils to do the same this year."

The Local Government Association welcomed the boost to council finances. The Conservatives attacked the government, claiming that the finance package would mean a large increase in council taxes and that under Labour taxes had risen by 23% for the average household.

webTitle: Analysis: Political parties and tax policy

fields.headline: Heartland murmurs
fields.standfirst:
When it comes to tax and spend, social policy and help for the poor, all the political parties are out of touch with their traditional voters

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText:
Analysis: When it comes to tax and spend, social policy and help for the poor, all the political parties are out of touch with their traditional voters

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.body:
Today's British Social Attitudes (BSA) report complements yesterday's from the Fabian Society in what they say about our attitudes towards tax. Spending wins over tax cuts by a large margin among both Tory and Labour supporters. (The table on the right is based on an August ICM poll; people were asked about spending v tax cuts, given that over the next few years government is going to have enough money to do either.) There is also a body of opinion out there in favour of redistributing income to the poor, even at the expense of tax rises.

Despite Thatcherism, it seems, social justice still conditions the response of a lot of people. According to the BSA, the middle class is pretty evenly split on the case for redistribution; the working class is two to one in favour. But progressives should not cheer too quickly. Fiscal ignorance abounds. People think the UK is more heavily taxed than other European countries - it is not. Some core attitudes are firmly regressive. Half the population, at least, opposes inheritance tax. A clear majority (58%) think income tax is "too high" and three-quarters say they are paying too much tax on petrol and in VAT.

There is a problem with these findings. Each year the BSA throws up fascinating observations - men became less tolerant of extramarital sex in the 1990s while becoming markedly more liberal about gay sex. But what people tell pollsters has no straightforward relationship to the way they outwardly behave, for example when they come to vote or when they buy rightwing newspapers.

The Fabians, admirably rationalist, think people would back more taxes at the ballot box if they were convinced the money went on good causes and was not "wasted". People are disconnected from government and think it unlikely extra tax would improve public services. The way forward, the Fabians say, is to make the whole business of levying tax and public spending much more transparent. A new independent watchdog should provide citizens with more information.

Perhaps people would be happier if they could guarantee their tax went to those universal favourites health and education. According to the BSA study, admittedly based on last year's data, roads and transport are much less favoured.

The other qualification to Fabian optimism is whether people trust government to do anything, especially spend well and wisely. Confidence in the state is diminishing here as in other western countries, which implies future support for higher taxes is going to be hard to muster.

The public is picky about who it thinks deserves to benefit from tax-derived spending. Successive BSA reports, going back to the period of Thatcherite triumphalism, have found a majority of people do favour welfare state solutions to social problems, including extensive redistribution of income to the less well off. But they have distinct views about who they think worthy of any extra state assistance. Those who care for disabled relatives and people with disabilities themselves score highest, especially among women. The unemployed and single mothers are at the bottom of the list, even among women. Working-class people - those in households where a breadwinner does a manual job - favour redistribution of income in principle, but are not at all sympathetic to the claims of the very poor as beneficiaries. A transparent tax system that better reflected the public will could look a lot meaner than the social security system we have.

Labour may take heart from the consistent finding that people are not against helping the unemployed with training and back-to-work schemes, such as the New Deal. Similarly Louise Casey, the homelessness tsar, is going with the grain of public opinion in her wish to help beggars with practical schemes for training and support rather than cash handouts.

Geoff Evans, the Nuffield College, Oxford, sociologist who contributed a chapter to this year's BSA on differences in attitudes across the social classes, concludes that both Labour and the Tories have a problem with their "heartlands" (as for working-class supporters of the Liberal Democrats, they turn out to be neither liberal nor democratic).

Labour's working-class base is to the left of official party policy on such issues as redistribution of income and progressive taxation. But the same supporters are noticeably to the right of Labour on crime and punishment and attitudes towards sexual and racial minorities. As for Europe, three-quarters of Labour's working- class support holds identifiably "rightwing" views. Labour has, of course, long been aware of the split. Since 1997 it has been Jack Straw's task to follow an illiberal line at the Home Office while (mildly) progressive policies have been followed by his colleagues in social security and the Treasury. The Tories are split, too. Their middle-class supporters are relatively benign on equal opportunities for blacks and Asians while their working-class support is vehemently opposed.

A political party system that mirrored public opinion would look something like this. The "left" party would tax and spend more, be hostile to the euro, pro hanging, but relatively liberal on race. The right party would be even harsher than William Hague on crime and punishment but keen on higher public spending. For all the accusations of populism levelled at Mr Hague, he seems incapable of repositioning his party on the terrain of spending and redistribution despite - on this evidence - the votes to be won there. He has a problem with Europe, too, since lower-class Tories are significantly more Eurosceptic than middle-class adherents, who might be turned off by hard-line anti-Europe policies.

If, meanwhile, there were a party based on the putative views of Guardian readers it would find itself pretty isolated from the mainstream of opinion, small in number but very progressive on tax and spend.

webTitle: Crossroads confirms star line-up for TV comeback

fields.headline: Crossroads confirms star line-up for TV comeback
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Actress Jane Rossington, who spoke the opening line in Crossroads 36 years ago, is to return to the ITV soap as Jill Harvey, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Actress Jane Rossington, who spoke the opening line in Crossroads 36 years ago, is set to return to the ITV soap as Jill Harvey.

Joining her in the new Crossroads line-up are former Coronation Street actress Sherrie Hewson, who plays receptionist Virginia Raven.

"To have been part of a programme which made television history was wonderful - and to be back at Crossroads as the series is reborn is really exciting," said Miss Rossington.

Other confirmed members of the cast include Last of the Summer Wine actress Kathy Staff, who plays Doris Luke, and Tony Adams as Adam Chance.

Jane Gurnett will play Kate Russell, the owner of Crossroads. Former Hollyoaks actors James McKenzie Robinson and Toby Sawyer have also been signed up.

The new Crossroads has gone into production at Carlton's studios in Nottingham and on location in the surrounding area after a break of 12 years.

Series executive producer Sharon Bloom promised viewers that the new show, which will be screened on ITV five nights a week from next spring, would be well worth watching.

"We'll be introducing some powerful new characters and storylines whilst retaining many of the aspects that made Crossroads such a well-loved programme for so many years," she said.

webTitle: Class divide centres on sex issues more than spending

fields.headline: Class divide centres on sex issues more than spending
fields.standfirst:
The rise of the Little Englanders
Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: The big differences of opinion between the middle and working classes centre on social and moral issues rather than taxation, spending and economic policy.
fields.body:
The big differences of opinion between the middle and working classes centre on social and moral issues rather than taxation, spending and economic policy.

The British social attitudes survey found both classes wanted more public spending and agreed the two top priorities should be health and education. But people from the working class were more conservative - and more out of sympathy with current Labour policies - on law and order, sexual morality and race.

A study by Geoffrey Evans of Oxford University found 60% of the working class thought homosexuality was "wrong", compared with 37% of the middle class.

The working classes were more likely to think the government's equal opportunities policies have "gone too far" and to be more sceptical about the EU.

Threequarters of the working class favoured keeping the pound as Britain's only currency, compared with 43% of the middle class.

Mr Evans said: "Working class voters might look for a party that more closely represents their views on issues such as immigration and minorities, and, rightly or wrongly, might consider the Conservatives."

Other breakdowns in the survey showed a big gulf between young and old. Nearly two thirds of 18- to 24-year-olds considered premarital sex to be "not wrong at all", but only 26% of over-65s agreed.

Two thirds of 18- to 24-year-olds did not belong to a religion, compared with only a quarter of those aged over 65.

The gender gap on social attitudes is narrowing. Men were slightly more in favour of marriage than women, but only a minority (27% of men and 21% of women) think married people are "generally happier" than the unmarried.

 Britons are becoming more permissive about the portrayal of sex in the media. Less than a quarter want to ban "frank" heterosexual scenes from regular TV channels, although 53% think such scenes should be shown after 10pm. Nearly half (48%) would ban homosexual sex scenes from regular channels, a fall of six points since 1995.

 Four people in five think the NHS should never ration treatment, but 56% think a younger person would currently get priority over an older one for an NHS heart operation. If rationing has to take place 60% want medical experts to take the decisions, not politicians or administrators.

 In 1983, 40% said they belonged to the Church of England, but by 1999 this had fallen to 27%. However nearly half (48%) said they "believe in God and always have done" - unchanged over the last 10 years.

 One in three people living in a big city have a yearning for the country life. Less than 5% of rural dwellers want to move to a big city. About three-quarters of those living in a country village want to stay put, compared with 30% of those living in a big city.

 Half the public never give money to beggars, 44% do sometimes and 5% do so often. Those most likely to give are young, have high incomes and are regular churchgoers. The frequency that people come across beggars has no effect on their likelihood of giving.

 Among women who work outside the home, 35% are "very satisfied" with their jobs, compared with 29% of men. Researchers linked this to more women working part time. Part-timers reported higher levels of job satisfaction.
