webTitle: Local councils offer vital grassroots link

fields.headline: Local councils offer vital grassroots link
fields.standfirst: Parish and town councils are ready to take on new responsibilities, if the government's rural white paper provides them, write James Bowe and Alan Jones
fields.trailText: Parish and town councils are ready to take on new responsibilities, if the government's rural white paper provides them, write James Bowe and Alan Jones
fields.body:
The imminent publication of the rural white paper represents the best opportunity for town and parish councils in years.

Supporters of the third tier of local government are waiting with bated breath to see if there is truth in the rumours that the paper will bring increased funding, new powers and closer working with district councils. Increasingly, it does look likely that often-dismissed parishes are set for a greater role in local government.

It may be hard to believe that the authorities popularly associated with the TV programme The Vicar of Dibley should be so anxiously awaiting modernisation. But parish councils have already shown they are ready by embracing best value. The 41 parish and town councils that are legally subject to the best value inspection regime because they spend more than £500,000 a year scored higher across the board in the best value audit than other tiers of local government, and those parishes that are not legally required to submit to best value are enthusiastically adopting the spirit of the new regime.

There are more than 80,000 town, parish and community councillors in England and Wales. They are able to take decisions on matters affecting their communities, which can range from planning and pavilions through to rights of way and roadside verges.

The 10,000 town, parish and community councils in England and Wales cover areas that range from small rural communities to major towns. All are independently elected, with powers to raise their own funds. They provide employment for more than 25,000 staff, while their annual expenditure exceeds £200m. Together, they can be identified as the nation's single most influential grouping of grassroots opinion-formers. Vicar of Dibley, anyone?

These councils are valuable because they are so close to the spirit of local democracy. They are the first tier of local government and perfectly placed to give a voice to their communities.

This puts parishes in an ideal position to counter the much-lamented crisis of apathy in local government. Clearly, if the electorate is to re-engage with local affairs, the sense of ownership which town and parish councils are able to foster is invaluable. The government is waking up to this reality. The task for ministers now lies in a re-engagement of local energy, in a kind of re-empowerment of community roots.

Without more powers and freedoms, the ability of modernised parish and town councils to deliver the government's goals and provide effective locally determined services cannot be fully realised. The rural white paper is not just a test for local councils but for ministers, too.

One need look no further than the millennium dome for a reminder of just how far short policy can fall of the ideals behind it. The government must trust local people to control their own affairs, otherwise modernised local government may end up in the same position as the dome - an empty shell.

 James Bowe and Alan Jones are officers of the National Association of Local Councils

These councils are valuable because they are so close to the spirit of local democracy. They are the first tier of local government and perfectly placed to give a voice to their communities. This puts parishes in an ideal position to counter the much-lamented crisis of apathy in local government. Clearly, if the electorate is to re-engage with local affairs, the sense of ownership which town and parish councils are able to foster is invaluable. The government is waking up to this reality. The task for ministers now lies in a re-engagement of local energy, in a kind of re-empowerment of community roots. Without more powers and freedoms, the ability of modernised parish and town councils to deliver the government's goals and provide effective locally determined services cannot be fully realised. The rural white paper is not just a test for local councils but for ministers, too. One need look no further than the millennium dome for a reminder of just how far short policy can fall of the ideals behind it. The government must trust local people to control their own affairs, otherwise modernised local government may end up in the same position as the dome - an empty shell.  James Bowe and Alan Jones are officers of the National Association of Local Councils

webTitle: Royal College of Nursing seeks general secretary

fields.headline: Royal College of Nursing seeks general secretary
fields.standfirst: Few will admit that they hanker after the post now occupied by Christine Hancock, writes Anne Gulland
fields.trailText: Few will admit that they hanker after the post now occupied by Christine Hancock, writes Anne Gulland
fields.body:
The most powerful position in nursing - and one of the most influential jobs in the NHS - will be advertised in the next few days as the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) seeks a replacement for its general secretary Christine Hancock.

After almost 12 years at the helm of the RCN, the most famous nurse in the country - after Charlie and Duffy from Casualty - is leaving next June to take up a less demanding role as president of the International Council of Nurses.

Her successor - who is expected to be unveiled in January next year - will inherit not only a £90,000 plus salary but one of the most high profile trade union jobs around. Society Guardian's recent Power 90 poll ranked Ms Hancock as the 14th most influential person in the NHS.

But trying to get anyone to admit they covet the post is tricky. Jane Salvage, director of nursing for publishing company Emap, and ex-nursing officer for the World Health Organization, is one of the few who will openly admit hankering after what she calls the top job in nursing.

'It's a great job. We're at a very interesting point in nursing's development and in the politics of the NHS and one of the reasons the job is so desirable and interesting is that in terms of the government's agenda you do have power to make sure that nursing makes its proper contribution.'

But those who regard the RCN as an essentially conservative organisation wonder whether the independently minded Salvage - who last year tried and failed to get the job of chief nurse for England - would get past the initial weeding out process.

Although she is well-known among nurses - she writes a regular column for Nursing Times - neither she, nor any candidate, can appeal to the membership because the general secretary's post is appointed by an RCN council committee rather than election.

Ray Rowden, health policy analyst and a frequent thorn in the college's side, says he is not going for the job, despite recently standing unsuccessfully for the elected post of RCN president.

He thinks the choice likely to be a current RCN official - such as Tom Bolger, the deputy general secretary, or Alison Kitson, director of the RCN institute (the college's educational and professional development arm).

'They're not going to go for anyone radical or exciting. I think it's going to be more of the same,' he says.

Mr Bolger is strongly fancied for the top job because he has been Hancock's deputy for 10 years and knows the RCN and its workings inside out. His gender could be a drawback in a woman-dominated profession, however, even though Ms Hancock's predecessor was a man, Trevor Clay.

Mr Bolger admits that he would consider the post - once he has seen the advertisement.

The leather-trousered, spiky-haired Ms Kitson would certainly "shock matron" according to some commentators. Others question whether she has the "common touch" that would endear herself to members.

Pippa Gough, head of the RCN's policy unit is seen as another possible candidate. But Gough, like Kitson, is regarded by many as more of a policy wonk than a dyed-in-the-wool trade unionist.

Mike Hayward, an RCN steward in Portsmouth and frequent critic of the RCN hierarchy, believes that the post will go to Bolder, Gough or Kitson, even though none, in his opinion, fit the bill.

'What we need is a leader with a good trades union background because, after all, that's what people pay their pound, shilling and pence for.'

A senior figure in the college says that so far just three people have informally indicated they will stand: Bolger, Kitson and Salvage.

The past three general secretaries - Hancock, Clay, and Catherine Hall - were outsiders, which could be good news for Salvage.

fields.headline: Sharif's party in shambles
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan's ousted ruling party is struggling under new leadership and a controversial allegiance, writes Rory McCarthy in Islamabad
Special report: Pakistan coup
fields.trailText: Pakistan's ousted ruling party is struggling under new leadership and a controversial allegiance, writes Rory McCarthy in Islamabad.
fields.body:
A year after the Pakistan Muslim League (PML) was pushed out of government in a military coup the party is in a shambles.

The party's chief Nawaz Sharif is serving a life sentence for hijacking and 14 years for corruption. In a country where personalities make political parties, the PML is left confused and riddled with infighting.

Mr Sharif's wife, Kulsoom, has taken charge, though she has no position in the party and barely spoke out while her husband was in power. She has led the PML into an alliance with its arch rival, the Pakistan People's Party (PPP), led by Benazir Bhutto.

The two parties have dominated political life since the last military dictator, General Zia ul-Haq, died in a plane crash in 1988.

Several of the PML's senior leaders including Gen Zia's son, Ijaz ul-Haq, are infuriated by Mrs Sharif's sudden influence and the idea of an allegiance with Mrs Bhutto. They prefer reconciliation with the military regime.

Both sides are taking a huge gamble. Mrs Sharif's alliance with the PPP against the military represents a staggering about-face for the party. And their call for democracy is raising some eyebrows in Pakistan.

When he was elected prime minister for the second time in 1997, Mr Sharif scrapped the president's most important powers, particularly his right to sack the elected government. Eventually the president resigned and was replaced by a friend of the Sharif family.

The prime minister also picked a fight with the chief justice, forcing him out after hundreds of PML workers stormed the supreme court. He then appointed his brother Shahbaz to chief minister of Punjab, the second most powerful position in Pakistan. The family grew incredibly wealthy, leading to Mr Sharif's conviction on corruption charges.

For 12 years the PML was defined by its opposition to Mrs Bhutto's PPP. Nawaz Sharif was encouraged by General Zia, the man who hanged Benazir's father.

The cross-party alliance is not new. Its leader, the veteran kingmaker Nawabzada Nasrullah Khan, has led alliances against Mrs Bhutto with the support of Mr Sharif and alliances against Mr Sharif with the support of Mrs Bhutto.

But it may be that Nawaz Sharif has gone too far in approving this alliance.

"It is an open question whether Nawaz voters and supporters will ditch him for this heretical conduct, but his political standing, and by that token the political rating of his faction, will suffer," said The News, a leading English language newspaper.

300 party dissidents, who opposed the alliance, stormed the party's Islamabad headquarters last week, tearing down and burning pictures of Nawaz Sharif.

Mr Sharif's supporters noted that the police stood by and allowed the riot to continue, perhaps in the hope of derailing the cross-party alliance against the military.

Last weekend another group of dissidents climbed on to the roof of the party office in Lahore and posed for cameras with their pistols, shotguns and Kalashnikov rifles, a blatant and unpunished defiance of the government's new curb on weapons.

One of them, Mr ul-Haq, has been widely tipped to become the prime minister, with the military ruler General Pervez Musharraf installing himself as president.

This split in the PML may be Mr ul-Haq's way of moving closer to the military in the hope of greater glory. If so he may have already lost the support of a large and crucial slice of his party.

webTitle: Mirror and Telegraph may cancel WH Smith distribution

fields.headline: Mirror and Telegraph may cancel WH Smith distribution
fields.standfirst:
Nov 27: Distribution row escalates
Nov 27: Papers plan to dump WHS
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: The Mirror and the Telegraph are considering cancelling distribution with WH Smith News, following Associated Newspapers' decision this weekend to terminate a £100m deal with the firm.

Nov 27: Distribution row escalates

Nov 27: Papers plan to dump WHS
fields.body:
The Mirror and the Telegraph are considering cancelling their distribution relationships with WH Smith News, following Associated Newspapers' decision this weekend to terminate a £100m deal with the company

The newspapers fear that WH Smith's plans to centralise newspaper distribution would damage their sales by threatening daily supplies to thousands of rural cornershops.

A spokeswoman for Trinity Mirror, owner of the Mirror, said: "We are looking at the implications that Associated's decision has thrown up."

However, she denied reports on this morning's Radio 4 Today programme that the Mirror had formally contacted WH Smith saying it intended to terminate its contract.

But the spokeswoman admitted it was something that had been considered. "We're mulling it over," she said.

Wally Cowley, circulation manager at Trinity Mirror, confirmed that the company was keeping its options open.

He said: "We are concerned about the action of WH Smith and we will monitor the ongoing situation closely with regard to our contract with them."

The feud between newspapers and WH Smith was sparked in April when the newsagent's wholesale arm said it wanted to centralise the existing regional distribution network established more than 100 years ago.

One senior newspaper executive said: "WH Smith say this is about all about service, but it is now about margins and power."

The Telegraph also confirmed that it was reviewing its deal with the distributor. "We have warned Smiths that they are playing with fire," said a spokeswoman.

She repeated comments made by Telegraph managing director Jeremy Deedes, saying that parent company Hollinger was always reviewing its distribution relationships "to get the best possible service".

News International, which owns the Times and the Sun, is considering taking control of its own distribution relationships. It announced yesterday that it was expanding its Birmingham-based prototype distribution system.

Meanwhile, Guardian distribution manager Bob Steadman said that the paper was monitoring WH Smith's performance.

He added the Guardian had no immediate plans to cancel its WH Smith contract but that it was "always an option".

fields.headline: Harpers & Queen editor-in-chief dies
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Fiona Macpherson, editor-in-chief of society glossy Harpers & Queen, has died aged 61, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Fiona Macpherson, editor-in-chief of Harpers & Queen, has died aged 61.

The National Magazine Company, which owns the society glossy, said Ms Macpherson had been suffering from cancer. She died peacefully this morning in London.

Ms Macpherson was one of the magazine industry's longest-serving editors, having joined Harpers & Queen in the 1970s as deputy editor. She later left the magazine to start a family, but returned as editor in 1994.

Two months ago Nat Mags poached Lucy Yeomans, deputy editor of Tatler, to edit the magazine and Ms Macpherson moved to the new position of editor-in-chief.

NatMags managing director Terry Mansfield said: "It is typical of Fiona that she didn't want anyone to know how ill she was. Just a couple of weeks ago, she finished working on the January issue of Harpers & Queen, a tribute to her great professionalism until the very end.

"Words cannot express how much we will all miss Fiona. She had style, presence and was an amazing journalist. Her grace, wit and charm were legendary and her very special personality graced the pages of every issue of Harpers & Queen she edited."

fields.headline: Normal service resumes for Millionaire
fields.trailText: 1.30pm TV overnights: Who Wants to be a Millionaire?'s audience fell by 3m viewers on last week's top prize performance, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The difference a bit of advance publicity and £500,000 in prize money can make to Who Wants to be a Millionaire?'s audience appears to be around 3m viewers.

Last night an average of 11.1m viewers tuned in to the ITV quiz show from 8-9pm for an instalment in which Racing Post tipster John Randall balked on the £1m question of which planet had a satellite called Oberon (it's Uranus), walking away with £500,000 instead.

Last Monday, when news of Judith Keppel becoming the first millionaire winner on Millionaire was leaked to the Sun in advance, the show attracted an average of 13.9m.

Elsewhere last night, BBC1's 9-10pm comedy line-up got the better of returning Michelle Collins drama Daylight Robbery on ITV.

The last in the current run of The Royle Family was brought forward to 9pm and took 8.7m and a 34% share.

A One Foot in the Grave repeat, selected by a viewers' phone poll, followed on at 9.30pm, with 8.8m and a 35% share.

Daylight Robbery, which stars Ms Collins as one of a gang of Essex housewives who become bank robbers, attracted 7.4m and a 29% share from 9-10pm.

On Channel 5, the terrestrial premiere of Boogie Nights, which stars Mark Wahlberg as a well-endowed youth who becomes a 1970s porn star under the tutelage of director Burt Reynolds, averaged 1.6m and a 14% share from 10pm.

webTitle: Arts: Danny Leigh talks to John Waters

fields.headline: Tinseltown must die
fields.standfirst: John Waters, one-time Pope of Trash, has gone back to his roots with Cecil B Demented, the story of a film-maker turned urban guerrilla. He explains why to Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: John Waters, one-time Pope of Trash, has gone back to his roots with Cecil B Demented, the story of a film-maker turned urban guerrilla. He explains why to Danny Leigh.
fields.body:
'This close up? Oh God... Really?" With just the hint of a grimace, John Waters is having his photo taken. There's a whir as the lens zooms right into his face. He shuffles in his seat, makes sure that familiar half-smirk is in position, and stares obligingly at the camera, back straight, hands in lap. "Oh God... I'm going to look like Lillian Gish on her deathbed."

But he does as he's asked and he smirks while he's doing it. Because that's what John Waters would do. Naughty, kitschy, cuddly Uncle John, everyone's favourite dirty-minded, camply dapper film-maker and raconteur, turned out just-so with his dinky pencil moustache and neat little green suede sneakers.

It's a willingness to accommodate somewhere between arch-professionalism and the plain good manners of an Eisenhower-era mother's boy. Uncle John, the 54-year-old clean-living, sleaze-fixated charmer who gladly transformed himself into a family-friendly cartoon character (literally so when he took a guest spot on The Simpsons).

Except there's always been a side to Uncle John that wasn't quite so accessible. The side that collects the bad art of serial killer John Wayne Gacy; the side with an antique electric chair in his Baltimore living room; the side, in short, forever slightly at odds with the lovable schlock-hound of public image.

And it's that side - furtive, gothic, more than faintly morbid - lurking in the background of his film industry romp Cecil B Demented, wherein a zealous young director and his band of deranged cinephiles embark on a kamikaze mission to kidnap an ageing, ill-tempered former starlet (played by Melanie Griffith) and destroy Hollywood.

Sweet-natured though the results may be, there's still a fierce bristle to Cecil's Tinseltown-baiting polemics: the kind of trashy confrontationalism many assumed lost during Waters's lengthy transition from the squalor of 1972's Pink Flamingos to the polished feelgood of 1998's Pecker.

Amid Cecil's retro air of Year Zero radicalism, there's a welcome reminder that, while its director may be one of the few film-makers who can talk with genuine ardour about ultrasuede, he's definitely the only one who would present his crew with Baader-Meinhof member Astrid Proll's photographic collection Pictures on the Run as a thank-you gift.

"Oh, they loved that," he beams. "But the Weathermen were actually my favourite terrorists. I mean, I liked Baader-Meinhof, and the Red Brigades too. But the Weathermen were really the biggest influence on the film, because that's who I remember growing up."

He leans in conspiratorially. "Did you know Bernadine Dohrn [leading light of the Weathermen] runs a day-care centre? There's a great book called Sixties Radicals Then and Now, and it's so depressing, because they all run day-care centres. Can you imagine taking your kid there? 'OK children, remember - question authority!'"

Yet, even coming from as taboo-busting a figure as Waters, opening a movie with a glitzy premiere being assailed with AK-47s isn't likely to win many friends in Beverly Hills. After all, ever since Charles Manson's acolytes ran amok at Roman Polanski's LA home (their number including the director's now-reformed friend Tex Watson), violence against its own has remained strictly verboten for the US film business.

Beneath the moustache, his top lip curls in amusement. "Oh, but I hate real violence. I can't even watch... what's it called? When Animals Attack? Right. But fake violence I love. And the whole idea was that if cinema-going were ever political, and people killed for their movies, then this is how it would happen."

There he goes again: the same old walking contradiction. Uncle John, who winces at cheesy TV shows, but gleefully mows down the (fictional) producers of (equally fictional) Forrest Gump sequel Gump Again. Mention their real-life counterparts and he barely stifles a sneer. "They won an Oscar and made a billion dollars. What have they got to be mad about?"

Mention Melanie Griffith, however, and he's tact personified, batting your cynicism right back at you. John, you must know people will see something pointed in casting the famously erratic Griffith as a tantrum-throwing has-been? "Well, we've all heard the stories. But I can tell you that if she was anything like that, she would never have got through a 31-day shoot in Baltimore." And, really, he sounds like he means it, the defence of his leading lady taking in flamboyant self-parody ("I liked her immediately - we met at Pia Zadora's birthday party").

He crosses his legs, uncrosses them, then crosses them again. "The thing is, if you have any kind of image, you make fun of it. That's how you destroy it. That goes for Melanie, and for me too. Cecil B Demented is as much a joke at my expense, because it's about the fact that you can't shock people any more. Everyone's hip now. No one rises to the bait." He throws his hands up in despair. "There's nothing left but snuff!"

He's got a point. When, as he says, "everyone gets the joke", and the likes of the Farrelly brothers have taken your hard-won niche and hawked it to the multiplex, what's a bad-taste veteran to do but reminisce? So, with Cecil, that's what Waters does. With its fond portrayal of the no-budget cause, that - minus the guns - is his own career up on screen. Nostalgia is everywhere.

Even the film's battlegrounds - two exploitation cinemas, one catering for karate flicks, the other for porn - are anachronisms. "Oh, those days are gone. Hollywood makes the action movies now, and porn cinemas are for people who like public sex, and since Aids you don't see many of them. No, it's gone. Over."

But does he honestly miss it? "Well, sometimes I miss that kind of insanity. I don't necessarily miss being poor. What I do think is sad is that everything is controversial now. I remember sitting through [1960s art movie] I Am Curious Blue, just because I thought maybe I could see full-frontal female nudity. Which, in itself, was the last thing I wanted to see.

"But everything's edgy now. I mean, that's the joke of this movie. Everyone wants" - he's smirking like a trooper now - "'edge credentials.' Now even the most outrageous movie is applauded. Back then, people hated them."

Indeed, through Cecil's mad-eyed idealism, you sense Waters's own distaste for the whole slick machinery of modern film-making, the unholy tag-team of PR cheerleaders and entertainment media. In a script full of razor-sharp gags, one of the best comes on the set of Gump Again, as a heavily-armed Cecil turns to a cowering journalist and screams "No more free food for you... hack!"

He leans in again. "You know, someone actually ended a relationship with me on that basis." Really? "Hm-hm. They said being with me was like always eating someone else's free food." I tell him that's one of the saddest things I've ever heard him say, and he can't stop laughing. "Oh, but it's a great line, isn't it? What can you say to that? You're right, you know? "You know those videos of people caught fucking on CCTV? They're incredibly popular. Bizarrely so. And I was talking to someone who produces them, and I said, 'Well, how come you don't get sued the entire time?' And he said, 'Oh, they're all very professional, they sign release forms.' So now, if you're a night watchman and you're found banging a cardboard box, you just sign your release form and take your money. Isn't that amazing?"

Waters waits dutifully for the flashbulb, then picks up where he left off. If there's one thing he loves, he says, it's flying business-class. "I don't feel guilty about that. I didn't fly first-class till I was in my 40s. Although I do miss it. You know why?" Another picture; another silence. "Because the cute people are always in economy."

He shuffles in his seat, makes sure that familiar half-smirk is in position, and stares obligingly at the camera, back straight, hands in lap. "Oh God... Naughty, kitschy, cuddly Uncle John, everyone's favourite dirty-minded, camply dapper film-maker and raconteur, turned out just-so with his dinky pencil moustache and neat little green suede sneakers. It's a willingness to accommodate somewhere between arch-professionalism and the plain good manners of an Eisenhower-era mother's boy. Uncle John, the 54-year-old clean-living, sleaze-fixated charmer who gladly transformed himself into a family-friendly cartoon character (literally so when he took a guest spot on The Simpsons). Except there's always been a side to Uncle John that wasn't quite so accessible. "Did you know Bernadine Dohrn [leading light of the Weathermen] runs a day-care centre? Beneath the moustache, his top lip curls in amusement. "Oh, but I hate real violence. I can't even watch... what's it called? When Animals Attack? Right. But fake violence I love. And the whole idea was that if cinema-going were ever political, and people killed for their movies, then this is how it would happen." There he goes again: the same old walking contradiction. Uncle John, who winces at cheesy TV shows, but gleefully mows down the (fictional) producers of (equally fictional) Forrest Gump sequel Gump Again. Mention their real-life counterparts and he barely stifles a sneer. "They won an Oscar and made a billion dollars. What have they got to be mad about?" Mention Melanie Griffith, however, and he's tact personified, batting your cynicism right back at you. John, you must know people will see something pointed in casting the famously erratic Griffith as a tantrum-throwing has-been? "Well, we've all heard the stories. But I can tell you that if she was anything like that, she would never have got through a 31-day shoot in Baltimore." And, really, he sounds like he means it, the defence of his leading lady taking in flamboyant self-parody ("I liked her immediately - we met at Pia Zadora's birthday party"). He crosses his legs, uncrosses them, then crosses them again. "The thing is, if you have any kind of image, you make fun of it. That's how you destroy it. That goes for Melanie, and for me too. Cecil B Demented is as much a joke at my expense, because it's about the fact that you can't shock people any more. Everyone's hip now. No one rises to the bait." He throws his hands up in despair. webTitle: Three hour train trip becomes nine hour ordeal

fields.headline: Three hour train trip becomes nine hour ordeal
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Passengers experienced the chaos on Britain's railways first-hand as they were forced to spend the night stranded on a train.
fields.body:
Passengers experienced the chaos on Britain's railways first-hand as they were forced to spend the night stranded on a train.

The 30 people set off from London's St Pancras station at 10pm last night on what should have been a simple journey of less than three hours.

But a power failure on the line south of Bedford left them marooned on board the Midland Mainline operated train for four hours, before it finally moving as far as Kettering station.

The bleary-eyed passengers were eventually taken by bus - which took another two hours - to Nottingham, where they arrived at 7am today, nine hours after setting off.

Housewife Diane Adams and her husband, Mark, a fork lift driver, said they were calling for compensation after having endured the nightmare journey.

The couple, from Bulwell, Nottingham, had been visiting the capital for the weekend as a surprise to celebrate Mrs Adams's birthday.

After finally arriving home, Mrs Adams said: "It was awful - that's the only word to describe it. The way we were all treated was disgusting.

"They kept coming over the public address system with this excuse and that excuse, but we were just stuck there not knowing what was happening. When we eventually got to Kettering they said there would be a luxury coach waiting, but it ended up being a dirty double-decker bus.

"It wasn't over when we got to the station either. I asked staff there how we were expected to get back home and they said we would have to pay for a cab."

The station staff eventually gave in and agreed to pay the taxi fare for anyone still needing to get home. Mrs Adams added: "It ruined what was a lovely weekend and no amount of compensation will make up for what happened."

The time taken for the journey highlights the problems people trying to use the country's railways network now face on a daily basis.

Before the speed restrictions imposed after the Hatfield train crash, the trip from London to Nottingham would normally have taken one hour and 45 minutes.

Midland Mainline spokesman Kevin Johnson said: "Two trains travelling into London and the one heading to Nottingham were stuck when the power failure left signals out of order for hours.

"By the time the fault was fixed the line near Kettering had been closed for essential track replacement work so the quickest way to get them home was by bus.

"We are really sorry that anybody travelling with us is experiencing extended journey times, but clearly this is too much."

All those on board will now be offered compensation for being delayed.

fields.headline: Soul picks up £3m Fanta
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Soul has strengthened its position on Coca-Cola's UK roster of ad agencies by winning its £3m Fanta business, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Soul has strengthened its position on Coca-Cola's UK roster of advertising agencies by winning its £3m Fanta account.

The agency, which only opened its doors for business five months ago, has beaten long-serving Coke agencies Leagas Delaney and Lowe Lintas to the business.

Last year the brand, which is the biggest orange-carbonated soft drink in the UK, spent £3m on UK advertising.

Charlotte Oades, marketing director for Coca-Cola Great Britain and Ireland, said: "Soul is a very promising new agency and one with whom we hope to do great work.

"We believe Soul's team has excellent creative credentials as well as a strong understanding of British consumers."

Soul continues to compete for Coke's multimillion pound European branding business.

fields.headline: The big move
fields.trailText: Alex Strick on the best books for children when it comes to the big move
fields.body:
They say that moving house is one of the most stressful activities you can undertake in your life (along with getting married and using public transport). And yet many of us subject ourselves to it at regular intervals. So it's important to spare a thought for any younger members of the family, for whom this may be a wholly new (and equally traumatic) experience. Here are just a few of the many children's books which choose moving house as their theme, or simply their backdrop.

The Barn (Gary Crew, illustrated by Tom Jellett, Franklin Watts, £3.99, 9-13 yrs) Carter Lawrance is not happy. His parents have bought a farm and the boy reluctantly leaves the cool city. Things get interesting when he finds a swamp with incredible insects. Close to the swamp there is a mysterious barn and Carter finds some prehistoric worms, but the most terrifying creatures are still to come! This short novel is part of the After Dark Series. It is craftily written, with suspense and a pinch of humour. Published in Australia in 1995, this is the first (1999) UK edition.

Mrs Bilberry's New House (Emma Chichester Clark, Mammoth, £4.99, age 3-6 yrs) This tale holds a slightly different message. Mrs Bilberry is exceptionally happy, living in a little yellow house with all her pets, although she can't help being inquisitive about what it would be like to live on the other side of the mountain. So she sets off round the mountain - only to find a rather familiar little yellow house.

Foxdown Wood (Beth Webb, Lion Publishing, £3.99, 9-13 yrs) A girl is deeply resentful of her mother for separating from her father and taking her to live in a run-down cottage. Then she becomes embroiled in a battle to save the local wood from property-developers in this time-travelling adventure story.

Don't Open Your Eyes (Ann Hallam, Dolphin, £4.99, 12+ yrs) introduces Diesel and her parents, for whom 57, Linden Grove appears to be a dream house. Until, that is, the dream turns to a nightmare, as strange night-time noises from the neighbours draw Diesel into a dark mystery.

A New Home for Tiger (Joan Stimson, illus. Meg Rutherford, Scholastic, £ 4.99, age 3-6 yrs) Tiger and his mother move house but Tiger is not sure he likes his unfamiliar new surroundings. He decides to head back to his old home, and in doing so recognises the true meaning of home. A colourful picture book.

Moving (by Michael Rosen, illustrated by Sophy Williams, Puffin, £4.99, 6+ yrs) This is an unusual and striking book. The family is moving house and cat is moving with them. This is the story of the move from the cat's point of view. It conveys a sense of the secret life of cats and has exceptional illustrations.

Penny and Pup (Linda Jennings, Illustrated by Jane Chapman, Magi, £4.99, 3-7 yrs) When Penny the dog moves house she feels lonely, so her family give her a toy pup to keep her company. Pup goes everywhere with Penny, so Penny doesn't feel the need to make any new friends. But one day Penny loses Pup. A touching story about friendship, with bold, vibrant illustrations.

 For more independent advice books for all ages and on all themes, order Book Trust's 100 Best Books (£3) by calling 020-8516 2993, or visit the Book Trust website at: www.booktrust.org.uk

fields.headline: Ros Coward
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The trashing of Dominique Voynet, France's environment minister, by Prescott and sections of the British press was astonishing.
fields.body:
The trashing of Dominique Voynet, France's environment minister, by Prescott and sections of the British press was astonishing. She was said to head a team of "French wreckers" who "sandbagged" Prescott. Or she was "too tired" to hammer out details of a compromise at the Hague implying she'd behaved "irrationally" before. What would you expect; French, a woman and an environmentalist - she might just as well have a couple of horns and a forked tail.

There were more obvious candidates for this diabolic role. The American negotiator Frank Loy went on Radio 4 to assert he would do nothing to "jeopardise the American lifestyle" and that the third world's best interests were served by America's growing - albeit polluting - economy.

But choosing Voynet as chief bogey-woman says much about the sorry state of British political culture. Days ago, Blair ranted about the British media's anti-Europeanism. Now he supports a deputy spouting sexist, chauvinistic and inaccurate nonsense.

In fact 15 European nations, of which Voynet was the chair, viewed the final compromise with the Americans as entirely dubious. This united refusal may prove a turning point in European political culture. In spite of Eurosceptic fantasies, Europe rarely acts as a political superstate. Individual countries are often divided by sectional interests. This time, even doubters like Denmark acted in concert for long-term wellbe ing. None was prepared to be bullied into accepting the indefensible.

Europe is growing more confident in resisting American imperialism and the idea that the interests of multinationals are the same as the interests of the world. This new political landscape won't melt away. There's a widespread perception that people are not in control of their own lives.

In the UK, though, this discontent has for the most part been harnessed to anti-European feelings which, after 20 years of press propaganda, are fertile ground. Fuel protesters are typical: European companies have unfair advantages; Europe interferes unnecessarily in their activities. But scratch the surface and there's something else. At a recent New Statesman meeting it was clear that the farmers at least had common ground with environmentalists. They were naive to imagine cheap fuel was the answer, but what they were actually concerned about was the loss of viable rural economy, the loss of local distinctiveness and the destruction of the countryside.

This is not to fall into a glib pro- Europeanism. On many occasions, the EU promotes multinationals' interests or acts like a small-scale global economy overriding local concerns. But on domestic emissions and the need for national and international action, European countries are way ahead. They have already done much, and know there's much more needed. Their new-found unity at the Hague in rejecting American imperialism could be the beginning of a new Europe.

webTitle: Canada's Chretien wins again despite `bitter' east-west divide

fields.headline: Canada's Chretien wins again despite `bitter' east-west divide
fields.trailText: The results of Monday's Canadian general election have proved a personal triumph for the prime minister, Jean Chretien, whose Liberal Party has been re-elected with an enhanced majority.
fields.body:
The results of Monday's Canadian general election have proved a personal triumph for the prime minister, Jean Chretien, whose Liberal Party has been re-elected with an enhanced majority.

The win is Mr Chretien's third victory in a row and comes in the wake of criticism over his decision to call an election less than three years into his five-year term. When US President Bill Clinton leaves office in January, Chretien will become the longest-serving leader of any of major industrial power.

However, the results also highlighted the nation's bitter east-west divide. The Liberals were trounced by the conservative Canadian Alliance in the three western provinces, but the Alliance failed to impress the more populous east.

Opposition parties had hoped to deprive the Liberals of an outright majority in the 301-seat House of Commons. Instead, the Liberals gained seats, improving from 161 to 173. The Canadian Alliance improved from 58 seats to 66, but its dreams of a breakthrough in pivotal Ontario fizzled - it won just two of the 103 seats in the most populous province, against 100 for the Liberals.

The Liberals also picked up eight seats in the mostly French-speaking province to evenly split Quebec's seats 37-37 with the separatist Bloc Quebecois.

The Bloc, which hopes eventually to win a referendum on seceding from Canada, received 40.5% of the Quebec votes, compared to 43.6% for the Liberals.

"This shows that Quebeckers want to turn the page, that we want to go forward as a country together," said John Rae, one of Chretien's campaign managers.

webTitle: Song completes £2.5m move to West Ham

fields.headline: Song completes £2.5m move to West Ham
fields.trailText: Rigobert Song has insisted he does not want to be compared to Rio Ferdinand after completing his £2.5m move from Liverpool to West Ham today.
fields.body:
Rigobert Song has insisted he does not want to be compared to Rio Ferdinand after completing his £2.5m move from Liverpool to West Ham today.

The Cameroon international is likely to fill Ferdinand's role in central defence, but insists he is a different type of player. "You can't compare us," he claimed. "I am different from Rio but I will offer the same hard work and desire to improve. I will be bringing my own experience and character to the club."

Song, 24, also denied that his move to Upton Park was a backward step, claiming: "The squad is as good. You could say West Ham are more ambitious because they want to improve. Liverpool are a big club - but so are West Ham."

And Song, who signed for Liverpool two seasons ago from Italian club Salernitana, said he had no hard feelings at his lack of recent action at Anfield.

"You have to respect the wishes of the manager and his team selection," he said. "He brought players in, but I still played four times for Liverpool this season, and I certainly don't think it didn't work out there."

fields.headline: French dockers end Calais strike
fields.trailText: Cross-channel ferry travel was beginning to return to normal today after striking French dockers ended a strike that had closed the port of Calais.
fields.body:
Cross-channel ferry travel was beginning to return to normal today after striking French dockers ended a strike that had closed the port of Calais.

Following talks with their employers, the Calais Chamber of Commerce, the dockers agreed to go back to work and hold more discussions on their pay dispute later.

P&O Stena - the main Dover-Calais operator - immediately sent an empty "trial" ferry to see if the strike was really over. That vessel, if able to dock, was to bring back around 120 of the 300 lorries queuing at Calais. The company was due to resume normal passenger crossings around lunchtime today.

Lorry queues had piled up both in Kent and in Calais after the action started suddenly at around 5.30 on Monday evening. Two Calais-bound ferries carrying a total of around 1,000 passengers had had to turn around and return to Dover after being unable to dock.

Police had put Operation Stack - in which the M20 in Kent is turned into a lorry park - into operation overnight. There were big queues for a time, but with Eurotunnel's freight and passenger train shuttles operating normally between Folkestone and Calais, the queues had already started to die down by the time the strike was called off.

London to Paris and Brussels high-speed Eurostar trains were also running as usual, while Dover-Calais freight sailings were being diverted to Zeebrugge in Belgium.

Ferry companies and UK haulage organisations had condemned the strike claiming that passengers and British industry were suffering from a French-only dispute.

P&O Stena Line spokesman Chris Laming said: "It is extremely inconvenient for British tourists and freight operators. Once again we are suffering at the hands of wildcat French strikers."

Travel across the Channel was brought to a standstill for days earlier in the year when French fishermen and farmers blockaded Calais and the Eurotunnel terminal in protest at fuel prices.

webTitle: Boca quick out of the blocks to beat Real

fields.headline: Boca quick out of the blocks to beat Real
fields.trailText: Boca Juniors became the first South American club to win the World Club Cup for six years today, beating European champions Real Madrid 2-1 in Tokyo's National Stadium.
fields.body:
Boca Juniors became the first South American club to win the World Club Cup for six years today, beating European champions Real Madrid 2-1 in Tokyo's National Stadium.

Argentina's Boca raced into a 2-0 lead after only six minutes with Martin Palermo scoring both goals. Marcelo Delgado set up the first, beating the offside trap before crossing from the left for Palermo, who evaded two defenders to score from close range with a sweeping half-volley.

Palermo's second was a gem. Collecting a long ball out of defence, he trapped it on the run, using his pace and strength to see off an ineffective challenge from Geremi before firing low and wide of Real goalkeeper Iker Casillas.

Roberto Carlos lashed home a trademark left-foot drive after 12 minutes to put Real back in contention and set up a fiercely competitive game played on a freezing, windswept night in front of more than 50,000 fans. Nearly 3,000 had made the trip from South America.

Real had the ball in the net twice in the second half, but both efforts were disallowed for offside. Raul, Guti and Figo, twice, also had chances, but Boca held out to become World Club champions for the first time since 1977.

They are the first South American side to win the cup since Velez Sarsfield of Argentina beat AC Milan 2-0 in 1994. Velez were coached by Carlos Bianchi, now the coach of Boca. South American clubs now lead the series 21-18.

Real Madrid (1) 1 - 2 (2) Boca Juniors

Real Madrid: Casillas, Karanka, Hierro, Carlos, McManaman (Savio 67), Makelele (Morientes 76), Helguera, Geremi, Figo, Guti, Raul.

Boca Juniors: Cordoba, Bermudez, Traverso, Ibarra, Matellan, Basualdo, Serna, Battaglia (Burdisso 90), Riquelme, Delgado (Schelotto 88), Palermo.

Referee: Julian Oscar Ruiz Acosta (Colombia).

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours indulge in all-in wrestling with the French environment minister
fields.trailText: Claudio Ranieri is hoping to ease his current problems in the way Chelsea know best, by splashing £6m on Anderlecht's Walter Baseggio. Baseggio has been voted Belgian player of the year for the past two seasons and, according to the Mirror, has also attracted the attentions of Lazio.
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri is hoping to ease his current problems in the way Chelsea know best, by splashing £6m on Anderlecht's Walter Baseggio. Baseggio has been voted Belgian player of the year for the past two seasons and, according to the Mirror, has also attracted the attentions of Lazio.

Fulham are still in the hunt for another Anderlecht star, Jan Koller, but the Belgians have told Jean Tigana he will have to pay £10m to sign him. The Czech giant has scored 10 goals in 12 games this season and, according to the Sun, the Belgian champions are reluctant to let him go.

Everton are ready to sell midfielder Alex Nyarko to Marseille, only four months after signing him. The 27-year-old has failed to impress at Goodison, according to the Daily Express, and Walter Smith will let Nyarko go, as long as he recoups the £4.5m he handed to Lens in the summer.

The Daily Express believes Aston Villa have added Lee Hughes to their strikers wish-list after continuing difficulties in tempting Celta Vigo into selling Benni McCarthy. John Gregory is prepared to offer West Brom £8m for their star player, but manager Gary Megson is refusing to sell.

Leeds will match any bid by Middlesbrough for Derby all-rounder Rory Delap. Delap is valued at £4m, but the Daily Mail believes David O'Leary will only move for Delap if he fails to sign Kieron Dyer for £15m.

Roma are trying to sign Italian international goalkeeper Francesco Toldo from Fiorentina, according to Planet Football, and are prepared to offer £14m plus defender Aldair and goalkeeper Francesco Antonioli in order to get their man.

West Ham will look to splash some of their Rio cash on Portuguese defender Daniel Kenedy. Harry Redknapp has been watching the 26-year-old fullback for 18 months, according to the Daily Express, but the Hammers were joined by four other Premiership clubs in watching Kenedy during Estrela Amedora's 1-1 draw with Leida last weekend.

Teamtalk hint at the possibility of Didier Domi following Alain Goma out of Newcastle United. The French full-back, highly-rated in his own country, has been in disappointing form this season, and could look for a move home if Goma gets his wish to leave granted.

Jim Jefferies wants to bring Colin Hendry to Bradford on loan. First choice defender David Weatherall is out for ten weeks, and Jefferies sees the former Scotland captain as ideal cover.

The Mirror reports that Spurs are watching Espanol's 24-year-old midfielder Sergio Gonzalez.

Dean Holdsworth could join Gillingham from Bolton this week for £500,000 according to the Mirror.

fields.headline: Capital stands by Tarrant
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Capital Radio says it will stick by star DJ Chris Tarrant although bankers identified him as symbolic of their core problems. Claire Cozens reports.
fields.body:
Capital Radio has insisted it will stick by DJ Chris Tarrant despite bankers identifying him as a symbol of the broadcaster's problems.

UBS Warburg yesterday slashed profit forecasts for the station and changed its recommendation on the stock from a "buy" to a "reduce".

Analysts said Capital's audience figures were being squeezed by London rivals. It also said that the flagship station, Capital 95.8FM, will have to make some major changes if it is to attract the 20-something audience it covets.

Capital 95.8FM has seen its lead over its rivals eroded in recent years in an increasingly competitive market.

According to figures published earlier this month by radio ratings body Rajar, Capital has been overtaken in the key 16 to 24-year-old sector for the first time.

Rival Kiss FM attracted 694,000 listeners in the youth market, narrowly ahead of Capital's 671,000 listeners.

But Capital Radio today insisted that Mr Tarrant's long-running breakfast show is here to stay.

A spokeswoman said: "It would be suicide to say we were getting rid of someone like Chris Tarrant. We want to keep our loyal listeners happy as well as younger listeners."

The broadcaster's new strategy is to keep favourite DJs such as Mr Tarrant and Steve Penk on air during the day.

Capital introduced new DJs including Craig David and Artful Dodger to its evening schedules to attract a trendier crowd after audience research showed its older listeners tended to switch off after 7pm.

webTitle: Publicis to merge advertising and marketing wings

fields.headline: Publicis to merge advertising and marketing operations
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Publicis is to merge its marketing and advertising operations, signalling a move away from high-profile TV campaigns. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Publicis, the French company that bought Saatchi & Saatchi earlier this year, is to merge its marketing and advertising operations, signalling a shift in emphasis away from high-profile TV campaigns.

The move will see Publicis's sponsorship and direct marketing operations come under the same roof as its advertising agencies, enabling the company to offer clients a single promotional team.

Until now, clients have had to deal separately with the company's subsidiaries.

Publicis's UK marketing operations include direct marketing agency Publicis Dialog, contract publisher Publicis Blueprint and digital marketing division Publicis Networks.

In an interview with the French newspaper Figaro, chairman Maurice Levy said the reorganisation would enable Publicis to offer clients a new contract giving them a single team at Publicis.

fields.headline: Channel 5's Rapidinsure needs £4m to survive
fields.standfirst: Nov 23: Channel 5 airtime-for-equity deal with charity site
fields.trailText: 12pm: Channel 5's first dot.com stake, Rapidinsure, has hit financial difficulties and needs £4m to survive. Amy Vickers reports. Nov 23: Channel 5 airtime-for-equity deal with charity site
fields.body:
Channel 5's first dot.com stake, Rapidinsure, has hit financial difficulties and needs £4m to survive.

Insurance intermediary Rapidinsure, which has now closed its website to non-members, said it was in talks with a buyer.

But the development has renewed industry doubts about the wisdom of Channel 5's investment, which gave Rapidinsure free advertising in return for an equity stake.

It has also prompted speculation about the broadcaster's three other airtime-for-equity deals with Cheekymonkey, TheFirstResort and Free2give, and BSkyB's dot.com investments in Toyzone.co.uk, LetsBuyIt.com and Mykindaplace.com.

However, given current market conditions and the sudden emergence of major players in the online insurance market, Rapidinsure's future remains uncertain.

Consolidation with an older online player like Screentrade or a buyout from a traditional insurance firm such AXA, Direct Line or Norwich Union now appears likely.

Rapidinsure attracted huge attention when it launched in March because Darryl Mattocks, founder of Internet Bookshop and Travelstore.com, was part of the management team.

First round funding of £1m got the business off the ground and Channel 5's 8% stake gave the site exposure on a terrestrial TV channel.

As part of the deal, Rapidinsure got the equivalent of £1m-worth of Channel 5 airtim,e which included a year-long sponsorship of its weather forecast.

Like other start-up internet companies, Rapidinsure has suffered from market conditions - it failed to raise second round funding in the summer and has ditched plans for a flotation next year.

webTitle: BBC moves into big screen big time

fields.headline: BBC moves into big screen big time
fields.trailText: A new deal between the BBC and MM Media Capital Partners will alllow the corporation to develop big budget projects for the cinema
fields.body:
The BBC is to take on Hollywood at its own game, under plans by new director general, Greg Dyke, to revolutionise British film-making. According to reports in the British Sunday papers and online, Dyke plans to lead the corporation into big-budget production, in a break with the BBC's tradition of smaller-scale period dramas.

Los Angeles and London-based finance house MM Media Capital Partners has confirmed that it is in negotiations with the corporation to provide over £220m worth of backing over the next three years. MM's contribution, which will boost the BBC's existing £10m annual film budget, will be added to the financial input of Intermedia, one of the company's behind the Gwyneth Paltrow hit Sliding Doors.

Dyke's plan for a full-scale Hollywood-style film studio at the BBC may be kickstarted by the long-promised big-screen version of the much-loved science fiction series Doctor Who (pictured) and the Sunday Times reports that a major movie adaptation and sequels are already in the pipeline.

Other mooted features include an £18m adaptation of Dodie '101 Dalmatians' Smith's novel I Captured the Castle; Anthony Minghella's period romance, The Assumption of the Virgin; and a drama about the life of Mary, Queen of Scots, written by Jimmy McGovern.

The corporation is also believed to be targeting such well known names as Mike Newell, Stephen Frears, Roger Michell, who helmed Notting Hill, and John Madden, who directed Mrs Brown for the channel before hitting the big time with Shakespeare in Love.

The BBC has traditionally achieved its biggest success on cinema screens with smaller-scale projects and the new deal will still leave room for low-budget works such as the recent sleeper hits East is East and Billy Elliott.

According to BBC creative director Alan Yentob, 'Small-budget films will still deliver surprise hits, and we will continue to make them, but there is a lot of talent which wants to work on a broader canvas'.

fields.headline: Testimoni - floods
fields.standfirst: Rosalia Losero describes the effect of recent floods on her alpine village
fields.trailText: Rosalia Losero describes the effect of recent floods on her alpine village
fields.body:
È cominciato tutto di venerdì. Ero in macchina quando si è scatenata la pioggia. Facevo fatica a guidare, ma non mi sono preoccupata. Pensavo fosse solo un temporale. Invece l'acqua è scesa a catinelle per quattro giorni! Abito in una valle di montagna vicino a Torino. È una valle lunga e stretta. La percorre la Stura, un torrente che viene dai ghiacciai e si ingrossa con l'acqua dei torrentelli che scendono dalle montagne. Il rumore della Stura è la nostra colonna sonora, ma venerdì notte mi pareva un boato minaccioso. Lo sentivo insieme alla pioggia e non sono riuscita a chiudere occhio.

Ed ecco che sabato mattina abbiamo cominciato a sentire il rumore delle frane: terra e roccia che si staccavano dalla montagna e rotolavano a valle. Dalla finestra vedevamo la strada che era diventata un torrente fatto di acqua, fango, pietre, rami, tronchi. Era un macello. "Ce la caveremo?" ci chiedevamo. Già alle sei di mattina l'aria era calda, soffocante e innaturale per un paese di montagna. Abbiamo barricato la porta di casa, per cercare di fermare il fango. Per fortuna il telefono funzionava, ma le notizie che arrivavano erano spaventose: più a valle erano crollati i ponti, in un paese il torrente si era addirittura portato via una fetta di cimitero, in un altro sette case erano state distrutte . . .

Siamo arrivati al lunedì mattina. Finalmente sulle cime è comparsa la neve. "Se nevica in alto, il livello dei torrenti scenderà" ci siamo detti. Ed è stato così.

Ora la grande paura è passata. Ci siamo rimboccate le maniche, ma il futuro ci preoccupa. È stata una vera batosta.

Glossario/Glossary

a catinelle buckets (of rain)

la batosta blow

cavarsela to get away with

chiudere occhio (coll) to have 40 winks

la macchina (coll) a car

un macello (coll) a mess

più a valle further down the valley

rimboccarsi le manicheto roll one's sleeves up

il torrentello mountain streams

 Rosalia Losero was talking to Mariacarla Pavoni

Già alle sei di mattina l'aria era calda, soffocante e innaturale per un paese di montagna. Abbiamo barricato la porta di casa, per cercare di fermare il fango. Per fortuna il telefono funzionava, ma le notizie che arrivavano erano spaventose: più a valle erano crollati i ponti, in un paese il torrente si era addirittura portato via una fetta di cimitero, in un altro sette case erano state distrutte . . . Siamo arrivati al lunedì mattina. Finalmente sulle cime è comparsa la neve. "Se nevica in alto, il livello dei torrenti scenderà" ci siamo detti. Ed è stato così. Ora la grande paura è passata. Ci siamo rimboccate le maniche, ma il futuro ci preoccupa. È stata una vera batosta. fields.headline: Beijing rushes to 'greenify' environment
fields.standfirst: The chronic water shortage in China has finally caught the attention of its rulers, writes John Gittings
fields.trailText: The chronic water shortage in China has finally caught the attention of its rulers, writes John Gittings in Beijing.
fields.body:
Two slim patches of grass on Tiananmen Square come as a surprise to many visitors. They were only planted last year, as a belated attempt to make the vast expanse of concrete a little more friendly. And they are actually green - unlike most grass elsewhere in Beijing where regular watering is discouraged because of a chronic shortage.

Beijing's water crisis is going from bad to worse. Last year, the water table was lowered by more than two metres and the underwater reserve shrank by 1.5bn cubic metres. Rainfall in the first half of this year was 39% less than average.

If Beijing needs any extra stimulus to take water seriously, it is the need to back up its bid to host the 2008 Olympics by looking green. Water conservation is an important part of the city's "Green Olympics" campaign, which also focuses on reducing atmospheric pollution, tackling factory waste and "greenifying" the environment.

The irony is that planting more trees and restoring grass - much of it ripped out in the Maoist decades - means a higher demand for water. Most greenery is kept alive by flood irrigation, with water channelled into miniature moats and ditches. The city is now shifting more than a million square meters green space to less wasteful spray irrigation.

No one hides the seriousness of the problem now. When Beijing was first built by the Ming emperors, says the latest edition of Beijing Review, it had enormous water resources, with lakes and springs which made it a city of gardens. Today, it has become "one of the driest cities in northern China due to drought".

The Miyun reservoir, built in the late 1950s with Chairman Mao himself wielding a symbolic spade, may dry up within two or three years if last year's drought reoccurs. Another important reservoir, the Guangting, can no longer supply the city because of heavy pollution in its upper reaches.

The immediate causes of the crisis are familiar ones. Beijing's population officially stands at 12m, but is swollen by at least 2m migrant workers. Improved living standards for the majority have increased the number of washing machines, flush toilets and other water-greedy appliances. There is massive wastage from poorly maintained mains while few people have enough social consciousness to turn off dripping taps in homes and on street standpipes. Water is virtually free: car washers and public baths have no incentive to limit their use.

Beijing's city government has started a water-saving campaign, backed by new restrictions. It is phasing in a "quota system" - a euphemism for scheduled cuts - which the privileged capital dwellers have largely avoided so far. Prices for tap water supply and sewage disposal have already risen though so far only marginally: the government is only too aware that a rapid price hike could provoke unrest. New reservoirs and more effective sewage plants are now being planned.

The water crisis is even worse outside Beijing. The state planning development commission has called for price reform throughout China where more than 400 out of 668 cities suffer chronic shortages. Peasant communities in some areas have waged war on their neighbours in disputes over water sharing.

The underlying causes are agricultural overuse, deforestation, and excessive reclamation of flood plains. This results in the paradoxical combination of worse floods and worse droughts as the land's water retention capacity diminishes. China's deserts are growing by 2,460sq km annually.

A plan to alleviate northern China's water poverty by diverting water from the Yangtze northwards - by one or more of three proposed routes - is likely to receive final approval soon. But this is no longer regarded as a save-all solution. "In the end," said the China Daily last week, "it is a redistribution of the same amount of water. The north will get more, but the south less."

A new survey published in Outlook, a magazine close to the administration of premier Zhu Rongji, warns that shortages of water, petroleum and grain are the biggest bottlenecks to future economic development. China is one of the world's 13 poorest nations in per capita water reserves.

Yet it is good news for hundreds of millions of Chinese accustomed to water rationing - in some cases only a few hours every other day - that the crisis has hit the capital so severely. China's leaders are becoming aware that the most serious threat to their rule may not be a desire for working democracy but a growing thirst for drinkable water.

webTitle: Nick Hornby and Emma Thompson collaborate on new film script

fields.headline: Nick Hornby and Emma Thompson collaborate on new film script
fields.trailText: As an adaptation of Nick Hornby's novel About a Boy goes into production, the British novelist teams up with Emma Thompson to write an original film script
fields.body:
Two more projects by British novelist turned Hollywood hot property Nick Hornby are being prepared for cinema screens. Hornby's best-selling novel About a Boy is to be directed by the team behind American Pie, Chris and Paul Weitz. Meanwhile, the Arsenal-supporting author is preparing an original film script in collaboration with actress pal Emma Thompson.

According to reports in the Hollywood trade paper Variety, New Line, which paid $2.75m (£1.93m) for screen rights to the novel on its publication three years ago, are responsible for the unlikely pairing of the gross-out directors with the touchy-feely material.

Hugh Grant is said to be in the frame to play the movie's hero: a wealthy 30-something with a fear of commitment who seeks out the company of single mums because he thinks that they are easier to leave. It is only after he develops a friendship with a partner's 12-year-old son that he experiences a change of heart. The film will shoot in Britain next March.

In an interview with People News, Hornby describes the script that he is developing with Thompson, who won an Oscar for her adaptation of Jane Austen's Sense and Sensibility, about a woman who discovers a video of her life and tries to change her future.

"It's a romantic comedy called Fast Forward', says the novelist. 'I did a treatment that was sent to Emma in an actress capacity. She liked it, and wanted to talk about it - so much so that I suggested we wrote the script together. It's an amazing experience, because she is just so smart."

fields.headline: TiVo rival slashes staff in strategic shift
fields.trailText: 11.30am: ReplayTV, the US rival to TiVo, has axed nearly half its staff and is abandoning the consumer electronics market, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Personal video recorder manufacturer ReplayTV, the US rival to TiVo, has axed nearly half its staff and is abandoning the consumer electronics market.

The company said late on Monday that it was cutting back on the manufacture and direct marketing of its personal video recorder boxes and interactive TV service to consumers.

Replay TV will focus instead on licensing the technology to set-top box manufacturers and other third parties, such as cable and satellite TV operators.

The dramatic shift in emphasis is a fillip for broadcasters who feared that the new generation of video recorders would sound their death-knell.

Just three months ago, BBC director general Greg Dyke warned that personal video recorders could torpedo ITV's revenues because the new video machines allow viewers skip all advertising breaks

ReplayTV is thought to have held talks with ONdigital and cable operators about bringing its boxes to the UK.

TiVo, which unlike ReplayTV charges a monthly subscription, launched in the UK this autumn in a joint venture with BSkyB.

It is the dominant force in the market in the US, with higher sales than ReplayTV, though take-up has not been as great as either company had hoped.

ReplayTV chief executive Kim LeMasters, former president of CBS, was among the casualties of the company's change of direction.

Replay Studios, the firm's LA-based content division, is also to be axed, just a week after it was set up.

The company abandoned a planned flotation in the summer following the collapse of technology stocks.

ReplayTV could not raise the investment needed to sustain a consumer marketing strategy, which is thought to be a significant factor in the decision to abandon that business model.

fields.headline: Ghetto blaster
fields.standfirst: Burgers, bars and high rents ... Lee Elliot Major  on the real impact of 'studentsville'
fields.trailText: Burgers, bars and high rents ... Lee Elliot Major on the real impact of 'studentsville'
fields.body:
Government and university authorities have ignored the impact of the huge growth in student rented housing, which has driven out low-income tenants and first-time home buyers from entire areas of cities.

Researchers have uncovered a new modern urban phenomenon: "student land". It can be observed in most city centres, from North Islington in London to Cardiff, Norwich and even among a few streets in St Andrews: clusters of privately rented houses almost exclusively let out to students.

Student land is characterised by tell-tale signs: lots of burger bars, take-aways, bars and clubs (providing part-time jobs as well as catering for student needs); a proliferation of letting agents; and a (usually dilapidated) university building close by.

University halls and residences have not been able to keep up with the explosion of student numbers during the last 20 years, and the student population (now 1.6m) has increasingly spilled over into local housingmarkets. Researchers, from York university's centre for housing policy, estimate that half of all students live in privately rented accommodation.

The problem with students land, according to the academics, is that it thrives on its own exclusive economy, with landlords unwilling to let to other groups. Landlords see students as reliable tenants, and can generate more lucrative returns from letting a shared house to several students at a time. A niche letting market has emerged as letting agents target student areas, in many instances consulting universities over students' requirements.

Residents on housing benefit, and first-time buyers increasingly find themselves priced out of the market, and forced to live elsewhere.

The researchers found, however, that the knock-on effects of the student housing market on local communities had been largely ignored by academic institutions. "We came to the conclusion that universities rely on private rented market and assume it can take the strain, but do so in a rather unthinking way," said David Rhodes. "There is also a complete absence of any government policy on student housing."

The authors of the study, which included a national survey of accommodation officers and nine local case studies, urge universities to liaise with local authorities on housing strategies in future. In some cases, universities had to deal withlocal residents who were unhappy about the impact of student "ghettoisation" on local amenities, which are geared increasingly to the student market. Some locals had formed residents' groups to represent their concerns to the university and the local authority.

The academics also uncovered evidence that landlords were oversupplying student markets, leaving many properties empty. The houses remained unfilled, either because of landlords' letting preferences or because other groups simply do not seek accommodation in the student areas.

In some areas, landlords were offering not only safe and well-maintained accommodation, but microwave cookers and satellite TV to attract students. In other districts, students were willing to live in poorer quality accommodation to save money or to be located in what was considered to be the right area.

If all this were not bad enough for those struggling to buy first houses, a new threat is emerging on the housing market. In some areas the "young ones" residents are now being dislodged by the "this life" generation of young house-sharing professionals. The researchers found evidence of this where demand for property is high, as in Islington, London. Here students are losing out to young single professionals jointly able to pay the higher rents asked by landlords.

 The nature and impact of student demand on housing markets by Julie Rugg, David Rhodes and Anwen Jones is published by York Publishing Services Ltd, email: orders@yps.ymn.co.uk.

webTitle: Chief social services inspector appointed in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Chief social services inspector appointed in Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Paul Martin has been appointed as chief inspector of the social services inspectorate in Northern Ireland
fields.body:
Paul Martin has been appointed as chief inspector of the social services inspectorate in Northern Ireland

Mr Martin's post involves advising the minister for health, social services and public safety, Bairbre de Brún, and senior officials on social work matters in both his own, and other, departments.

"I am delighted to take up this position at a time of change and renewal in social work here," said Mr Martin.

"Over the last decade, I have been involved in leading in the production of a number of reports which have significantly impacted on this work. In a number of cases I have found that being involved in this work was profoundly moving.

"This, in particular, applied to Living with the Trauma of the Troubles which looked at the social and psychological needs of those affected by the violence of the last 30 years and the quality of the services provided to them".

Mr Martin, who is 50, was educated at St McNissi's College, University College Dublin and the University of Ulster. From 1974 to 1989 he worked at the northern health and social services board in a number of posts, including principal social worker, with responsibilities including family and child care, older people and people with disabilities.

webTitle: El Tel at the point of no return

fields.headline: El Tel at the point of no return
fields.standfirst:
Boro look to the usual suspects
Harry Pearson: Boro beware cockney messiahs
fields.trailText: Terry Venables was always going to be linked with Middlesbrough, but when reality bites, Venables' love of business looks likely to win over his love of coaching.
fields.body:
It used to be Tommy Docherty. Later it was Ron Atkinson. These were always the first names in the frame whenever a major managerial vacancy arose, put there with a knee-jerk scribble of the bookies' pen and little thought for the reality.

Now it is Terry Venables. Whenever a recent shortlist has been drawn up, from Blackburn Rovers to Fulham to Chelsea to England, El Tel's has been the first name on the bookmakers' team-sheet, and also on those compiled by his media allies. Now Venables is in the frame again, hardly a gilt-edged one but enticing enough, and more than a figment of the bookmakers' imagination.

This is a real offer, a big job and one that Venables could do. And the problem is that he is thinking of turning it down. If he does, it is hard to see him ever again returning to club management. At 57 time is running out - and, it seems, enthusiasm.

Middlesbrough's offer to Venables is basically to take charge of the first team and steer them away from relegation while taking the current manager Bryan Robson under his wing in the hope that he can teach young "Pop" a few tricks of the trade - managerial tricks, of course, not business tricks.

Having worked together during England's relatively suc cessful Euro 96 campaign, the idea seems sound. If Venables cannot see fit to take this on, he should surely be eliminated from all further inquiries. The time has come to put up or shut up.

Despite the saying that you should always stick to what you do best, Venables has always fancied himself as much as a businessman as a coach, whether it be marketing women's wigs, writing novels, inventing television de tectives, owning night-clubs or football clubs.

And, despite a well-publicised brush with the Department of Trade and Industry in 1998, when he was banned from being a company director for seven years, that fascination for non-coaching activities remains as strong as ever and looks likely to thwart Middlesbrough's plan to bring this Messiah into the life of Bryan.

Venables is spending much time and money in Spain trying to set up a hotel complex for use by teams needing warm-weather training, along the lines of the La Manga sports complex. He also hopes to set up an academy in Spain where promising young players from around the world would come to develop their skills.

Although attracted to the idea of becoming Robson's guardian angel, Venables feels he cannot give a full-time commitment to a club over 200 miles away from his London stomping ground, while also getting the Spanish project off the ground.

He has other commitments: football schools in England which he is also trying to establish in the United States; a column in the News of the World, a Saturday lunch-time spot on Virgin Radio and a contract as regular expert on ITV's Champions League coverage.

It is the itinerary of someone who looks to have long ago given up on ever getting the right call from the right club. After none too impressive stints at Portsmouth and Crystal Palace his reputation was no doubt higher in the minds of the bookies and his media allies than it was in the minds of the men who count: club directors. He fancied the England job again but there he was thwarted by his past.

And it is the possible resurrecting of that past that could also prove a viable reason to stay out of the limelight by turning down Middlesbrough's offer.

Eddie Ashby is Venables's former financial adviser and personal assistant who worked for several of his companies even though, as an undischarged bankrupt, he should not have held managerial positions. In 1997 Ashby was jailed for violating bankruptcy laws and, angered by the way he felt Venables subsequently treated him, he has not spoken to his former partner since.

On his release from jail Ashby began talks to publish his side of the story in which he looks set to reveal more about Venables's activities while in charge at Tottenham, England and Portsmouth. The book is due out soon.

But, whatever the reason, Venables's love of business looks finally to have grown deeper than his affection for football management. El Tel appears happy with that. The rest football should accept it too.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk
