It is the itinerary of someone who looks to have long ago given up on ever getting the right call from the right club. After none too impressive stints at Portsmouth and Crystal Palace his reputation was no doubt higher in the minds of the bookies and his media allies than it was in the minds of the men who count: club directors. He fancied the England job again but there he was thwarted by his past. And it is the possible resurrecting of that past that could also prove a viable reason to stay out of the limelight by turning down Middlesbrough's offer. Eddie Ashby is Venables's former financial adviser and personal assistant who worked for several of his companies even though, as an undischarged bankrupt, he should not have held managerial positions. In 1997 Ashby was jailed for violating bankruptcy laws and, angered by the way he felt Venables subsequently treated him, he has not spoken to his former partner since. On his release from jail Ashby began talks to publish his side of the story in which he looks set to reveal more about Venables's activities while in charge at Tottenham, England and Portsmouth. The book is due out soon. But, whatever the reason, Venables's love of business looks finally to have grown deeper than his affection for football management. El Tel appears happy with that. The rest football should accept it too.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: How do you achieve discipline and provide children with support?

fields.headline: Lean on me
fields.standfirst: How do you achieve discipline and provide children with support? Ask their peers, says  Jerome Monahan
fields.trailText: How do you achieve discipline and provide children with support? Ask their peers, says Jerome Monahan
fields.body:
Nine years ago Highfield Junior in Plymouth had troubles. Fights were common in the playground and ill-feeling would follow children indoors - disagreements erupting again as classroom punch-ups. In the corridors, displays were defaced and smashed. Meanwhile, children upset by their classmates' intimidating behaviour were leaving.

Now, the school has been transformed. "It is a place where the pupils respect property, their teachers, and each other," says deputy head Kathryn Palmer.

What makes this improvement particularly remarkable is that the main responsibility for it lies with the children. Highfield Junior offers a vision of how far a commitment to student-centred discipline can carry a school. Under the headship of Lorna Farrington - now a leading educational consultant - Highfield trail-blazed many of the peer-support systems that are now catching on widely across the UK.

"The school was not a safe place," says Farrington. "Despite working flat out we were making little headway. Our thinking was wrong. We spent our time forever intervening and telling children what they should be doing. We were ignoring that they were the greatest asset we had in trying to improve things."

The central mechanism for change at Highfield became class circle time, familiar enough as a structure for general discussion or topic work in primary schools, but now made into a forum where children could bring up the problems they were having with one another and work to find solutions. "The secret was to concentrate on the behaviour and not the person," explained Farrington. "We explicitly educated the children to become responsible and gentle in their dealings with one another."

This meant that when, for example, a child's aggressive behaviour was raised, the circle would discuss, in general, ways of asking to join in with others' play that didn't involve thumping people. If a problem persisted, then the child in question could nominate up to three "guardian angels" - fellow pupils whose help could be sought if difficulties arose.

Another innovation was the creation of "playground peacemakers". Children became trained mediators, offering support to those involved in break-time bust-ups. "They were taught the value of giving those in conflict the chance to think up ways for themselves of solving their arguments," said Farrington.

Meanwhile circle time continued to evolve. One successful development saw the children interviewing prospective teachers - including the new head needed when Lorna Farrington left to promote the Highfield model nationally. "With everyone's agreement we filmed these sessions," said Palmer. "They were very revealing - some talked to the children as though they were aliens. One head decided he couldn't do it."

Farrington. says: "It is about giving children choices in their dealings with one another. We love instructing children to go off and make friends without thinking of the hundreds of skills that that entails. There is no such thing as a bully or bullying. They are meaningless words and do nothing to tackle the problems children face managing their relationships. That is where the effort needs to be concentrated."

"We do not claim to have all the answers," says Palmer. "But the benefits to the school have been enormous, with much of the petty conflict that used to clog up the day being resolved without teachers having to intervene.

But schools attempting to solve disruptive and antisocial behaviour by establishing peer-support schemes must often overcome opposition from both teachers and students before the full benefits can be felt. Writing in a forthcoming edition of The New Therapist magazine, Professor Helen Cowie of the School of Psychology and Medicine at the University of Surrey, Roehampton, identifies a variety of constraints.

"Teachers are sometimes hostile about handing over responsibility for aspects of discipline," explains Cowie. "Then some schemes must cope with pupils sabotaging them by inventing problems and making hoax demands. Also, those participating can encounter a range of negative responses." Cowie identifies how macho attitudes can act as a barrier to boys getting involved.

"Without everyone's backing such schemes cannot succeed," says Sally-Anne Wilsher, the head of sixth form at Wanstead High - one of five London secondary schools funded by The Mental Health Foundation to set up peer-support mechanisms. "What's needed is a culture of care in which they can grow," she adds. This is a view shared by Cowie who recognises that "some school environments can be so aggressive that the work of peer supporters is ineffective."

Getting parents on-side is particularly important: "Some are understandably intolerant of such things as bullying - they want six dead bodies hanging from the yard-arm," says Steve Baker, head of Lipson Community College in Plymouth. "But once they see how effective good peer support can be, such hot-blooded attitudes do cool."

Children leaving Highfield are lucky having Lipson to go to, as it is a secondary environment in which the same student involvement ethos applies. A common misgiving of primary teachers committed to peer support is the possibility their pupils will be disillusioned when they move on.

At Lipson, circle time continues in every year group and older pupils offer the younger ones a wide range of peer mentoring and befriending. "It is the little 'uns coming from a whole variety of primary schools that are the biggest problem," says sixth-former Adam Hodges. "They often arrive with no idea of conflict resolution."

The other great benefit of peer support at Highfield has been the boost it gives children's confidence and communication skills. Ten-year-old Helen Naylor is a veteran of the system: "Before, I didn't want to go to school - if you had problems you had to be violent or keep them to yourself. Now it's different - things get sorted out." Her proudest moment was successfully resolving an argument between two girls. "They were being horrible. I asked if they wanted me to do mediation. They did and afterwards became best friends. It was really good - it's like one of the best lessons at school."

At Annandale Primary in Greenwich, Charlotte Evans, 10, is clear about the benefits of being a mediator: "It takes time but you do get listened to and it really does calm people down. I used to be so nervous but helping others has made me feel so much more self-confident."

"But establishing effective peer support means risks must be taken," says Lindsay Ancock, head of learning support at St Marylebone Girls - another of the schools receiving Mental Health Foundation funding. "It is contrary to the mechanistic, statistics-driven way in which education has been going. It has nothing to do with league tables and everything to do with individuals having the space and time in which to resolve their difficulties with one another."

 Helen Cowie and Patti Wallace's Peer Support In Action is published by Sage Publications at £15.99, contact: 020 7330 1234 Lorna Farrington's book Changing Our School is available from Loxley Enterprises: 01752 513858

fields.headline: Le pari de l'Art
fields.standfirst: Part of Palais-Royal metro station has been redesigned - with glass baubles. As  Zo Eisenstein finds out, you either love it or hate it
fields.trailText: Part of Palais-Royal metro station has been redesigned - with glass baubles. As  Zo Eisenstein finds out, you either love it or hate it
fields.body:
À quelques pas du musée du Louvre à Paris, une création artistique qui ne passe pas inaperçue a été inaugurée le 30 octobre. Sur la place Colette, dans un cadre architectural autrement très classique, l'entrée du métro Palais-Royal a été re-lookée par l'artiste Jean-Michel Othoniel. Son Kiosque des Noctambules est fait de métal et de grosses perles de verre coloré : sur six poteaux, deux coupoles, l'une couleur de soleil et l'autre de lune. Prendre le métro ici n'est plus la même expérience. Une nouveauté, certes, mais qu'en pensent les Parisiens ? J'ai demandé l'avis de quatre étudiants en histoire de l'art que j'ai rencontrés devant la bouche de métro.

Qu'en penses-tu ?

Céline: Je trouve ça original. Finalement, c'est dans la continuité de ce qu'a fait Guimard mais un siècle après. C'est plutôt marrant.

Christophe: C'est de l'art dégénéré, une nullité absolue. C'est plutôt insultant, une insulte à l'architecture classique. J'espère qu'il y aura bientôt beaucoup de tags et que les chiens pisseront dessus.

Stéphanie: Déjà, je pense que c'est bien, un renouvellement de l'art dans la ville. Le verre est très beau. Je ne sais pas ce que ça donne dans la nuit mais illuminé, ça doit tre très impressionnant. Je trouve que ça va très bien dans ce quartier mais je ne l'imaginerais pas à Barbès, par exemple.

Ruth: C'est très beau, toute cette couleur. J'aime bien, mais comme j'étudie l'histoire de l'art, j'ai l'habitude de voir des choses comme ça tout le temps. Ça ne me choque pas.

Imposer l'art aux gens et à la ville, est-ce une bonne chose?

Céline: Oui. Mais je ne sais pas si c'est vraiment imposer, c'est plutôt proposer.

Christophe: C'est pas de l'art, c'est une décoration. Il n'y a rien de nouveau. C'est un choix politique nul, de l'art officiel. C'est le ministère qui a imposé ça, c'est de l'art technocratique. Ça n'a aucun intérêt. Paris, c'est déjà de l'art en soi.

Stéphanie: La ville doit encourager l'art contemporain et pas seulement préserver l'art du passé, l'art nouveau, les bouches de métro anciennes. L'art est partout, m me si c'est pas toujours construit ni adapté, ni catalogué comme de l'art. On peut trouver de l'art dans les égouts, dans les catacombes, au Louvre.

Ruth: Je suis belge et j'étudie ici à Paris. En Belgique, il y avait une expo très importante et c'était aussi mettre de l'art partout dans la ville. Tu ne pouvais vraiment pas l'éviter. Chaque fois que tu te promenais, tu voyais un objet d'art et je trouve ça très bien que l'art se rapproche des gens.

Comment te sens-tu quand tu passes par cette bouche de métro?

Céline: Plutôt de bonne humeur. Ça me plaît beaucoup.

Christophe: Ni bien, ni mal, ça ne provoque rien en moi, sinon un peu de colère parce que je sais comment ça a été fait. C'est une imposture, de l'art ministériel. Il y a une volonté d'originalité exacerbée alors que c'est nul. Ce qui est dommage, c'est que les touristes un peu cons s'extasient devant ça alors qu'il y a la Comédie-Française et le Louvre à côté.

As-tu reconnu le soleil et la lune?

Céline: Oui, c'est vrai, les couleurs chaudes pour le soleil, les couleurs froides pour la lune.

Christophe: Ah oui, formidable comme symbole. Mê me un peu ésotérique.

Stéphanie: La lune a l'air plus grande que le soleil, il y a des personnages dessus. Mais chacun son interprétation de l'art. Il y a sûrement des gens qui vont voir deux coupoles kitsch et c'est tout.

Quel est l'avenir de l'art dans la rue?

Christophe: Avant, il y avait une bouche de métro en cuivre vert, Belle Époque. C'était assez joli. Ils auraient pu penser à quelque chose d'un peu harmonieux avec l'ensemble. C'est pas que ce soit laid en soi, mais ça n'a rien à faire là. C'est une volonté de mélange qui est absurde.

Ruth: Je pense que dans les villes comme Berlin, ils vont beaucoup plus vers cette poussée de l'art. À Paris, ça a l'air d'être le début. J'espère que ça va continuer.

Glossaire/Glossary

art nouveau art movement from the end of the 19th century

Barbès working-class area of Paris

la bouche de métro metro entrance

les cons (coll) idiots

le cuivre copper

s'extasier devant to be in raptures over

Hector Guimard designed Paris's Art Nouveau metro stations

une nullité worthless rubbish

ça ne provoque rien en moi it does nothing for me

tre re-looké (coll) to be given a new look, makeover

webTitle: Bradbury, great novelist, great critic, dies at 68

fields.headline: Bradbury, great novelist, great critic, dies at 68
fields.standfirst:
Obituary
Andrew Motion and Kazuo Ishiguro pay tribute
David Lodge: "he was my literary twin"
Ian McEwan: the great listener
fields.trailText: Sir Malcolm Bradbury, one of the most prolific and influential novelists, critics and academics of his generation, died unexpectedly yesterday at the age of 68.
fields.byline: John Ezard, Jeevan Vasagar and Maev Kennedy
fields.body:
Sir Malcolm Bradbury, one of the most prolific and influential novelists, critics and academics of his generation, died unexpectedly yesterday at the age of 68.

He had been unwell for some months with breathing difficulties but his illness had not been regarded as serious. News of his death - less than a year after he was knighted in the new year honours list - stunned his friends. He had been moved at the weekend into a hospice near his home at Norwich.

He lived in the area for 30 years and was renowned as founder of the University of East Anglia's creative writing school, which has produced a crop of eminent fellow-novelists including the Booker prize winners Kazuo Ishiguro and Ian McEwan. He was the school's emeritus professor.

Last night his friend, the novelist Rose Tremain, said Sir Malcolm had suffered since last summer from a condition known as cryptogenic organising pneumonia (COP).

He was being treated with steroids. But, Ms Tremain said: "We were all very worried because he seemed to be having a reaction to steroids." His agent Jonathan Begg said: "We thought his illness was being kept under control. It was not expected to come to this. I am very sad. We were all very fond of Malcolm. He was a great novelist, a great literary critic and a favourite author.

"One of the amazing things was to see the way he could work in so many different genres. He had a gift for tying up the strands of his work in a way that made sense. He had such a strong grasp of all the facets of his gift.

"In the last couple of months, when he was really quite ill at home, he was writing away every day: that's what he did in his life - write."

Ian McEwan said last night: "What was superb about him was that his mind was always open, he never became an old fart. He was an ambassador for the British novel and he was marvellous at it.

"The real tragedy is that his latest book is really his major work. It's a real novel of ideas and he was looking forward to going to America to promote it."

Ms Tremain said: "He wore his erudition and his scholarliness with great grace. He had a wonderful sense of humour. He came first at the party and was the last to leave."

David Lodge, novelist and academic, said: "I feel quite an extraordinary sense of loss personally. He was something of an inspiration to me when I was starting out."

Sir Malcolm leaves a widow, Elizabeth, and two sons. His early fame as a writer was as a sharp, disillusioned chronicler first of redbrick universities, then of staff antics on the 1960s "plate-glass" campuses.

He published five novels, the first, Eating People is Wrong, in 1959. The best known is still The History Man (1975), his televised satire about a far-left careerist academic inching towards Thatcherism.

He also adapted eight books for television, including Tom Sharpe's Porterhouse Blue, and wrote episodes of Inspector Morse and Kavanagh QC.

fields.headline: Gentle giant
fields.standfirst:
Malcolm Bradbury has died, aged 68. Andrew Motion, his successor at the University of East Anglia, pays tribute, while Kazuo Ishiguro, a former student, recalls a generous and inspiring teacher

Obituary
Great novelist and critic dies at 68
David Lodge: "he was my literary twin"
Ian McEwan: the great listener
fields.trailText: Malcolm Bradbury has died, aged 68. Andrew Motion, his successor at the University of East Anglia, pays tribute, while Kazuo Ishiguro, a former student, recalls a generous and inspiring teacher.
fields.body:
To realise that Malcolm Bradbury, who died yesterday, was 68 years old, is strangely to be reminded how vividly his name is associated with youth. Although his most recently published novel, To the Hermitage, has (ominously, it now seems) an elegiac feel about its concern for reputation and achievement, much of his previous writing is pre-occupied with people at the start of their lives. The main characters of The History Man (1975) may have been adults, but their audience - and in a sense, their stimuli - were their charges: the undergraduates and postgraduates who would be the building blocks of post-war Britain.

Malcolm had a kind of genius for seeing things in such terms. In the same way that his fiction is engrossed by the evidence of evolution, his critical writing is brilliantly alive to ideas of progress and change. And it was written in a sympathetic, complementary style: where the fiction fizzes with comic possibilities, the critical prose is measured, highly organised and - though never dull - always methodical. The two together give the impression of a man whose gifts were in perfect balance.

And, of course, there was another gift: the gift of teaching. His arrival at the University of East Anglia, where he was appointed professor of American literature in 1970, marked the beginning of something exceptional. In those days, creative writing courses were generally sneered at by the general public (and by many academics, too), who preferred to think that good writing, if it happened at all, was likely to be produced by lonely individuals starving in attics. The MA course that Malcolm set up with Angus Wilson did more to challenge such prejudices than anything else - and now might be said to have destroyed them altogether.

When I took over the running of the course from Malcolm on his retirement five years ago, I was in no doubt that it was - and should, in a sense, remain - "his". It was his foundation, and although I was bound to adapt it in certain ways, the core values that he had shaped were unquestionably good and true. He had delighted in the success of former students such as Ian McEwan (the first person to sign up) and Kazuo Ishiguro, and had appreciated that the reputation of the course depended on such conspicuous figures.

But he had also encouraged the idea that the course could be evaluated by other means - by helping people to discover themselves in ways which might not take them on to a world of bright lights, but would make them better at whatever else they did. Better readers, better teachers, better at being decent people.

Why? Because he himself was a person of unusually broad humanity: compassionate in his politics, generous with his time and attention, courteous in his habits, by turns amusing and grave in his talk, and expansive in his interests. Although he is associated with a particular place, his work and his sympathies depended greatly on his experience of travel.

His legacy is highly significant and substantial. At a time when the study of literature within universities was undergoing a huge rethink (the expansion of the institutions themselves, the challenge to "new criticism", the arrival of critical theory), he positioned himself at the heart of all the important debates. As a novelist he was at once satirical and engaged; as a critic he was adept at fielding new ideas and expert in elucidating them; and as a teacher, he was a pioneer.

When Malcolm left UEA he behaved impeccably, stepping back from the course and keeping a fatherly watch from afar. He never interfered, never offered unwanted advice, and was always encouraging. I felt, in our conversations about "how things were going" - as I suppose his students must have done - at once defended and set free.

Like others, I had hoped that his retirement would be a great deal longer, and allow a great deal more time for the books, TV adaptations and lectures that a full-time job had kept him from writing. Yesterday's news is utterly dismal. He had already given so much, yet had so much more in him to give.

'There was a liberating feeling'
Kazuo Ishiguro

Malcolm Bradbury was a gentle, respectful teacher of creative writing. These qualities showed not just in his manner when discussing the work of students, but in the way his course was structured. No prescribed work, no exercises, no set lines, acres of time. He believed in the seminar format. Perhaps this was because, as a shy man, he wasn't comfortable with one-to-one sessions; more likely, he felt the seminar would prevent unbalanced responses to a person's work.

He always discouraged dogmatic stances; the emphasis was always the diversity of what constituted good writing. There was a liberating feeling that you could turn up with almost any kind of writing - an intense Joycean monologue, a gritty slice of northern realism, a piece of soft porn - and he would insist the group look at it with seriousness and evaluate it on its own terms.

Two things he used to say in those groups have remained with me over the years. "Never assume that English is the only language," he muttered one afternoon, lighting his pipe. And perhaps, most important of all, his gently asserted refrain, that a person could only become a "real" writer by "discovering his or her own voice".

He never took the easy way out by falsely flattering writers. But he was generous as a tutor, and, unsurprisingly, generous in the wider world as a critic. Perhaps he did do hatchet jobs, but in the 20 years since I ceased to be his student, I never came across any.

I remember once finding him at a party in the mid-80s, extremely despondent after reading a scathing Martin Amis review of his Rates of Exchange. But then 10 years later, when following the publication of Amis's The Information, it seemed to be open season for attacking Martin, I noticed a glowing review in the Times - penned by Malcolm. He was generous; but above all, he regarded literature, in all its aspects, as a serious matter.

webTitle: House of Lords staff accused of racism

fields.headline: House of Lords staff accused of racism
fields.trailText: Banqueting managers at the House of Lords made racist remarks about Asian and black peers, and treated an Asian clerk as aservant, an employment tribunal heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Update: the applicant's case, below, against the House of Lords and two employees was unanimously dismissed by the Employment Tribunal in December 2000 and that decision was upheld by the Employment Appeal Tribunal in October 2001.

Banqueting managers at the House of Lords made racist remarks about Asian and black peers, and treated an Asian clerk as aservant, an employment tribunal heard yesterday.

Black peers were routinely refused function rooms even when they were free, said Sri Lankan-born Phyllis Jayaratne, a clerical officer in the banqueting department.

Mrs Jayaratne, 54, is claiming that her boss in the Lords racially discriminated against her while she was a clerk in the department. She told the hearing in Croydon, Surrey, that her managers had talked of Asian peers turning their dining rooms into a "curry house".

The main culprits were assistant banqueting manager Rupert Ellwood and banqueting manager Lorna McWilliam, she said. They deny the allegations.

She also said her relationship with her bosses was a "master-servant" relationship.

The clerical officer, who has been on sick leave since last year, said that it was Mr Ellwood who had refused black peers function rooms.

She added: "To Miss McWilliam, any white person who helped a non-white person is either white trash or a prat."

Mrs Jayaratne, from Ilford, Essex, is seeking compensation against the clerk of the parliaments.

The tribunal continues.

fields.headline: Obituary: Sir Malcolm Bradbury
fields.standfirst:
Prolific novelist and critic renowned for his wry observations of academia and his support for new talent through creative writing courses

Andrew Motion and Kazuo Ishiguro pay tribute
Great novelist and critic dies at 68
David Lodge: "he was my literary twin"
Ian McEwan: the great listener
fields.trailText: Prolific novelist and critic renowned for his wry observations of academia and his support for new talent through creative writing courses.
fields.body:
"The door of a room adjoining opens a little; a dark, tousled-haired head, with a sad visage, peers through, looks at Howard for a little, and then retreats. The face has a vague familiarity; Howard recalls that this depressed-looking figure is a lecturer in the English department, a man who, 10 years earlier, had produced two tolerably well known and acceptably reviewed novels, filled, as novels then were, with moral scruple and concern.

"Since then there has been silence, as if, under the pressure of contemporary change, there was no more moral scruple and concern, no new substance to be spun. The man alone persists; he passes nervously through the campus, he teaches, sadly, he avoids strangers."

In these words, Sir Malcolm Bradbury, who has died aged 68, made his own Hitchcockian, though uncharacteristically reclusive, appearance in The History Man, his greatest and most influential novel. His death marks the close of half a century of academic and literary history, of which he was par excellence the chronicler.

Malcolm Bradbury was born in Sheffield, the son of Arthur Bradbury, a railway worker, and his wife Doris, and grew up in Nottingham, where he attended West Bridgford grammar school. He took a first-class degree in English at the then fairly new University of Leicester, and did postgraduate work at Queen Mary College, London, at Manchester and in the United States, before taking up his first full-time appointment in 1959, in the adult education department at Hull University.

In 1961, he moved to the English department of Birmingham University, where he met another recently- appointed lecturer, David Lodge, with whom he was to form a long and close friendship and amiable rivalry. In 1965, he joined the new University of East Anglia, and, in 1970, became professor of American studies; he was to remain in Norwich for the rest of his life.

Bradbury was a prolific writer - as an academic critic, as a novelist and humorist, and for television, a medium which increasingly fascinated him. His many critical works included The Modern American Novel (1983), No, Not Bloomsbury and The Modern World: Ten Great Writers (both 1987), From Puritanism To Postmodernism: A History Of American Literature (with Richard Ruland, 1991) and Dangerous Pilgrimages (1995).

He also edited The Penguin Book Of Modern British Short Stories (1987) and The Atlas of Literature (1996), to which he was also a major contributor over an astonishingly wide range of topics. His original television dramas included the two four-part series, The Gravy Train (1990) and The Gravy Train Goes East (1991), both sharp and uncomfortably accurate satires on the politics of the European Community, as well as Cuts (1996), which contrasted the visible consumption of television companies with the starvation of universities in an age of sado-monetarism.

Apart from his original scripts, he adapted a wide range of books for television, ranging from Tom Sharpe's Porterhouse Blue and Kingsley Amis's The Green Man to Stella Gibbons's Cold Comfort Farm and the Dalziel and Pascoe novels of Reginald Hill. It is a matter of regret that his adaptation of William Cooper's Tales From Provincial Life, a novel with which he had particularly close affinities, has not yet reached the television screen.

Bradbury, however, made no secret of the fact that fiction, and in particular the novel, was his true love. "Like most comic novelists, I take the novel extremely seriously," he said. "It is the best of all forms - open and personal, intelligent and inquiring. I value it for its scepticism, its irony and its play." His first novel, Eating People Is Wrong, which picked up the baton from Kingsley Amis's Lucky Jim, appeared in 1959 and was an instant success - though it owed more to American writers like Trilling and Bellow than to Amis.

From then on, his novels appeared at the rate of roughly one a decade, with Stepping Westward (1965), The History Man (1975), Rates Of Exchange (1982), Dr Criminale (1992) and To the Hermitage (2000), based on Diderot's visit to the court of Catherine the Great, a brilliant departure from the form which he had made so much his own.

In almost all of Bradbury's novels, the most frequently recurring theme is that of the slightly naive, liberal innocent, usually an academic, hilariously abroad in an unfamiliar, and occasionally slightly threatening, context, a theme which developed naturally from his frequent foreign travels, often under the auspices of the British Council. In Rates Of Exchange, the imaginary Slakan language was largely invented over several years by the combined contributions of the polyglot participants of the council's annual Cambridge seminar of contemporary writing, of which Bradbury was the founder and, for many years, chairman.

Of all his novels, however, it was The History Man by which he will be most lastingly remembered, and which indeed was one of the outstanding novels of its decade. It charts the successful career of the manipulative and promiscuous radical sociologist, Howard Kirk, at the new University of Watermouth (which bears more than a passing resemblance to East Anglia), and satirises savagely his substitution of "trends for morals and commitments".

Kirk moves through the university like a Marxist Iago, wrecking careers, corrupting innocence and generally subverting stability in the name of history. "I know how your aggression operates," one of his more perceptive colleagues tells him. "If you wanted someone through a window, you wouldn't push him yourself. You'd get someone else to do it. Or persuade the man he should do it himself, in his own best interests."

All Bradbury's novels, for all their surface wit and comedy, have serious moral and philosophical subtexts; in The History Man the wit is darker, the satire more biting, the atmosphere more menacing and the conclusion more hopeless. Bradbury was always fascinated by the experimental fictive techniques of contemporary American novelists, and The History Man shows a marked development in his own writing in its unvaried use of a present tense, which reports without comment or analysis the speech and actions of the characters. The technique adds menace to the atmosphere of alienation and moral nihilism.

Bradbury's contribution to the literary life of his time was as extraordinary as his prolific output, and deserves equal notice. He will be properly remembered for his part, with Angus Wilson, in founding in 1970 - and, for many years, teaching - the creative writing programme at East Anglia. At the time the only MA of standing in the subject in Britain, and today, in spite of many imitators, still the most distinguished - not least in the number of distinguished writers it can claim as graduates - it did much to allay the suspicions of such courses.

His generosity to all literary ventures he regarded as worthy was remarkable, and his inability to reject appeals for help was a severe trial to his agent. The list of organisations to which he was prepared to give precious time was impressive, and included the Booker Prize management committee, the British Association for American Studies, the SDP arts policy committee, the Eastern Arts Association, the King's Lynn literary festival and the Norwich festival.

To few, however, did Bradbury give as much time and attention as he did to the affairs of the British Council, of whose literary work, at one time very much under threat of abolition, he was an invaluable supporter. Apart from serving as a foundation member of its literary advisory committee, he was single-handedly responsible for transforming its contemporary writing seminar, the chairmanship of which he took over in 1976, from a rather routine English studies event into one which brought together writers, translators, journalists, publishers and academics from all over the world to meet British writers, many of whom found foreign translators and publishers at it.

The seminar took place during an annual fortnight in a Cambridge college, and was conducted, in sympathy with his own love of parties, in appropriately carnival conditions. After relinquishing the chairmanship to Christopher Bigsby in 1984, Bradbury continued to revisit the seminar every year to give readings, his visits invariably providing an occasion for a party of Bradburyesque proportions.

His tours overseas for the council, many of which reappeared transmogrified in his novels, were invariably marked by unscheduled revelry, as well as by serious literary discussions. After retirement in 1995, he found a new platform, and a new source of conviviality, as a guest lecturer on Swan Hellenic cruises.

When the British Council's literature department decided to produce an annual anthology of the most recent British writing it could use to publicise new young writers abroad, it was natural for it to look first to Malcolm Bradbury for help and encouragement, and as an editor of the first two volumes (1992 and 1993). This was a time when the publication of an anthology launched under the council's auspices was hardly calculated to produce favour- able reviews, however illustrious the editor.

It was largely due to his support that New Writing (named, at his suggestion, in honour of John Lehmann's earlier venture) survived a difficult birth, and went on to become one of the few refuges for the short story in the 1990s. Many of his own creative writing graduates first published in the series.

If he was preeminently a gregarious man, happiest in the social context of conferences, seminars and meetings, and generous with his friendship, Bradbury was even more markedly a devoted family man. In 1959, he married Elizabeth Salt, who was, throughout his life, the greatest single source of happiness and support to him, and by whom he had two sons. He was appointed CBE in 1991, for services to literature, and was knighted in 2000.

Literary London is much the poorer for the loss of its own History Man, and of a voice unequalled for its humanity and wit.

 Malcolm Stanley Bradbury, writer and teacher, born September 7 1932; died November 27 2000

Literary London is much the poorer for the loss of its own History Man, and of a voice unequalled for its humanity and wit.  Malcolm Stanley Bradbury, writer and teacher, born September 7 1932; died November 27 2000

webTitle: Grapevine: Meldreth Manor School  in Hertfordshire

fields.headline: Sex on the timetable
fields.trailText: Meldreth Manor School in Hertfordshire
fields.body:
When Paula Doran visited Meldreth Manor School near Royston in Hertfordshire to present the Pamela Sheridan award, she asked pupils what they remembered about the lessons that led to their success: "The one with the courgettes and the condoms", came one reply.

Doran is practice development director with the Family Planning Association, which promotes the award for practitioners in the field of sex education. Pamela Sheridan was an early pioneer of sex education, beginning her career as a volunteer in a clinic in the 1930s.

A lot of sex education in schools remains "hit and miss" according to Doran, "without any real sense of an integrated approach into the whole subject of personal, social and health development [PSHE]". The awards cover primary, secondary, special education and community projects.

Meldreth Manor won the special education award because of the positive approach taken to teaching sex education to pupils with a range of learning and physical difficulties. "There's a tendency with some schools of this nature to view sex education as simply about guarding pupils against the dangers of abuse. At Meldreth, the programme is tailored to meet the needs of the pupils."

Ivy Bank High School in Burnley won the secondary award, which Doran will present today during the school's special assembly held to mark World Aids Day. Richard Burbery, head of PSHE at the school, ensures that sex education is broadly balanced and well integrated. All pupils at key stage 3 undertake an hour's sex education a week, and all teachers attend training.

One of the judging criteria for the award is evidence of a commitment to challenging sexism, racism and homophobia, and Burbery says this is important. "We start by turning the tables, getting the pupils to question the reasons behind prejudices. This leads into group discussions, throwing up views that may need to be challenged. From there we're able to introduce role play, videos, quizzes or written work to get the pupils to really empathise with the targets of such prejudice," Burbery says.

Involvement is a high priority at Ivy Bank. Recently, the school held an evening specifically for parents to explain the sex education programme.

And Burbery is always seeking to improve provision. One idea is to trail single-sex groups at the top end of the school, which could be beneficial in discussing such issues as contraception, especially with boys, who tend to "switch off", Burbery says.

Local greengrocers had best stock up on those courgettes.

The FPA will be providing guidance for teachers in the near future. Visit www.fpa.org.uk or call 0845 310 1334. See First Edition, page 54

fields.headline: Kingston seeks broadband partner
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Kingston Communications is to seek a partner for its broadband network plans, with BSkyB an early favourite, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telecoms operator Kingston Communications will seek a partner for its broadband network plans, with BSkyB an early favourite.

Kingston said it will team up with other companies to build the system, thus reducing the company's financial burden in the project from a predicted £1bn to £150m.

Analysts are hoping that Kingston will join with digital TV broadcaster BSkyB, although the company has yet to choose a partner.

Both companies have an interactive TV partnership in the Hull region, but Kingston faces competition for BSkyB's services.

One industry source said: "A number of people, including Kingston, are talking to BSkyB about a deal over DSL roll-out."

Fears about Kingston's cash situation were further reduced by the announcement of a £250m borrowing arrangement.

Concern was mounting that Kingston would have to seek investment funds at a time when the telecoms sector is out of favour with the stock market.

Meanwhile, Kingston said its first half pre-tax earnings had fallen from £14.8m to £8.8m, due to increased investment in its infrastructure, though turnover rose 17% to £108.6m.

The City, however, chose to concentrate on the cost-trimming proposals, which provided some rare good news from a debt-ridden sector. Kingston's shares rose 10%, or 25p, to 267p in early trading.

fields.headline: Future Network appoints Sutcliffe to London office
fields.trailText: 11am: Andy Sutcliffe has been appointed group publisher of Future Network's music, sport and entertainment titles, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Andy Sutcliffe, who co-founded magazine publisher Cabal, has been appointed group publisher of Future Network's music, sport and entertainment titles.

He will be responsible for a string of magazines including Total Football and Total Film.

Mr Sutcliffe, the reluctant star of Trouble Between the Covers, a BBC documentary about the publishing industry broadcast earlier this year, will join Future's London offices.

His arrival at Future comes eight months after he quit as managing director of Cabal, the magazine company he founded with partner Sally O'Sullivan in 1998. Cabal is responsible for Real Homes and Front magazines.

Mr Sutcliffe said at the time of his departure: 'When you are small, you need luck. Competing with IPC and Emap is not the easiest thing in the world."

His appointment comes as Future is restructuring its business, merging the music titles with its former sport and entertainment division.

Mr Sutcliffe will handle the London-based titles, while sport and entertainment publisher John Bickley will continue as group publisher of the Bath-based sport and entertainment magazines.

Mr Sutcliffe is curently working at John Brown Publishing as a consultant.

webTitle: Labour faces election dilemma on taxes

fields.headline: Labour faces election dilemma on taxes
fields.standfirst: Ministers may repeat 1997 pledge despite calls for rethink
fields.trailText: Earmarked taxes are winning the support of some senior ministers as the government grapples with the dilemma of whether to go into the general election with a repeat of its 1997 election pledge of no increases in income tax in the next parliament.
fields.body:
Earmarked taxes are winning the support of some senior ministers as the government grapples with the dilemma of whether to go into the general election with a repeat of its 1997 election pledge of no increases in income tax in the next parliament.

Earmarked taxes are seen by some, including Home office minister Charles Clarke, as the best means of improving the popularity of direct taxes with voters. However, the Treasury dismissed suggestions that as much as half of all income tax should be earmarked for an NHS tax. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is also no longer an anthusiast.

Research published at the weekend by the independent taxation commission, established by the leftwing think tank Fabian Society, shows that government anxiety over income tax has forced it to place an excessive emphasis on indirect taxes such as VAT.

The inquiry proposes an NHS tax explicitly funded from general tax, building on tax duties earmarked for health and congestion charges for transport. A member of the commission, Julian Le Grand, said an earmarked NHS tax would make both the public and the electorate accountable for the state of the NHS. He added it would allow other public services to be better funded since at present the NHS is taking up more and more of the tax take.

The inquiry criticises the Labour government for failing to challenge the prevailing orthodoxy that taxation is in itself illegitimate. It says taxes are never going to be popular, but accuses Labour "of acting as if proposals to raise taxes cannot win votes". The inquiry also says that the"prevailing political orthodoxy" on tax means the poor are paying proportionately more than the rich in tax.

Between 1978 and 1998-99, the richest fifth have seen their share of the nation's post-tax income rise from 36% to 45%. This is partly due to successive cuts in income tax - now only 26% of total tax revenues - and the increasing importance of indirect tax.

The bottom fifth of the income distribution pay around 28% of their gross income in indirect taxes, such as VAT or petrol duties, compared to only 12% of the top fifth.

The injustice is only removed when the distributional impact of public spending is also taken into account. Around half of the gross income of the bottom 40% of the income distribution comes from the state.

Apart from the earmarked NHS tax, the report calls for a 50% top rate of tax applied to taxable incomes of more than £100,000 a year, a proposal rejected by Tony Blair and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, be fore the last election. The higher rate tax would raise £2.9bn and affect 200,000. The money would finance an increase in the personal allowance by £250 and an increase in the threshold for the 40% rate to £30,000 taxable income from the present £28,400.

The commission also proposes that the rich pay higher council tax, a flat rate personal allowance and realignment of the national insurance upper earnings limit with the higher rate of tax.

Polls commisioned by the Inquiry found that 80% would prefer extra public spending to tax cuts. Asked separately whether they would like a 1p increase in unspecified public spending, 40% said yes. Asked if they would like the money devoted to the NHS, 80% said yes and asked if they would like the money go to education, 68% replied positively.

Labour strategists have been wary of such poll findings, arguing that they are not borne out in the polling on election day. The strategists point to separate poll findings published by the inquiry suggesting voters believe taxes are too high, and do not support an inheritance tax. But the commission argues that most people suffer a deep sense of disconnection from the taxes they pay and the public services which these finance.

The Treasury, and a minority of the Fabian Society inquiry rteam members, oppose earmarked taxes on the grounds that they reduce the flexibility flexibility within the tax system. Opponents also fear that if the NHS tax revenues are registered separately - either through pay slips or by separate taxes linked to specific revenue stream - then other taxes for less popular services will become more difficult to raise.

The inquiry suggests the current state of public revenues are good enough not to require short term tax rises. But it points out that public spending as a proportion of GDP - 40.5% - will be lower at the end of the period 2001-4 than when the Conservatives left office in 1996-7.

It also points out that the proportion of national income taken in taxes in the UK is 6% lower than the EU average. Only Ireland and Spain have lower overall tax rates.

The inquiry, chaired by Lord Plant of Highfield, who was responsible for an earlier influential Labour party report on electoral systems, suggests that confidence in public spending has also been undermined by the way in which the government publishes self-congratulatory annual reports on its own activities.

The commission suggests that such reports are worthless in an age when government is not trusted. It concludes: "The very fact that these annual reports are evaluations of government by government undermine their credibility. They could be paragons of self-criticism, and they would still be regarded as suspect by the media and the public."

It proposes an independent office for public accountability, expanding the roles of the present national audit office and audit commission. It also suggests a royal commission on taxation to provide impartial evidence on how possible new or reformed taxes would work, and whether they would meet government objectives.

webTitle: Law Society in the dock over 'racism and sexism'

fields.headline: Law Society in the dock over 'racism and sexism'
fields.trailText: Lawyers for Kamlesh Bahl, the former Law Society vice-president, yesterday accused the solicitors' professional body of breaching natural justice and denying her a fair hearing by forcing her out within days of a report which found her guilty of bullying staff.
fields.body:
Lawyers for Kamlesh Bahl, the former Law Society vice-president, yesterday accused the solicitors' professional body of breaching natural justice and denying her a fair hearing by forcing her out within days of a report which found her guilty of bullying staff.

Ms Bahl, 44, took her claim for sex and race discrimination, victimisation and constructive dismissal to the Watford employment tribunal, which is expected to hear a stream of witnesses over the next four weeks.

Her supporters, including the Society of Black Lawyers, claim the case exposes institutional discrimination in the legal profession. Well-wishers demonstrating outside the tribunal waved placards reading "Ethnic cleansing at the Law Society". Om Prakash Sharma, president of the National Council of Hindu Temples, said: "The unjust, racist and sexist excesses of the Law Society need to be challenged".

The saga has proved highly expensive and embarrassing for the body which regulates and represents the 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales. "I don't think there will be much change from £2m by the time the tribunal finishes," said one member of the society's 75-strong council.

Witnesses for the Law Society include two district judges. Ms Bahl, who is expected to give evidence today, was in line last summer to become the first Asian solicitor and first woman to head the 175-year-old organisation, but was forced to resign in March after findings that she had bullied and harassed five staff members.

An inquiry headed by Lord Griffiths, a former law lord, found all the allegations could be proved. He said her behaviour had been "at times demeaning and humiliating and at other times offensively ag gressive." One victim underwent counselling for stress.

Ms Bahl, a former chairwoman of the Equal Opportunities Commission, is not challenging the Griffiths inquiry, although she does not accept its findings and denies that her behaviour amounted to bullying.

Her claims centre on the way the society dealt with complaints against her and her exclusion so quickly in the inquiry's aftermath.

She alleges that the way the society dealt with the bullying allegations was in breach of its own dignity at work policy. She claims the way the complaints were made public breached her right to privacy, and accuses the society of failing to give her a right of appeal against Lord Griffiths' findings. Not giving her sufficient time to answer the allegations breached natural justice and her right to a fair hearing, she argues.

Robin Allen, Ms Bahl's QC, told the tribunal: "The conclusion she bullied is something which she very much disagrees with. The applicant does not accept she was a bully, she doesn't accept the conclusions reached by Lord Griffiths."

Ms Bahl alleges that after she announced she was launching a sex and race discrimination claim against the society, she was victimised and then treated in such a way that she was entitled to resign and claim compensation for unfair dismissal.

A few days after the Griffiths report the council voted in her absence to suspend her. In preparation for a special general meeting of the whole profession to decide whether to expel her, copies of the Griffiths report were sent to all 80,000 solicitors. Before the meeting could be held, she resigned.

The tribunal hearing, adjourned yesterday after legal argument, resumes today.

webTitle: Channel 4 winter arts line-up 'a bit thin'

fields.headline: Channel 4 admits to weakness in winter arts line-up
fields.trailText: 2.45pm A Channel 4 executive has admitted its winter schedule was 'a bit thin' in serious arts programmes, write Matt Wells and Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A senior Channel 4 executive admitted today that its winter schedule was 'a bit thin' in serious arts and culture programmes.

Janey Walker, managing editor of commissioning, conceded that the broadcaster's new season of programmes didn't include enough serious arts programmes.

But she insisted that the broadcaster still took its obligations seriously. "We are very committed to arts programmes at Channel 4," she said at a Voice of the Listener & Viewer seminar in London.

Ms Walker was responding to questions from VLV members who were unhappy with Channel 4's winter output, which includes a programme on cannibalism and the provocative drama Metrosexuality.

Earlier, Channel 4 chairman Vanni Treves told the seminar that the station should remain a public organisation if it was to retain its role as a public service broadcaster.

Mr Treves said that the broadcaster's not-for-profit status meant that it could cross-subsidise programmes without having to meet shareholder obligations.

"It will be informative, irreverent and innovative, but not always everyone's cup of tea," he added.

"Not every programme is expected to earn its keep in terms of the advertising revenue it attracts. Indeed, many of the programmes we are most proud of and are most appreciated by audiences are loss-making in terms of strict accounting."

Mr Treves listed Longitude, Dispatches, Philosophy for Beginners, Right to Reply and Channel 4 News as examples of loss-making shows, adding that "fully 40% of Channel 4's entertainment programmes are uncommercial in the normal sense of the word."

His speech followed renewed speculation that the forthcoming communications white paper would pave the way for a privatisation.

webTitle: Mediavest UK chairman to step down

fields.headline: Birchall to step down at Mediavest
fields.trailText: 8.15am: The chairman of one of the UK's top media buyers, Mediavest UK, has announced he is to quit, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
One of the UK's biggest media buyers, Mediavest UK, has been left with a gaping hole at management level after chairman Adrian Birchall announced he was going to quit.

He will retire from the business on December 31 and there are no plans at this stage to replace him.

Jim Marshall will continue as chief executive officer.

"Adrian's contribution has been invaluable, initially in building MediaVest in the UK and more recently his work in Europe," said Mr Marshall.

"He should be enormously proud of his achievements and the management team that he has put in place. The management team is ostensibly the same as at the time of launch but now more mature."

Mr Birchall's departure marks the end of a glorious career. He was one of the founding partners of The Media Centre, one of the UK's first major standalone media companies, which he set up in 1991.

Under his leadership, The Media Centre became one the most successful media companies in London, named "Media Agency of the Year" on two occasions and regularly leading the new business league table.

In 1997, The Media Centre became MediaVest.

Mr Birchall oversaw the launch in May of the Starcom MediaVest Group, which is now ranked among the world's top full service independent media companies.

Its clients include Avon, Capital One Financial, Diageo, Ernst & Young, Fiat Auto, Mars, Philips, Procter & Gamble and the Australian Tourist Commission.

Mr Birchall said: "I am very proud of what we were able to achieve in the early days of The Media Centre and later at MediaVest UK and Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

"It has been very exciting to be involved with the merger of MediaVest and Starcom to create the Starcom MediaVest Group, one of the biggest media companies in the world."

He began his media career in 1969 as a media researcher at Lintas London. At 28, he was named media director at BBDO London. In 1986, he joined D'Arcy UK as media director and vice-chairman. He was named chairman and chief executive of The Media Centre in 1991 before becoming president of MediaVest EMEA in 1997.

Mr Birchall's departure marks the end of a glorious career. He was one of the founding partners of The Media Centre, one of the UK's first major standalone media companies, which he set up in 1991. Under his leadership, The Media Centre became one the most successful media companies in London, named "Media Agency of the Year" on two occasions and regularly leading the new business league table. In 1997, The Media Centre became MediaVest. Mr Birchall oversaw the launch in May of the Starcom MediaVest Group, which is now ranked among the world's top full service independent media companies. Its clients include Avon, Capital One Financial, Diageo, Ernst & Young, Fiat Auto, Mars, Philips, Procter & Gamble and the Australian Tourist Commission. Mr Birchall said: "I am very proud of what we were able to achieve in the early days of The Media Centre and later at MediaVest UK and Europe, the Middle East and Africa. "It has been very exciting to be involved with the merger of MediaVest and Starcom to create the Starcom MediaVest Group, one of the biggest media companies in the world." He began his media career in 1969 as a media researcher at Lintas London. At 28, he was named media director at BBDO London. In 1986, he joined D'Arcy UK as media director and vice-chairman. He was named chairman and chief executive of The Media Centre in 1991 before becoming president of MediaVest EMEA in 1997.

fields.headline: Eidos losses deepen
fields.trailText: 10am: Eidos, the creator of cyberbabe Lara Croft, is facing a difficult Christmas as a result of shortages of PlayStation 2, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Eidos, the troubled creator of cyberbabe Lara Croft, continues to be hit by the non-appearance in the UK of the much-hyped PlayStation 2.

Chief executive Mike McGarvey said today that the shortage of the consoles spelt another miserable Christmas for the games company.

Last year the company found itself with stockpiles of unwanted games, including the legendary Tomb Raider series, after over-estimating customer demand.

Eidos today revealed the scale of the problem by reporting pre-tax losses for the first half of the year of £82.3m, up from £37.9m for the same period last year.

Mike McGarvey, chief executive of Eidos, said: "We have been affected by industry-wide issues. Consumers are looking for new hardware and fewer units of software are being sold."

Eidos has made sure it did not make the same mistake this year with just one of its 19 PlayStation 2 games available to the public over Christmas.

"We are not expecting a boost over Christmas because of the mature PlayStation market," added Mr McGarvey.

The company has been reeling from the resignations in the past two months of chief executive Charles Cornwall and finance chief Jeremy Lewis, following the collapse of takeover talks with French rival Infogrames.

In a further blow, Eidos has decided to write down its £34m investment in internet company Express.com to zero, after the fledgling business-to-consumer company experienced "challenging trading conditions".

This was the key contributor to exceptional charges of £54m, which took the shine off a 23% increase in turnover to £57m. Mr McGarvey said the failed investment did not contribute to the departure of the two board members.

Eidos's boss took a bullish stance on the results, pointing to a 14% cut in marketing and sales costs and the success of the Who Wants To be a Millionaire? spin-off, but he admitted the crucial Christmas period will continue to see flat sales for the industry.

"The overall market will be flat. The Ninetendo market will be down 25% and so will the PlayStation market, though Pokemon games will push sales up.

"Sales for this year will still be in the $16bn range, which is the same number as in 1999."

fields.headline: Orange chief to step down
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Orange chief executive Hans Snook is to step down when the company floats early next year, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Hans Snook, the idiosyncratic chief executive of mobile phone company Orange, today confirmed that he is to step down when the company floats early next year.

Mr Snook will become a special adviser to Michael Bon, chairman of Orange and chief executive of France Telecom, which bought Orange in a £27bn deal in May.

He will be replaced by France Telecom's executive vice-president, Jean-Francois Pontal.

The departure of one of the most colourful figures in the telecoms industry had been widely predicted.

The fact that Orange will be listed in Paris rather than London has been cited by City observers as a key reason for his departure.

webTitle: Government set for more air traffic strife

fields.headline: Government set for more air traffic strife
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government is  set for yet another face-off with rebel backbenchers over the proposed part-privatisation of Britain's air  traffic control system, in a last-ditch bid to get its transport bill through parliament before next week's state opening.
fields.body:
The government is set for yet another face-off with rebel backbenchers over the proposed part-privatisation of Britain's air traffic control system, in a last-ditch bid to get its transport bill through parliament before next week's state opening.

Transport minister Lord Macdonald told the Today programme the government had no intention of dropping its PPP plan. "We believe that what the air traffic services need in this country is a massive injection of investment, and we are looking at over £1 billion going in over the next decade," he said.

"We have come forward in a spirit of compromise"

Meanwhile, an influential Labour MP has called on the government to abandon its controversial proposals. "A gracious withdrawal might be a good idea," said Crewe and Nantwich Labour MP Gwyneth Dunwoody, who chairs the Commons transport sub-committee. Nats did not need the PPP plan, she said, adding: "It certainly needs money, but it is a service which makes money ... so it could go to the open market, it could borrow quite happily because it has a guaranteed stream of income, and it could find the cash it needed in order to modernise."

Plans for a public-private partnership (PPP) for National Air Traffic Services were rejected for a second time by the House of Lords last night, leaving the Government just four days to try once more to force the bill past peers.

Following the Lords' vote to put off the sale until after the next general election, transport minister Lord Macdonald announced a compromise solution to be put before the Commons today, which would see it delayed by just three months.

While he was hopeful that this would be enough to smooth the bill's passage through the upper house at the third attempt, it seems unlikely that it will silence Labour rebels in the Commons, 37 of who voted against the sell-off earlier this month.

Failure to gain Lords assent for the sell-off by the end of this week would delay the transport bill, which forms a keystone of deputy prime minister John Prescott's programme and includes legislation to set up the Strategic Rail Authority and introduce congestion charging in the cities.

The government wants to sell off 51% of NATS to one of three bidders in spring 2001, to enable £1 billion of investment in its antiquated technology.

But shadow transport secretary Bernard Jenkin said: "It is time for the government to climb off their high horse and listen to the cross-party consensus for a better solution.

"John Prescott cannot even command the confidence of his own party in either House and this is another mess that he has created."

Baroness Thomas of Walliswood, Liberal Democrat transport spokeswoman in the Lords, said: "Most people are opposed to privatising our skies.

"Part-privatisation of NATS was not in the 1997 Labour Manifesto. If the Government now wants to put our air up for sale, they should put it to a vote at the next general election."

Paul Noon, general secretary of the air traffic controllers' union IPMS, said: "The government's proposals have failed to win the confidence of Parliament, the public or professionals in the industry. The government should now enter constructive talks on a way forward that will command the support of the industry and the people who make the system work."

He called on the government to consider a not-for-profit trust, which he said would meet all the investment and financial objectives without the dangers of operation for profit.

webTitle: Class divide centres on sex issues more than spending

fields.headline: Class divide centres on sex issues more than spending
fields.trailText: The big differences of opinion between the middle and working classes centre on social and moral issues rather than taxation, spending and economic policy.
fields.body:
The big differences of opinion between the middle and working classes centre on social and moral issues rather than taxation, spending and economic policy.

The British social attitudes survey found both classes wanted more public spending and agreed the two top priorities should be health and education. But people from the working class were more conservative - and more out of sympathy with current Labour policies - on law and order, sexual morality and race.

A study by Geoffrey Evans of Oxford University found 60% of the working class thought homosexuality was "wrong", compared with 37% of the middle class.

The working classes were more likely to think the government's equal opportunities policies have "gone too far" and to be more sceptical about the EU.

Threequarters of the working class favoured keeping the pound as Britain's only currency, compared with 43% of the middle class.

Mr Evans said: "Working class voters might look for a party that more closely represents their views on issues such as immigration and minorities, and, rightly or wrongly, might consider the Conservatives."

Other breakdowns in the survey showed a big gulf between young and old. Nearly two thirds of 18- to 24-year-olds considered premarital sex to be "not wrong at all", but only 26% of over-65s agreed.

Two thirds of 18- to 24-year-olds did not belong to a religion, compared with only a quarter of those aged over 65.

The gender gap on social attitudes is narrowing. Men were slightly more in favour of marriage than women, but only a minority (27% of men and 21% of women) think married people are "generally happier" than the unmarried.

 Britons are becoming more permissive about the portrayal of sex in the media. Less than a quarter want to ban "frank" heterosexual scenes from regular TV channels, although 53% think such scenes should be shown after 10pm. Nearly half (48%) would ban homosexual sex scenes from regular channels, a fall of six points since 1995.

 Four people in five think the NHS should never ration treatment, but 56% think a younger person would currently get priority over an older one for an NHS heart operation. If rationing has to take place 60% want medical experts to take the decisions, not politicians or administrators.

 In 1983, 40% said they belonged to the Church of England, but by 1999 this had fallen to 27%. However nearly half (48%) said they "believe in God and always have done" - unchanged over the last 10 years.

 One in three people living in a big city have a yearning for the country life. Less than 5% of rural dwellers want to move to a big city. About three-quarters of those living in a country village want to stay put, compared with 30% of those living in a big city.

 Half the public never give money to beggars, 44% do sometimes and 5% do so often. Those most likely to give are young, have high incomes and are regular churchgoers. The frequency that people come across beggars has no effect on their likelihood of giving.

 Among women who work outside the home, 35% are "very satisfied" with their jobs, compared with 29% of men. Researchers linked this to more women working part time. Part-timers reported higher levels of job satisfaction.

webTitle: The rise of the Little Englanders

fields.headline: The rise of the Little Englanders
fields.standfirst: Xenophobic views are increasing, says survey, as figures reveal widening gap on nationality, race and foreign affairs
fields.trailText: Xenophobic views are increasing, says survey, as figures reveal widening gap on nationality, race and foreign affairs. John Carvel reports.
fields.body:
A sharp increase in the number of Little Englanders who do not identify themselves as British and tend towards racist and xenophobic views is disclosed today by the National Centre for Social Research in its annual survey of social attitudes.

As power devolved to Scotland and Wales over the first two years of Tony Blair's government, the proportion of English people saying they owed allegiance to England, not Britain, grew from 7% to 17%.

The researchers discovered no evidence of resentment in England about power passing to the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly, but the figures suggested that 6m adults in England no longer subscribed to a British national identity.

More than a third of this group (37%) freely admitted to being racially prejudiced, compared with 17% of those who continued to assert their Britishness.

They were also much more likely to think that immigrants take jobs away from people who were born in Britain (70%), that it was "bad" that people from ethnic minorities were getting ahead (26%), and that attempts to give equal opportunities to blacks and Asians in Britain had "gone too far" (46%).

The Little Englanders were also more likely to say it mattered a great deal to being English that people were white and born in England, with English parents.

Nearly threequarters (73%) wanted to keep the pound as Britain's only currency and 22% thought Britain should quit the EU altogether - a much more strongly Eurosceptic stance than among those acknowledging British nationhood.

The survey by John Curtice, of Strathclyde University, and Anthony Heath, of Oxford University, concluded: "We have found that those who feel English are indeed different from those who feel British, being consistently more inclined to want to shut out the outside world. Indeed 'Little Englanders' appear to be alive and well, if not yet very thick on the ground."

By contrast 6% of those who described their ethnic origin as black and 7% of those who said they were Asian classified themselves as English, not British. More than a third said they were British, not English.

The survey found a quarter of people living in England thought Scotland should become completely independent, but the most common response to Scotland's status was indifference. More than half would be "neither pleased nor sorry" if Scotland were to become completely independent.

A fifth of English people wanted independence for Wales, either inside or outside the EU. And a majority (54%) thought Northern Ireland's long-term interests would be with the rest of Ireland rather than as part of Britain.

But these reformist views did not lead to any great appetite for devolution within England, where 15% favoured regional assemblies and 18% wanted an English parliament.

"This is probably why the somewhat muted attempts by the Conservative party to identify itself as the party of English interests have met with an even more muted response," the study said.

One reason why English nationalism might struggle to assert itself was a lack of potent symbols belonging to exclusively England after centuries of intertwined British culture.

More than half thought fox hunting and Guy Fawkes night were English rather than British institutions. Paradoxically, a third thought the same about the Houses of Parliament, the centre of the British democratic state.

As power devolved to Scotland and Wales over the first two years of Tony Blair's government, the proportion of English people saying they owed allegiance to England, not Britain, grew from 7% to 17%. The researchers discovered no evidence of resentment in England about power passing to the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly, but the figures suggested that 6m adults in England no longer subscribed to a British national identity. More than a third of this group (37%) freely admitted to being racially prejudiced, compared with 17% of those who continued to assert their Britishness. They were also much more likely to think that immigrants take jobs away from people who were born in Britain (70%), that it was "bad" that people from ethnic minorities were getting ahead (26%), and that attempts to give equal opportunities to blacks and Asians in Britain had "gone too far" (46%). The Little Englanders were also more likely to say it mattered a great deal to being English that people were white and born in England, with English parents. Nearly threequarters (73%) wanted to keep the pound as Britain's only currency and 22% thought Britain should quit the EU altogether - a much more strongly Eurosceptic stance than among those acknowledging British nationhood. The survey by John Curtice, of Strathclyde University, and Anthony Heath, of Oxford University, concluded: "We have found that those who feel English are indeed different from those who feel British, being consistently more inclined to want to shut out the outside world. By contrast 6% of those who described their ethnic origin as black and 7% of those who said they were Asian classified themselves as English, not British. More than a third said they were British, not English. But these reformist views did not lead to any great appetite for devolution within England, where 15% favoured regional assemblies and 18% wanted an English parliament. fields.headline: Populism doesn't rule
fields.standfirst:
Leaders should ignore some social trends

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: Every year Roger Jowell and his colleagues at the National Centre for Social Research produce a fascinating snapshot of our beliefs. Over time the pictures become a movie of contemporary mores. Yet it turns out to be more art house than Hollywood action: it is a film in which not a great deal happens.Core attitudes are remarkably stable.
fields.body:
Every year Roger Jowell and his colleagues at the National Centre for Social Research produce a fascinating snapshot of our beliefs. Over time (today's is the 17th in the British Social Attitudes series) the pictures become a movie of contemporary mores. Yet it turns out to be more art house than Hollywood action: it is a film in which not a great deal happens. Core attitudes are remarkably stable. A slight movement in a progressive direction is detectible in attitudes towards sex and personal relationships. As the UK ages it seems that it is not becoming more illiberal: the 60s generation are retaining their permissiveness into their dotage. But at the same time solid blocks of opinion were and remain in favour of capital punishment and censorship and resent efforts being made to secure equal opportunities to blacks and Asians.

Similarly, attitudes towards taxing and spending are far from volatile. In the days of high Thatcherite triumphalism, as now, most British people said they wanted to keep the welfare state. They say (by smaller margins) they want government to be an active redistributor of money from better to less well off. They say they want government to spend more on key public services - health and ed ucation head the list - rather than cut their taxes. But what do such findings mean? If populism ruled Jack Straw would become even more illiberal on crime and punishment and William Hague, no slouch in the populist stakes, would move his party leftwards on fiscal matters.

Ultra democrats might regret that there is any gap between party lines and public attitudes. Others might rejoice that parties have not entirely thrown over their historical identities for the sake of buying popularity. One reason they have not is that attitudes and votes do not align at all closely. There is a bigger split between the social classes than between the parties on Europe. Were Mr Hague to move his party to accommodate the anti-gay, anti-immigrant sentiments of his working-class supporters he might end up alienating his middle class - as the Romsey byelection showed. Labour also has problems with its "heartlands", which are to the left of the leadership on public spending and tax but decidedly to its right on social issues. The lesson must surely be that political leadership is fraught with risk. Get too far out of line with core support and you lose votes - or provoke apathy.

fields.headline: Kamera snaps up BBC's Kaza
fields.trailText: 8.15am: The boss of BBC Worldwide's internet and interactive division has joined European internet TV firm Kamera, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The boss of BBC Worldwide's internet and interactive division has taken a non-executive board position at European internet TV firm Kamera.

Drew Kaza will become a Kamera board member at the next annual general meeting at the start of 2001.

The company's strengths are in interactive docu-soaps and it has recently signed a global format deal with Endemol to produce an interactive series called F*cking Famous.

Mr Kaza said: "It's an interesting little company. They're onto a pretty good thing with the streaming stuff they've been doing already, and are definitely going places."

He said it was too early to suggest a working relationship with BBC Worldwide and Kamera, but added: "Obviously I see some way in which Kamera's business is very complementary to the focus of BBC Worldwide internet and interactive,"

Mr Kaza's appointment is something of a coup for Kamera, which is expanding its internet production activities across Europe.

Having Mr Kaza on the board will enable the company to tap into international contacts and strengthen its focus on internet TV rights management and international business.

Dan Willstrand, Kamera's chief executive, said: "As the quality of streaming media gets closer to broadcast television, it is important to learn from people with extensive media experience.

"Mr Kaza has a wide-reaching experience within television business worldwide and will provide Kamera with excellent contacts in the industry, as well as a wealth of expertise that will enhance our business proposition."

Before joining the BBC, Mr Kaza was managing partner at media consultancy Mediaplex and before that, president at United International Pictures (UIP) Pay-TV Group in London.
