webTitle: TWI signs up Fantasy Football producer Jacobs

fields.headline: TWI signs up Fantasy Football producer Jacobs
fields.trailText: 8am: Sports production and rights agency TWI has hired Fantasy Football League producer and Avalon TV head of development Andy Jacobs, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Sports production and rights agency TWI has hired Andy Jacobs, Fantasy Football League producer and Avalon TV head of development, to join its development team.

Mr Jacobs will take up his post as senior development producer with TWI, the London-based TV production arm of Mark McCormack's International Management Group, immediately.

He will join a development team headed by TWI senior vice-president Alastair Waddington.

The company's recent production credits include The Second World War in Colour and Britain at War in Colour.

During his time at Avalon, Mr Jacobs series produced Fantasy Football League for BBC2 and Fantasy World Cup for ITV.

He is a former editor of FHM magazine and currently writes and presents a football radio chat show for TalkSport.

webTitle: Radio 1 DJ Mayo on way to 5 Live

fields.headline: Radio 1 DJ Mayo on way to 5 Live
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Simon Mayo, the last of Radio 1's "old guard" still to have a daily show, quit the station yesterday for the more mature pastures of Radio Five Live.
fields.body:
Simon Mayo, the last of Radio 1's "old guard" still to have a daily show, quit the station yesterday for the more mature pastures of Radio Five Live.

Mayo, 42, who was heralded as a youthful antidote to veterans such as Dave Lee Travis and Simon Bates when he arrived in 1986, will host a daily afternoon show on the BBC's news and sport network. He joins a former Radio 1 colleague, Nicky Campbell, who presents the morning phone-in programme on Five Live.

The departure of Mayo has prompted a shake-up at Radio 1. He will not be replaced directly, but other presenters have been shuffled around the schedules to fill the gap.

Bob Shennan, controller of Radio Five Live, said: "This is a great signing for us. Simon is a tremendously skilled and intelligent radio presenter whose style is ideally suited to Five Live."

Following Mayo's departure, Radio 1 has embarked upon its first big shake-up since Chris Evans left. Jo Whiley moves from lunchtime to a 10am start, finishing with Newsbeat at 12.45pm. The Mark and Lard show is brought forward to 1pm, while Chris Moyles has been given an extra hour and will start at 3pm. Scott Mills's early breakfast show is being extended by 30 minutes and will be on air from 4am to 7am. Sara Cox's programme is moved back half an hour to start at 7am, but will finish at 10am instead of 9am.

Mayo will present his last Radio 1 show on February 16 and begin broadcasting on Five Live in May. His new programme will follow the format of the Ian Payne show, which includes an interview and live discussions. Prime minister's question time and sporting events will also be broadcast live.

Payne, Five Live's afternoon show presenter, will host a new daily sports programme. Sport on Five starts on January 1 and will be broadcast at 7pm.

fields.headline: Columnist leads Express exodus
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A star columnist and a respected political journalist led an exodus of staff from the Daily Express last night, a week after the paper was taken over by a soft porn and celebrity magazine publisher.
fields.body:
A star columnist and a respected political journalist led an exodus of staff from the Daily Express last night, a week after the paper was taken over by a soft porn and celebrity magazine publisher.

Mary Kenny, who also writes for the Catholic Herald, and political editor Anthony Bevins said they were not prepared to work for Richard Desmond's empire. Ms Kenny said his media stable, which includes Asian Babes magazine, OK! and the Fantasy Channel, "coarsened culture".

Peter Hitchens, a long-serving Express writer who takes a strong moral line in his columns, was thought to have handed in his notice.

The Science editor, Michael Hanlon, has also left for the Daily Mail. The managing director of Express Newspapers and another writer were also said to be on the verge of quitting.

The new management at the Express is understood to be surprised that the Daily Express editor Rosie Boycott, who has a strong feminist background, has not yet walked out. But friends of Ms Boycott said she would wait to be sacked, out of loyalty to her staff .

She has told colleagues that if she is dismissed, the new owners will have to honour the pay-off terms in her £350,000, two-year contract.

Ms Kenny left the paper yesterday. She told the Guardian's media website: "I just feel the new regime would not be compatible with my identity as a Catholic writer. That is the only real standing I have in my life. I don't think that fits comfortably with Mr Desmond's stable of magazines.

"What concerns me is the coarsening of the culture and from that point of view I cannot wish him well."

Mr Bevins said: "I don't want to work for Mr Desmond. I joined the Express from the Independent in 1998 because I thought that it was worthwhile to try to move the Express from being a rabid right-wing Thatcherite organ to something more responsive to the mood in the country.

"I am a serious journalist. I don't want to be doing anything that is not journalism."

Mr Hanlon was offered a job before the Express deal was announced.

Andy Jonesco, managing director of Express Newspapers, and Ros Wynne-Jones, a feature writer, were said to be on the verge of leaving.

Ian Monk, spokesman for Mr Desmond, said: "We wish them all well. Some people will leave, and other good people will come. That's the way it goes."

webTitle: Business: WH Smith hits back at Daily Mail group

fields.headline: WH Smith hits back at Daily Mail group
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: WH Smith last night accused Associated Newspapers - publisher of the Daily Mail - of potential breach of contract over its decision to cancel a £100m distribution deal.
fields.body:
WH Smith last night accused Associated Newspapers - publisher of the Daily Mail - of potential breach of contract over its decision to cancel a £100m distribution deal.

As its shares plunged 8% in early trading, the retailer issued a strongly worded defence of its decision to change the way magazines were moved around the country while denying that this would affect newspapers.

WH Smith officials admitted that the move by Associated would damage its bottom line but said it was unlikely to be as much as the £6m to £7m yearly that has been suggested.

The company said: "WH Smith believes that Associated Newspapers, in serving notice of its intention to cease using WH Smith News for the distribution of a large proportion of its newspapers from the end of May 2001, is acting without justification and in potential breach of contract."

WH Smith reiterated its view that it had taken no steps to change the arrangements for the distribution of newspapers "and has no intention of doing so".

But it made no apology for trying to shake up magazine distribution through a deal with Tesco and Safeway, claiming that the established system was inefficient and outdated. The company said: "Our view is shared by the British Retail Consortium, who represent a wide range of retailers."

Associated wrote to WH Smith on Friday saying that it was giving the contractual six months' notice of plans to cancel two thirds of its distribution contracts. Associated and other newspaper publishers believe that the move by WH Smith to change magazine distribution could put independent newsagents out of business and endanger the sale of newspapers.

There was speculation that trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, was going to be dragged into the dispute; WH Smith would not confirm or deny that it had called for a meeting with him. WH Smith shares ended the day down 32p at 421.5p.

fields.headline: Chivas Regal targets young drinkers with trendy makeover
fields.trailText: 8am: Premium Scotch whisky brand Chivas Regal 18 has been given a facelift in a bid to rejuvenate the brand's image, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Premium Scotch whisky brand Chivas Regal 18 has been given a facelift in a bid to rejuvenate the brand's image.

The move is part of an attempt by owner Seagram to appeal to a younger drinker in an increasingly difficult whisky market.

The company has already launched an advertising campaign and has revamped sister brand Chivas Regal 12 in a bid to make the whisky trendier.

Chivas Regal is a premium blended Scotch whisky whose main competitor is Johnny Walker, owned by UDV.

Seagram launched the 18-year-old version, Chivas Regal 18, three years ago in the US and it has since been introduced in Japan and Latin America. It is now gearing up for a Europe-wide launch.

The whisky market has been declining in recent years as young consumers gravitate towards white spirits such as vodka and tequila.

The difficulty for whisky manufacturers is how to attract younger drinkers without alienating their core market.

The new design, created by brand consultancy Identica, will aim to give the 18-year-old whisky a more sophisticated look.

Seagram Scotch Whiskies marketing manager Gustavo Clauss said: "Chivas Regal 18's new design captures the distinctive qualities of Chivas Regal, while informing the customer of the rare and special status of this premium whisky.

"By adding to the brand's aura of quality and heritage, we are seeking to build on the success of Chivas Regal and reinforce the brand's position as the perfect gift for the sophisticated whisky drinker."

Seagram is trying to sell all its drinks brands to concentrate on its entertainment businesses.

webTitle: Bell takes top editorial job at Guardian Unlimited

fields.headline: Bell takes top editorial job at Guardian Unlimited
fields.trailText: 8.15am: MediaGuardian.co.uk's executive editor, Emily Bell, has been appointed to the wider role of editor-in-chief of Guardian Unlimited.
fields.body:
MediaGuardian.co.uk's executive editor, Emily Bell, has been appointed to the wider role of editor-in-chief of Guardian Unlimited, the Guardian newspaper's network of websites.

The new position, the equivalent of an assistant editor's position on the newspaper, has been created to support GU's ambitious expansion plans in the coming year.

Ms Bell, who is on maternity leave until January, will be responsible for all editorial activities across the GU network, adding to her involvement in MediaGuardian.co.uk.

She will report directly to Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger and will work alongside Simon Waldman, head of Guardian Unlimited.

Mr Waldman will now focus more on commercial, technical and strategic development.

Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian said: "The increasing relevance of the internet has created the need for a new position at Guardian Unlimited to ensure editorial cohesion between the paper and its web operations.

"Emily has a wealth of experience and talent and is perfectly positioned to build on the huge success of the site."

Ms Bell was previously business editor of the Observer. Prior to that she was deputy business editor and media business editor. She joined the Observer from advertising trade magazine Campaign in 1990.

webTitle: Farr joins shortlist for top JWT job

fields.headline: Farr shortlisted for top JWT job
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Former BBC marketing chief Sue Farr is in the running for the job of chief executive of ad agency J Walter Thompson. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Sue Farr, former marketing chief at the BBC, is in the running for the prestigious job of chief executive of advertising agency J Walter Thompson.

A senior executive at JWT confirmed that Ms Farr has been in discussions with the agency and is on the shortlist of candidates for the post.

Other names in the frame include M&C Saatchi's joint chief executive, Moray MacLennan, and Brett Gosper, chief executive at Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper's.

Ms Farr's entry in the race comes seven months after she left the corporation following a shake-up by the new director general Greg Dyke.

Her career in marketing and advertising spans 23 years. She spent 13 years in marketing and advertising at companies including Mars, Heinz and WCRS before joining Thames TV as director of corporate affairs in 1990.

Ms Farr was director of the Marketing Society in 1998 and named advertising woman of the year in 1997. The glamorous Ms Farr is a regular feature on the advertising circuit and a prominent member of the Women's Advertising Club of London.

The source also confirmed that Nigel Long, chief executive at Partners BDDH, is not in the running and quashed rumours that Richard Hytner, chief executive at Publicis, is a candidate.

Whoever gets the job will take control of the UK's third largest ad agency and one that is a key player within the WPP network, the world's largest communications services group.

JWT counts some of the UK's biggest spenders among its clients, including Unilever, UDV, Kellogg's and Boots.

A number of internal candidates are also thought to be competing for the job, which was left vacant in September when Stephen Carter departed to join NTL, the cable TV and telecoms operator.

David Lamb, the agency's global business director, is understood to be a strong candidate.

JWT has long maintained a practice of promoting talent from within and some industry sources have expressed doubt as to the likelihood of an external appointment.

A senior executive at JWT confirmed that Ms Farr has been in discussions with the agency and is on the shortlist of candidates for the post. Other names in the frame include M&C Saatchi's joint chief executive, Moray MacLennan, and Brett Gosper, chief executive at Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper's. Ms Farr's entry in the race comes seven months after she left the corporation following a shake-up by the new director general Greg Dyke. Her career in marketing and advertising spans 23 years. She spent 13 years in marketing and advertising at companies including Mars, Heinz and WCRS before joining Thames TV as director of corporate affairs in 1990. Ms Farr was director of the Marketing Society in 1998 and named advertising woman of the year in 1997. The glamorous Ms Farr is a regular feature on the advertising circuit and a prominent member of the Women's Advertising Club of London. The source also confirmed that Nigel Long, chief executive at Partners BDDH, is not in the running and quashed rumours that Richard Hytner, chief executive at Publicis, is a candidate. Whoever gets the job will take control of the UK's third largest ad agency and one that is a key player within the WPP network, the world's largest communications services group. JWT counts some of the UK's biggest spenders among its clients, including Unilever, UDV, Kellogg's and Boots. A number of internal candidates are also thought to be competing for the job, which was left vacant in September when Stephen Carter departed to join NTL, the cable TV and telecoms operator. David Lamb, the agency's global business director, is understood to be a strong candidate. JWT has long maintained a practice of promoting talent from within and some industry sources have expressed doubt as to the likelihood of an external appointment.

fields.headline: The best massage scene
fields.standfirst: Charlie's Angels
fields.trailText: Charlie's Angels
fields.body:
Millionaire businessman Roger Corwin (Tim Curry), suspected of kidnapping rival mogul Eric Knox, is waiting for his weekly massage at Madame Wong's House of Blossoms. As he lies face down on a massage table, he talks on a mobile phone.

"He said what? 'Over my dead body'... Well, I can accept those terms."

With a grunt, he ends the call. Alex (Lucy Liu) enters, disguised as a geisha. He turns to her dismissively.

"It's getting a little chilly in here Yoko. I could use some warming up."

A look of repulsion flashes across her face.

"At your service."

"Good."

Corwin rests his head on the table.

"So, can we get started sometime this millennium?"

Alex applies oil to her hands, then runs toward the prostrate Corwin.

"Banzai!"

She lands, standing, on his shoulders. His back cracks loudly. He moans ecstatically.

"Oh yeah!"

She begins walking up and down his back.

"You're holding a lot of tension in your fourth and fifth vertebrae. Let me see if I can work..."

She jumps up and down on him.

"... it out."

He groans with pleasure, as she starts to massage his face and neck with her feet.

"Just by activating energy points, you can increase circulation, alleviate pain, or even..."

With her toes, she twists his head backwards. He begins snoring.

"... render a man unconscious."

See also: Pulp Fiction, Superman, Howard The Duck

Don't see also: 8 Women

Pointless trivia: Lucy Liu dropped out of New York University after studying for only year because of what she called its "dark and sarcastic" atmosphere.

webTitle: Israel washes its hands of boy's death

fields.headline: Israel washes its hands of boy's death
fields.standfirst:
General claims Palestinian bullets could have killed child
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A senior Israeli general waged a lonely battle yesterday to erase the stain that is the emblem of the Palestinian intifada: the terrified 12-year-old boy shot dead in his father's arms.
fields.body:
A senior Israeli general waged a lonely battle yesterday to erase the stain that is the emblem of the Palestinian intifada: the terrified 12-year-old boy shot dead in his father's arms.

At a Tel Aviv press conference, Major-General Yom-Tov Samia, the commander of Israeli forces in Gaza, where Mohammed al-Durreh was killed on September 30, released the results of an investigation that purports to clear his soldiers of the boy's death.

"A comprehensive investigation conducted in the last weeks casts serious doubts that the boy was hit by Israel defence forces' fire," his report said. "It is quite plausible that the boy was hit by Palestinian bullets."

Even in Israeli army circles, the investigation has become controversial, disowned by the chief of staff and criticised by MPs for compounding the army's biggest public relations disaster of recent months.

None of the more than 280 killed in the past two months has haunted Israel as deeply as Mohammed al-Durreh. His killing, opposite an army post at Netzarim junction, was captured in horrifying detail by a television cameraman, the most damning piece of evidence for charges by interna tional human rights organisations that Israeli soldiers have killed children and used excessive force against Palestinian protesters.

The death also became the engine of the protests, which have given way in recent weeks to well-planned guerrilla attacks on Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza.

Yesterday, the start of Ramadan, brought no respite. Israeli officials expect the violence to rise during the Muslim holy month.

Despite the weekend's meetings between Israeli and Palestinian security officials, there were bursts of gunfire near the city of Bethlehem last night, and continued recrimination over the death of five Palestinian men near Qalqilya. Israel accused the men of plotting attacks on settlers; the Palestinians said they were killed in cold blood.

Millions of television viewers watched Mohammed al-Durreh's final moments.

Although the Israeli army apologised days later, and admitted that its soldiers probably killed the boy, Gen Samia argued yesterday that it, and television viewers, all came to the same, wrong conclusion: that his men fired the fatal bullets.

Gen Samia's investigation makes no pretence at being thorough or impartial. He called it a "moral exercise", intended to show that "we are not the army that kills kids just like that".

He went on: "A picture was presented that turned things upside down, as if the Palestinians were the good guys and we were the violent ones."

But Gen Samia's investigation is arguably fatally flawed, since it was conducted under his direct supervision, even though, as Gaza commander, he is the man ultimately responsible for the boy's death.

He also admitted yesterday that the Israeli army "unintentionally destroyed" crucial evidence from the scene by razing the bullet-scarred concrete water butt and cinderblock wall where father and son vainly sought shelter.

His investigation made no use of the medical records for Mohammed, who was treated at Shifa hospital in Gaza, or his father, Jamal, who survived after being hit by eight bullets. There was no postmortem examination.

It did not interview the Palestinian cameraman who recorded the death for French television.

According to Charles Ender lin, the Israeli bureau chief for France 2 TV, it took more than three weeks for investigators to pick up a copy of the video cassette.

The army built its case on an elaborate re-enactment of the boy's death, for which the cinderblock wall rebuilt, and on analysis of the angle of gunfire, based on frozen images from the footage of Mohammed's death.

It also suggests that Jamal al-Durreh was a suspected collaborator, whose death could have been sought by the Palestinians, and blames the father and other locals for failing to rescue the boy.

The general said the bullet holes in the wall suggested that father and son were out of range of most of the soldiers firing from the Israeli bunker, and that it was "plausible" that they were shot by Palestinian gunmen firing from the side.

webTitle: G2: Maggie O'Kane on Bloody Sunday

fields.headline: One day in Derry
fields.standfirst:
As the families prepare to give evidence in the Bloody Sunday inquiry, Maggie O'Kane pieces together the tragic sequence of events through the converging stories of two young men

Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: As the families prepare to give evidence in the Bloody Sunday inquiry, Maggie O'Kane pieces together the tragic sequence of events through the converging stories of two young men
fields.body:
Gerard Donaghey was dressed in his weekend gear: a pair of tight Wrangler jeans, size 34 waist, 29 leg, and a matching denim jacket, a blue shirt and a blue jumper. He was 17 and had got his first job as a storeman in the Carling brewery in Londonderry. He liked keeping himself smart.

He sent his elder sister, Mary, a letter from prison asking her to buy the Wranglers out of his credit union savings. He had been released five weeks before Bloody Sunday, having served a six-month sentence for throwing stones at British soldiers - the mandatory term for the offence. And he had joined the Fianna, the young IRA.

Donaghey said he would have his rice pudding when he got back from the anti-internment march. He left the flat carrying his roll-up tobacco and lighter in his hand. His Wranglers were too tight to get anything into his pockets - even small change.

The city coroner would remark afterwards that the autopsies showed that most of the 13 bodies had soup and potatoes in their stomachs. Sunday lunch was important in the Londonderry ghetto of the Bogside. Afterwards the women who spent most of the week working in the shirt factories and producing between six and 10 children went to the cemetery to get away from their kids and have a cigarette in peace.

It was January 1972, the year Nixon faced Watergate and Mark Spitz won seven golds at the Munich Olympics. Twenty-nine years later, a £10m public inquiry into what happened will hear for the first time this week from the families of the dead and wounded. Their words will be recorded by stenographers using the computer software developed during the OJ Simpson trial.

Over the next year, three judges from Britain, Australia and Canada will preside over the presentation of 1,500 statements from the families of the victims, clergymen, soldiers, journalists and photographers. Already, the opening testimony of the Bloody Sunday tribunal is the longest in British legal history, lasting for 38 days and going on for one and a quarter million words.

About the same time that Donaghey was leaving the flat, Private 027 was pacing about the cement covered yard of the Protestant church on William Street. He was a radio operator with 1 Para, of the Parachute Regiment. Brutalised by Belfast and Aden, the Parachute Regiment provided the shock troops of the British army. They were brought in from Belfast specially for the Bloody Sunday march.

This is the story of the Paratrooper and the Rioter: a snippet of the 70,000 pages of evidence submitted to the inquiry. Two men, one 17, one 19, whose paths almost crossed one January Sunday in a place in and around Glenfada Park North.

Today Glenfada Park is surrounded on three sides by murky puddles and maisonettes with cracked windowpanes and peeling paint. On a nearby wall a giant mural of an IRA hunger striker shows him watched over by the long suffering Mother Ireland. Except for the video rental shop on the corner and a bullet hole in one wall the size of a small orange, it looks much as it did when Donaghey ran through it trying to escape from Private 027 and his unit.

Private 027 had been with the paratroopers in Belfast for six months. Their most dangerous enemies were the IRA snipers. "We were under sustained stress, playing mind games with an ephemeral enemy. Living in that environment gave rise to the expression 'Going ape'. Another term used was 'beasting', when pent-up tensions were released ... The prospect of going to Derry was regarded with some relish. There was the anticipation that we were about to be given the opportunity to confront the enemy," he said.

Except that the enemy - the IRA - had promised the organisers they would take the weapons out of the area for the march. At least one IRA man, however, did fire at least one shot at soldiers. The Guardian's Simon Winchester, who was there, wrote afterwards: "Most of us believed there had been one shot fired around 4pm." He also said the paratroopers came under machine gun fire after they started firing at the crowd.

British government officials had considered other ways of dealing with the young men like Donaghey who offended the sensibilities of the army and Protestant businessmen by declaring their ghetto "Free Derry". The no-go area was creeping street by street into the city centre. Another day, and the rubble barricade separating "Free Derry" from the army-controlled centre of town moved a couple of yards closer. A secret foreign office memo written by Adrian Thorpe, then 29 and now the British ambassador in Mexico, had included other observations on how to deal with Londonderry's troublesome Catholics: "Have always been in favour of encouraging the no-go areas to rot from within. There is no reason why we should not encourage the breakdown of essential services and the spread of disease etc."

The new military commander in Northern Ireland, Major General Robert Ford, recommended another strategy in a private memo to his commander, General Tuzo: "I am coming to the conclusion that the minimum force necessary to achieve the restoration of law and order is to shoot selected ringleaders."

Even that had fallen short of the demands of the Protestant businessmen in the town who met with Ford two weeks before the march, asking him to clear the Rossville flats at the heart of the no-go area where 5,000 people lived. "They also wanted curfews and shooting on sight," according to a confidential memo to Tuzo, written just before 1 Para was ordered from Belfast to Londonderry.

When Private 027 left the army, he took a cardboard box with him full of mementos and notes of his two years with the paratroopers. It included his diary of Bloody Sunday.

"We had blackened faces. We knew we were going through the rubble barricade, which was drawn back for us. I remember the intense feeling of adrenalin as we were swept along with events ... I do not think that anyone with any level of authority knew exactly what we were going to do after that. I think it was pretty clear that we were there for a special occasion ... 1 Para was the 'Rot tweiler' of the British army - as a unit is one of a range of tools for those in authority to choose from. If misapplied or directed either by senior commander or politicians, then that is where the responsibility must lay."

Donaghey, like most of Londonderry in 1972, went from school to the barricades to stone soldiers. In the Guild Hall in Londonderry today there are people - even among the legal teams and journalists - who were probably throwing stones that day. Catholics couldn't vote because many were too poor to own their own house and pay rates; a corrupt city council gerrymandered in favour of the Protestant population.

Civil rights were on the agenda in Londonderry just like everywhere else. Internment without trial polarised the British-backed Protestant ruling class and the rowdy, increasingly dangerous Catholics. Hundreds of young men were joining the Fianna - though Donaghey was the only one of the dead with any military links.

After Bloody Sunday, more than 270 people died in the worst single year of the troubles. A month after Bloody Sunday the official IRA, in what they said was a revenge attack, blew up a priest, a gardener and five cleaning women at the officers' mess of the 16th Parachute Regiment in Aldershot: women not unlike the Londonderry mothers and sisters who escaped to the cemetery on Sunday afternoons for a break from their children.

While Donaghey, the storeman, was waiting to be called up for the great fight for Irish freedom, he was seeing a girl called Hester, who was a Protestant. He was planning to propose to her.

Private 027 had no Hesters in his life. Belfast was a dangerous place for British soldiers. They were confined to base, sealed into a surreal and violent macho world with its own rites of passage. "Soon after arriving in Belfast, I received a beating from an individual who lived in a world I can't comprehend. He had all the attributes of a para: efficient soldier, excellent shot, and a top recruit.

"One day he took a sub-machine gun from the barracks and tried to rob a post office in Belfast. He was given five years and was dishonourably discharged." There were others that Private 027 remembers: a corporal called 036 who shot a Chinese waiter after a fight over the bill - and was considered a hero.

Private 027 recalled a discussion from before 1 Para left their army base for Londonderry: "I have a clear memory in my section of seven or eight of us being in barracks in our denims and T-shirts. Our platoon lieutenant came in. I don't remember all that was said at that meeting, but I remember it revolving around the possibility of getting 'some kills' the following day."

The highly paid, high profile barristers appearing in the Guildhall to represent the families of the dead are attempting to prove that the decision to send 1 Para into Londonderry was approved at the highest political level, that it went as far as the then British prime minister, Edward Heath. They insist that there would be no record of such a dramatic change in policy but claim that the architect, Maj Gen Ford, could not have sent his soldiers in on such a controversial mission without high level approval. Heath says he never saw any such memo and will come to the tribunal next year to testify.

On paper, hints that the army was about to resort to illegal means to subdue Londonderry made it as far as the high-level joint security committee. Its members included army and police chiefs and Heath's security adviser, who were told: "Following a meeting of local businessmen, certain measures were in mind with a view to putting down the troublesome hooligan element there. It may be very difficult to solve within the law."

Private 027 doesn't read or write memos, but he was there when Ford cheered his men into the Bogside: "Go paras, go go go!"

"I ran along the right-hand side of Rossville Street hunched over in anticipation of incoming fire," said Private 027. "I have no recollection now of any shots striking the road in front of me, but there may have been ... As one of my section reached the pavement ... he went down in a kneeling position, raised his rifle to his shoulder and without pause or hesitation commenced firing towards the centre of the crowd ... Within seconds other soldiers came on the scene, some kneeling, some standing, joining in the firing ... two people at the centre of the barricade that had been facing us fell within seconds of each other.

"One chap, I think he was a full colonel, ran up beside me pushing his way between two other soldiers who were firing, so that he could commence firing himself. He indicated to me that he thought what was happening was great. He was exuberant. I was as keen to find a target as anyone, but I did not see anyone with a weapon or an explosive device.

"I lowered my weapon and looked at the guys firing. I have a clear memory of consciously thinking: what are they firing at? - and feeling some inadequacy. What was I not seeing that I ought to be seeing ... I had the distinct impression that this was a case of some soldiers realising this was their opportunity to fire their weapons and they didn't want to miss the chance.

"I received a ceasefire order over the radio from Major Looden. I clearly recall him shouting, 'cease fire, cease fire'. I shouted out the order several times and moved from my position to the soldiers near me and tapped some men on the shoulder and shouted the order."

At least nine people had already been shot dead and a dozen injured by the time Donaghey ran into the grimy complex of maisonettes known as Glenfada Park North with dozens of others - all trying to escape the paratroopers.

After the ceasefire, Private 027's statement to the tribunal said the paratroopers kept killing. "As far as I am concerned, what occurred after the ceasefire was initiated by Lance Corporal F and Soldier G, who had a preconceived notion of what they were going to do that day. I thought it was their aggressive positive actions that incited a few other loonies to join in." The soldiers insist they found themselves at the centre of an IRA ambush.

"As I came on the scene there was at least one body down," Private 027 continued. "I saw a crowd of about 40 shocked and terrified people ... trying to get away. Some were frozen in a static huddle. I saw no civilians with weapons, no threatening gestures. I have an image of watching men about 10 metres away from me carrying the bodies away.

"I remember that the man in the pale grey guit was the last to be removed. I watched men in donkey jackets and flat caps who were very close to me, pick up the body and walk away. I remember wondering if I was supposed to be shooting these people."

Nine people were shot in Glenfada Park after the ceasefire. Four of them died there.

Donaghey was carried three doors away into the house of Raymond Rogan, chairman of the Bogside tennis association. Donaghey had been shot in the abdomen and was bleeding to death. Rogan tried to drive him to hospital but the car was stopped by soldiers.

He explained that Donaghey was wounded and needed to get to hospital. "Let the bastard die," said the soldier. A nurse approached and asked if she could help and the soldier, in his own admission, said: "'Fuck off Florence, this one is shitted.' I do not know if he was actually dead but he looked like he was."

The soldiers on the barricade then forced Rogan out, commandeered his car with the dying Donaghey inside and took him to a military headquarters, and from there to a detention centre. When his brother-in-law was called to pick up the body, four nailbombs, each roughly the size of half a brick, were lodged in the pockets of the jeans - the same Wranglers that couldn't take a pack of roll-ups.

Rogan said: "If Gerard Donaghey had bombs on him I would never have taken him in the house. It is one thing being helpful trying to save someone's life - it is another thing to put other people at risk, especially family. No way would I have brought him in."

Another neighbour, Leo Young, who helped carry Donaghey out, said when he was shown police photographs of his dead body with nailbombs in the pockets: "When I saw the photograph marked 'two', I simply could not believe it. I saw his body lying in the house. I helped to carry him to the car and I sat in the car with him for 10 minutes ... I was at his head looking down at his body. There is no way I could have missed the nailbombs shown in photograph two."

Private 027 spent the night after Bloody Sunday on a factory floor and early the next morning, back in Belfast, all hell was breaking loose. The army were accused of excessive force and killing civilians - but a damage limitation exercise was under way as soon as the firing stopped.

"Afterwards the mood in the back of the Pig [armoured car] was not so much euphoria as release of tension. There was almost a silence and a sort of feeling - Bloody hell, what happened there ... there was already a recognition that there was a problem that had to be explained away ... The whole point of the conversation was to sort out our stories and alibis prior to the ammunition check ... There was some serious thinking going on by people wanting to cover their arses ... The line the army took, that was passed down from our superiors, was that a number of the killed had been han dling weapons ... and there was strong evidence of weapons being found on a body and that weapons had disappeared."

Private 027 remembers being called in for a briefing with the army lawyers before he went in to give his evidence. "A couple of days later I was flown in a Sioux helicopter to Coleraine ... I was called into a meeting with a lawyer. The lawyer and I sat either side of the desk and he wrote the statement as I spoke.

"I described shooting from the small wall by Kells Walk towards the centre of the crowd behind the rubble barricade. The lawyer stood up and expressed surprise and said something like: 'We can't have that, can we private? That makes it sound like shots were being fired into the crowd.' I was very surprised."

There is no reason why we should not encourage the breakdown of essential services and the spread of disease etc." The new military commander in Northern Ireland, Major General Robert Ford, recommended another strategy in a private memo to his commander, General Tuzo: "I am coming to the conclusion that the minimum force necessary to achieve the restoration of law and order is to shoot selected ringleaders." Even that had fallen short of the demands of the Protestant businessmen in the town who met with Ford two weeks before the march, asking him to clear the Rossville flats at the heart of the no-go area where 5,000 people lived. "They also wanted curfews and shooting on sight," according to a confidential memo to Tuzo, written just before 1 Para was ordered from Belfast to Londonderry. When Private 027 left the army, he took a cardboard box with him full of mementos and notes of his two years with the paratroopers. It included his diary of Bloody Sunday. "We had blackened faces. We knew we were going through the rubble barricade, which was drawn back for us. I remember the intense feeling of adrenalin as we were swept along with events ... I do not think that anyone with any level of authority knew exactly what we were going to do after that. I think it was pretty clear that we were there for a special occasion ... 1 Para was the 'Rot tweiler' of the British army - as a unit is one of a range of tools for those in authority to choose from. If misapplied or directed either by senior commander or politicians, then that is where the responsibility must lay." Donaghey, like most of Londonderry in 1972, went from school to the barricades to stone soldiers. In the Guild Hall in Londonderry today there are people - even among the legal teams and journalists - who were probably throwing stones that day. Catholics couldn't vote because many were too poor to own their own house and pay rates; a corrupt city council gerrymandered in favour of the Protestant population. Civil rights were on the agenda in Londonderry just like everywhere else. Internment without trial polarised the British-backed Protestant ruling class and the rowdy, increasingly dangerous Catholics. Hundreds of young men were joining the Fianna - though Donaghey was the only one of the dead with any military links. After Bloody Sunday, more than 270 people died in the worst single year of the troubles. A month after Bloody Sunday the official IRA, in what they said was a revenge attack, blew up a priest, a gardener and five cleaning women at the officers' mess of the 16th Parachute Regiment in Aldershot: women not unlike the Londonderry mothers and sisters who escaped to the cemetery on Sunday afternoons for a break from their children. While Donaghey, the storeman, was waiting to be called up for the great fight for Irish freedom, he was seeing a girl called Hester, who was a Protestant. He was planning to propose to her. Private 027 had no Hesters in his life. Belfast was a dangerous place for British soldiers. They were confined to base, sealed into a surreal and violent macho world with its own rites of passage. "Soon after arriving in Belfast, I received a beating from an individual who lived in a world I can't comprehend. He had all the attributes of a para: efficient soldier, excellent shot, and a top recruit. "One day he took a sub-machine gun from the barracks and tried to rob a post office in Belfast. He was given five years and was dishonourably discharged." There were others that Private 027 remembers: a corporal called 036 who shot a Chinese waiter after a fight over the bill - and was considered a hero. Private 027 recalled a discussion from before 1 Para left their army base for Londonderry: "I have a clear memory in my section of seven or eight of us being in barracks in our denims and T-shirts. Our platoon lieutenant came in. I don't remember all that was said at that meeting, but I remember it revolving around the possibility of getting 'some kills' the following day." The highly paid, high profile barristers appearing in the Guildhall to represent the families of the dead are attempting to prove that the decision to send 1 Para into Londonderry was approved at the highest political level, that it went as far as the then British prime minister, Edward Heath. They insist that there would be no record of such a dramatic change in policy but claim that the architect, Maj Gen Ford, could not have sent his soldiers in on such a controversial mission without high level approval. Heath says he never saw any such memo and will come to the tribunal next year to testify. On paper, hints that the army was about to resort to illegal means to subdue Londonderry made it as far as the high-level joint security committee. Its members included army and police chiefs and Heath's security adviser, who were told: "Following a meeting of local businessmen, certain measures were in mind with a view to putting down the troublesome hooligan element there. It may be very difficult to solve within the law." Private 027 doesn't read or write memos, but he was there when Ford cheered his men into the Bogside: "Go paras, go go go!" "I ran along the right-hand side of Rossville Street hunched over in anticipation of incoming fire," said Private 027. "I have no recollection now of any shots striking the road in front of me, but there may have been ... As one of my section reached the pavement ... he went down in a kneeling position, raised his rifle to his shoulder and without pause or hesitation commenced firing towards the centre of the crowd ... Within seconds other soldiers came on the scene, some kneeling, some standing, joining in the firing ... two people at the centre of the barricade that had been facing us fell within seconds of each other. "One chap, I think he was a full colonel, ran up beside me pushing his way between two other soldiers who were firing, so that he could commence firing himself. He indicated to me that he thought what was happening was great. He was exuberant. I was as keen to find a target as anyone, but I did not see anyone with a weapon or an explosive device. "I lowered my weapon and looked at the guys firing. I have a clear memory of consciously thinking: what are they firing at? - and feeling some inadequacy. What was I not seeing that I ought to be seeing ... I had the distinct impression that this was a case of some soldiers realising this was their opportunity to fire their weapons and they didn't want to miss the chance. "I received a ceasefire order over the radio from Major Looden. I clearly recall him shouting, 'cease fire, cease fire'. I shouted out the order several times and moved from my position to the soldiers near me and tapped some men on the shoulder and shouted the order." At least nine people had already been shot dead and a dozen injured by the time Donaghey ran into the grimy complex of maisonettes known as Glenfada Park North with dozens of others - all trying to escape the paratroopers. After the ceasefire, Private 027's statement to the tribunal said the paratroopers kept killing. "As far as I am concerned, what occurred after the ceasefire was initiated by Lance Corporal F and Soldier G, who had a preconceived notion of what they were going to do that day. I thought it was their aggressive positive actions that incited a few other loonies to join in." The soldiers insist they found themselves at the centre of an IRA ambush. "As I came on the scene there was at least one body down," Private 027 continued. "I saw a crowd of about 40 shocked and terrified people ... trying to get away. Some were frozen in a static huddle. I saw no civilians with weapons, no threatening gestures. I have an image of watching men about 10 metres away from me carrying the bodies away. "I remember that the man in the pale grey guit was the last to be removed. I watched men in donkey jackets and flat caps who were very close to me, pick up the body and walk away. I remember wondering if I was supposed to be shooting these people." Nine people were shot in Glenfada Park after the ceasefire. Four of them died there. Donaghey was carried three doors away into the house of Raymond Rogan, chairman of the Bogside tennis association. Donaghey had been shot in the abdomen and was bleeding to death. Rogan tried to drive him to hospital but the car was stopped by soldiers. He explained that Donaghey was wounded and needed to get to hospital. "Let the bastard die," said the soldier. A nurse approached and asked if she could help and the soldier, in his own admission, said: "'Fuck off Florence, this one is shitted.' I do not know if he was actually dead but he looked like he was." The soldiers on the barricade then forced Rogan out, commandeered his car with the dying Donaghey inside and took him to a military headquarters, and from there to a detention centre. When his brother-in-law was called to pick up the body, four nailbombs, each roughly the size of half a brick, were lodged in the pockets of the jeans - the same Wranglers that couldn't take a pack of roll-ups. Rogan said: "If Gerard Donaghey had bombs on him I would never have taken him in the house. It is one thing being helpful trying to save someone's life - it is another thing to put other people at risk, especially family. No way would I have brought him in." Another neighbour, Leo Young, who helped carry Donaghey out, said when he was shown police photographs of his dead body with nailbombs in the pockets: "When I saw the photograph marked 'two', I simply could not believe it. I saw his body lying in the house. I helped to carry him to the car and I sat in the car with him for 10 minutes ... I was at his head looking down at his body. There is no way I could have missed the nailbombs shown in photograph two." Private 027 spent the night after Bloody Sunday on a factory floor and early the next morning, back in Belfast, all hell was breaking loose. The army were accused of excessive force and killing civilians - but a damage limitation exercise was under way as soon as the firing stopped. "Afterwards the mood in the back of the Pig [armoured car] was not so much euphoria as release of tension. There was almost a silence and a sort of feeling - Bloody hell, what happened there ... there was already a recognition that there was a problem that had to be explained away ... The whole point of the conversation was to sort out our stories and alibis prior to the ammunition check ... There was some serious thinking going on by people wanting to cover their arses ... The line the army took, that was passed down from our superiors, was that a number of the killed had been han dling weapons ... and there was strong evidence of weapons being found on a body and that weapons had disappeared." Private 027 remembers being called in for a briefing with the army lawyers before he went in to give his evidence. "A couple of days later I was flown in a Sioux helicopter to Coleraine ... I was called into a meeting with a lawyer. The lawyer and I sat either side of the desk and he wrote the statement as I spoke. "I described shooting from the small wall by Kells Walk towards the centre of the crowd behind the rubble barricade. The lawyer stood up and expressed surprise and said something like: 'We can't have that, can we private? That makes it sound like shots were being fired into the crowd.' I was very surprised."

webTitle: Ministers suffer party funding defeat in Lords

fields.headline: Ministers suffer party funding defeat in Lords
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The government last night faced a stinging defeat at the hands of the Lords - its 37th in the parliamentary session - as ministers struggled to rescue as much of their legislative programme as possible before the end of the longest session in recent history.
fields.body:
The government last night faced a stinging defeat at the hands of the Lords - its 37th in the parliamentary session - as ministers struggled to rescue as much of their legislative programme as possible before the end of the longest session in recent history.

As ministers steeled themselves for an anticipated showdown over the controversial sell-off of the national air traffic control system (Nats), Tory and Lib Dem peers voted by 199 to 136, a majority of 63, to demand tax relief to political parties for donations of up to £500 during a debate on a separate bill.

The government will try to reverse this in the Commons tomorrow if the political parties, elections and referendums bill is to become law as planned by the end of this week.

Peers have appeared increasingly assertive in recent weeks, inflicting defeats on issues as diverse as lowering the gay age of consent, the disqualifications bill and the transport bill.

As peers limbered up for a fight last night over the part-privatisation of Nats, the constitutional dispute highlighted by their rebellions looked set to widen today when Lady Jay, leader of the Lords and the shadow leader, Lord Strathclyde, clash over the next stage of reforms of the second chamber. The two sides are due to meet to discuss for the third time terms of reference of the proposed joint committee of both houses which will consider the next stage of Lords reforms.

Lord Strathclyde is insisting that a reformed second chamber should have a large elected element with full powers to act as a check on the Commons.

Lady Jay is insisting that the committee should look only at "parliamentary aspects" of a reformed second chamber, and focus on the relative powers of the Commons and Lords, especially the power of the Lords to block legislation.

The Conservatives believe the joint committee should also discuss the method of election of the second chamber, arguing powers and composition of the second chamber are inextricably linked. The Tories now favour a second chamber with as much as 50% elected.

Lady Jay insists the issue of composition and method of election have largely been settled by the royal commission into the future of the Lords chaired by Lord Wakeham. Lord Wakeham opposed more than 30% elected.

Without an overall majority in the Lords, ministers have suffered a string of defeats and made a series of concessions in an attempt to get their crowded legislation through in time for the Queen's speech opening the next session of parliament.

fields.headline: The right is in crisis and still Labour is running scared
fields.standfirst:
Blair is in a position of unprecedented strength - but he won't admit it

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Back in mid-September, the Anglo-American right believed it was winning hearts and votes. George W Bush was 10 points ahead in many polls, and Gallup said William Hague had eased into a five-point lead. The Labour party was plunged into the alarm that is far more habitual to its nature than arrogance.
fields.body:
Back in mid-September, the Anglo-American right believed it was winning hearts and votes. George W Bush was 10 points ahead in many polls, and Gallup said William Hague had eased into a five-point lead. The Labour party was plunged into the alarm that is far more habitual to its nature than arrogance. Excitable rightists proposed a benign and irresistible synergy. Bush would walk it, Hague would surge, and the secret longing of global electorates to be rid of the curse of social democracy, with its high taxes and big governments, would miraculously be satisfied.

Two months is not a long time in politics, but has plainly been decisive in destroying this dream. It has been a terrible time for the right. Not everybody, perhaps, has grasped how terrible. The synergy is working in exactly the opposite way. Of all the people who need to understand this, the most important are Tony Blair and his colleagues. This is a story not just about the future of conservatives.

Mr Bush now seems likely to be the next president, and no one would doubt that he's a man of the right, often the far right. He is pro-tax-cutting, anti-green, anti-government, the spokesman for big business against community values. But he won't be able to do much of what he talked about in the campaign let alone the primaries. Legislatively he's emasculated, politically he's hog-tied. He has no mandate and already seems to know it. The Gore-Nader vote supplied a majority for progressivism. Americans will not forget the most protracted lesson they've ever had in what majorities mean, nor forgive a president who ignores the ambiguous politics the count has yielded.

So there will be no surge that Hague can borrow from President George W. The times are not a'changing, as his own fortunes show. September's clamorous hostility to Labour from a fuel-starved country swiftly dissolved. Three byelections leave the government unmarked.

To have any chance of winning in May, the opposition should be 10 points ahead. But it is 13 points behind, clinging to the September blip as reassurance that Labour has no lead it can rely on. If the fuel rebellion had resumed, I might agree. When the question is not about petrol but about Hague's party, however, the verdict proves remarkably resistant to the bilious venom the Tory press has been evacuating for many months on Tony Blair.

This is not for want of effort by the press, or error by the government. Transport and health offer consumers and voters daily pain that shows how calamitously unsuccessful Labour's efforts to improve services have so far been. But the Tories are losing not gaining support as the rail crisis intensifies!

Despairing of Hague, the Mail and Sun hope Blair gets only a modest majority, and portray the country as the ruined creation of New Labour. Voters have more intelligence. Stolidly if unkeenly they know which side, in a hard world, talks most sense. It is perfectly obvious they have no intention of installing William Hague as prime minister. A lame-duck US president may be driven to make his conservatism seem more compassionate than he wanted, but he cannot make it travel.

Labour, in short, faces the election in a position of unprecedented strength. It doesn't like being told that. Just as the press wants to pretend the battle is tight, the party likes to be seen listening to the people and taking nothing for granted. Yet there's a cost in that strategy. It's as important to use power going into an election as coming out of one. A defensive campaign, when the enemy is already routed, would be a seriously missed opportunity.

Mr Blair is already changing his stance a bit. Too much was made last week of his suggestion that it was time to move on from Thatcherism. It once suited the right to call him Thatcher's creature, and the conceit was a political convenience he seldom challenged. The connection was always exaggerated. On public services, on the role of the state, on constitutional change, on Europe, Blair has never been a Thatcherite.

Nonetheless, last week's renunciation was that of a prime minister emboldened to banish pretences he has hitherto been happy to sustain. Attacking the "forces of conservatism", as he did at the 1999 conference, far from being his greatest error, came close to his real nature. It is still regarded by key people around him as the finest speech he ever made.

He is making room to repeat the message. Tax, he thinks, is a Labour issue, because the Tories abandoned their tax-cut guarantee and are left scrabbling round in no man's land trying to defend the proposition that they remain simultaneously committed to tax cutting and service expansion. The Labour leadership, though less candid than it's urged to be by this week's valuable report from the Fabian Society tax commission, is happier than it was in 1997 to go to the country as the party never known to promise tax cuts. Though 2000 might be called its annus horribilis, this was also the year when it began to feel at ease with its core tradition as the party of high spending.

So there's a decent chance of Labour using its ascendancy to make some confident statements in favour of what it stands for in one major field. What about the other one that really counts? Here the signals are less promising. Rather than using its extraordinary domination to take charge of the politics of Europe, it's in danger of handing that issue to the other side.

One still hears not only cabinet sceptics but cabinet europhiles say that all discussion of the euro should be avoided before and during the election. The reason for this reveals a defensiveness that's hard to credit. However badly Hague does, the argument runs, he is sure to win some seats. It will be important, therefore, to stop him claiming that even 20 seats, let alone the 40 Tory gains that would still be consonant with a smashing Labour victory, were attributable to his onslaught against the euro. By refusing to engage, these tacticians say, Labour maximises its chances of holding and winning the referendum they want to follow the election.

That's really said as a device to keep the Sun on side. The stronger Labour looks, the more pathetic such thinking seems. The government has already proved its resilience of its support to massive press attack, from the Sun among others, over Europe among other things. The leader of the opposition still puts Europe at the top of his battle-plan every time he speaks. So the Tories may soon be famous for only two things: as an anti-Europe pressure group, and the party that promises to let you turn left at a red light - a bewitching symbol of its intellectual paralysis.

Yet top Labour honchos are advocating that this should not be pointed out. They evidently do not understand the depth of the crisis on the right. They feel for ways not to mention the biggest question of our time, fearful that they might not carry the argument. George Bush was a loser behaving like a winner. He looks as though he's made it. How much worse for Tony Blair to be a winner behaving like a loser.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Snub of the day
fields.body:
Snub of the day

William Hague may live to regret not courting newest media baron, Richard Desmond - owner of the Daily and Sunday Express and the Star - by failing to respond to a request for an interview from Desmond for OK! magazine. "Hague said he would call me," said a miffed Desmond, "but he never did and if he can't return my calls then he is not the man who should be running this country."

Flak fielder of day

Keith Vaz, minister for Europe. He admitted to John Redwood that he is responsible for the "Eurogrid" - the advance warning system of any Euro developments that could cause problems for Tony Blair. He added: "There are no specific costs associated with work on the European news grid, which is compiled as part of normal working practices."

Today

Commons: Countryside and rights of way bill, Lords amendments. Lords: Disqualifications bill, third reading. Children (leaving care) bill, Commons amendments. Criminal justice and court services bill, Commons amendments.

fields.headline: Israel is defending the indefensible
fields.standfirst:
The settlements policy is immoral and should be abhorrent to Jews

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Wherever you are in the world, the global news TV channels follow you into your hotel room, blasting out the same images of the conflicts that fail to resolve themselves: fiasco in Florida, fury in the Middle East.
fields.body:
Wherever you are in the world, the global news TV channels follow you into your hotel room, blasting out the same images of the conflicts that fail to resolve themselves: fiasco in Florida, fury in the Middle East.

The yellow flares and white smoke from the West Bank and Gaza are less diverting than pregnant chads. We have seen and heard everything before, over and over, decade after decade. It is tempting to go on regarding the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians as a contest between sides who have equal and irreconcilable grievances. I do not believe that's true any more. South Africa was also an intractable problem, but there was a right and a wrong. The Middle East is moving in the same direction. Increasingly, this is a battle for liberation. The Israelis have turned into oppressors.

Yasser Arafat is not Nelson Mandela; Ehud Barak is not an Afrikaaner. The two men and their chief advisers know - have known for years now - what a peace deal could look like, almost down to the last detail. But they are also politicians. Barak is dependent on a pure-PR electoral system - which hands the balance of power to headbangers - and on Israeli public opinion, ever bigoted and self-righteous, and currently leaning towards voting Binyamin Netanyahu back into office again. What can you say?

Arafat has his own problems. Democracy in Palestine may be more inchoate than in Israel, but he is not - as both the Israeli public and the generals like to make out - a dictator, or even a master strategist. Until the breakdown of talks last summer, he was becoming increasingly unpopular for being too cosy with the Israelis. And right until this round of violence started, he was under pressure from extremist groups not to do a deal. Not yet eyeless, I saw it myself on the streets of Gaza. Israeli troops are on street corners, rather than policing a straightforward border, because of the settlements in Palestinian areas. These palpably fall within the intent of illegality intended by the Geneva Convention in 1949 (Convention IV, Article 49): "The occupying power shall not deport or transfer parts of its own civilian population into the territory it occupies." They are even more palpably an arrogant and immoral attempt at gaining lebensraum, which should be abhorrent to Jews above all people.

But latest unofficial figures (not officially denied), show that the budget for settlements has hardly been cut by the present government, and construction has started on almost 3,000 new settler homes in the 18 months since Barak replaced Netanyahu. That is on top of the day-to-day indignities. Of course, Palestinians are angry.

The Israelis are desperate to prevent a UN observer force diluting their military power. At the same time, they are acutely aware that one random act of grand-scale murder could unleash a full-scale war. If that happens, what do the Israelis think they would be fighting for? Freedom? The freedom to do what?

fields.headline: Straw cuts short secrecy debate
fields.standfirst:
Tories attack guillotine

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Freedom of information: Tories attack guillotine
fields.body:
Jack Straw last night imposed a guillotine to force the much criticised freedom of information bill through parliament after MPs tabled 118 last minute amendments to improve the legislation. The home secretary poured scorn on Conservative protests at his decision to curtail debate on the bill by accusing them of never wanting to introduce such reforms in 18 years of power. The bill, he said, had been subject to "extensive" scrutiny in both the Lords and the Commons. Without the timetable, there was no chance of getting the measure on to the statute book.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, blamed Mr Straw's "incompetence" for the timetable motion, which limited debate to four and half hours. She said: "The government has tried to pack far too much into too little time. It has hopelessly overloaded the parliamentary timetable. Now it has the choice to either lose bills or brutally cut parliamentary debate in a cynical way."

The freedom of information bill, she complained, would make "more things secret, not fewer..." and give the government "more power to withhold information". The home secretary also came under fire from Gillian Shephard, the former Tory employment secretary, for introducing an "illiberal" measure. Mr Straw accused her of believing "that freedom of information bills were only for oppositions - not for people in government".

Another Tory, Richard Shepherd (Aldridge-Brownhills) said the government was disposing of the most important means of giving legiti macy to the laws it created. "It is destructive of this House and its standing among those who send us here."

But Mr Straw's biggest critics came from the Liberal Democrats and three chairman of infleuntial backbench committees. Robert Maclennan, the Lib Dems' constitutional affairs spokesman and Simon Hughes, the party's home affairs spokesman, tabled two amendments - one extending the right of the public to know about facts behind government decisions and the other giving the public new rights about the release of information following accident investigations. This included stronger powers for the release of information on health and safety matters.

They won the backing of Tony Wright, Labour chairman of the public administration committee, David Davis, Tory chairman of the public accounts committee, and Robin Corbett, Labour chairman of the home affairs committee, who also expressed disatisfaction with the bill.

Labour backbench opponents who felt the bill was still too weak made it clear they would be supporting the government. David Clark, the former Cabinet minister, who saw his original white paper rewritten by Mr Straw, defended the need for the bill to get on the statute book.

David Winnick, Labour MP for Walsall North, said that the bill was still imperfect "but let no one think the Tories would ever have introduced freedom of information legislation if they were in power".

webTitle: Iranian hardliners accuse Britain of fomenting revolt

fields.headline: Iranian hardliners accuse Britain of fomenting revolt
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Iran's ultra-conservatives are accusing the British government of trying to overthrow the Islamic Republic by encouraging students and others to revolt.
fields.byline: Geneive Abdo in Tehran and Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Iran's ultra-conservatives are accusing the British government of trying to overthrow the Islamic Republic by encouraging students and others to revolt.

A series of articles in two national newspapers which serve as mouthpieces for hardliners accuse Britain of seeking to replace the US in trying to foment a revolution in Iran.

Although the foreign office supports the reformers in Iran, a spokesman denied categorically any attempt to stir up internal dissent. "There is nothing in that. It is just the right-wing press," he said.

He played down the criticism, insisting that much attacks appeared at regular intervals in Iran's conservative media.

As part of the latest campaign, the newspaper Resalat newspaper carried the headline "Civil disobedience by decree of London". The daily Kayhan, another conservative organ, has carried similar reports.

Opinion in Iran is divided between the hardliners, critical of links with the west, and the reformers, grouped round the president, Mohammad Khatami, and the foreign minister, Kamal Kharrazi, who favour opening up Iran.

Relations with Britain were restored two years ago after Tehran vowed not to carry out a religious edict against the author Salman Rushdie, even though many Iranian clerics say the fatwa still stands.

As a sign that relations between the two countries were getting back to normal, the foreign office spokesman said that two British ministers, Richard Caborn and Nick Raynsford, had visited Iran recently, and a new Iranian ambassador had arrived in London. The Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, has accepted an invitation to visit Iran next year, after an earlier visit was postponed.

The spokesman said there had been no change in policy towards Iran. "We believe it is important to encourage Khatami and the reformers. We are trying to do that while continuing to raise concerns about human rights and Iranian support for terrorism and reports that it is developing weapons of mass destruction."

The criticism of Britain began on Thursday, after an article in the Guardian reported that members of Iran's most powerful national student organisation had declared Mohammad Khatami's presidency a failure. It quoted student leaders as saying they planned to adopt a strategy of "civil disobedience" to force the adoption of Mr Khatami's reform programme.

It was followed by a report on the BBC. A cartoon in Resalat showed a BBC satellite dish sending messages to a crowd of Iranian protesters.

fields.headline: Diver clinging to boat 'snatched by shark'
fields.trailText: Forensic tests on the battered remains of a lunchbox and lifejacket will show whether a diver has become the fourth victim of a shark attack in less than three months off the coast of Australia.
fields.body:
Forensic tests on the battered remains of a lunchbox and lifejacket will show whether a diver has become the fourth victim of a shark attack in less than three months off the coast of Australia.

Danny Thorpe, 47, an abalone fisherman, was last seen clinging to his capsized boat a week ago by his fellow diver Howard Rodd, who survived by swimming 15 miles to the shore clinging to the lid of an ice-box, then walked another nine miles through mangroves to find help.

Mr Rodd said his friend's fear of sharks kept him clinging to the boat, which overturned in stormy seas off Ceduna, south Australia. His body has not yet been recovered, although wreckage from the boat has been salvaged for forensic examination.

"We expect the experts will be able to tell us exactly what caused the tears to the lifejacket and what took the huge chunk out of the side of the lunchbox," a police spokesman said yesterday.

Mr Thorpe went missing near where two surfers were killed by shark attacks in late September. Three weeks ago a middle-aged swimmer was killed by a great white shark in waist-deep water off a beach at Perth, in Western Australia. On average there is one fatal shark attack a year around the Australian coast.

At a tearful press conference, Mr Rodd spoke of his regret at leaving his friend to swim for help. "I stayed with him and we sat on the boat for hours and hours, but the trouble was we were blowing offshore."

He said his friend clung to the boat and refused to put on a wetsuit because of the belief that they encouraged shark attacks by making people resemble seals in the water.

Australia takes the world's biggest catch of abalone from the wild, worth more than A$100m (£37m) a year to the fishing industry.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Tom and Jerry

fields.headline: Animal magic
fields.standfirst: It was ultra violent, morally questionable - and aimed at children. But nobody ever said Tom and Jerry did us any harm. As the first new episode in 30 years prepares to hit our screens,  Stuart Jeffries explains why
fields.trailText: It was ultra violent, morally questionable - and aimed at children. But nobody ever said Tom and Jerry did us any harm. As the first new episode in 30 years prepares to hit our screens, Stuart Jeffries explains why.
fields.body:
In 1975, Tom and Jerry became the best of friends. Jerry sported a red bow tie and the pair went out together, sometimes hand in hand, to solve anodyne little mysteries. They never had a cross word, still less an insanely violent brawl. Garden rakes did not smack into Tom's face as he raced round a corner. Heavy irons did not plummet onto his head leaving a nasty mark that he would shake away before resuming the chase. Instead, a typical scene would involve Jerry, perched on Tom's head, tenderly brushing the cat's fur with a toothbrush.

This nonsense couldn't carry on for long. The New Tom And Jerry Show, which was screened on Saturday mornings on the ABC network in the US in the mid 70s, proved not only unpopular but nearly incomprehensible to viewers. No one wanted Tom and Jerry to become like Yogi Bear and Booboo. Ratings were properly lousy and The New Tom And Jerry Show was pulled after season two. It is rarely seen even in reruns nowadays.

That said, there is a website devoted to the proposition that this was Tom and Jerry's best series, that the slapstick animation reached its peak here. But then there are always websites devoted to the indefensible.

The sanitised Tom and Jerry had only been made by creators William Hanna and Joseph Barbera because cartoon violence was prohibited on the network on Saturday mornings.

All this is salutary stuff, because we stand, or even slump, at the threshold of the first new Tom and Jerry cartoon for more than 30 years. Let's hope it adheres to the principles of the classic 1940-1957 MGM era - to be exceptionally violent, preferably in a manner that would drive Mary Whitehouse to distraction.

A special seven-minute episode has now been created by Joseph Barbera. Called Mansion Cat, the episode will feature Barbera voicing the owner of a mansion which will be destroyed by Tom and Jerry. Not bad going given that both the protagonists are now 62. The Cartoon Network will present the world premiere as part of its regular 24-hour Tom And Jerry New Year's Day special, which also includes 161 MGM Tom and Jerry shorts.

But this seven-minute episode has a lot to live up to. After all, Tom and Jerry have won seven Oscars, and not one of them was awarded to mark their career achievements in being nice to each other.

The story was always the same. The mouse (Jerry) triumphed over the cat (Tom). How could this be? Because Tom lost his temper, while Jerry kept his. This was the most important lesson that Tom and Jerry taught: rage rendered one impotent in a conflict.

That said, there is still one episode that I cannot bear to watch. It's an episode released on June 14, 1947 called Dr Jekyll And Mr Mouse, in which Tom, turned basement chemist, invents a potion to make himself evil and super-strong. But before Tom can drink it and administer feline rough justice to the mouse, Jerry gets hold of a draught. He mutates into a muscley supermouse who turns on his attacker and beats him up thoroughly.

I found this disturbing because it flew in the face of the moral code to which we have had occasion to refer: the mouse should triumph, not through illicit pharmaceuticals, but through intelligence and sang-froid.

The best episodes of Tom and Jerry, made for MGM during the 40s and 50s, were underwritten by the flourishing signature of producer Fred Quimby that appeared on the credits. The infinitely inferior ones of the 60s were not.

As a homage, in The Simpsons, the Mayor of Springfield is called Quimby, and he has a dissolute son called Freddie (who can forget that marvellous cartoon moment when Freddie savaged a snooty French waiter for mispronouncing "chowdah"?). I love the Simpsons for enshrining this cartoon memory in its characters' names.

But the Simpsons celebrate Tom and Jerry better through Itchy and Scratchy, the extremely violent cartoon that Bart and Lisa watch on TV.

In the French-themed Let Them Eat Scratchy, Scratchy (the cat) chases Itchy in Tom and Jerry style, but then gets trapped in a guillotine. Itchy chops up his head and then puts a stick of dynamite into his skull which explodes. After watching this, Lisa and Bart sit back, laughing uproariously: children aged 8 and 10, whose favourite TV show is one in which a mouse does things to a cat that even Jerry in his most vengeful mood would not contemplate. It's a homage that works by taking Tom and Jerry to its logical conclusion.

Shouldn't we worry about this terrible impact of cartoon violence on children? Itchy and Scratchy laughs at the very question. It speaks up for all those children who watched the raw, violent Tom and Jerry but were not corrupted. No, we shouldn't worry: this is, after all, a parody. It's a pleasure to watch and not one that leads to copycat violence. Or copymouse violence.

 The new Tom and Jerry cartoon can be seen on New Year's Day on the Cartoon Network.
