fields.headline: Nationalists' rise shocks Romania
fields.trailText: Romania's efforts to catch up with other former communist countries on the way to European integration suffered a setback yesterday, when it was confirmed that the Christian Democrats, who lead the present coalition government, had suffered a devastating defeat in Sunday's election.
fields.body:
Romania's efforts to catch up with other former communist countries on the way to European integration suffered a setback yesterday, when it was confirmed that the Christian Democrats, who lead the present coalition government, had suffered a devastating defeat in Sunday's election.

The extreme nationalist Greater Romania party (PRM) came a close second to the leftwing Party of Social Democracy (PDSR), while the Christian Democrats failed to get a seat in the next parliament.

The former Communist and ex-president Ion Iliescu, who leads the PDSR, now faces the hard task of defeating the nationalist leader Corneliu Vadim Tudor in the run-off for the presidency on December 10.

Meanwhile the victors must persuade leaders of the European Union, the World Bank and the IMF, on whom Romania depends for urgent loans, that they are committed to the outgoing government's economic programme, which includes the privatisation of much of the economy.

The sweetness of victory for the Socialists was soured by their own failure to win a majority in parliament and the nationalist successes.

They must now court one or more of the three smaller parties which won seats in parliament: the National Liberals, the Democratic party and the Democratic Alliance of Hungarians. None has ruled out entering a coalition government against the nationalists, but each would demand a high price.

Most shocking to many commentators was the high youth vote for the extreme nationalists. fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • At this time of year, we must all take care not to upset children with unpalatable facts, as the acting editor of Radio 1's Newsbeat, Rod McKenzie, understands. Rod sent journalists a memo on the subject. "Please remember that a lot of children listen to us, especially at breakfast," reads his message to staff, "and we should avoid copy lines that suggest Father Christmas/Santa doesn't exist. Non-parents may laugh, but it really can cause upset among our youngest listeners." Indeed so. But how to illustrate the message? Well, where better, when thinking of the little ones, than a trip to death row? "In the case of the Texas death row man," he says, referring to John Paul Perry, the man with the mental age of six who spoke of his belief in Santa while awaiting a lethal injection, "I would suggest a line: 'he still believes Santa will visit him at the age of 44'." Mmm.

 At this time of year, we must all take care not to upset children with unpalatable facts, as the acting editor of Radio 1's Newsbeat, Rod McKenzie, understands. Rod sent journalists a memo on the subject. "Please remember that a lot of children listen to us, especially at breakfast," reads his message to staff, "and we should avoid copy lines that suggest Father Christmas/Santa doesn't exist. Non-parents may laugh, but it really can cause upset among our youngest listeners." Indeed so. But how to illustrate the message? Well, where better, when thinking of the little ones, than a trip to death row? "In the case of the Texas death row man," he says, referring to John Paul Perry, the man with the mental age of six who spoke of his belief in Santa while awaiting a lethal injection, "I would suggest a line: 'he still believes Santa will visit him at the age of 44'." Mmm.

 The BBC's commitment to preserving childish fantasies prospers elsewhere. On last Wednesday's Blue Peter, shot at York's Railway Museum, presenter Simon Thomas told viewers: "before the arrival of the train, travel across Britain was very slow and difficult." Ah but how long ago that seems today.

 While we nervously await a writ for calling Richard Desmond a porn magnate, the Express purchaser settles in. He has already done a tour of the Blackfriars HQ, during which he popped into managing director Andy Jonesco's office, and was so impressed he bagged it on the spot. "I don't mean to be rude or anything," said the lovable pornster, "but fuck off out of this office, I want it cleared in two hours." Careful not to lose dignity, the MD took the two black bin bags offered him, and was last seen wandering around looking for free desk space.

 While editor Rizla Rosie Boycott clings on (only out of loyalty to her staff; she's barely conscious of jeopardising her pay-off), Mr Desmond takes the big decisions. The Express has deployed internet "firewalls" to prevent staff visiting porn sites, for example, and these have now been lifted. As a tribute to Mr Desmond, the Diary is lifting its own porn firewall for the first time since Stuart Bell's Paris 69, and will feature one of his more upmarket titles (Readers' Wives, Asian Babes, or Forum) as inaugural Magazine of the Month.

 June Backen emails concerning chicken soup. "Re your mother's recipe, haven't you forgotten to add the vegetables?" she asks. "This is a very serious business," adds June. It is indeed - the WHO recently highlighted the medicinal power of the broth - which is why we mustn't get ahead of ourselves. So far we have 1) bought the boiler, 2) removed schmaltz, 3) cleaned and quartered it, 4) boiled it up in a full saucepan, and 5) turned down heat to let simmer while we skimmed the water at least three times. The next step, tomorrow, is giblets. The vegetables must wait.

 Speaking of vegetables, Sun showbiz reporter Dominic Mohan attacks Michael Jackson both for overactive lachrymals and his looks. "With a face like that," he writes, "I'd cry too." This is odd. It can't be all the alleged cosmetic work on Mr Jackson's face that disturbs him, since Dominic recently spent about £2,000 having his teeth prettified. Rumours that, with a TV career in mind, he is considering further surgery to uncross his eyes, are unconfirmed.

 An audacious sting ends unluckily in Richmond, Surrey, where a 32-year-old swapped a £55 price tag on pair of jeans in the Dickins and Jones store with one for £32. All went well when he paid the lower price, but his mistake was in then leaving behind both the jeans (for collection later the same day) and his real name and address. Following the resulting appearance before the beak, a fine and costs have boosted the cost of the denims to £182.

fields.headline: No: 1770
fields.standfirst: Jorg Haider
fields.trailText: Jorg Haider
fields.body:
Bless you. I said Jorg Haider.

Bless you. No, Jorg Haider ...

Ble ... The far-right Austrian politician, former leader of the Freedom Party and the man who has been dubbed the "pariah" of Europe.

Ah, right. That Jorg Haider. I wasn't aware there was another one.

I was thinking of the Austrian folk-singing sensation whose CD is released this very week. Indeed, they are one and the same.

Gracious! I had utterly no idea. It's absolutely true. To the accompaniment of cheering crowds, and the graceful melodies of the accordion, Jorg belts out traditional Austrian folk "anthems", with lyrics such as: "There's only one Carinthia/I want to thank God for our lakes and mountains/You won't find a sad girl here." But, of course, the record has absolutely "no political connotation", according to Mr Haider's producer, Erwin Jop.

Of course not. Haider is obviously just a man who loves his country. Particularly its lakes and mountains. And what better way is there to celebrate them than through the beautiful medium of song? Mmmm, yes, Haider is particularly fond of mountains. Indeed, when he reached the grand old age of 50 earlier this year, Jorg commandeered an entire mountain to celebrate the event. Thousands of Haider groupies were mesmerised by traditional Alpine songs, stunt fliers and an apple strudel that was the size of a house.

Wow! An apple strudel that was the size of a house? Well, it was probably more of a small chalet to be honest.

Still, that's pretty impressive. I'm not surprised Haider is doing so well at the polls. It's amazing what a bit of filo can do.

Any other political leaders that are likely to follow suit? Well, General Wiranto, the former security chief of Indonesia, crooned his way through an album entitled For You My Indonesia. And, of course, Clinton proved early on that he had a certain sax appeal.

Simply not available in the shops: Tony Blair sings the hits of Steeleye Span.

fields.headline: Llewelyn Thomas
fields.standfirst: Shy and witty son overshadowed by memories of his poetic father.
fields.trailText: The copywriter Llewelyn Thomas, who has died aged 61, was a witty, erudite and convivial man in the company of those he knew and trusted. But his life was overshadowed by the genius of his father - he was the eldest child of Dylan Thomas and Caitlin Macnamara - and by the feeling of abandonment he experienced in his youth.
fields.body:
The copywriter Llewelyn Thomas, who has died aged 61, was a witty, erudite and convivial man in the company of those he knew and trusted. But his life was overshadowed by the genius of his father - he was the eldest child of Dylan Thomas and Caitlin Macnamara - and by the feeling of abandonment he experienced in his youth.

At heart, he was a shy person. He dreaded appearing at events to mark Dylan's work and went out of his way to hide his background. Those who worked with him during the manic, inventive years he spent in London, at the advertising agency J Walter Thompson (JWT) during the 1960s, knew better than to talk about his parents. In Dawlish, the Devon seaside town where he settled in 1994, he was known simply as Tom Llewelyn; even his doctors were unaware of his true identity.

Born in Hampshire, Welly, as he was known affectionately by the cousins with whom he grew up, spent his early years in Blashford, on the edge of the New Forest, where the nomadic Caitlin had left him in the care of her sister Brigit, and their mother Yvonne, when he was only two years old. He was later sent to Magdalen College school, Oxford, a miserable experience which haunted him for the rest of his life. Through the trust set up to deal with his father's royalties, he went on to Harvard.

After graduation, he joined the advertising agency and rapidly established himself at the centre of its gang of eccentrics - the self-styled "wit and sophistication of JWT". He arranged mock seminars that aped those run by the management, and dreamed up anarchic games in which nobody ever seemed to know the rules or bothered to keep the score.

Thomas's work showed a similarly inventive and humorous streak. He was, say contemporaries, a brilliant writer with a totally original mind; he would be called in to work on new projects because he had such an unusual way of looking at things.

He won prizes for his Campari adverts, introducing the word "macerated" to bemused and less well-read executives, and came up with a macabre Kit-Kat storyline, in which mourners arrived at a wake to find chocolate as the only refreshment. The proposed campaign never took off, but the slogan "It has to be Kit Kat" was briefly taken up.

During the 1970s, Thomas worked at JWT's Australian offices, in part to get away from those who had known Dylan or who insisted on talking about him. On his return to England, he resigned from the agency by sending a telegram from the pub, and took up work as a gardener.

Just as abruptly, he left London some years later, and was eventually discovered living in a bedsit in Hull. He later travelled to Spain, where his gambling instincts won him almost £30,000 - on the lottery, according to one version of events; on a complicated accumulator bet on the horses, according to another.

Racing was certainly anabiding passion, as were games and quizzes of all kinds. At the time of his death, Thomas, who inherited his father's fondness for alcohol, was well placed in an internet share-dealing competition.

He read extensively, was a keen collector of books and loved writing. But his works of fiction did not meet with the same success as his copywriting. None of his science fiction or crime stories were published, and some felt the sharp wit and intellect so evident in his conversation did not show itself in his prose. Others, however, have been readier to praise his writing; a family member who approached one of the crime novels with trepidation found it a "well-researched, first-class whodunnit".

Thomas married Rhiannon Edwards in 1962, though the marriage was later dissolved. He is survived by their daughter Jemima. He spent his last years in the company of Fiona Green, a school friend of his sister Aeron, whom he met again at Caitlin's funeral.

 Llewelyn Thomas, copywriter, born January 30 1939; died November 13 2000

webTitle: Rail travel: PM warns of 'overreaction' to crash

fields.headline: PM warns on 'overreaction' to crash
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday voiced private fears that the rail industry may be overreacting to the Hatfield crash when he met industry leaders for a fourth time since the accident.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday voiced private fears that the rail industry may be overreacting to the Hatfield crash when he met industry leaders for a fourth time since the accident.

He and the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, urged industry leaders to speed up communicating information to passengers and to make sure a proper timetable was in place in time for travellers to plan for Christmas.

Mr Blair focused heavily on the industry's method of assessing risk and asked the leaders whether they had gone too far in response to the crash. He questioned whether they needed to take a more balanced view.

He said it was for them to make a judgment, but expressed fears that long-term damage was being done to the railways by the massive safety checks.

The industry leaders reported that 150 miles had been repaired, a third of the track required to be replaced. Over 260 speed restrictions had been removed and a further 139 had been lifted to 49mph. Mr Blair was also told that further speed restrictions may be lifted tomorrow, when the Railtrack board receives a further report from its engineers. The issue will also be discussed by the new Railtrack chief executive, Stephen Marshall, with the health and safety executive.

After the meeting, Richard Brown, of the Association of Train Operating Companies, said Christmas routes and timetables would be issued by December 4 and that passengers would be able to make reservations from December 7.

Stewart Francis, of the Rail Passengers Council, expressed frustration at the time being taken to get services back to normal. "Passengers are fed up and their patience is growing very thin. We need collective responsibility by the industry to accelerate the process of improving the railways," he said.

The meeting came as a new twist to the Hatfield rail inquiry emerged when crash investigators revealed that they have been examining couplings on the crash train for potential faults. They are concerned that the carriages did not remain upright after the crash. Part of the London-Leeds express came off the rails, hitting the concrete support carrying the overhead cables.

Investigators agree that a cracked rail was the main cause of the crash which killed four people. Great North Eastern Railway said last night: "The couplings met the required standards set by the health and safety executive and were fit for the purpose."

The Shadow Strategic Rail Authority has delayed announcement of a new franchise for the east coast main line, at present operated by GNER, pending further investigations into the Hatfield crash. The announcement was due last week.

Railtrack could also be at fault for the derailment of the London-Scotland express on Sunday in Lanarkshire. Vandalism has been discounted by crash investigators. The Virgin train, which had been travelling at only 15 mph, was diverted because of routine maintenance work.

fields.headline: Hamleys toys with selling up
fields.standfirst: As one famous name trips up over closed escalators, another reports signs of recovery for department stores
fields.trailText: As one famous name trips up over closed escalators, another reports signs of recovery for department stores.
fields.body:
A sale is being considered for Hamleys after months of uncertainty about the future of the 240-year-old toy shop in the West End of London.

Simon Burke, the chairman, yesterday said that he has called in merchant bank Close Brothers to explore a number of options, including offloading the world-famous shop into private hands.

"We are not able to say whether any offer is likely to be forthcoming," he added.

The announcement came after it emerged that Close Brothers has approached a number of venture capital companies on behalf of Hamleys.

Alchemy, narrowly the loser in the sale of Rover, reportedly said that it has been asked a number of times whether it is interested in making a bid.

Richard Ratner, of broker Seymour Pierce, suggested that news of the sale might have been leaked to provoke interest.

"I think Close Brothers have had this for the last couple of months and in our view it has been leaked to try and find a buyer," he said.

The likely price per share would be around 170p and not the rumoured £2, he added. This estimate would give the company a total price tag of about £35.7m.

The company employs 540 staff at 21 stores areound the country, including the Toy Stack chain.

In June, the company briefly entered into takeover talks with Charterhouse Development Capital, with discussions understood to be pitched around a sale at the 170p a share. News that these talks had broken down caused Hamleys' shares to plummet.

The company has also had to weather four profit warnings in the past two years, though this autumn it announced a slim profit of £9,000 for the 26 weeks to September 23.

This was despite largely flat sales during a slow period in the toy market.

Sales had also been hit by the fuel crisis, a reduction in tourist numbers this summer and disruptive refurbishment at the flagship Regent Street store, where escalators were out of service for five weeks.

The toy company said it had managed to turn around losses of £2.6m incurred in the same period the previous year. This had been done by improving margins and cutting costs.

At the time, Mr Burke hinted that the company, which floated in 1994, may not be best suited to the hazards of the stockmarket.

"We have already had to think about what we would do if there was a bid for the company and to consider whether it belongs on the stockmarket," he told the Sunday Telegraph. "Small companies need a good reason to be on the stockmarket. Yes, there's status and kudos, but there has to be more than that.

"If it needs to raise capital, or the proprietors need to dispose of shares or it needs to issue paper for a takeover, then fine. But if there is none of the above there has to be a question mark."

Yesterday Mr Burke said he was quietly optimistic about achieving reasonable takings during the Christmas period. But he added: "It will be hard work."

Mr Ratner of Seymour Pierce said the crucial holiday season was likely to be "OK, though not wonderful" across the sector thanks, in part, to Christmas Eve falling on a Sunday.

The shares last night closed 12p up at 143.5p.

Sales had also been hit by the fuel crisis, a reduction in tourist numbers this summer and disruptive refurbishment at the flagship Regent Street store, where escalators were out of service for five weeks. The toy company said it had managed to turn around losses of £2.6m incurred in the same period the previous year. This had been done by improving margins and cutting costs. At the time, Mr Burke hinted that the company, which floated in 1994, may not be best suited to the hazards of the stockmarket. "We have already had to think about what we would do if there was a bid for the company and to consider whether it belongs on the stockmarket," he told the Sunday Telegraph. "Small companies need a good reason to be on the stockmarket. Yes, there's status and kudos, but there has to be more than that. "If it needs to raise capital, or the proprietors need to dispose of shares or it needs to issue paper for a takeover, then fine. But if there is none of the above there has to be a question mark." Yesterday Mr Burke said he was quietly optimistic about achieving reasonable takings during the Christmas period. But he added: "It will be hard work." Mr Ratner of Seymour Pierce said the crucial holiday season was likely to be "OK, though not wonderful" across the sector thanks, in part, to Christmas Eve falling on a Sunday. The shares last night closed 12p up at 143.5p.

webTitle: Business: Brits go far to avoid tobacco tax

fields.headline: British go far to avoid tobacco tax
fields.standfirst:
One in three cigarettes are bought from smugglers or abroad

Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Soaring excise duty has encouraged British smokers to buy a third of their cigarettes either overseas or from smugglers, according to Imperial Tobacco, the maker of brands such as Lambert & Butler and Embassy.
fields.body:
Soaring excise duty has encouraged British smokers to buy a third of their cigarettes either overseas or from smugglers, according to Imperial Tobacco, the maker of brands such as Lambert & Butler and Embassy.

The company yesterday announced that its annual earnings in the UK were down £1m to £329m, although surging demand from the continent helped push up overall pre-tax profits by 13% to £450m.

Chief executive Gareth Davis said the environment in Britain "wasn't getting any easier", with few signs of hope that the government would reduce taxes.

Mr Davis suggested that the only glimmer of hope for the industry was that the British were "more exercised about excise" after protests against the price of fuel.

A 23% rise in international operating profit included a big increase in sales of cigarettes to British holidaymakers in Europe. They are now allowed to take home as many as they want for personal consumption. Imperial also reported strong business in Africa, Asia and Australia.

The company is hoping to inject some life into the British market by introducing a de vice which allows customers to make "factory-quality" cigarettes at home.

Gold Leaf Concept allows smokers to buy a pack containing tobacco, filter and paper for 20 cigarettes, together with a plastic machine which rolls the ingredients into well-rounded cigarettes.

Mr Davis said handmade products were becoming increasingly popular among cost-conscious smokers; tax on hand-rolling tobacco is about 65% in Britain, as opposed to 80% on cigarettes.

"As governments rack up excise taxes, customers are starting to search for greater value, and for ways to economise. In many countries, roll-your-own tobacco is an economy driver."

Imperial already owns Rizla, the leading maker of cigarette paper, and recently bought a Belgian roll-your-own business called Baelen.

Mr Davis said hand-rolling tobacco had always been popular in markets such as the Netherlands. He attributed this to Holland's tradition as a "great seafaring nation" and to a traditional lack of cigarette factories.

"It's a very, very longstanding thing over there," he said. "There is absolutely no stigma about roll-your-own cigarettes."

Imperial's shares rose 17.5p to 740p.

webTitle: Allders puts furniture in town centres

fields.headline: Allders puts furniture in town centres
fields.trailText: Allders, the department store group, is inaugurating a chain of town centre home furnishing shops which it hopes to expand across the country. The first three will open, in premises bought last month from C&A, early next year in York, Guildford and Kingston.
fields.body:
Allders, the department store group, is inaugurating a chain of town centre home furnishing shops which it hopes to expand across the country. The first three will open, in premises bought last month from C&A, early next year in York, Guildford and Kingston.

It will then look to take over stores from rivals in other towns and cities and stock them with homeware products and accessories.

Harvey Lipsith, Allders' chief executive, said last night that he was still interested in bigger acquisitions despite talks collapsing with House of Fraser and Bentalls.

He dismissed speculation that Allders itself could be under threat from Minerva, the property company which has built up an 11% stake. "I still believe that consolidation, if handled properly, is right for the market," he said. "However, no one player is going to make it alone. There's a need for a catalyst but I don't know where it will come from."

Mr Lipsith said Allders had a "good working relationship" with Minerva. He was convinced the approach was not masking a more sinister motive.

Allders yesterday announced full year profits, before tax and exceptionals, down to £13.5m from £14.8m a year ago. The 1999 figures were boosted by an extra week's trading and the company said comparable profits rose 5.5% with like-for-like sales up 2%.

The final dividend, to be paid on February 22, is maintained at 5p which makes a total of 8.4p when combined with the interim.

The news failed to set the City alight and the shares were unchanged at 104.5p last night. This is some way off the high for the year of 137p but comfortably ahead of the 85p low.

Mr Lipsith said department stores had been through a tough few years but there were signs of recovery. Rivals were now sprucing up their stores rather than relying on discounting to win customers.

webTitle: Business: Fed chief will remain key figure

fields.headline: The folly of falling out with Greenspan
fields.standfirst:
Notebook: Fed chief will remain key figure

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: So George W. Bush has decided it is all over bar the shouting. Most likely he is right. The Gore team will no doubt continue the battle but it is hard to see how the courts can provide the vice-president with the keys to the Oval office.
fields.body:
So George W. Bush has decided it is all over bar the shouting. Most likely he is right. The Gore team will no doubt continue the battle but it is hard to see how the courts can provide the vice-president with the keys to the Oval office.

Conventional wisdom has it that the financial markets are likely to prefer a tax-cutting, business-loving, Bush presidency. Putting more money in consumers' pockets, runs the argument, should boost the stock market. That, in turn, will suck in international investors who will have to buy dollars in order to acquire US assets. Nor are the economic advisers who cluster around Mr Bush likely to favour foreign exchange market intervention to weaken the greenback, whatever the wishes of, say, the European Central Bank.

There are those who argue that Mr Bush will be hamstrung by Washington gridlock at its most acute, but given the amount of pork in the barrel the president-presumptive should be able get quite a bit of his own way.

Yesterday's reception was hardly rapturous. The Dow managed a decent enough rally, though part of that must be down to the hope that an end to America's electoral marathon might, finally, be in sight. For the dollar, however, it was a day in the doldrums even though the euro remains the market's favourite whipping boy and Tokyo's political impasse makes the Washington version look a mere bagatelle.

In the longer term, the key to how markets will fare under Bush will lie in the development of relations between the White House and the Federal Reserve. For much of the two Clinton administrations they have generally been fairly good.

While the performance of the economy has no doubt made it easier for the White House to maintain a relaxed view of Fed policy - at least in public - there does seem to have been an awareness that being at loggerheads with Fed chairman Alan Greenspan is at best unprofitable and at worst counterproductive.

Whether Mr Bush has absorbed the lesson is open to question. One wonders what he would make of it if Mr Greenspan decided that tax cuts were providing too much of a boost to the economy and that a touch or several on the interest rate tiller would be appropriate. Markets would find such a tug of war unsettling.

True enough, it will be for the next president to decide if Mr Greenspan should be offered yet another term. But it is a double-edged sword.

Even if the Messrs Bush and Greenspan become economic soulmates (an unlikely scenario) Mr Greenspan may decide that, come the summer of 2004, he has done enough for the US economy.

Mr Bush might be able to ride out the loss of the Fed chairman to retirement even in an election year. Any suspicion that he had been pushed out and the Republicans would get a graphic reminder of just how many votes there are in the US bond market.

George Bush senior reportedly blamed Mr Greenspan for his defeat in the 1992 presidential race. It is not beyond the bounds of possibility that George junior may have a similar beef with the Fed chairman come the next election.

Cazenove shock

It would be fanciful to see yesterday's announcement from Cazenove as a long-delayed echo from the City's big bang. It is a shock, nonetheless.

Back in 1986, Cazenove - the bluest of City blue-bloods - opted out of the corporate marriage market which left plenty of firms and their buyers repenting at leisure. Instead it chose to keep its independence; to use its reputation and connections to carve out its own distinctive place (nothing so vulgar as a niche at Cazenove) in the post big bang City.

Much of that, however, is to change. Though independence remains non-negotiable, one or more outside investors will be invited to buy shares in the firm. Such a move on its own would be revolutionary enough. In the event, it is but a prelude to a stock market flotation, expected in 2002.

So what has caused the change of strategy? Cazenove acknowledges that being an unlimited partnership has its disadvantages. The new structure will have the advantage of being more easily understood by international clients; it will provide more resources. Crucially, according to Cazenove, it will allow employees to be rewarded with shares.

None of this is exactly rocket science. Whole legions of companies, for example, have long seen shares and share options as a handy way of rewarding - and keeping - staff. Cazenove's conversion, however, shows just how competitive the market has now become.

The interesting question now is how well Cazenove, where discretion is not so much a virtue as a way of life, will cope with the culture shock of the switch into the public domain and the scrutiny which is the inevitable accompaniment. Still, knowing how much you are worth will be considerable consolation.

fields.headline: AEA bales out of nuclear clear-up
fields.standfirst: Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
fields.trailText: The nuclear industry yesterday received a vote of no confidence when AEA Technology, a safety adviser to BNFL and the Ministry of Defence, announced plans to bale out of decommissioning and radioactive waste disposal.
fields.body:
The nuclear industry yesterday received a vote of no confidence when AEA Technology, a safety adviser to BNFL and the Ministry of Defence, announced plans to bale out of decommissioning and radioactive waste disposal.

AEA, the former commercial arm of UK atomic energy authority will sell off most of its nuclear interests to concentrate on rail and environmental projects in a move which has alarmed green campaigners.

The company earned £70m through sales in the first half of this year, but its chairman Sir Anthony Cleaver said: "Nuclear is a mature market and we do not see opportunities for significant growth as we do elsewhere. It is not a vote of no confidence, it is just a realistic response to what has been happening over the last few years."

Negotiations with potential buyers have started. The first sales could be completed within six months, but other parts of the business could take up to three years because of regulatory sensitivities. Companies such as BNFL, ABB of Switzerland and Siemens of Germany are thought to be likely bidders.

Environmental organisations said the move showed once again the dangerous legacy of the nuclear industry, which had been built up without adequate thought given to the winding down process.

Dr Helen Wallace, a Greenpeace scientist who specialises in the nuclear industry, said: "This leaves a question mark over who is going to be looking after the waste that currently exists and needs constant monitoring."

Other experts said they were surprised at AEA's decision, when the position of nuclear contractors was improving owing to to increased pressure on governments to clean up faster.

AEA has struggled since privatisation four years ago to make its mark as a fully commercial concern partly because of the decrease in volume of the government contracts originally committed to the company.

Last month the group issued a profits warning, and yesterday it announced pre-tax profits on ordinary activities of £2.7m, down from £8.9m. Operating profits slumped from £11.8m to £1.4m. Group turnover was constant at £171.9m compared to £171.3m, while the dividend remained unchanged at 3.8p. Shares in AEA, which hit a £10 peak in 1998, last night ended the day down 6.5p to 334.5p, close to where they started in 1996.

Analysts said that moving from a slow growth area such as nuclear waste to faster moving areas such as rail made sense. But they added that AEA shares would continue to stagger along at low levels until there were firm signs of the asset sales being completed.

The disposal programme will go hand in hand with measures to improve shareholder value, including the possible flotation of its intellectual property business, the search for joint ventures in its engineering software operation and the strengthening of its management team.

Costs are also to be cut, through more job losses. Some 50 mainly senior managers left AEA in the first half of the year, costing the company £1.9m in redundancy pay-offs.

The engineering software division recorded an operating loss of £1.9m. By contrast rail profits have been booming particularly in Britain.

fields.headline: 'Target banks' call on drug money
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Banks, bureaux de change and travel agencies that act as money-laundering fronts for the drugs trade should be targeted by police forces around the world, Keith Hellawell, Britain's anti-drugs coordinator, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Banks, bureaux de change and travel agencies that act as money-laundering fronts for the drugs trade should be targeted by police forces around the world, Keith Hellawell, Britain's anti-drugs coordinator, said yesterday.

Speaking at a conference, Drugs: an international dialogue, Mr Hellawell said that the collusion of financial institutions and countries that allow anonymous bank accounts with the drugs trade was a major obstacle to tackling the spread of narcotics.

"Rather than just seeing dawn raids on dealers and users of drugs, I would like to see dawn raids on a series of banks, travel agents and bureaux de change that front and launder this drug money," he told delegates.

Mr Hellawell said that the issue of laundering and financial support for the trade had only been "played with" and that it needed to be pushed to the top of the political agenda.

The collusion, either knowingly or otherwise, of financial institutions in the drug trade was seen as a major obstacle to tackling drug trafficking. Countries that allowed people to open bank accounts identified only by number offered crucial anonymity to the drug trafficker, Mr Hellawell said.

Such countries include Costa Rica and Switzerland.

"The first thing to do is to persuade countries and states that have these banking systems to adapt into conventions.

"Of course, if these states are in Europe but don't want to join the EU then it is hard to make sanctions work," he said in a veiled reference to Switzerland.

Often travel companies are established as fronts for laundering drug money, and exchanging it for other currencies is a way of cleaning cash.

In the UK, all regulated deposit-taking organisations - there are 554 - ranging from high street and private banks to solicitors, accountants and insurance companies, are obliged to disclose suspicious transactions to the National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS).

There is concern within NCIS, however, that 49% of all suspicious deals are reported by the four high street banks.

webTitle: Trains on time? You'll have to wait 20 years

fields.headline: Trains on time? You'll have to wait 20 years
fields.standfirst:
Senior transport executive admits some bidding companies have length of their contracts to reach 94% punctuality targets
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Weary rail passengers could wait 20 years before they can expect 94% of the trains to run on time, a senior transport executive told MPs last night.
fields.body:
Weary rail passengers could wait 20 years before they can expect 94% of the trains to run on time, a senior transport executive told MPs last night.

The admission by Mike Grant, chief executive of the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority, astounded MPs on the Commons public accounts committee who were yesterday hearing evidence on action to improve train services. The 94% figure was the rail companies' punctuality target before the Hatfield train crash.

Mr Grant - who is also director of passenger rail franchising - told MPs that he would be giving some of the train companies bidding for new franchises their entire new operating period to get their services back to normal.

But two operators - Chiltern railways, which has won a 20-year contract to run services out of Marylebone station to Aylesbury, Banbury and Birmingham, and Go-Via, which has a 20-year deal to run services from Victoria to Brighton and the south coast - had been required to reach this target within, respectively, four and 10 years, Mr Grant pointed out.

The latter company recently took over from Connex South Central which is losing its contract because services were running so late.

Mr Grant explained to an incredulous David Davis, the Tory chairman of the committee: "The huge investment in infrastructure that is required over the next few years will mean that it will take a considerable time to return services to the original standards of punctuality -which is why we are allowing this to extend to the period of the new contracts."

Mr Grant did, however, indicate that the new authority was going to sharpen the rules regarding trains that were very late.

He said the present rule that allows trains to run up to an hour late before anyone can claim compensation was going to be revised.

He also indicated that talks with one inter-city operator, Great Western, which runs services between London and Penzance and Bristol and South Wales, would include asking the firm to pay compensation when trains were running 30 minutes late.

One MP, Alan Williams,who represents Swansea West, described the strategic rail authority as "a joke."

"What exactly are you responsible for?" he asked.

Mr Grant replied that the authority was responsible for rail franchises, who owned the railways, and the agenda for the future.

He admitted, however, that it was not looking at scrapping the existing privatised system if it did not work.

He did concede that if rail directors faced corporate man-slaughter charges, this might change attitudes to running the railways.

Mr Grant replied that the authority was responsible for rail franchises, who owned the railways, and the agenda for the future. He admitted, however, that it was not looking at scrapping the existing privatised system if it did not work. He did concede that if rail directors faced corporate man-slaughter charges, this might change attitudes to running the railways.

webTitle: Commuter diary: Making tracks - destination unknown

fields.headline: Making tracks - destination unknown
fields.standfirst:
Every day this week, Yorkshire commuter Richard Culf will describe his experiences with Britain's collapsing rail system

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Every day this week, Yorkshire commuter Richard Culf will describe his experiences with Britain's collapsing rail system.
fields.body:
"Can I renew my rail pass for another month, please?"

"A month?" said the man at the ticket desk with a degree of incredulity I hadn't heard since Tony Hancock went to give blood. "Are you sure?" he asked, as if this was the most bizarre request ever made.

I nodded and handed over £60 - resigned to another four weeks of battling the odds to get to and from work - a journey of some 20 miles between Ilkley and Leeds.

My transaction done , another passenger rushed in to inquire about the elusive 06:44 to Bradford. "Cancelled mate - no unit, you see," explained the ticket clerk ("no unit" being a technical term often used in the railway industry to explain the regular mystery of train non-appearance).

And so started another week in the life of a West Yorkshire commuter. Boarding the 06:53 to Leeds (marked Bradford on the station monitor - as it has been every morning since I can remember) my fellow commuter's plight put me in mind of my own journey on the previous Monday.

I had expected trouble when I left home. A weekend of track remodelling at Wortley Junction outside Leeds had meant suspended services and what are rather endearingly termed "special buses", which did not auger well for a swift resumption of the normal timetable on Monday morning.

Getting on the train, everything appeared to be in order. Unfortunately, as so often is the case, everything was not in order. Track works had overrun, and a little while into our journey we were told we were not in fact going to Leeds but to Shipley, near Bradford, where a con necting service would be waiting.

It was indeed waiting - but in the form of a seatless bus (likened by one astute passenger to a sardine tin on wheels) now overflowing with disgruntled passengers. Maybe it would have been nice to tell us where we were going before we set off.

Late and fed up, I presented my now all-too-familiar apologies at work, two and a half hours and 20 miles after I had set off.

In contrast, yesterday's journey was uncharacteristically incident-free. Can they keep it up all week?

webTitle: Ski guide 'saw no risk' in avalanche alert

fields.headline: Ski guide 'saw no risk' in avalanche alert
fields.trailText: A guide involved in one of Scotland's worst mountaineering disasters discounted warnings of "considerable" avalanche hazards, a fatal accident inquiry heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A guide involved in one of Scotland's worst mountaineering disasters discounted warnings of "considerable" avalanche hazards, a fatal accident inquiry heard yesterday.

Roger Wild, 47, told an inquiry into the deaths of four climbers on Aonoch Mor that on the day of the accident he did not have a "greater feeling of risk" than any other.

The mountain guide insisted he had looked at the forecast the night before the disaster and although some areas were graded category three, indicating a considerable avalanche hazard, in other areas the snow was reported to be generally well-bonded and stable.

The tragedy, on the 1,220 metre (4,000ft) mountain in the Ben Nevis range in December 1998, caused the deaths of Emma Ray, 29, and her boyfriend Paul Hopkins, 28, both from Wilmington, Kent, and Matthew Lewis, 28, and Ian Edwards, 30, both from Dartford, Kent. They were killed when the avalanche struck as the party of Venture Scout leaders began a winter survival training course.

The group went out at 9am but were hit by an avalanche an hour later. Mr Wild, of Fort William, and two other climbers, survived after spending 16 hours buried under a wall of snow before being dug out by rescuers.

The survivors, Stephen Newton, 24, and his girlfriend Sarah Finch, 25, dug small air holes in the snow, enabling them to breathe.

Mr Wild later told the inquiry at Fort William sheriff court that he had visited the area where the avalanche occurred half a dozen times previously, when the risk had been graded category three or four, to carry out similar training, and had not had any problems.

On this particular occasion, he assessed the snow conditions on the slope, he said. "The conclusion I came to was there was no avalanche risk in that immediate area." Mr Wild said he started to instruct the group on how to use an ice axe and when it came to the stage where he wanted them to slide down the slope and stop themselves with their ice axes, he climbed a little further up to check the conditions again before trying the technique himself first.

He told the hearing he slid about five or 10 metres and when he came to a stop he was aware of a thin layer of snow coming down and covering his boots.

Mr Wild said he was then swept away before finding himself buried face down in the snow, unable to move.

"I shouted, but had no response and quickly remembered that sound doesn't travel very quickly through snow. I was not in a position to move.

"The most movement I could make was to scrape with my fingers. I did attempt to excavate with my fingers, but this was not even a remote possibility."

Mr Wild said that the next thing he remembered was hearing voices of rescuers. He began shouting and was quickly dug out.

He said he estimated the avalanche had happened at around 10.30am and he was dug out at around 1.30am the following day, leaving him buried for 15 hours.

He was taken to Belford hospital in Fort William where he was treated for frost nip to the fingers and possible kidney damage before being discharged on December 31.

Asked by procurator fiscal Derek Buchanan if he would do anything differently should a similar situation arise again, he replied: "No."

Mr Wild, who qualified as a mountain guide in 1992 and four years later founded his own mountaineering company, said he thought the avalanche could have been triggered by the considerable rise in temperature, from minus 2C at 7.45am to 2C around two hours later."

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: Boy, 12, gets £3.5m for car injuries
fields.trailText: A schoolboy who was hit by a motorist, who had been warned six times by worried local residents to cut his speed, was yesterday awarded £3.5m agreed damages to compensate him for his "devastating" injuries.
fields.body:
A schoolboy who was hit by a motorist, who had been warned six times by worried local residents to cut his speed, was yesterday awarded £3.5m agreed damages to compensate him for his "devastating" injuries.

Jamie Webb, now 12, was seven when he was knocked down outside his home in Bedfont, west London, in August 1995 by Richard Darbon.

The youngster and his parents, Lucy and Bryan, who now live in Wraysbury, Berkshire, were at the high court in London yesterday to hear Mr Justice Popplewell approve the settlement sum.

Jamie's counsel, Colin MacKay QC, said: "A speeding driver who had been warned not once but six times by local residents to be more careful about his driving through the estate, hit Jamie, and he suffered injuries of the greatest severity." He added: "His left side is fairly useless. His right arm is serviceable and his right leg is serviceable, but he now faces a wheelchair existence."

Judges found in Jamie's favour against Mr Darbon, of Bedfont, in August 1997.

Mr MacKay said the youngster had retained his happy pre-accident temperament, adding: "His character shines through his disability."

The judge approved the settlement figure and also a £40,000 payment to the family for their past care, hearing that they may take a holiday.

Outside court, the family's solicitor, Tom Cook, said that the speed limit in the area was 30mph. Mr Darbon was driving at 30mph or 31mph at the time of the accident. However, most of the residents of the estate thought the limit should be 15mph or 20mph. Mr Cook said: "There had been a 'kill your speed' campaign locally because there had been a couple of accidents involving children."
Press Association

webTitle: Police drop rape case against pop star

fields.headline: Police drop rape case against pop star
fields.trailText: Investigations into a rape allegation against singer Mick Hucknall were last night dropped 24 hours after he was arrested and questioned by detectives.
fields.body:
Investigations into a rape allegation against singer Mick Hucknall were last night dropped 24 hours after he was arrested and questioned by detectives.

Surrey police confirmed they would not pursue the complaint made against the Simply Red star, who was arrested on Sunday after a woman told police he had sexually attacked her.

The singer, 40, who has connections with the Labour party and has been involved in several government think-tanks, had denied the claim.

A police spokesman said yesterday: "Following the recent arrest of a 40-year-old man in connection with allegations of rape, following an investigation by Surrey police, it has been decided that this matter will not be subject to further police investigation."

Hucknall is the second high profile celebrity in a month to have been questioned by Surrey police in connection with an alleged sex attack.

Former Jam singer, Paul Weller, was arrested in October in connection with a rape alleged to have taken place in Farnham, Surrey, four years ago.

The star, 42, who was later freed without charge, expressed anger at the publicity given to his arrest and called for more protection to be given to those accused of such crimes.

He claimed that his reputation had been tarnished even though there was no substance to the allegation, and branded the legal system, in which only the alleged victim in a rape case is guaranteed anonymity, "grossly unfair".

Weller also suggested that the news of the charges being dropped would not receive the same prominence as that of his arrest.

webTitle: Arts: Pop stars and their influences

fields.headline: What, no Elvis?
fields.standfirst: Ask pop stars who influenced them and the last thing you'll get is an honest answer. John Aizlewood takes issue with the NME's new poll
fields.trailText: Ask pop stars who influenced them and the last thing you'll get is an honest answer. John Aizlewood takes issue with the NME's new poll.
fields.body:
Tricky customer, influence. The question of where your sound originates is one to be got through without attracting comment. Depending on whether you are a pop, rap or synthesiser act, whip out the Beatles, Public Enemy or Kraftwerk as an influence and nobody will bat an eyelid. Replace that holy pantheon with Billy J Kramer & the Dakotas, MC Hammer or Fiction Factory and suddenly you are as unwelcome as a live Phil Collins album.

This probably explains the results of a survey of current worldwide artists who were asked to name their influences by the British music paper NME. The results make curious reading.

David Bowie is the most influential artist ever, followed by Radiohead, the Beatles, Public Enemy, Miles Davis, Kraftwerk, the Sex Pistols, Eminem, Nick Drake and the Smiths. This leaves no room for Elvis Presley, James Brown, the Velvet Underground, Pink Floyd, Chic, Bob Marley, Joy Division, Led Zeppelin, the Rolling Stones, the Beach Boys, Hank Williams, the Clash, any blues artists, Motown, Frank Sinatra or, perhaps unsurprisingly, Fiction Factory.

According to the Collins English Dictionary, influence is "the effect of one person or thing on another". Therefore, merely liking someone is not good enough, nor is not wanting to get caught out.

Yet, on listening to the 18 artists who make up the British and American top 10s - the Beatles, Sade, Ricky Martin, R Kelly, OutKast, Limp Bizkit, Jay-Z, Offspring, Nelly, Westlife, Texas, Craig David, Coldplay, Enya, Steps, Robbie Williams, Whitney Houston and Eminem - there is little evidence that most of the NME's winners have any resonance.

Bowie is the safest of bets until 1984's Tonight. Several phases - glam icon, pale Berliner, wide-trousered funker - ensure that nobody selecting him will be ridiculed, unless they mention Tin Machine. Yet do we hear David Bowie everywhere? Hardly. Whole musical genres - hip hop, boy bands, alt.country, R&B - owe him nothing.

Despite occasional attempts at resuscitation, glam is long dead; the market for Thin White Dukes has never been buoyant; and Let's Dance was more of a Nile Rodgers than a Bowie effort. Listen for Rodgers's Chic today, though, and you will find them quickly: Texas, R Kelly, Whitney Houston, Craig David and Steps from the top 10ers.

Anyone with a reasonable grasp of a pop song is influenced by the Beatles. Fine. Elvis Presley, however, is seemingly too passé for inclusion, yet he influenced everyone who has made a record. Radiohead clearly begot Coldplay, plus some rotten bands who will be lucky to secure a deal. Did more artists not mention REM or the Velvet Underground? Apparently not. Public Enemy, deserving of an appreciative nod at best, have influenced many hip-hoppers, but Nelly, Jay-Z and OutKast are hardly ground-breaking colossi.

Miles Davis was jazz and had attitude, so artists are merely pretending to like him, and his supporters will be hard-pressed to hum anything from Kind of Blue. The wonderful Kraftwerk, far more emotional than popular perception has it, stopped influencing anyone after the mid-1980s synth boom waned, while the Smiths were many things, but never influential. The Sex Pistols weigh heavily upon Offspring, albeit not as heavily as the Clash, while Nick Drake is a bedsit Miles Davis: lovely, desperately moving, but resolutely unheard. And he was no Bob Dylan.

Perhaps a Florida-style recount may be in order. Then the top 10 would more likely be: the Beatles, Chic, Bob Dylan, Bob Marley, Elvis Presley, REM, Rolling Stones, Frank Sinatra, Velvet Underground and Hank Williams.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Somerset
fields.trailText: Somerset
fields.body:
A cottage dating from Cromwell's time, on the edge of a straggling village, was once the place where the cobbler lived and worked. What used to be his workshop is now a store and woodshed.

One morning recently, when the present owners lifted the latch and looked in, they were surprised by the sight of an elderly ewe with a patchy fleece and big areas of bare, blotchy skin. She had not just wandered in. Someone had put her there overnight, and made sure she was secure and comfortable. She had been suffering from "flystrike" and her hooves were in poor condition.

Flystrike occurs when blowflies lay eggs on soiled or sweaty fleece; maggots hatch from the eggs, burrow in, and feed on the sheep's flesh. Untreated, flystrike can kill an animal. But this ewe is safe and recovering.

Whatever her history, she is now fortunately placed, sharing a well-grassed former tennis court with a pigmy goat, well fed, and receiving expert veterinary care. The pigmy goat is one of four living in the cottage's grounds, which are, in effect, a sanctuary for small and smallish animals. Years ago a woman arrived with a female guinea pig in her pocket, saying that she simply could not cope with it. Other guinea pigs followed and multiplied. There are currently a dozen, some with young, awaiting placement in suitable homes.

In the middle of the nearby wood is a pond with two islands, inhabited by seven ducks, one tame enough to undo a visitor's shoelace. Ducklings on our village pond seldom survive the threat from magpies, crows or rats for more than a few days. But here, three years ago, when 11 duck eggs were laid, 11 ducklings hatched safely and grew to maturity.

 Steve Bell is on holiday

fields.headline: German murder suspects freed
fields.trailText: Three Germans arrested for the alleged racist killing of a six-year-old boy in 1997 have been released after a key witness made contradictory statements and failed to recognise two suspects in photographs.
fields.body:
Three Germans arrested for the alleged racist killing of a six-year-old boy in 1997 have been released after a key witness made contradictory statements and failed to recognise two suspects in photographs.

A Dresden prosecutor, Hans Strobl, said the third suspect had a solid alibi. The 15-year-old witness said the victim's family told him the suspects' names and gave him money, Mr Strobl said.

The suspects - two men and a woman aged 20 to 25 - were arrested last week in connection with the death of Joseph Kantelberg-Abdulla, who had an Iraqi father and a German mother. In 1998 the police concluded that his death was an accident, but they are now examining if mistakes were made.

Politicians were shocked by published extracts of witness statements collected by the family, who claim that Joseph was tortured, drugged and beaten by 50 neo-Nazis, who then threw him into a pool in Sebnitz, eastern Germany. Chancellor Gerhard Schröder showed solidarity and met the boy's mother in Berlin.

Prosecutors said they had no evidence that the three are involved in east Germany's burgeoning far-right movement.

Residents of Sebnitz have cast doubt on the neo-Nazi claim. "In their despair and grief, the family probably blurred the borders of reality," the mayor, Mike Ruckh, said.

fields.headline: The lie about perfect families
fields.trailText: This week my children learned that their family might have lasted longer if their parents had got married rather than just living together. Family breakdown surveys (a regular event these days) are always perplexing in our house since we - my two daughters and I - are under the apparent delusion that we still are a family, albeit one where the parents live apart. Our children have the audacity to feel normal: laughing and crying as well as succeeding and failing at very much the same rate as their more fortunate friends in nuclear units down the road.

Our children have the audacity to feel normal: laughing and crying as well as succeeding and failing at very much the same rate as their more fortunate friends in nuclear units down the road.

Never mind. I suspect their illusions will be shattered when they hit the "marriage/family/citizenship" lectures that our leader is so keen on promoting in schools. I could write the copy: family breakdown leads to poverty, depression and instability with educational and emotional damage to the children. Great. Maybe the next statistical survey that tries to quantify damage could consider how my children's confidence will be undermined by being labelled as unwitting suicide bombers in the grand social project of family happiness.

Since we're obviously the demons in this fairy tale, I feel less guilty about spreading further heresy by suggesting that our current notion of family is more propaganda than truth anyway. The history of family has been a constant process of a social evolution.

For much of the last millennia it was at its most secure when women and children were property and God was on man's side (this is not feminist revisionism, it is just fact). Then gradually we came to see childhood as a precious romantic, commodity and soon after that women learned how to spell inequality.

If you think about it, some kind of revolution was inevitable. How you tell it from there depends on your political persuasion. You can either blame 60s liberalism for destroying authority and breeding hedonistic irresponsibility, or you can attack consumer capitalism for creating an appetite that demanded two incomes and put work above the needs of child-rearing. If we could stop squabbling for a moment we might have to admit it was maybe a mixture of the two. But to admit that would mean accepting things as they are rather than trying to scare the genie back into the bottle.

But even if we try to rewind the tape how far back do we go? Not to the Victorian family, clearly - that was Maggie's fantasy and everyone knows she's barking now. So do we really mean the 50s? That never-never land when the family's job was to somehow make sense of the horrors of the second world war? What looked good in technicolor advertising was always a lie. You only have to consider the fact that Rock Hudson, the Hollywood icon of 50s marriage, was gay. What do we think actually went on in that bed with Doris Day?

If we can't go back, how to we go forwards? Well, that's not easy either, since even science is out to redefine the family now: surrogacy, sperm donation, designer babies, not to mention the latest revelation in IVF that there are children walking around whose biological father is actually their grandfather. Would someone like to tell me what exactly is a normal family these days?

At the last survey, some 25% of all domestic units are not ones New Labour would approve of. Of course the divorce rate has brought problems for parents and children alike. Marital breakdown is very painful (the right-wing accusation that it was all about hedonism makes me fear I might be a closet masochist). It can and often does bring emotional and psychological damage in its wake.

But with understanding and support both on a personal and cultural level the damage could be less rather than more, temporary rather than permanent. Some of us are doing OK. But when did you last read a story about happy achieving kids from divorced homes? When did Panorama ever come knocking on my door?

Of course, I'm lucky. I earn money. I'm middle class. I can play the system. (Are we really saying it's a question of money and class? I thought it was meant to be a moral crusade.) Yet the things that would make my family life easier money can't buy anyway: better state schools, better transport system, cleaner environment and some radical rethinking on our insane culture of work. For that you need a political revolution. So how about we settle for one thing now: a let-up from all the rhetoric which tells me that the sins of the parents will bring down destruction on my children.

Mind you, it is possible that by the time my kids hear the marriage/ family lecture in school they'll be stable enough not to believe it. But then questioning dubious authority is a mark of good citizenship. Thanks, Tony. I couldn't have done a better parenting job myself.

A titanic folly

For those paid-up members of the Free Valium for Christmas club, the news that the BBC has bought Titanic to plug that sinking moment between the pudding and family meltdown will come as a great relief. Given that it is three hours long and almost everyone has seen it at least twice, it is highly likely that most of us will fall asleep before we get to the Cathy-Heathcliffe bit in the water.

The BBC won't care. As long as you switched channels it will have been seen to have succeeded in its ratings war with ITV and therefore justified the reputed $10m it spent to buy it. (Though you may have to watch it half a dozen more times over the next few years for it to balance the books successfully.)

Greg Dyke's project is well known and easy to sympathise with. He, more perhaps than any other director general before him, has to square the circle of making the BBC popular enough to justify public money while making it distinctive enough to argue that it's giving a unique service. Easy, right? That used to be where BBC2 came in.

The "can't be got anywhere else" bit. So what does BBC2 have to offer for the festive season? According to the press release, it's a "leisurely" Christmas. We have a food night, gardening night, and a Christmas tree decoration night. (OK, one of those is made up but can you guess which?) For those who still aren't satisfied there'll be carols from King's, the Nutcracker and the three tenors. Meanwhile, for the really recalcitrant, serious lot, there's an Arena on Clint Eastwood and a documentary on spy fiction.

God knows it hurts to say this, but for the first time ever in the history of the BBC we have two women controllers of the TV networks and all they have to offer is Kate Winslet in wet clothes. Roll on BBC4, the BBC's new digital arts channel. Or when it says arts, does it really mean Ben Elton on books and Anthea Turner on magazine culture? Maybe Titanic doesn't look so bad after all.

 Charlotte Raven is away until January.

fields.headline: What lies beneath
fields.standfirst: Did Leonardo paint a saucy parody of his Mona Lisa? Jonathan Jones on why oil and eroticism mix so well
fields.trailText: Did Leonardo paint a saucy parody of his Mona Lisa? Jonathan Jones on why oil and eroticism mix so well.
fields.body:
Painting was sexy in the Renaissance. It was lascivious, lurid, voyeuristic, and indulged in spectacular fantasies. In paintings by Titian, Correggio and Giorgione, and even in lost masterpieces by Leonardo da Vinci and Michel-Angelo, women have sex with a swan, a bull, and a shower of gold. The god Jupiter, who takes on these forms in the stories by Ovid that they illustrated, also snatched the boy Ganymede (in the guise of an eagle, naturally) and Renaissance painters loved to paint that, too.

So we should not be surprised by recent headlines in the Italian press hailing "the topless Gioconda", a nude pastiche of Leonardo's Mona Lisa that art historians now claim was copied from an original by the Florentine master himself.

The painting known as Monna Vanna, painted by Leonardo's pupil Andrea Salai in 1515, has the Mona Lisa's smile, but she's naked, displaying her breasts. American art historian David Brown, curator of Italian Renaissance painting at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, argues that Leonardo painted a lost saucy parody of the Mona Lisa for his patron Giuliano de Medici, and that the Salai is a copy.

The erotic possibilities of the Mona Lisa have long been recognised as part of her fascination: just what is she smiling about? Whether or not Salai's Monna Vanna is directly inspired by Leonardo, it is another illustration of the central place of eroticism in early 16th-century painting. It was then that oil paintings started to be regularly commissioned for private pleasure. Leonardo's Leda and the Swan, destroyed possibly because of its indecency but known through copies, and perhaps his lost original for the Monna Vanna, are among the first examples.

What was it Renaissance viewers enjoyed about paintings that made them want to hang them at home? Was it the perfection of the perspective, the detail of nature? Perhaps. But maybe it was the sex.

When oil paint started to be used in the 15th century, it was an unprecedented technology for portraying flesh: it allowed bodies to be depicted as if they were present and graspable by the viewer. One thing it gave painters was the power to arouse.

Giorgione's Sleeping Venus (c1509) is not in the least spiritual: she's naked, asleep. She's painted with lingering sensuality. Correggio's Jupiter and Io (c1532) is outrageous: the naked nymph, with her bottom to us, is being groped by the god in the form of a cloud. Correggio imagines the impossible copulation with perverse detail: the soft, blue-grey cloud wraps itself around Io's hard, white flesh.

Eroticism is not incidental to these paintings. It shapes style as well as content. These are some of the first paintings in which paint itself, the sensuous experience of oils, is celebrated: they are paintings that break free from religious and other functions to declare themselves as hedonist visual objects. And the pleasure of paint is explicitly tied to other kinds of pleasure. Nowhere is this more evident than in Titian's mythological paintings, which were so popular that some of them exist in multiple versions made by the artist and his studio in response to demand: about 30 contemporary painted or engraved copies of his Venus and Adonis were made.

In 1837 the Duke of Cumberland gave five paintings to the new National Gallery in London but said they were unsuitable for public view. The museum agreed, keeping them away from the eyes of the crowd throughout the 19th century, in the privacy of the director's office. The paintings, including a copy of Michelangelo's lost Leda and the Swan (c1529), were not even acknowledged in the gallery's catalogue until 1929.

In the 20th century, however, Renaissance art was often studied precisely as a humanist sanctuary from the obscenity of modern art: paintings of Venus were seen as neoplatonic allegories. It simply was not done to call a Cupid a Cupid. Renaissance art's open eroticism is something we still often conceal, not by hiding paintings away, but by just not seeing it.

fields.headline: The blame game
fields.standfirst: John Prescott's ridiculing of France's environment minister, Dominique Voynet, struck a familiar chord with Hella Pick, former diplomatic editor of the Guardian. Here she explains why, when it comes to diplomatic warfare, females often take the flak
fields.trailText: John Prescott's ridiculing of France's environment minister, Dominique Voynet, struck a familiar chord with Hella Pick, former diplomatic editor of the Guardian. Here she explains why, when it comes to diplomatic warfare, females often take the flak.
fields.body:
Marathon negotiations are enough to try anyone's stamina. When they drag on all night, fatigue is inevitable and tempers fray. Irrespective of gender, the attention span of even the most eager participant is bound to shorten. Sometimes, sheer exhaustion all round produces agreement; sometimes it merely prolongs deadlock and stimulates the blame game.

The breakdown of the world climate change conference in the Hague has produced a sexist version of the blame game that should have been binned long ago - but alas, has not. When John Prescott, hardly the most disciplined of politicians, stormed out of the ministerial summit on Sunday morning, the inquest began almost immediately.

But it occurred to no one to suggest that it was Prescott's sex, his attributes as the male of the species, that must be held responsible for lack of insight into the compromises required to secure agreement on cuts in greenhouse gases.

For his part, Prescott had no problem in identifying the guilty party: it was easier to put the blame for breakdown on a woman's shortcomings than to analyse the real factors, in particular American reluctance to make any real sacrifices with emission targets. Never mind that Dominique Voynet was negotiating on behalf of the European Union, or that she had the backing of the French cabinet.

According to our deputy prime minister, the talks broke down because "she was exhausted and tired" and was unable to understand the finer points of the compromise that the US, with Britain's backing, was prepared to make. She was a woman and an easy target.

Understandably, Voynet believes the conference has introduced her to an extreme example of male chauvinism. In this case, two forceful characters have had a very public clash.

But of course this is not a one-off occurrence. Negotiations, almost by definition, are nerve-racking. Opposites have to be reconciled. Men, almost always in the preponderance, prefer the locker-room atmosphere and find women an intrusion when the negotiating becomes tough.

Of course there are exceptions, where men are prepared to recognise that women bring an extra element of patience and of insight, perhaps even of flattery and personal appeal, which can produce accord. But when negotiation goes wrong, such attributes count for nothing.

There is an old Jewish definition of anti-semitism: "When you ask who is guilty, name the Jew." The same, as often as not, is applied to women negotiators, when no agreement can be reached. Blame the woman, or flatter the woman, but whichever way, assume that women are somehow different in a negotiation and at best are unreliable.

In the foreign policy arena, senior women are still few and far between. Margaret Thatcher, of course, was always sui generis. But it is worth remembering that she became known for her "handbag" diplomacy - has any man ever become known for his "briefcase" diplomacy?

And there were some European leaders who were firmly convinced she became a little more pliable if they sent her flowers before a major negotiation. President Mitterrand went in for red roses. The Italians thought yellow blooms went down even better.

Israel's Golda Meir was another woman prime minister who provoked strong feelings in her negotiating partners. Her most famous clash was with Austria's chancellor Bruno Kreisky in 1973, after he had given in to the demands of Arab terrorists and closed down the Schoenau reception camp for Soviet Jews.

Meir flew to Vienna on a wave of worldwide protest to castigate Kreisky. He later claimed the meeting was so stormy that she would not even accept a glass of water. The Israelis said this was untrue. Far worse, however, it has since transpired that, at the time of the meeting, Kreisky already had some inkling that Egypt was about to launch the Yom Kippur war; but that he was so angered by what he considered to be a female tantrum about the Schoenau closure that he kept silent on the likelihood of military action against Israel from Egypt.

Within the diplomatic service, few women reach the upper echelons. Four years ago, Britain's most senior diplomat, Pauline Neville-Jones resigned from the Foreign service, convinced her superiors had refused her promotion on the grounds that she was a woman. She had set her sights on becoming ambassador to France and when that post was given to a male colleague who was her junior, she was sure she was the victim of discrimination and spoke out publicly. And the response? Sour grapes was muttered in high places.

Women across the Atlantic fare little better. April Glaspie was the US ambassador in Iraq in 1990 when Saddam Hussein was planning the invasion of Iraq. She has been widely blamed both for misinterpreting his intentions and also for suggesting to the Iraqi leader that the US would maintain a hands-off policy in his territorial dispute with Kuwait.

As a woman, she was not the right person to handle an Arab leader. It is certainly true that she did not realise Iraqi action against Kuwait was imminent: she was so reassured by her talks with him that she went on leave shortly before the invasion began. On the other hand, would a male diplomat have been less fallible?

And would he have stayed at his post, given that the message conveyed had not been something Glaspie had drafted, but had been instructions from the male secretary of state in Washington? The message she had been told to deliver was to the effect that Iraq and Kuwait should settle their difficulties on their own. There was no stipulation that a settlement had to be by peaceful means. Yet when events spun out of control, it was Glaspie who took the flak.

The United Nations has a few senior women, but the idea of a woman to head the organisation as Secretary-General has so far always been dismissed. There have been rumours that Sadako Ogata, the High Commissioner for Refugees, would have liked to stand in succession to Boutros Boutros-Ghali; or that Mary Robinson, the former Irish president and now UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, has aspirations for the Secretary-General's post. But almost as soon as those names have been mentioned, the idea has been quashed by male colleagues.

Ogata's ability as administrator and negotiator was questioned. Robinson, who was so popular in the Irish context, is now criticised in the international context for allegedly being high-handed, unwilling to consult, too protocolaire, a clothes horse and so on. Her proven abilities for conciliation, a prime requisite for the UN Secretary-General's post, are seemingly of no consequence.

Finally, there is little need to point to Hillary Clinton's efforts to overcome male distrust of her every move; though to be fair, there is no shortage of women who question her credentials for high office. No doubt her record in the US Senate will be put under an extra-sharp magnifying glass. But she has already given ample proof of her ability to fight back at male chauvinism - and if she has time to focus beyond the impasse over the US presidential election, Hillary Clinton will surely cheer on Dominique Voynet in her determination to twist the knife into John Prescott.

Finally, there is little need to point to Hillary Clinton's efforts to overcome male distrust of her every move; though to be fair, there is no shortage of women who question her credentials for high office. No doubt her record in the US Senate will be put under an extra-sharp magnifying glass. But she has already given ample proof of her ability to fight back at male chauvinism - and if she has time to focus beyond the impasse over the US presidential election, Hillary Clinton will surely cheer on Dominique Voynet in her determination to twist the knife into John Prescott.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Punjab hit by bomb attacks.
Three bombs exploded in eastern Punjab province yesterday, injuring at least 19 people, the police said.
fields.body:
Punjab hit by bomb attacks.
Three bombs exploded in eastern Punjab province yesterday, injuring at least 19 people, the police said.

Two bombs went off within minutes of each other in the capital, Lahore, seriously injuring nine people.

The third bomb ripped through a crowded market in a town north of the capital. No one has claimed responsibility.
AP, Lahore

Officer admits spying charge

A former Japanese naval officer, accused of leaking defence secrets to a Russian military attache, pleaded guilty yesterday.

Shigehiro Hagisaki, 38, a former lieutenant commander, was arrested by the police in September at a Tokyo restaurant after he handed over various documents to the Russian embassy official.
AP, Tokyo

Havel falls ill, halts schedule

The Czech president, Vaclav Havel, is suffering from a viral disease, and his official programme has been cancelled, his spokesman said yesterday.

Medical tests show he is developing pneumonia. The spokesman added that he was being treated with antibiotics at his residence outside Prague.

Mr Havel, once a chain-smoker, had a third of his lung and a tumour removed in 1996. He has been in poor health since then.
AP, Prague

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: No, really, it's fine. In fact, we're doing something else tonight. Something so exclusive, we can't even tell you about it. Sidelines would like to state categorically that we are not remotely interested in going to the Madonna gig at Brixton Academy, nor to pre-show dwinks, nor the party afterwards. The whole thing is totally last year-ish and we'd rather stay in playing with the cat. Not that we, er, will be.
