No, really, it's fine. In fact, we're doing something else tonight. Something so exclusive, we can't even tell you about it. Sidelines would like to state categorically that we are not remotely interested in going to the Madonna gig at Brixton Academy, nor to pre-show dwinks, nor the party afterwards. The whole thing is totally last year-ish and we'd rather stay in playing with the cat. Not that we, er, will be.

Meanwhile, have you noticed a lack of softness and gentleness in your life (which cannot be ascribed to lack of cat)? Do you insist you are right, dress in trouser suits and dismiss men's opinions as valueless? Are you "not just a nag but a character-demolisher"? Then, according to divorce-lawyer-about-town Vanessa Lloyd Platt, you are one of the Dragon Women, a terrifying new breed of female whose unbridled aggression and inner insecurity is destroying their relationships.

Lloyd Platt, who is happily married with two children, identifies a number of varieties of this monstrous character. Dragon Girls are young women who "believe boys and men are a waste of space"; Dragon Hunters "carry an aura of desperation and self-loathing and display inappropriate behaviour in social gatherings"; Dragon Spiters are "divorced or single women who ... have turned into man-haters". Recognise anyone you know? Thought not. Or has someone turned gender into a competition without telling us?

And surely one has to be a pretty tough cookie to have practised as a lawyer, while raising a family, while writing a book slamming your sisters. Or is Lloyd Platt simply her own model for www.women (that's warm, welcoming and wise, girls), the new millennial compromise she advises to guarantee health and happiness.

What insidious nonsense. Fortunately, Associated Newspapers are now on hand-holding terms with Hello! which means the Daily Mail soon won't have room for the likes of this, its pages being full of photographs of glamorous women, some of whom, doubtless, will be actual divorcees.

fields.headline: Britain 'backing US against world court'
fields.trailText: Human rights activists have accused Britain of giving way to US pressure and siding with Washington to undermine efforts to create an international criminal court to try those charged with crimes against humanity.
fields.body:
Human rights activists have accused Britain of giving way to US pressure and siding with Washington to undermine efforts to create an international criminal court to try those charged with crimes against humanity.

The claim came as the White House prepared to tell a UN conference in New York that the US would only sign the treaty to create the court if it was given guarantees that no American would ever be put on trial before it.

As recently as August the Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, opposed the US position, telling Washington that its objections were "misplaced" and that the treaty would not expose US military or civilians to vexatious prosecutions, as the White House and Republican congressional leaders believe.

Britain denies that it has weakened its approach, but human rights activists claim that it tried to block an effort by the EU to take a firm common stand this week against continuing US demands for exemption.

At an intergovernmental EU meeting in Paris on October 31, the British delegate Elizabeth Wilmshurst, who is Mr Cook's deputy legal adviser, opposed parts of a plan for European countries to unite in opposition to Washington's demand for Americans to be exempted.

The demand is among the key issues under discussion at the UN preparatory commission meeting on the international court, which began yesterday.

Campaigners say that a strong common position by EU members is crucial to resisting US efforts to secure an exemption. "A weak position by the EU will undermine the efforts of other countries to stand up to the US," Richard Dicker, of Human Rights Watch, said. "Britain is playing a dangerous game which puts the effectiveness and credibility of the court at risk."

British sources agree that Ms Wilmshurst successfully objected to part of a "lobbying note" drafted by France for presentation to the US. But Britain remained committed to the EU common position agreed in Paris, the sources said.

The US is one of only seven countries - the others include China, Iran, Iraq and Libya - which voted against the plan to set up the court, known as the Rome treaty, in 1998.

Pentagon chiefs oppose any attempt to put US service personnel under any form of international jurisdiction, and Republican leaders in Congress have made it clear that any treaty that failed to exempt the US from international jurisdiction would not stand a chance of being passed.

The court would be "dead on arrival" on Capitol Hill, the Senate foreign relations committee chairman, Jesse Helms, said earlier this year. He has even proposed legislation barring US officials from cooperating with the court as long as Congress has not ratified the treaty.

It seems unlikely that the US will ratify the treaty, even with the exemption sought by the Clinton administration, if George W Bush becomes the next president. The secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, supports the setting up of the court, but her prospective Bush administration successor, General Colin Powell, is not expected to agree.

Britain and the other EU states were among the 115 countries which signed the treaty. The court will come into existence when 60 states have ratified the treaty. So far 22 have done so, including France.

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why
fields.body:
Easy lover... Nice to see that with America still fumbling its way towards the installation of a chief executive, the man with his finger firmly on the tawdry, squabbling pulse of the nation has absconded from his homeland and headed for London. So yes, give it well and truly up for the arrival of Jerry Springer, priapic talk-show ringmaster and - lest we forget - one-time Democratic hopeful (before all that business with the hookers being paid by cheque banjaxed his political ascendancy).

And what could have possibly lured him away from the US? A quick guest slot on Richard and Judy? The first rustlings of panto season? No, it's Miss World, that grand old bastion of end-of-the-pier dimwittery, the 50th edition of which ageing roué Springer will be hosting, at - just when you thought it couldn't get any better- the Millennium Dome this Thursday evening. Me? Thanks for the offer, but I'm washing my hair.

Dog day... Meanwhile, on an altogether more savoury note, good liberal parents hoping to lure their offspring away from the impending horrors of Pokemon 2000 this Christmas may be interested to know that 102 Dalmations premieres early next week, with human stars Glenn Close and Gérard Depardieu in attendance. The screening is to be held at the Odeon Leicester Square, to be followed by a biped knees-up at Victoria Embankment Gardens.

Who likes short shorts?... Elsewhere, for those about to rock, you can salute yourselves when knuckle-scraping behemoths AC/DC (pictured) - you know, Australian, guitarist dresses like a schoolboy - pitch up at customs in readiness for a British tour starting at the Birmingham NEC this evening. For a rather fresher take on axe heroics, however, you might be better off with the inspired racket of And You Will Know Us By The Trail Of Dead, whose current UK tour continues until its finale at London's ULU a week Friday.

webTitle: Leader: Gore is right to fight

fields.headline: Gore is right to fight
fields.standfirst:
In the US, a constitutional crisis looms

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore is right to reject the Republican fix in Florida. The decision by the state's top election official and keen Dubya fan, Katherine Harris, to cancel Palm Beach county's revised returns, ignore numerous other irregularities, and declare the election for George W Bush is only the latest in a series of malign machinations.
fields.body:
Al Gore is right to reject the Republican fix in Florida. The decision by the state's top election official and keen Dubya fan, Katherine Harris, to cancel Palm Beach county's revised returns, ignore numerous other irregularities, and declare the election for George W Bush is only the latest in a series of malign machinations. The Texas governor's hard-faced cheerleaders have challenged the Democrats' attempts to secure an accurate tally every step of the way. The Bush camp precipitated this crisis by being the first to go to law, then escalated by moving the dispute into federal court. But when court rulings on hand recounts went against them, they resorted to appeals, delay, abuse and pressure on local officials.

Intimidation may have been a factor in the sudden decision of Miami-Dade supervisors to abandon the county's crucial hand recount. The Republicans disenfranchised thousands of people there by insisting on excluding ballot papers where, thanks to outdated equipment, the voter's intention was unclear in a machine count. They have cynically profited elsewhere from "butterfly" ballots and "dimpled chads" that led yet more thousands of Gore supporters to misdirect or spoil their votes. More sinister abuses, such as "lost" ballot boxes and discriminatory practices in ethnic minority areas, have in effect been allowed to stand by Ms Harris's decision. Even as they attempt to celebrate this sullied, unsafe "victory", the Bushmen remain intent on drawing in the nation's highest judicial authority, the US Supreme Court, to buttress their bogus, anti-democratic tactics. Mr Gore is right to fight on because, simply put, he almost certainly won Florida on November 7 and a fair and accurate return would confirm that view.

All the same, Americans, until now for the most part wallowing serenely in a sea of complacency, must finally be awakening to the prospect of a full-blown constitutional crisis. How else to describe a situation in which the election is over, in theory, but the outcome, in practice, is fundamentally disputed?

For consider: the popular vote went to one candidate, the electoral college (possibly) to another. Congress, like the country, is almost exactly split, politically, ideologically, and geographically. The executive branch is impotent, the transition is paralysed, and an inauguration boycott is threatened. Absurdly, Mr Gore or Mr Bush's running mate, Dick Cheney (if he is well enough), could cast a deciding vote in the Senate if the electoral college returns are disputed and, perhaps, deliberately manipulated for partisan reasons. In Florida, the courts and legislature are at each other's throats as Republican election officials and politicians accuse Democratic judges of bias. In Washington, a Supreme Court staffed by political appointees whose conservative-dominated outlook was itself a contentious campaign issue is now asked to decide whether the Florida vote was fair. Each day, the antagonists' language grows more divisive and rebarbative. And still there is no finishing line.

So much for the separation of powers, for all those famous checks and balances. Even if Mr Bush wanted to do the decent thing, if a final, reliable Florida tally went against him, the Reagan era retreads around him, and business and defence interests beyond, simply would not let him. After eight years, the GOP wants the White House too badly to let go. Outraged by the Republican fixers, Mr Gore is now far more determined to fight than he was on election night. Despite the uncharted, scary ramifications, he can do no other. If this does not all add up to a constitutional crisis, what on earth does?

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Subway | The Night Porter | Breaker Morant | Lust for Life
fields.body:
Subway

(Luc Besson, 1985)

10pm, FilmFour

Not one to hang about, Besson opens at full blast, with a blond-haired Christopher Lambert, pursued by hoods in big black cars, kamikaze-driving his way out of trouble, doing more for little Renaults than Nicole ever could. The action doesn't live up to that helter-skelter opening, and unlike his Nikita, Besson never quite distracts us from the silliness of the plot: wooden Lambert, hiding out in the subway, doesn't engage like Anne Parillaud. But for sheer style, Besson's right on the money.

The Night Porter

(Liliana Cavani, 1974)

12.05am, FilmFour

In a Viennese hotel in 1957, musician's wife Charlotte Rampling (pictured) encounters Dirk Bogarde's furtive night porter. They lurch back into their sado-masochistic relationship of the war, when he was an SS officer, she a prison camp inmate. The performances are fine in a wan and haunted way but the film drifts around notions of dominance and submission and settles for bouts of doom-laden, melancholic sex.

Breaker Morant

(Bruce Beresford, 1979)

1am, Carlton Cinema

Boer war drama about three Australian officers - Bryan Brown, Edward Woodward, Lewis Fitzgerald - courtmartialled for executing prisoners. Extenuating circumstances emerge during the trial, but it is expedient for the authorities to convict the trio. Movingly told, with a quiet sense of outrage; Jack Thompson as the defending officer is pick of a strong cast.

Lust For Life

(Vincente Minnelli, 1956)

1am, TCM

An intense and dedicated performance from Kirk Douglas drives this unusually astute biopic about Vincent Van Gogh. Douglas learned to paint for the role, but the real energy is in his anguished depiction of the artist's tormented psyche, a man constantly on the edge of breakdown. Minnelli, who blends many of the paintings into the narrative, fashions a complex if overheated picture of both man and artist, and there's a fine performance too from Anthony Quinn as Gauguin.

fields.headline: New inquiry into Kohl's finances
fields.standfirst: Special report: the German corruption scandal
fields.trailText: The discredited former German chancellor Helmut Kohl may face new corruption charges. State prosecutors announced yesterday that he was being investigated on suspicion of using more than £77,000 of party funds as personal spending money.
fields.body:
The discredited former German chancellor Helmut Kohl may face new corruption charges. State prosecutors announced yesterday that he was being investigated on suspicion of using more than £77,000 of party funds as personal spending money.

Prosecutors in Bonn said they had decided to begin a new inquiry into Mr Kohl's financial dealings after obtaining evidence which suggested that he had used part of a £300,000 internal party cash transfer to spend on "what he thought fit".

The cash was transferred in installments from the Christian Democrat's parliamentary party to the party proper in 1997-98, when Mr Kohl was chancellor. He is alleged to have spent £77,000 without offering any official explanation.

Mr Kohl's lawyer, Stephan Hothoff-Pförtner, dismissed the new investigation, saying: "It is simply the completion of a legal formality. It has nothing to do with new allegations."

But the Bonn chief prosecutor, Bernd König, said the new inquiry was being treated as separate from the previous one, which revealed that Mr Kohl had illegally channelled more than £600,000 of undisclosed donations into party funds. On Friday his office applied to have Mr Kohl's immunity from prosecution as an MP lifted.

The new investigation is a setback for Mr Kohl, who has being trying to rehabilitate himself as the "unification chancellor" since returning to parliament in September.

Last week newspapers began serialising his diary, which provides a personal account of the events surrounding the scandal that engulfed him a year ago. He used the diary to launch an attack on the current CDU leadership, accusing it of playing a behind-the scenes "game" to oust him.

Biographers have questioned Mr Kohl's claim that the diary was written at the time of the scandal. They say its style suggests that it was written long afterwards as part of a deliberate ploy to gain public sympathy.

webTitle: Sting in the tail for Reed

fields.headline: Sting in the tail for Reed
fields.trailText: Reed Elsevier's acquisition of US textbook publisher Harcourt General has been applauded by shareholders and analysts alike. Since it was unveiled back in October, Reed shares, up 27p to 681p yesterday, have risen 15% as analysts rushed to heap lavish praise on the deal.
fields.body:
Reed Elsevier's acquisition of US textbook publisher Harcourt General has been applauded by shareholders and analysts alike. Since it was unveiled back in October, Reed shares, up 27p to 681p yesterday, have risen 15% as analysts rushed to heap lavish praise on the deal.

Deutsche Bank has become the latest broker to wax lyrical on the strategic merits of the deal. Setting a 2001 price target of 800p, it hailed the purchase as a big step for Reed in achieving its growth targets.

The deal could have a sting in the tail. Reed acquired Harcourt for $4.5bn cash and the assumption of $1.2bn debt. Although it is selling businesses worth $2.06bn to Canada's Thomson Corporation, it financed the deal through a $6.5bn banking facility. fields.headline: A warm feeling for Debenhams
fields.trailText: It would be perhaps fair to say that when Terry Green, the highly respected chief executive of Debenhams, left the company in September most City pundits were not predicting a near 50% rise in the shares. In fact, on the day Mr Green left the price tumbled 8%.
fields.body:
It would be perhaps fair to say that when Terry Green, the highly respected chief executive of Debenhams, left the company in September most City pundits were not predicting a near 50% rise in the shares. In fact, on the day Mr Green left the price tumbled 8%.

But by the time London closed for business yesterday, this is exactly what had happened. After rising 16.75p to 271p, the shares were standing 88.5p above the level they hit the day Mr Green left to join another Green, Mr Philip Green, at BHS.

The Square Mile is starting to warm to Debenham's new boss, former trading director Belinda Earl. She has delivered not only a solid set of full year figures, but also a 7.5% increase in like-for-like sales in the first seven weeks of the new fiscal year. The best may be yet to come.

Apparently, the word coming out of Debenhams' London headquarters is that this Christmas, unlike those of recent years, could be a very profitable one. It seems that the clothing market is showing rare signs of stability in the run-up to the year's most critical trading period, with none of the main players threatening a price war.

Moreover, Debenhams is said to have evidence that price deflation in areas of market is easing and in some places turning, with prices actually rising. Indeed rival Allders , unchanged at 104.5p, yesterday said that sales were moving ahead.

All of which, dealers say, has prompted Schroder Salomon Smith Barney to slap a 320p target price on the stock. The broker is said to be telling clients that, if conditions hold, Debenhams will make a mockery of profits forecasts which are still bunched around £190m for the full year.

Elsewhere, leading shares were making steady progress on a what dealers were describing as a typical Monday - trading was light, with turnover just topping 1.2bn. Spiced by some takeover speculation in the banking sector, a solid start to proceedings on Wall Street, and a bounce for battered software stocks, the FTSE 100 managed to end the session 47.1 points higher at 6,374.7.

It was the banking sector that got the FTSE off to a flying start. Alliance & Leicester raced ahead on reports that National Australia Bank, owner of the Clydesdale and Yorkshire banks, was considering a £4bn bid. At one point its shares touched 709p, only to fall back, closing up 24.5p at 664p, after analysts poured cold water on the reports. Apart from the regulatory problems, most reckon that Alliance & Leicester is not big enough for NAB to bother with.

Meanwhile, Abbey National pushed up 5p to £11.08 on chatter that Lloyds TSB, unchanged at 700p, will gatecrash any deal with Bank of Scotland, 5p higher at 719p.

Computer services stocks rallied with Sema, the culprit of last week's rout, spearheading the bounce. It shares, which fell 44% on Friday after a catastrophic profits warning, gained 20p to 366p. Elsewhere, Logica rose 76p to £16.06 and CMG gained 32p to 957p. The FTSE Techmark 100 edged up 56.65 to 2,801.99.

On the downside, telecom equipment maker Marconi dipped 31p to 685p ahead of Wednesday's half-time figures. Word has it that the outlook statement for the second half of the year will not inspire confidence.

And lower down the corporate scale, Capital Radio slipped 97.5p to £10.75 after UBS Warburg cut its earnings forecasts and lowered its price target - to £10 from £17 - on concerns about the short-term advertising outlook.

Concrete producer RMCheld its ground in the face of a savage downgrade, again from UBS Warburg. Cutting profit forecasts for the next four years, UBS said the outlook for RMC's German operations (27% of group turnover) are bleak. Nevertheless, RMC shares ended unchanged at 549, propped up takeover speculation. Some of the City's more educated players are adamant that a bid from Germany is on the way.

fields.headline: At this price?  Allen
fields.trailText: Yesterday was a rough day for the management of Allen, the building and utility services group, whose results appeared to have left the City deeply troubled.
fields.body:
Yesterday was a rough day for the management of Allen, the building and utility services group, whose results appeared to have left the City deeply troubled.

For the first time in 54 years the company announced a loss in its building division and put the blame on a number of bad contracts in Yorkshire.

Allen's response has been swift. Allenbuild Projects, responsible for the problem, has been closed and procedures surrounding contracts have been "tightened".

The company has also installed Nick Davies as divisional managing director, but he has only been in office since the beginning of September so his impact is impossible to judge.

However, this poor performance has obviously hit the balance sheet with Allen reporting pre-tax profits, for the six months to October 1, down to £540,000 from £10m last time.

Its share price is in a far from healthy state and yesterday slipped a further 32p, more than 13%, to close at 213p. This is a long way off its year high of 340p, though ahead of the 190p low.

But Allen does appear determined to bolster its standing in the market, planning to spin off its Speedy hire services division, with Easter pencilled in as the ideal date to complete the move.

Speedy was a bright spark on an otherwise faintly depressing results statement with operating profit increasing to £8.2m from £7.3m.

This year saw the company make the decision to withdraw from housebuilding and sell this division to Morris Homes. Unfortunately, Allen is in dispute with Morris over discrepancies relating to the division's net assets.

While shares in Allen are unlikely to slip much further over the next few months, an instant recovery is certainly not on the cards.

Of crucial importance will be the speed with which Allen can restore profits in the contracts building division but news of this, once again, is not expected to be fed through until the middle of next year. Hold.

fields.headline: Men are from Mars
fields.standfirst:
And John Prescott is not from Venus

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: A new attack on the masculinity of British politics has come from France's environment minister, Dominique Voynet. Angered by John Prescott's attack on her performance at the failed climate change summit, she branded him an "inveterate macho man."
fields.body:
What is it about male British politicians and their female French counterparts? Why do men of our governing classes so rile the femmes among theirs? Barely a decade has passed since the former French premier Edith Cresson insisted that at least one in four English men were homosexual. Now a new attack on the masculinity of British politics has come from France's environment minister, Dominique Voynet. Angered by John Prescott's attack on her performance at the failed climate change summit, she branded him an "inveterate macho man."

She had good cause. Mr Prescott had not just blamed Ms Voynet for the talks' collapse, he had diagnosed her failings in classically sexist terms. She was "tired and exhausted" he said, adding that she did not understand the complexities of the negotiations. Short of reassuring Ms Voynet that she needn't have bothered her pretty little head with such trifles as global warming, Mr Prescott could not have played the male chauvinist pig more adroitly. As the French minister put it herself, in Mr Prescott's world "a woman obviously has to be tired, fearful and not understand things."

Still, will the deputy PM's faux pas hurt him - or will he be able to laugh it off with more "macho, moi?" bravado? The latter is more likely. For most Britons already know that John Prescott is no new man, but an unreconstructed, Labour stalwart of the old school. Sexism comes with the territory: like calling female secretaries "love", it's just the old way of doing things. Those who expect better from the second ranking member of the British government should not hold their breath: part of Mr Prescott's appeal is his bluff manner, his "authenticity". Besides, he won't get too much flak for this from a right-wing press which usually takes such pleasure savaging his eccentric brand of syntax. After all, Mr Prescott wasn't just attacking a woman, but a European woman. That will go down awfully well.

webTitle: Labour faces election dilemma on taxes

fields.headline: Labour faces election dilemma on taxes
fields.standfirst:
Ministers may repeat 1997 pledge despite calls for rethink

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Elections 2000
fields.trailText: Earmarked taxes are winning the support of some senior ministers as the government grapples with the dilemma of whether to go into the general election with a repeat of its 1997 election pledge of no increases in income tax in the next parliament.
fields.body:
Earmarked taxes are winning the support of some senior ministers as the government grapples with the dilemma of whether to go into the general election with a repeat of its 1997 election pledge of no increases in income tax in the next parliament.

Earmarked taxes are seen by some, including Home office minister Charles Clarke, as the best means of improving the popularity of direct taxes with voters. However, the Treasury dismissed suggestions that as much as half of all income tax should be earmarked for an NHS tax. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is also no longer an anthusiast.

Research published at the weekend by the independent taxation commission, established by the leftwing think tank Fabian Society, shows that government anxiety over income tax has forced it to place an excessive emphasis on indirect taxes such as VAT.

The inquiry proposes an NHS tax explicitly funded from general tax, building on tax duties earmarked for health and congestion charges for transport. A member of the commission, Julian Le Grand, said an earmarked NHS tax would make both the public and the electorate accountable for the state of the NHS. He added it would allow other public services to be better funded since at present the NHS is taking up more and more of the tax take.

The inquiry criticises the Labour government for failing to challenge the prevailing orthodoxy that taxation is in itself illegitimate. It says taxes are never going to be popular, but accuses Labour "of acting as if proposals to raise taxes cannot win votes". The inquiry also says that the"prevailing political orthodoxy" on tax means the poor are paying proportionately more than the rich in tax.

Between 1978 and 1998-99, the richest fifth have seen their share of the nation's post-tax income rise from 36% to 45%. This is partly due to successive cuts in income tax - now only 26% of total tax revenues - and the increasing importance of indirect tax.

The bottom fifth of the income distribution pay around 28% of their gross income in indirect taxes, such as VAT or petrol duties, compared to only 12% of the top fifth.

The injustice is only removed when the distributional impact of public spending is also taken into account. Around half of the gross income of the bottom 40% of the income distribution comes from the state.

Apart from the earmarked NHS tax, the report calls for a 50% top rate of tax applied to taxable incomes of more than £100,000 a year, a proposal rejected by Tony Blair and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, be fore the last election. The higher rate tax would raise £2.9bn and affect 200,000. The money would finance an increase in the personal allowance by £250 and an increase in the threshold for the 40% rate to £30,000 taxable income from the present £28,400.

The commission also proposes that the rich pay higher council tax, a flat rate personal allowance and realignment of the national insurance upper earnings limit with the higher rate of tax.

Polls commisioned by the Inquiry found that 80% would prefer extra public spending to tax cuts. Asked separately whether they would like a 1p increase in unspecified public spending, 40% said yes. Asked if they would like the money devoted to the NHS, 80% said yes and asked if they would like the money go to education, 68% replied positively.

Labour strategists have been wary of such poll findings, arguing that they are not borne out in the polling on election day. The strategists point to separate poll findings published by the inquiry suggesting voters believe taxes are too high, and do not support an inheritance tax. But the commission argues that most people suffer a deep sense of disconnection from the taxes they pay and the public services which these finance.

The Treasury, and a minority of the Fabian Society inquiry rteam members, oppose earmarked taxes on the grounds that they reduce the flexibility flexibility within the tax system. Opponents also fear that if the NHS tax revenues are registered separately - either through pay slips or by separate taxes linked to specific revenue stream - then other taxes for less popular services will become more difficult to raise.

The inquiry suggests the current state of public revenues are good enough not to require short term tax rises. But it points out that public spending as a proportion of GDP - 40.5% - will be lower at the end of the period 2001-4 than when the Conservatives left office in 1996-7.

It also points out that the proportion of national income taken in taxes in the UK is 6% lower than the EU average. Only Ireland and Spain have lower overall tax rates.

The inquiry, chaired by Lord Plant of Highfield, who was responsible for an earlier influential Labour party report on electoral systems, suggests that confidence in public spending has also been undermined by the way in which the government publishes self-congratulatory annual reports on its own activities.

The commission suggests that such reports are worthless in an age when government is not trusted. It concludes: "The very fact that these annual reports are evaluations of government by government undermine their credibility. They could be paragons of self-criticism, and they would still be regarded as suspect by the media and the public."

It proposes an independent office for public accountability, expanding the roles of the present national audit office and audit commission. It also suggests a royal commission on taxation to provide impartial evidence on how possible new or reformed taxes would work, and whether they would meet government objectives.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: We spelt wrongly the name of the artist Chris Ofili in the Living section of Weekend, page 59 onwards, November 25. We misspelt his name - inserting an extra f - in a blurb on the front of the magazine, in a headline and throughout the piece. The article itself was extracted from a book in which his name was also misspelt but we do not present that as an excuse for not noticing the error ourselves. Apologies.
fields.body:
We spelt wrongly the name of the artist Chris Ofili in the Living section of Weekend, page 59 onwards, November 25. We misspelt his name - inserting an extra f - in a blurb on the front of the magazine, in a headline and throughout the piece. The article itself was extracted from a book in which his name was also misspelt but we do not present that as an excuse for not noticing the error ourselves. Apologies.

We misspelt the name of the composer Harrison Birtwistle, page 17, G2, yesterday (Guide Monday), imposing on him an unwanted h. Apologies.

The quoted passage attributed to John Heywood, in a piece headed Golden oldies, page 3, Saturday Review, November 25, was, in fact, from Thomas Gray's Elegy Written In a Country Churchyard (1751): "The boast of heraldry, the pomp of pow'r..."

In an article on the paperbacks page of the Saturday Review, page 11, November 25, we twice mentioned the new book by Terry Jones and on both occasions got it wrong. We called it The Knight and His Lady, and The Squire and His Lady. It is, in fact, called The Lady and the Squire. The page heading notwithstanding, it is a hardback...

Jeremy Hardy's column will henceforth appear on Wednesdays, not Tuesdays as we mistakenly said in an early edition of the paper on Saturday (November 25).

The Italian Serie A team Reggina comes from Reggio Calabria and not from Reggio Emilia, Sport, page 3, yesterday.

One of the pictures used to illustrate a piece about Chicago, page 12, Travel, November 25, did not show the Sears Tower, contrary to what the caption said. It showed the Hancock Building.

The little statue in Brussels of the boy urinating, the Manneken-Pis, page 2, G2, yester day, is not in the Grand Place. It is in the Rue de l'Etuve.

In an article, page 27 (Sport), November 17, we suggested that the ECB (England and Wales cricket board), had handled relations with the media, and Sky TV in particular, very badly. We should have said that the writer, Paul Allott, worked for Sky as a commentator.

Homophone corner, from our TV notes, page 56, The Guide, November 25, where we described the film, No Way Out, as a "taughtly paced political cover-up thriller..."

fields.headline: NHS: a mixed report
fields.trailText: I woke up on July 21 with a mouth full of blood. Because I had breast cancer two years ago, cancer was immediately suspected. I now know, more than 18 weeks later, and after having had, at leisurely intervals, two x-rays, both of which showed a patch on my lung, one CT scan and one needle biopsy, that I have a cancer in my left lung.
fields.body:
I woke up on July 21 with a mouth full of blood. Because I had breast cancer two years ago, cancer was immediately suspected. I now know, more than 18 weeks later, and after having had, at leisurely intervals, two x-rays, both of which showed a patch on my lung, one CT scan and one needle biopsy, that I have a cancer in my left lung. I do not, as yet, know whether I have a primary lung cancer or a secondary breast cancer. I am waiting for an appointment with an oncologist.

My GP has done her damnedest to speed up the process, so I have probably waited for a shorter time than many, but, after 18 weeks, it would seem appropriate that I might be receiving treatment, not still awaiting a final diagnosis. The system does not seem to be particularly responsive to my desire to live.
Dorothy Kirk Gunnislake, Cornwall dorothykirk@freezone.co.uk

I spoke to a friend this morning who has just returned from hospital after having his gall bladder removed. The hospital involved is the Glenfield hospital, Leicester, and he has nothing but praise for his treatment and the efficiency and caring attitude of all staff. He also commented on the pristine condition of the wards.

With the unremitting negative reporting about the NHS, in which the Guardian is not entirely blameless, it is nice to know that another side to the story exists.
Peter Ward
Bristol peter_gavin.ward@virgin.net

fields.headline: Whose risk?
fields.trailText: Alexander McCall Smith writes (Privacy - the last frontier, November 27): "we do not object to insurance companies seeing our health record or asking when and from what cause our parents died". Well, I do.
fields.body:
Alexander McCall Smith writes (Privacy - the last frontier, November 27): "we do not object to insurance companies seeing our health record or asking when and from what cause our parents died". Well, I do. Insurance is a benefit only as a mechanism to share risk, with insurance companies retaining a small consideration for administration. In practice, insurance companies seem concerned to eliminate risk rather than to spread it. They do their utmost to retain as profit as much of their premium revenue as they can and the value they provide to policyholders diminishes proportionately. A great deal of private sector insurance is barely insurance at all.
Jon Gray
Bath jon@grays.demon.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Some friendly advice for Express staff

fields.headline: Some friendly advice for Express staff
fields.trailText: Oh my! The new owner of Express newspapers is a ruthless multi-millionaire driven by money and status who uses four-letter words and wants a say in what goes on his new newspaper's front page (Can this man really make things OK! at the Express?, November 27).
fields.body:
Oh my! The new owner of Express newspapers is a ruthless multi-millionaire driven by money and status who uses four-letter words and wants a say in what goes on his new newspaper's front page (Can this man really make things OK! at the Express?, November 27). Well, that makes him different from all other newspaper owners, past and present. Er... I don't think so, folks! As for increasing the print run of the Express by 250,000 copies a day and launching a £1m television promotion campaign - well, what will this monster think of next?

Instead of wringing their hands and moaning, Express journalists should get down on their knees and thank their lucky stars that anyone would gamble his fortune on trying to rescue a newspaper group that many think is beyond revival. If there's anyone I feel sorry for in this venture, it's Richard Desmond. You know what they say: How do you make a small fortune out of the Express? Start off with a big one! Talking of hunches, call me cynical, but I would bet that the reason Rosie Boycott is still hanging around as we speak (Monday) has as much to do with waiting for the pay-off as her "genuine respect for her favoured staff".

And before anybody asks, no, I do not want a job - I'm more than happy with the one I've got.
Wendy Henry
Editor, The Real Homes Magazine wendy.henry@cabalcomm.com

webTitle: Half of UK 'on internet within six months'

fields.headline: Half of UK 'on internet within six months'
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: More than half of Britain's adult population will be using the internet regularly within six months, according to a report released today.
fields.body:
More than half of Britain's adult population will be using the internet regularly within six months, according to a report released today.

The report, Embracing Technology, produced by online bank Egg and research company Mori, says that around 15m people now have internet access at home and forecasts this will increase to 23m by mid-2001. "We are on the verge of a fundamental shift in attitude to technology and the way that it affects life in the UK," said Egg chief executive Mike Harris.

"By mid-2001 more than 23m people in the UK will be online. Nearly one in three say they would vote via the internet in the next general election.

"While currently only 7% of the population depend on technology for buying goods and only 8% for banking, Mori's findings show this is set to change.

In the next four to five years about 12m (30%) say they would feel comfortable banking on the net and a similar number can envisage themselves buying a mortgage or insurance online.

People's dependence on new technology products is also growing. The report says 14m people believe they cannot live without their mobile phone, 28% feel they are dependent on new technology for keeping in touch with people and gathering information.

Within four to five years about 10m people will depend on new technology for shopping and 14m for banking.

Some 53% of those surveyed said they were dependent on their PCs.

And although 60% of users say they are not dependent on the internet, 55% not dependent on digital TV and 53% are not hooked on email, this could change quickly.

Robert Worcester, chairman of Mori said: "Once we've acquired the mobile or the digital TV, and become comfortable with them, we find that we end up using them for all sorts of extra useful things that we didn't originally anticipate. And over time this greater breadth of use leads to dependency."

There are restrictions, though. The report says that new technology is central to British life, but there are still 29m adults who do not use a PC and 9m say they never will. Nearly 18m people have a PC or laptop for personal use, but as many as 61% of them use it just for word processing.

But, according to Mr Harris, the future is looking good for internet companies.

On average, internet users spend nearly four hours a week accessing the internet at home.

The report, which surveyed over 2,000 people around the country, will be updated every year to keep track of the changing trends, Mr Harris said.

fields.headline: Cod facts seal fate
fields.trailText: As a biologist, I was the first grey seals research officer to carry out a census of seals in the 1960s (Scottish fishermen call for seal cull to save cod, November 27). I have therefore seen the arguments for and against culling them for 40 years.
fields.body:
As a biologist, I was the first grey seals research officer to carry out a census of seals in the 1960s (Scottish fishermen call for seal cull to save cod, November 27). I have therefore seen the arguments for and against culling them for 40 years. Amid the plethora of agonised rhetoric, I would remind readers that, in 1960, there were one tenth the number of grey seals there are today but the arguments were exactly the same. Fishermen's livelihoods were threatened - so we were urged to cull seals.

I do not doubt the plight of fishermen and wish I could alleviate it, but the increase in seal numbers is a phenomenon we don't really understand, and we should not draw the simplistic conclusion that seals eat fish, therefore they should go.

We understand the marine ecosystem so poorly. Each cod produces millions of eggs and this is related to the complicated consumer events in the marine food chain: why else is the North Sea not overflowing with cod? We contend inconclusively with other issues that are more likely to cause fluctuation in cod stocks: pollution, over-fishing, climate change etc - but of course we cannot deal with these as simplistically.

In the 60s, the salmon was the subject of outrage. We found that about 15% of those caught in static nets around Scotland bore healed or healing parallel slashes on their flanks. "QED," said the government; "seals are the only things in the sea with claws therefore we can estimate total seal damage to salmon stocks."

I was able to consult virtually all the seal biologists in the world and none of them had any experience of a seal using its flippers to attack a fish; it was always done mouth first. Yet the House of Lords agreed to a seal cull on the "evidence" that seals consume measurable quantities of salmon.
Ted Smith
Wantage, Oxon aquabiol@aol.com.co.uk

If seal are living on cod, how can their numbers increase while cod stocks collapse? The truth is that fishermen have caught cod faster than cod can reproduce. Arguing about seals just postpones the day when the problem gets tackled.
David Cooper (ex skipper of LN168 Kathleen May)Kings Lynn, Norfolk info@accuramatic.co.uk

How about we cull a few fishermen instead so there's enough fish for the remainder?
Chris Millest
Swindon, Wilts millest_c@southmead.swest.nhs.uk

fields.headline: Sisters must keep mum
fields.trailText: "Family friendly" policies (Child benefits?, Office Hours, November 27) aim to help individuals who are solely or jointly responsible for the care of children to meet those children's needs while giving their employers value for the money they, like the rest of us, need to earn.
fields.body:
"Family friendly" policies (Child benefits?, Office Hours, November 27) aim to help individuals who are solely or jointly responsible for the care of children to meet those children's needs while giving their employers value for the money they, like the rest of us, need to earn. As yet rare "privileges" like parental leave or part-time working are not for mothers, they are for children, who need parents to be able to be there for them. They don't come with full pay, either, (more's the pity). So why this sad and unsisterly sniping?
Penelope Leach
President, National Child Minding Association

The chief executive of Ann Summers says she's a "footy fanatic" (Media, November 27). Does this refer to a new piece of fetish equipment to go with the crotchless pants?
Steve Mahony
Halifax

Alan Kerr (Letters, November 27) is strangely incomplete on the subject of Glasgow football teams other than Rangers and Celtic. He cites Partick Thistle but omits Queen's Park, the oldest club in Scotland and the only amateur side in Britain to play in a senior professional league - they're in Scotland's second division, Thistle in the third.
WG Wilde
Glasgow

I must object to Harold Lewis's description of the Tories as being "as attractive as cold custard" (Letters, November 27), as I am particularly partial to this delicious confection."Congealed gravy" would be more appropriate.
Jill Burgess
Long Ditton, Surrey jill.a.burgess@lineone.net

Don't you admire the way John Prescott stands up to the French while giving in to the Americans (Prescott says French sank climate deal, November 27)? Odd business, sovereignty.
John Parry
Richmond, Surrey

fields.headline: A rash of train-spotting
fields.trailText: The three articles about railways (Rail chaos, November 25) lead me to do something I have never envisaged doing before: writing in support of Railtrack and the train operating companies (they should still be in public ownership in my humble opinion, but that's another story).
fields.body:
The three articles about railways (Rail chaos, November 25) lead me to do something I have never envisaged doing before: writing in support of Railtrack and the train operating companies (they should still be in public ownership in my humble opinion, but that's another story).

In his article from Agra, Luke Harding claims superiority for Indian railways over those of the UK, citing the Taj Express as an example. When I last rode this train 20 years ago it was still steam hauled and took just over three hours for the journey from Delhi to Agra, approximately 200km. Since then the line has been electrified and the train now takes 2hr 40min for the journey, a speed of just over 47 mph - hardly express speed considered against Railtrack, even with speed restrictions.

On the same page John Vidal travelled from London to Birmingham via Peterborough and then returned to London using the Virgin service now reduced to one train per hour. I calculate this final leg of the journey to have taken him 2hr 47min. If he had cared to make the five minute walk between Birmingham's New Street and Snow Hill stations, he could have taken a Chiltern Railways train which, even allowing for speed restrictions, would have delivered him in far less time and with less overcrowding.

Across the page, Peter Hetherington outlined the difficulties experienced by businessmen in the north and their problems reaching London to attend meetings. Obviously journey times everywhere have been extended due to the necessity to undertake track renewal and signalling maintenance etc.

All this was triggered by the tragic accident at Hatfield, but is not a recent phenomenon: the rot set in when Messrs Marples and Beeching decided that the building of motorways was the answer to the nations' transport problems, and that thatwas where money should be invested, to the detriment of the rail network.
Peter RG Kennard
Warwickshire Railway Society Solihull, West Midlands

From the GWR timetable, Paddington to south Wales, "October, 1883, and until further notice": "The published Train Bills of this company are only intended to fix the time at which passengers may be certain to obtain their tickets for any journey from the various stations, it being understood that the Trains shall not start from them before the appointed time, but the Directors give notice that the Company do not undertake that the trains shall start or arrive at the time specified in the Bills; nor will they be accountable for any loss, inconvenience or injury, which may arise from delays or detention, unless upon proof that such loss, inconvenience, injury, delay or detention arose in consequence of the wilful misconduct of the Company's Servants."
Not a lot of change there, then.
J Brian Harrison-Jennings
Huddersfield

If Railtrack and the operating companies want to brighten their tarnished image, why not bring us into line with our rational European partners by running normal train services on December 25 and 26, as was the case in the bad old days of steam?
B Sykes
Brough, East Yorkshire

In those far-offs days of fast trains, I used to buy a day return between London and Newcastle for £30 to attend a training course. This week I attempted to do the same, only to be told that because I was intending to take an earlier train (to make up for delays in the timetable) they would charge me £152 for the privilege. Getting the public back on to public transport? Where are my car keys?
Ann Davies
London, Ann.Davies@ukgateway.net

fields.headline: Islamic law advances in Nigeria
fields.standfirst: President Obasanjo fails to save fellow Christians from rigours of sharia as Muslims seek a solution to their ills in the law of the prophet
fields.trailText: President Obasanjo fails to save fellow Christians from rigours of sharia as Muslims seek a solution to their ills in the law of the prophet.
fields.body:
Until this week most of Augustus Tarosi's customers were Muslims. They drank beer openly at his roadside bar, unfazed by the growing clamour for religious law in Kano city, northern Nigeria. But now the Muslims stay away and it is only a matter of time before the Caris Tavern disappears too.

At the weekend Kano became the latest and most volatile Nigerian state to impose full sharia law, including flogging for drinking alcohol and amputation and death for worse offences.

Mr Tarosi, a Christian, said his Muslim customers drank openly because no one was offended. "But we are all scared now and we only say what we think among ourselves."

"They tell me to be careful, to go and stay in the army barracks where I will be protected. But this is my business, the source of my living to feed my family, and I must think of what else to do.

"If we stay open it will be very dangerous. Before the law takes its course the hooligans will take advantage to loot our property."

Kano is the most populous and wealthiest state in northern Nigeria. It also has the biggest Christian population, mostly traders from the south, and a long history of bloody, religious clashes, often provoked by minor disputes. Thousands have died in rioting over such issues as Christians evangelising inside the old Muslim city walls.

Almost miraculously, that has not happened with the introduction of sharia. No one has died. But they are mindful of the hundreds killed earlier this year in Kaduna state in violence provoked by the mere proposal to introduce Islamic law.

A milder form of sharia, mostly confined to the civil courts for those who wanted it, has long been practised in Kano. The new laws are harsher and compulsory. They bar alcohol, sex outside marriage and women working in many jobs. Public transport and schools will soon be sexually segregated.

Old punishments - stoning for adultery and amputation for theft - which were scrapped under British rule, have been reinstated.

Theoretically Islamic law will not apply to Christians, but few believe that, and thousands of outsiders have already left the largely non-Muslim Sabon Gari district of the city, which is a regular target for religious fanatics.

Businessmen have sent their wives and children to their homes in the south. Some shops are already boarded up and abandoned.

The pressure for full sharia came not from Kano's religious or political establishment but from the street. The state governor, Rabiu Kwankwaso, resisted for months, until he was vilified by the very citizens who elected.

"If you are a politician you can't ignore the appeal," said one of Kano's leading Islamic scholars, Suliman Kumo. "The governor of Kano tried his best to sideline the issue . . . but he realised he had no alternative but to make a declaration in favour of sharia.

"For some incomprehensible reason the sharia issue has become so emotional and the one issue that has united people in northern Nigeria. I've never seen a single issue do this in Nigeria. Partly it's rebellion against a non-functioning system."

There is little doubt that many ordinary Nigerians embrace Islamic law as an act of desperation rather than a religious value system. Islamic intellectuals may talk of sharia as a rulebook for life, but it is sold to many ordinary Muslims as a solution after so many failed alternatives - democracy, military rule and now the reign of President Olusegun Obasanjo.

The principal selling point amounts to a holy war on the corruption that is frequently blamed as the source of most of Nigeria's woes.

"There used to be very little corruption as we know it today," said the president of the supreme council for sharia, Ibrahim Datti Ahmad.

"This part of the country was peaceful and law abiding. Now, like the southern part of the country, we have violent crimes, armed robbery, arson, hired killings, corruption, especially the misappropriation of public funds in an open and shameless manner. We have a few years of this British common law and centuries of the other, so we are able to compare the two systems and see which is better for us."

Mr Ahmad predicts that even southern Nigerian states will see the benefits of sharia and embrace it.

But Christians warily eye what has happened in those areas where Islamic law has already been introduced.

The governor of Zamfara, the first state to adopt sharia, says he draws no distinction between Muslims and Christians. Among sentences passed by the Islamic courts there in recent months are the amputation of a man's leg for stealing a bicycle and an arm for stealing a cow. In August two motorbike-taxi drivers were lashed for carrying female passengers. The most controversial sentence was 180 lashes imposed on a pregnant unmarried girl. She will be publicly flogged 40 days after the baby is delivered.

In Kano, city employees in one district have been warned that they will be fined a day's pay every time they miss prayers.

The sharia question has divided Nigeria as no other has since the civil war 30 years ago, and provided one of the biggest challenges to President Obasanjo's leadership.

Some have called Islamic law a time bomb waiting to tear Nigerian apart. Certainly it has exacerbated the long-simmering tension between the north and south.

If there is one thing its supporters and critics agree on, it is that President Obasanjo's handling of the issue has been disastrous.At first he refused to interfere, saying that he believed the movement would simply fizzle out.

They drank beer openly at his roadside bar, unfazed by the growing clamour for religious law in Kano city, northern Nigeria. But now the Muslims stay away and it is only a matter of time before the Caris Tavern disappears too. At the weekend Kano became the latest and most volatile Nigerian state to impose full sharia law, including flogging for drinking alcohol and amputation and death for worse offences. Mr Tarosi, a Christian, said his Muslim customers drank openly because no one was offended. "But we are all scared now and we only say what we think among ourselves." "They tell me to be careful, to go and stay in the army barracks where I will be protected. But this is my business, the source of my living to feed my family, and I must think of what else to do. webTitle: Naval officer cleared of bludgeoning wife to death

fields.headline: Naval officer cleared of bludgeoning wife to death
fields.trailText: Sub-lieutenant David Crawley, 39, a Royal Navy marine engineer, was yesterday acquitted of bludgeoning his wife to death with a rolling pin.
fields.body:
Sub-lieutenant David Crawley, 39, a Royal Navy marine engineer, was yesterday acquitted of bludgeoning his wife to death with a rolling pin.

Sub Lt Crawley, 39, broke down for several minutes in the dock at Winchester crown court after the jury returned not guilty verdicts on charges of murder and manslaughter on the grounds of provocation.

Sub Lt Crawley said during the two-week trial that while he was taking a shower on December 13 last year, an intruder smashed his wife Jayne on the head 12 times with the rolling pin she kept in their bedroom as security for when he was at sea.

When he returned to the bedroom, he found her lying in a pool of blood.

The prosecution alleged that Sub Lt Crawley snapped during an argument, possibly about money, and beat his wife with the rolling pin.

In a statement read out by his solicitor, John Griffin, after the verdict, Sub Lt Crawley urged the police to catch his wife's killer. Mr Griffin said: "His beloved wife Jayne was cruelly murdered. He urges the police to reopen the investigation so the real perpetrator of this tragic crime can be brought to justice."

Police said they would review the case.

During the case, police said they could find no evidence of an intruder, and that his wife's blood was found on Crawley's underpants.

webTitle: Poor scratch a living from fossil trade

fields.headline: Poor scratch a living from fossil trade
fields.standfirst: Brazilian palaeontologists protest that precious relics are being snapped up by tourists and foreigners
fields.trailText: Brazilian palaeontologists protest that precious relics are being snapped up by tourists and foreigners
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Santana do Cariri
fields.body:
Francisco Antonio keeps dozens of perfectly fossilised fish, insects and flowers in his front room. "You find these everywhere here. If someone wants to pay me for one, then maybe I can buy myself a kilo of rice."

Mr Antonio supplements his meagre income from working on the land in the drought-afflicted north-east of Brazil by selling fossils to tourists and palaeontologists.

He is known locally as a "fishmonger", because of the abundance of fish fossils in the Araripe mountains, which is the world's most important site of the early Cretaceous period. Mr Antonio, 56, will sell you items worth several hundred pounds in Europe or the US for the equivalent of some spare change.

Researchers have found about 30 species of fish here, almost all the orders of insects, crustaceans, and 18 types of flying pterosaurs. The only three-dimensional fossil of a dinosaur's soft tissue was found here in the 1990s.

But the remoteness of the Araripe mountains, 1,100 miles north of Rio de Janeiro, combined with the poverty of the local population and the absence of any policing, has allowed most of the fossils to end up in foreign museums or private collections.

Brazilian scientists are enraged by the plunder of their national heritage.

"We have all the deficiencies of a third world country in terms of infrastructure and supervision", Alexander Kellner of the National Museum in Rio de Janeiro said. "It is just not fair that other countries with more money can come and take things away."

"In Brazil there is an active palaeontological community. The primary material which is leaving the country is hindering our research."

Artur Andrade, a geologist who works for the ministry of energy and mines, believes there is an organised system of fossil trafficking.

"We are impotent because the statutes are so archaic", he said.

Two years ago Santana do Cariri, a small town in the heart of the Araripe region, reopened its paleontology museum. Its coordinator, Maria Iva Peixoto, said it had helped to stop trafficking because local people brought fossils there instead of selling them. Sometimes the museum's director pays small amounts to the "fishmongers" for valuable items.

But the illegal trade continues. European academics, who are often more interested in their own research than in the issue of Brazilian sovereignty, regard the fossil trade as beneficial.

David Martill, a paleontologist at Portsmouth University, said: "I personally have no interest in seeing the trade stopped, provided that the material ends up in a scientific collection rather than on the top of someone's mantlepiece."

He added: "Also, the trade provides work for some very, very poor people, honest people who are close to starvation when the crops fail - as they do frequently in the [Araripe]."

webTitle: Care industry waits on appeal of Cambridge Two

fields.headline: Case that left homeless out in the cold
fields.standfirst:
Care industry waits on appeal of Cambridge Two as fear drives needy away from shelters

More about the Cambridge Two
fields.trailText: Care industry waits on appeal of Cambridge Two as fear drives needy away from shelters
fields.body:
A chilly day in Cambridge and a group of homeless people huddle in a car park, arguing and drinking. When the police move them on they will grumpily shuffle toward another gloomy corner in which to congregate.

Close by, on the other side of Midsummer Common is The Bus drop-in centre. A few years ago some 120 homeless people came and went freely, enjoying warmth, company and a hot meal. And then two of the centre's managers were arrested for "knowingly permitting" heroin dealing.

On Friday Ruth Wyner and John Brock - the Cambridge Two as they came to be known - will hear whether their appeal against their controversial conviction is to be overturned.

But no matter what the result, the case has caused great damage to the many organisations up and down the country who work with homeless people and drug users.

Some centres have seen a reduction in volunteers, worried that they too could also be accused of not doing enough to tackle drug dealing. Others have found fundraising ever more difficult. Many - The Bus included - have been forced to scrap "open door" policies and now monitor comings and goings with CCTV cameras and registers.

Inevitably this has led to suspicion between clients and staff at centres. One field worker said that some clients now saw hostels as another law enforcement agency. Some of the most vulnerable stay away, and this at a time when the government is urging the sector to be more inclusive.

The Bus, for example, continues to do invaluable work but now caters for a maximum of 80 visitors daily and, on one day this week, was down to the 50 mark. The rest are still out there but now loiter in parks, streets and the car parks.

At the heart of the case and of the ongoing insecurity in the sector is the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971. There was never any suggestion that Wyner and Brock, who were jailed in December last year for five and four years respectively, were involved in the dealing. The accusation was that they had not done enough to halt the trade.

Section eight of the act states that a person commits an offence if "being the occupier or concerned in the management of any premises he knowingly permits or suffers" a series of illegal activities including the supply of controlled drugs. It is also forbidden to allow the smoking of cannabis.

Following the conviction of the Cambridge Two, there was debate in the Commons over the original intentions of the act. Some MPs argued that it was intended to target the organisers of druggie nightclub parties. Many, including Cambridge Labour MP Anne Campbell, have argued that a simple modification of the wording of the section - perhaps by replacing the word "knowingly" with "wilfully" - could be enough to clarify the problem.

Thus far, however, the government has set its face against tinkering with the act.

There is real anger and frustration that in the 30 months since the arrest of Wyner and Brock there has been no firm guidance from ministers even though they have been keen for charities and organisations to work more inclusively with homeless people including those who use drugs.

Of course, it is impossible to work with homeless people without working with drug users. New statistics claim that 86% of homeless people take drugs and 57% are regarded as "problem drug users".

Sharon O'Hara, head of supported housing for the English Churches Housing Group - which has 2,500 beds for homeless people - said: "The case lessened our ability to work with drug users.

"Staff in some organisations have become much more wary about housing users in the first place. They want more information about someone before taking them in. And then if they discover drug taking, they are more likely to exclude the user forever. In the past they might have given them more chances. There has been little information from the government.

"There seems to be a conflict between it wanting us to be more inclusive and the concerns from staff over what will happen to them if they do work with people working with drugs."

Those who work with the homeless have been left in limbo. Martin Blakebrough, of the Kaleidoscope drop-in centre in Kingston-upon-Thames, Surrey, which takes in up to 500 addicts every day, said: "How far do you have to go to protect yourself? Do you have to search everyone who comes in?"

A judge suggested to Mr Blakebrough that Kaleidoscope should use sniffer dogs to help banish drugs.

But Mr Blakebrough said: "It is vital for street work that you retain the confidence of clients. Dogs sniffing around the centre would hardly engender mutual trust."

fields.headline: Bangladesh fire deaths spur anger
fields.trailText: The death of about 50 workers - mainly women and children - in a Bangladesh garment factory on Saturday has refocused attention on the poor working conditions in the industry.
fields.body:
The death of about 50 workers - mainly women and children - in a Bangladesh garment factory on Saturday has refocused attention on the poor working conditions in the industry.

Most of them died in a stampede prompted by a fire in the Chowdhury Knitwear Garments factory, in Shibpur, south-east of Dhaka. Nearly 100 people are being treated in hospital and more deaths are expected.

The Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Association's failure to protect the 1.2m workers, mostly women, who form the backbone of the industry, is causing growing anger.

About 300 have died since 1990, mainly in fires. People are asking how many more must die before something is done.

The repetition of the statements customarily issued in the wake of such accidents has intensified the public shock and anger at the government and factory bosses.

The prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, expressed her shock and sympathy at the incident and ordered an investigation. She also promised that those to blame for the deaths would be punished.

The leaders of the association once again vowed to improve safety measures in the factories. But independent observers believe that nothing will be done.

They predict that factory staff, though fearful, will once again go back to work, the inquiry report will never see the light of the day, and people will forget the tragedy, as they have forgotten others.

"You must understand that the victims are not only poor, but they're women. And who cares for them?" said Khushi Kabir, an activist for women's rights.

Most Bangladeshi garment factories are housed in rented buildings not designed for such use.

Few factories have an alarm system and the fire extinguishers rarely work. Staircases are invariably narrow, gates remain locked during working hours, and most factories lack emergency exits.

As a result, in an emergency - especially a fire - the workers often find themselves trapped, leading them to join potentially fatal stampedes or jump from the windows.

On Saturday, when fire broke out in the Chowdhury factory, most of the victims died in a stampede which began when firefighters cut open the locked gates.

If the gates could have been opened quickly then lives would have been saved, a fire brigade official said.

The factory management reportedly locked the gates in an effort to prevent its workers disrupting production by going outside for fresh air.

The factory owner, Sagar Chowdhury, said the fire was caused by a short circuit.

webTitle: India urged to save tiger after 'record' poaching

fields.headline: India urged to save tiger after 'record' poaching
fields.trailText: An environmental group accused the Indian government yesterday of failing to protect the dwindling tiger population, which it said was hurtling towards extinction on the subcontinent.
fields.body:
An environmental group accused the Indian government yesterday of failing to protect the dwindling tiger population, which it said was hurtling towards extinction on the subcontinent.

The Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA), which has offices in London and Washington, said that at least 100 tigers in India had been killed by poachers this year, a record number.

Criminal gangs were able to operate with "virtual impunity" because senior politicians were indifferent to the tiger's "desperate" plight, the agency said.

The Indian environment minister, TR Baalu, admitted in parliament yesterday that tigers were being poached, but put the death toll so far this year at 26.

About half the world's 5,000 to 7,000 tigers are said to live in India, and the EIA argues that any scheme to protect them will fail without a dedicated wildlife preservation unit blessed by the Indian prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, who has so far shown little interest in the problem.

"The tiger is on the brink of extinction. Unless Mr Vajpayee acts, history will remember him as the prime minister who allowed the tiger to die," its spokesman, Peter Richardson, said.

The problem was illustrated last month when poachers broke into a zoo in the southern city of Hyderabad and skinned a tigress. The government ordered an inquiry but no progress has been made

In January the police made their largest ever seizure of big-cat skins - four tiger and 70 leopard - which they retrieved in n Uttar Pradesh, together with 150kg (24 stone) of bones, which are usually smuggled out of India and sold for use in medicines and virility potions.

"The tiger is caught in a rapidly downward spiralling situation. This year's seizures show an escalation of the onslaught against the species," Mr Richardson added.

webTitle: Theatre accolade ends veteran actress's 33-year wait for an award

fields.headline: Theatre accolade ends veteran actress's 33-year wait for an award
fields.trailText: An actress who has been on the stage 33 years "without winning a single thing" triumphed yesterday by taking one of her profession's leading best actress awards.
fields.body:
An actress who has been on the stage 33 years "without winning a single thing" triumphed yesterday by taking one of her profession's leading best actress awards.

Paola Dionisotti won the London Evening Standard theatre award, beating stars including Harriet Walter and Barbara Jefford.

The ceremony also showered praise on a "promising" teenage actor who was a millionaire Hollywood personality as a child before his career collapsed: Macaulay Culkin, star of the Home Alone films.

Ms Dionisotti was honoured for what is regarded as her profoundly moving performance as an island woman in Further than the Furthest at the National Theatre. The play is loosely based on the fate of the inhabitants of Tristan da Cunha, north of the Falklands, when they were temporarily evacuated to Britain in the 1960s.

The best actor award went to Simon Russell Beale for his Hamlet, also at the National.

Two other prizes went to plays with contrasting treatments of Irish themes. Marie Jones's work Stones in his Pockets won the best comedy award for its story of the intrusion of Hollywood film-making into an Irish village.

Gary Mitchell, a Belfast dramatist, won the most promising playwright award for The Forces of Change, his thriller at the Royal Court theatre about the tensions of reform and of confronting Protestant terrorism within the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

fields.headline: Internet know-how
fields.standfirst: Hunting for software
fields.trailText: Hunting for software
fields.body:
Where do you begin? There's a vast number of software manufacturers out on the net, flogging their products as hard as they can using all the web wizardry available. Some are more informative than others, but if you want a reliable and thoroughly independent evaluation by practising teachers, specially trained to assess software, www.teem.org.uk/cgi/user/index/ is one of the best places to start.

Teachers Evaluating Educational Multimedia do not write "reviews", which are normally one person's subjective assessment, but evaluate. Teachers test the software for up to three months in class, describe what works and what doesn't, and then give an honest assessment of the pros and cons. If, say, the publisher's recommended age range is off the mark, the evaluator will say so and indicate the true age range.

Parents Information Network runs a kitemarking scheme for software that supports children's learning at home and uses teachers and parents to evaluate each product over a two-month period.

The British Educational Communications and Technology agency's British Educational Communications and Technology agency's evaluations of software produced up to 1998 but not updated since then are being phased out over the next year. But they are still worth a look, as many of the hundreds of titles listed have become well-used favourites.

For a quick flick-through of many of the latest titles, Becta's Educational Software Database Becta's Educational Software Database currently gives a basic listing of what a CD covers, key words, type of computer needed, and a reference to any reviews in the press - though not of too much use if you don't have the back issue. It will be relaunched in January 2001 and include more technical details.

For specific searches, some subject organisations supply their own lists. For languages, say, try Hull University or the Centre for Information on Language Teaching and Research. If your own does not have one, it may need lobbying! (A list of associations is at: http://vtc.ngfl.gov.uk/vtc/curriculum/subject_assoc/index.html).

For an overview of what's new, try the Educational Software Publishers Association site. It only carries publishers' publicity and specifications but gives an idea of what's around. Equally, leading software suppliers such as REM and AVP, both of which produce regular printed catalogues, have up-to-date listings on the web.
