webTitle: Trade figures march to a different tune

fields.headline: Trade figures march to a different tune
fields.standfirst: The Aurora caused statistical ripples amid a wave of exports to Europe
fields.trailText: It's a mystery, one City analyst observed last week as the latest trade figures were published. While manufacturers complain loudly that sterling's overvaluation against the euro is pricing them out of European markets, the data tells a different story.
fields.body:
It's a mystery, one City analyst observed last week as the latest trade figures were published. While manufacturers complain loudly that sterling's overvaluation against the euro is pricing them out of European markets, the data tells a different story.

In fact it tells two stories, one about Britain's trade with the European Union - where the trade deficit has almost closed - and another about trade with the rest of the world, which is collapsing, sending the deficit to record levels.

The most recent figures from the office for national statistics show that exports to the European Union are increasing at a healthy rate and Britain's trade deficit with the EU is almost in balance. The deficit with the EU over the three months to October stood at £178m, the smallest shortfall since the second quarter of 1991. Britain posted a trade surplus with the 11 members of the eurozone in October, for the second month in a row.

The picture for trade with the rest of the world is much grimmer. Over the past three months, imports have grown three times as fast as exports and the non-EU trade deficit has widened to a record £7.5bn. The trade figures can be erratic - a large import such as the cruise ship Aurora distorts the trade figures for several months because it will appear in the monthly trade figures with the EU and aggregated world figures, and again in the quarterly figures.

The picture emerging, however, is consistent - but puzzling. Sterling has been trading at more than €1.55 - the equivalent of more than DM3 - for a nearly a year. That surely must be making it hard to sell British goods in Europe. On the other side of the picture, since February sterling has fallen sharply against the dollar. That ought to be making British goods more attractive in these markets.

So why does the opposite appear to be happening? City analysts offer several explanations. First, changes in the currency are more important than its absolute level. Sterling made most of its gains against European currencies in late 1996 and in the first half of 1997, a climb which took it from DM2.20 to DM3 within the space of eight months. It started climbing again at the start of 1999 and peaked at DM3.40, but the ascent was less rapid. This year, it has swung around in a range of DM3.10-3.40.

The period of gravity-defying ascent is when many manufacturers give up and decide that exporting in the face of such uncertainty is a mug's game. Once the currency stabilises, firms that have survived have an incentive to stick it out.

Kate Barker, chief economic adviser to the Confederation of British Industry, says that in today's more competitive environment firms hang on to markets at all costs. "People used to be more willing to give up markets. Now they are reluctant to unless they absolutely have to," she says. Often that means slashing profit margins on exports to Europe to paper thin levels, hoping that other markets or home sales can keep the business afloat.

But the high exchange rate is changing the face of British manufacturing. Low valued-added areas such as metal bashing and basic chemicals are shrinking, as firms go out of business or shift to more profitable lines, while hi-tech sectors such as pharmaceuticals and IT are growing rapidly.

High value-added firms have less problem surviving the high exchange rate be cause they compete less on price. "The new economy bits of manufacturing are doing well," says Robert Barrie, UK economist with Credit Suisse First Boston. "Whereas the car industry and other areas where there is structural change going on are doing less well."

Mr Barrie says trade patterns are usually dictated by the speed at which different economies are growing rather than movements in exchange rates. Economic growth in 11 members of the eurozone has outstripped UK growth in every quarter since the start of 1999, and as result the continent is sucking in imports from Britain, narrowing the deficit with Europe. Growth in many other parts of the world economy is slowing however, bring about a collapse in demand for British goods.

Britain's problems with trade outside the EU began during the Asian crisis in late 1997, according to Geoffrey Dicks, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland. The currencies of the countries at the centre of the crisis - Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and Korea - collapsed. When they had recovered sufficiently from the damage wrought by crisis and were able to start exporting again, their goods were extremely cheap.

"A big hole opened up [in non-EU trade] at the time of the Asian crisis," says Mr Dicks. "We are still seeing an enormous volume of imports from these countries. They are swamping the world."

At the same time, after making a rapid recovery initially following the crisis, these countries' economies are starting to slow down, making it harder for British firms to sell goods in their markets.

The real worry is what happens next. Partly as a result of the record expansion of the US economy, world growth this year has been its strongest for more than 10 years. Most analysts expect the American economy to slow next year, and some are even predicting it could experience a hard landing - a recession.

European growth is already easing, which may make it harder for British firms to keep a foothold on the continent.

"But the fun starts if the US economy really does slow down," says Mr Dicks. "Can the world live without the US acting as the consumer of first resort?"

webTitle: So you want to be a... University lecturer

fields.headline: So you want to be a...
fields.standfirst: University lecturer
fields.trailText: University lecturer
fields.body:
Coo-wul! Pardon?

What a wicked view from your window! What do you mean precisely?

That's a great patio. Ah, you mean the Founder's Quadrangle.

Right. I could really get into this. How do I become a lecturer? Isn't that a bit premature?

You what? Well, I'm about to interview you for an undergraduate place.

It's never too early. I suppose not. I was four when I decided to be a don.

Precisely. So what do you do? University lecturers teach academic or vocational subjects at degree level using various methods of teaching from seminars, lectures, tutorials to demonstration and fieldwork.

You're all experts, right? A lecturer specialises in a particular topic or course option and extensive knowledge is needed in this field. The topic will need to be researched on a regular basis to ensure that the information is up-to-date at all times.

Nice long holidays? Far from it. The majority of the lecturer's time is spent researching and preparing their presentation to students, marking assignments and exams, and feeding back the information to their students.

What skills do you need? A lecturer obviously needs extensive knowledge in the specified field of their subject and needs to enjoy teaching and training others. Excellent communication skills, both written and spoken are also very important. Lecturers must be flexible in their teaching methods, able to perform on a one-to-one basis or in front of hundreds of students.

Sounds a bit dry. Far from it. Many lecturers get asked to advise students on their careers and personal problems as well as their studies. Some even specialise in student counselling or become wardens of residential halls.

What qualifications are necessary? A first or at least an upper second honours degree, and a postgraduate or equivalent professional qualification. It's usual these days to have or be working towards a PhD, and have a record or research publication. The time taken to gain the relevant qualifications means that most people cannot apply until into their mid-twenties at the earliest.

Telephone 01904 434222

webTitle: If you ask me...about extra provision for special needs

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My five-year-old grandson has a speech impediment for which he has been statemented. He has benefited from extra help in his mainstream school, but it's difficult to discover what further provision he could get. Are there any organisations that offer guidance on this issue?
fields.trailText: My five-year-old grandson has a speech impediment for which he has been statemented. He has benefited from extra help in his mainstream school, but it's difficult to discover what further provision he could get. Are there any organisations that offer guidance on this issue?
fields.body:
Susan Rees, adviser, Advisory Centre for Education

Find out how the school organises the help that is specified in the statement. A timetable of help might be useful, and a list of targets it is working towards, which should be included in an individual education plan (IEP).

Targets should be measurable so that they can be used as evidence in any application for more help if your child is not making sufficient progress.It's important that the statement is specific and clear. If there is doubt about the type of provision required, or the hours, raise this when it is first drawn up or, failing that, at the annual review of the statement - ask that the statement be amended.

Our publication - The Special Education Handbook - provides a straightforward explanation of the law and guidance on special needs so that parents know what to expect and what part they can play. It is available priced £8 plus £1 p&p from ACE at Unit 1c Aberdeen Studios, 22, Highbury Grove, London, N5 2DQ.

John Wright, adviser, Independent Panel for Special Education

If your grandson is already receiving speech therapy at school as part of his special educational provision, he will almost certainly have a statement of special educational needs. The local education authority is responsible for ensuring that arrangements for monitoring his progress, including the success or otherwise of the speech therapy, are in place and operating.

Statements must be reviewed by the LEA at least every 12 months, and parents are involved in this. As well as submitting a written report, parents have access to a copy of the reports from the professionals involved, are invited to a meeting with them, and get a copy of the review summary report after the meeting.

The issues which must be addressed by a review are: Is the statement still effective? Is the child making progress towards the objectives set out in the statement? Have the child's needs changed? Is the special educational provision still suitable in terms of meeting the child's needs? Are any changes needed to the statement?

If the system is working properly - that is, according to the Education Act 1996 - a parent should not have to pay for an independent report on their child, or to pay for speech therapy. But if things are not operating according to the law in your area, you should get immediate advice.

Tessa Sambrook, helpline and policy manager

Most of us take for granted the ability to communicate, and it's hard to conceptualise the problems that children may have in this area. But speech and language difficulties are a disability and they affect over a million children in our schools. Because language acquisition is developmental some of the difficulties that children encounter are not always obvious at early stages.

Children with speech and language impairments (SLI) may, with support, operate quite well in the context of the infant curriculum, but struggle in junior school as levels of understanding and use of language are higher. For children with SLI it can be very challenging if their needs are not clearly identified and understood by all those working with them.

Statements may involve speech and language theory and should quantify the time given to the therapist to carry out a range of functions - including one to one, paired or group therapy; assessing and monitoring the child; drawing up programmes for the child; working with and training class teachers, learning support assistants and parents; and/or helping with the differentiation or modification of the curriculum. The time allocated will vary from child to child and be influenced by other factors, for instance the training of the teacher.

 Afasic can provide help and advice with speech and language impairment. Its confidential helpline is open Mon-Thurs, 11am to 2pm, on 0845 3555577; or visit: www.afasic.org.uk

 IPSEA offers free and independent advice on special educational needs and can be contacted on 0800 018 4016; or visit: www.ipsea.org.uk

 ACE advice lines are open every weekday afternoon between 2pm and 5pm on 0207 354 8321; or visit: www.ace-ed.org.uk

fields.headline: Bottom's up
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones finds her midwinter morning is brightened by some midsummer madness
fields.trailText: Janet Jones finds her midwinter morning is brightened by some midsummer madness
fields.body:
A wet Monday morning too, approaching the darkest day of the year. Barely light outside, the staffroom smelling of wet coats and dripping umbrellas ...

Yet we laughed.

You may not laugh. There's nothing like being told that somebody else finds something funny, to kill a joke. Let's see. This is how it went:

"Hi."

"HI."

"Did you have a nice weekend?"

"Yes. Did you?"

"Yes ... in fact I went to a party on Saturday - a fancy dress party. I dressed up.'

"Did you go on the bus?"

That was the point at which the party-goer's eyes twinkled. He decided he would take the risk and take the trouble and tell all. He would share his pantomime.

He was Oberon, King of the Fairies. His tights were grey. His jacket was a precise amount too small, beaded and flamboyant. "Feminine," he said.

His face was painted gold. He wore his crown with a kingly tilt.

Titania was hard by, and they set off together in state in the back of a taxi. Now Oberon and Titania speak Spanish at home as Titania is not so comfortable in English. This meant that when the taxi got lost, as Oberon told me, "very near" - a few streets away "from the party", it was Oberon who ventured into the corner shop to ask the way. "You know how it is in the city," Oberon went on, "nobody knows anything." And he left the corner shop in some irritation, with no more information than when he had entered it. Oberon headed straight for Titiania and the taxi preparing to express his frustration.

Yet even he could see the widening eyes of the horrified couple among which he had sat himself to exclaim at the corner shop's unhelpfulness. And when he heard muffled shouts from Titania somewhere outside in the distance - he realised he had got into the wrong car.

Oberon made his apologies and left.

fields.headline: Talking turkey
fields.standfirst: Dreading another year of soggy sprouts and cremated potatoes? Take a crash course, says  John Crace
fields.trailText: Dreading another year of soggy sprouts and cremated potatoes? Take a crash course, says John Crace
fields.body:
Christmas dinner was never my mum's finest hour. Cooking bored her profoundly at the best of times and the idea of prolonged warfare with a 12lb turkey was enough to render her comatose. She went through with it, though, partly out of a sense of tradition and partly because she, quite rightly, recognised that my dad had no intention of lifting a finger and we'd be eating cornflakes if she didn't. So we all endured the annual ordeal of irradiated poultry and soggy sprouts, and if Her Maj's speech wasn't exactly a high point of the day for any of us, it was at least a signifier that dinner was over.

It seems that my mum is far from alone in her turkey nightmare. Even those who are on nodding terms with their kitchen for the other 364 days of the year frequently crank themselves into a blind panic at Christmas. The potential problems are awesome; first there's the pressure of the family gathering, when blood groups, which ought to have been separated at birth and kept that way, coagulate under the same roof. Then there's the sheer weight of numbers, as so many fall for the fallacy that more equals merrier. And finally there's the unfamiliarity of the food. Who on earth can be bothered to eat turkey at any other time of year? Add to all this, lethal quantities of booze and you've got a recipe for everything except an edible Xmas dinner.

But help is at hand. This year, starting on November 29, Bedford College is running a series of four three-hour evening classes to help with the Christmas catering. The course aims to steer the uninitiated through the uncharted waters of creating a Christmas diary and menu, cooking and storing cakes, puddings, pies and biscuits, preparing and presenting meats, fish, vegetables and sauces to the more familiar territory of choosing which £2.99 Bulgarian red is most suitable for your in-laws.

The man behind the course is Raj Mandal, Bedford's head of hospitality. "So many people these days have little confidence in their cooking ability," he says. "Many get by on pre-cooked easy meals and there's little opportunity for kids to learn basic skills from their parents. So when these kids leave home, they've no real idea of what they should be doing in the kitchen."

Having seen almost every imaginable cock-up in his years in the kitchen, you would expect Mandal to adopt a safety first approach to Xmas. But far from the bog standard turkey, he aims to coax his students through fruit cakes, latticed mince pies, pork and egg pies, supreme of salmon, not to mention various sauces. The cost of all this is £55 which might seem steep until you realise that the cost of the food is included and that you can take it all home with you.

The even better news is that if you affect even greater incompetence than normal, you might be able to get Raj to do most of the work for you. "I guess I would step in to help if I saw someone making a complete dog's dinner of a salmon," he concedes.

So there you have it. Your food shopping and preparation all done for you for £55. It sounds irresistible. But what will Raj be up to come Christmas day.

"I'll be sick of turkey by then, so I'll go for a slow-roasted fillet of beef." So who will be cooking it. "I'm hoping to get my wife to do it," he whispers, "but don't put that in because I haven't yet got round to discussing it with her."

fields.headline: Bad form
fields.standfirst: Britain's shocking adult literacy levels could trigger a US-style election fiasco, reports  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Britain's shocking adult literacy levels could trigger a US-style election fiasco, reports Peter Kingston
fields.body:
At the moment, two overseas sagas are competing for British schadenfreude: the problems which have hit the French beef industry and the US presidential elections.

Although understandable, our smirking in the former case is hardly justifiable given our own recent history with les vaches folles.

But we can't be too smug either about the ludicrous shenanigans in Florida. According to the Basic Skills Agency, that sort of fiasco could happen over here if we had a more complex electoral system.

Evidence from the US suggests that poor literacy could have been a significant factor in the confusion in two of the now critical voting areas.

According to the Agency, in Palm Beach County, where much of the controversy about supposed poor design of ballot papers is centred, some 22% of adults have lowest levels of literacy. In West Palm Beach City, 32% of adults have literacy so poor that they would struggle with documents that were of even moderate complexity in design.

The point, says the Basic Skills Agency, is that levels of poor literacy in this country are marginally worse than in America. In Britain, 23% of people having the lowest levels of literacy compared with 22% in America.

Problems with voting could occur in our general elections if a more complex system of voting were introduced, says Alan Wells, director of the Basic Skills Agency.

"'The election confusion in Florida vividly shows how poor basic skills have an impact on all aspects of people's lives and can ultimately lead to their political views being ignored.

"Research shows that people with poor basic skills are less likely to vote in the first place and more likely to be disillusioned with politics, and it seems that even when they do, their poor skills can prevent their voices being heard."

Ballot design has been cited as a cause of the Florida problems. These would be particularly difficult for those with low literacy.

"This has to do with the way people develop habits of reading lists, and that the Florida ballot papers go against this habit, particularly confusing for those with the poorest levels of literacy," says Wells.

"For instance, when we read lists, our tendency is to read down a list of items. So on the Florida ballot papers, on the left hand page of the ballot, one would read down from Bush to Gore, without noticing, perhaps, that the right hand page of the ballot showed another candidate's name in the second slot.

Thomas G. Sticht, an international consultant in adult education, says some of the disputed ballot papers in Florida seem to have problems of "set" or "S-R Compatibility", concepts which have been understood for some 50 years in the "human factors engineering" field of psychology.

"Set" refers to the habits people develop for viewing conventional documents. "To read down a list jumping alternately from a left hand list on one page to a right hand list on another violates the principle of "set" that we typically use to read lists," says Sticht.

On the disputed ballot, a voter would read the Bush name and the coordinated arrow and dot to be punched, he explains. "Then, in reading down to the second name, Gore in this case, one would typically look to the second dot as that dot that is S-R compatible with the second place name. But in the case of the Florida ballot, if one punched the second dot, one would punch the selection for the candidate on the opposite page.

"These kinds of violations of 'set' or 'S-R Compatibility' in document design pose more of a problem for the least literate adults, particularly if they are elderly, because they are burdened by the requirement to occupy working memory with decoding the printed language while also trying to figure out the design of the document."

Alan Wells adds: "Without taking sides over who wins the election in America, I hope that whoever does puts improving basic skills high on their agenda. For too long in this country, poor literacy and numeracy were not given the proper attention they deserve and only now we're beginning to address the severe problems we have here."

webTitle: Vice-chancellors' election: time for an end to the 'cosy club'

fields.headline: Vice-chancellors' election: time for an end to the 'cosy club'
fields.trailText: Traditionally it is an election that attracts no interest whatever outside the ranks of the 115 UK university heads who make up this curious organisation
fields.body:
It promises to be another close presidential contest, but when the result is announced by the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals (CVCP) this week the protagonists will not be going to court. "I shall not be demanding a manual recount," promises Ivor Crewe, head of Essex University, and one cannot imagine his opponent Roderick Floud, provost of London Guildhall, resorting to ungentlemanly tactics either.

Traditionally it is an election that attracts no interest whatever outside the ranks of the 115 UK university heads who make up this curious organisation. But by the time the new president to succeed Sir Howard Newby is declared, the CVCP will have changed its name to Universities UK to signal a more public and assertive role.

It was absurd that the body representing British universities should be known as a committee, suggesting a "cosy club", said Crewe, a political scientist who has headed Essex since 1995.

Both aspirants want to step up lobbying of the government and believe that this year's funding settlement is a credit to the CVCP's efforts. "It is a sign that we are winning the battle to demonstrate the good sense of investing in higher education," says Floud.

An economic historian who has been at the helm of London Guildhall for 12 years, Floud also believes they have succeeded in making the case in the English regional development agencies, as well as Wales and Scotland, for recognising universities as important businesses and vital for hi-tech industry and the knowledge economy.

This lobbying no longer works by the "mythical quiet word in the Athenaeum Club", believes Crewe. "The right approach is lobbying based on hard evidence."

Pay would be the key issue of the next few years, he argues. The government had taken a small step towards dealing with the problems raised by the Bett report but not far enough. "Academic salaries are woefully inadequate. Year on year universities find it more difficult to recruit high-quality staff in areas where there is competition with the private sector." To union pleas that money is there to raise pay, he replies that vice-chancellors cannot afford to give the increases they want to.

Floud is anxious for the new style CVCP to play a more active role in Europe, particularly now that the two bodies representing university heads throughout the European Union, Turkey and the former Soviet republics have voted to merge.

webTitle: Colleges are gearing up to fight for their financial autonomy

fields.headline: The bottom line
fields.standfirst: Colleges are gearing up to fight for their financial autonomy, reports  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Colleges are gearing up to fight for their financial autonomy, reports Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Colleges are consulting lawyers over plans to strip them of the right to appoint their own auditors. Government is proposing that colleges should lose powers to select and brief accountants in the wake of the recent debacle at Halton college, which overclaimed £14m.

College managements have reacted angrily to what they see as a radical attack on their autonomy. They had until yesterday to respond to proposals that the Further Education Funding Council and its successor the Learning and Skills Council will in future appoint the auditors.

Weak auditing procedures were highlighted in a scorching report by the Commons Public Accounts Committee on Halton college last year "... the failings at Halton arose through a combination of a strong-willed principal, a weak audit process and a governing body that was not on top of the situation ..." the committee concluded.

Baroness Blackstone, the further education minister, announced in April that auditing procedures in colleges would be tightened up.

The funding council sent colleges a circular in October stating that it "was required to take over responsibility" for the external audit of the individualised student records (ISRs) which institutions submit three times a year.

The circular outlined two options: that the funding council, and by ex tension its successor, the Learning and Skills Council, appoint auditors for the ISRs, or that they appoint auditors to scrutinise ISRs and colleges' end-of-year funding claims. These claims, filed in the autumn following each college year, cover about a third of the cash they receive from government.

If colleges are found to have been over optimistic in their applications for funds and not recruited the student numbers they predicted, they have to repay the overclaim.

A spokesman for the funding council said that the consultation was about how the government's instructions were to be carried out, not whether they would be. That, so far as he understood, was not up for debate.

Following advice on the situation from a leading accountancy firm, colleges are seeking an opinion from lawyers on the issue and the conduct of the consultation exercise.

According to the Association of Colleges, the FEFC and LSC are not following government orders on the transfer of audit powers over the final funding claims but acting off their own bats.

David Gibson, the association's chief executive, said: "Whilst appreciating that it's only a consultation exercise at this moment there hasn't been time for colleges to consult their governors before responding, and a large number of colleges have expressed the gravest of concerns."

Joanna Tait, principal of Bishop Auckland college, said: "I think there is a conflict of interest if the body providing the funds becomes involved in checking the spending of the money."

The proposals attack the heart of a college corporation's autonomy and independence - reaffirmed in the Learning and Skills Act, linked to the principle that its governors are to be held accountable for negligent error.

"If they are to be held accountable then they must also be entrusted with the responsibility which goes with it," she said.

Although the choice of auditors will be restricted to an approved list, whoever appoints them, Tait said that the power to choose auditors was significant. And it also included scope to brief them on particular areas.

fields.headline: Dream world
fields.standfirst: Oxford will not compete internationally until it ditches its medieval management system.  John Kay, who resigned as head of the Said Business School, explains why
fields.trailText: Oxford will not compete internationally until it ditches its medieval management system. John Kay, who resigned as head of the Said Business School, explains why
fields.body:
The University of Oxford is one of Britain's great institutions. It commands affection and respect across the world. Yet today there is also a sense of malaise, both inside and outside the university: a belief that Oxford finds it difficult to adapt to changing educational and social needs, a fear that it can no longer maintain its pre-eminence. There is real cause for this disquiet, but the university seems unable even to address the question.

It is not easy to describe Oxford's governance structure. This difficulty is not just my own. Management consultants Coopers & Lybrand, reporting on Oxford's governance in 1996, noted that "in one of our meetings, the expression of bewilderment by one person was explained by others as being due to the fact that he had been in Oxford for only seven years."

The university has no structures of authority, responsibility and accountability, and many of its officers and members have no concept of such structures. The system is a morass of committees with ill-defined and often overlapping jurisdictions.

The consequence of this miasma is not only the waste of time and paper. It is the absence of any means of resolving contentious issues in a consistent way. Or often at all. As Coopers & Lybrand observed, "in many cases, university decisions are not specifically made at all, they just emerge".

The source of ultimate authority at the university is Congregation: the "parliament" of all the Oxford faculty, some 3,000 in number. The impracticality of Congregation as a forum for decision-making is so clear that I came to learn that the words "this might have to go to a Congregation" became a powerful argument against a proposal.

Quality control requires clarity and firmness. The lack of either is potentially disastrous for an institution with aspirations to high standards. For example, I was involved in an assessment of a probationary Oxford lecturer. The case was clear. The individual had poor teaching evaluations and a thin research record: an external assessor from a redbrick university affirmed that the person concerned would not qualify for tenure at his own institution. Both Oxford and the individual concerned would have been better off if the lecturer had been transferred to a less exalted university. This could easily have been arranged.

But Oxford is full of kind and well-meaning people, so non-renewal would not have been contentious. I learned that a decision not to renew the contract, even if agreed by all the senior academic staff at the business school, would have to go first before a committee of 16 people (several more junior than the individual concerned) and then on to a still larger committee. That committee would contain nobody with any knowledge of the subject or of a business education, but might well overturn the original recommendation: it would certainly scrutinise procedure in minute detail and seek common ground between conflicting positions. It was apparent that non-renewal was simply impractical.

Thus the university proceeds by a mixture of general inertia and random initiatives. The business school was the largest of recent initiatives. When I became director in 1996, it was clear to me that the first priorities were to establish a development strategy; to identify the early steps needed to implement that strategy, and to put forward proposals for the operational management of the school to the university. The preparation of a strategy went well. I held enthusiastic meetings with colleagues. We spent a day with all our management faculty formulating a strategy document. The paper runs to 50 pages, defines the immense potential of a business school in Oxford, and I remain proud of it. My hope was that we could discuss this strategy with the university and then begin the implementation of an agreed plan.

At this point, the process ran into the ground. The university had no mechanism for proceeding with such discussions. I was advised that I had to turn the document into specific proposals which would then be considered by diverse relevant committees. But a plan to establish a new institution rests on interlinked initiatives. You cannot discuss courses, staffing and building independently of each other, even if there were different committees for all these things.

We encountered the same incapacity to reach a conclusion in relation to salaries and recruitment. It is not possible to attract an internationally distinguished business school faculty if a newly appointed lecturer is paid less than £20,000 and the standard professional salary is around £40,000. (Would you listen to a lecture on corporate finance or option pricing from someone earning less than a receptionist at an investment bank?) But Oxford, like other universities, cannot afford to pay all its staff at the rate necessary to attract capable business-school teachers. Although I spent many, many hours at meetings discussing salaries, this fundamental issue was never discussed. Most time was devoted to the search for ambiguity - could we establish a formula which actually paid people more while appearing not to do so? In the end, this approach offered no real answer: when it comes down to it, people are either paid more or they are not.

It is difficult - or impossible - for people outside Oxford, used to normal management processes, to deal with those who hold executive titles but who do not have executive functions. Outsiders expect to negotiate agreements with responsible officers on the basis that the results of such negotiation will be honoured. But this expectation cannot be satisfied because the individuals who conduct the negotiations lack appropriate authority. This situation was a source of incomprehension and eventually of frustration to Wafic Said, who spent five years trying to persuade the university to accept his £20m gift.

With my colleagues, I sought to establish a governance structure that would enable the business school, at least, to make decisions. We put forward proposals under which an executive committee of the school would have reported on operational matters to a board made up of senior members of the university plus experienced outside business people, and on academic matters to a university committee. This corresponds, more or less, to the way leading academic institutions around the world are run.

I was not successful even in securing serious discussion of these suggestions. The clarity of responsibility I sought was not the Oxford way, and by diluting the role of university committees it was feared that the business school would undermine Oxford's ostensible democracy. At this point I finally understood that creating an institution within Oxford which could compete with major international business schools was impossible.

How can an institution that is so badly run have been successful for so long? The answer runs, I believe, as follows. The art of managing a successful academic community involves balancing the need for pluralism and individual intellectual freedom with a shared commitment to the values and success of the institution. The decentralised collegiate structure of' Oxford, combined with its inchoate committee processes, sustained that balance for many years. But this achievement depended on a high degree of social homogeneity among the members of the university, a relatively slow-moving environment and little external pressure. Faced with internal heterogeneity, much greater outside pressure and a rapid pace of change, this structure has ceased to work.

For activities which are well established and reasonably successful - and this is true of most of what Oxford does - the paralysis of decision-making and an absence of capacity to devise policy or strategy result in slow decline, but not immediate disaster. Oxford is not collapsing, simply sliding gradually into mediocrity. We can argue about the significance of published league tables, but there is no doubt that Oxford is losing its pre-eminence among British academic institutions, and that these in turn are falling increasingly behind the top US schools. While the power of the Oxford brand is still extraordinary, and the quality of the best students, teaching and research remains outstanding, an increasing amount of activity is mediocre and amateur.

There is a widespread perception within Oxford itself that the governance structure is in need of reform: there has even been a recent committee of inquiry, led by a former vice-chancellor, although its results were of little consequence. But the capacity to generate reform internally is limited by a lack of understanding of the nature of the problems.

These problems were well identified by the Coopers & Lybrand report (prepared as part of the background to the committee of inquiry). But Coopers' comments - although made with obvious respect for the institution - were brushed aside. There are those who think that any criticism of Oxford's procedures - even from its own consultants or members - must be the product of misunderstanding or malice.

As Coopers & Lybrand emphasised, the search for participatory democracy is doomed. It is not only that an organisation of the size and complexity of Oxford cannot be run by an assembly of 3,000 people, important though that point is. It is also that, even if they could do it, they should not. Any reader of John Bayley's admirable Iris and the Friends will recognise that the characters described are people who should be left free to develop the products of their extraordinary talents, while others, with fewer gifts but more relevant experience worry about the level of student fees, the design of the reception area in the business school, and the salary paid to a computing assistant.

The inability to understand that democracy does not preclude delegation and expertise is general. The construction of a business school is a £30m task and it was obvious to me that we needed a project manager who could answer the questions raised by the architects and engineers - questions, for example, about the ventilation system or the materials to be used. I was refused permission to hire such a person. I was told that in Oxford the way to deal with such issues was to appoint - of course - a committee of academics. Hiring someone would also cost money, while the time of academics, who should have been doing teaching and research, was assumed to be free.

This problem went deep. All the support functions of the university -from accounting to fundraising to marketing - are underpaid and under-resourced. Professional skills are not valued, nor the individuals who have them.

As a result, the university fails to take advantage of the talents and often extraordinary commitment of its non-academic staff, who in turn feel demoralised and fearful of any show of initiative. The notion that effective management and free intellectual inquiry are incompatible derives from the belief that if you give people authority to fix Iris Murdoch's bookshelves they will start telling her what to write. This fear should not be discounted completely - there are people like that - but there are also ample means of safeguarding against them. The ideal of a community of scholars is well worth preserving, but we should be clearer about what it does and what it does not mean.

The most vibrant academic institutions - like Harvard and Stanford today, or Oxford in its glory days - are those which give scholars the financial and practical freedom to pursue the goals of scholarship. In a modern world, this is achievable, as at Harvard and Stanford, only through effective professional management of the institution.

webTitle: Is the foundation degree just another confusing qualification?

fields.headline: Fancy a quickie?
fields.standfirst: Is the foundation degree just another confusing qualification, asks  Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: Is the foundation degree just another confusing qualification, asks Simon Midgley
fields.body:
The first of the quickie "foundation degrees" designed to boost massively the numbers of young people going into higher education are unveiled today.

Hospitality, new media design, internet computing, music and multimedia and community enterprise are among the 40 subjects in this list of prototypes designed to achieve Tony Blair's vision that a half of all people aged 30 and below will be pursuing university-level qualifications by 2010.

Former polytechnics, older universities and 70 further education colleges are included in the 21 consortia sharing £5m of government funding to pioneer foundation degrees. Oxford Brookes university, for instance, is leading a consortium of three colleges, plus the British Hospitality Association and the Groupe chez Gerard, which will produce a hospitality, leisure and tourism degree.

At present some 30% of the under 30s go through higher education. The way government has decided to achieve the prime minister's target is to make university study more accessible to groups that have hitherto been under represented. For many, the traditional bachelors degree - designed to cater for the 7% of the age cohort which went to university in the early 1970s - would not be suitable.

The new foundation degree however, which is designed to meet intermediate skill shortages, is intended to be a more accessible qualification for a wider range of students.

Announced by David Blunkett, the Secretary of State for Education and Employment, in a landmark speech on the future of higher education at Greenwich University in February, the foundation degree will in fact be the main vehicle for achieving this increased participation.

A key architect of the new degree, David Robertson, Professor of Public Policy at the Liverpool John Moores University, says the award should improve access to the workplace and widen participation.

The new degree, he adds, is a mix of the academic and vocational. It should give students opportunities for direct entry into the labour market and a guaranteed opportunity to progress at some later stage onto the third year of an honours degree.

All foundation degrees must also include some exposure to the workplace; normally take two years; and involve some degree of employer influence on their content. It is also hoped that such degrees will be developed in curriculum areas such as the new economy, which are not covered by existing intermediate awards (HNDs, for example).

The old model of going to university, Professor Robertson says, was a middle-class one in which students went away from home to study and their costs were largely met from the public purse. However, working class people traditionally left school early to go to work and then perhaps at some later stage bought more education from the local further education college at their own expense.

To bring higher education to those people in the inner cities, Robertson adds, you had to deliver it locally, via further education colleges. Higher education courses in further education colleges were the first rung of a climbing frame that led on to university and then paid work.

The foundation degree, though, has its critics. One such is Baroness Perry, President of Lucy Cavendish College, Cambridge. She says that well established qualifications such as HNDs, HNCs and City and Guilds and newer qualifications such as NVQs already offer routes to higher education.

"To introduce yet another qualification is unnecessary and unfortunate," she says. "Because it just further confuses both the young people and their employers at a time when everybody agrees we need to simplify things."

She also thinks that the new two-year degrees could devalue the currency of four-year vocational degrees offered in the new universities, the former polytechnics.

The Confederation of British Industry sees potential in the new degree, but warns of possible pitfalls. For the new qualification to be valuable, Anne Lindsay, the CBI's policy adviser for higher education, says it has to feature "real" employer involvement.

She adds that the qualification - meant to address the specific skill needs of discrete sectors - also needs to be relevant and up-to-date in terms of skills content in a practical working environment.

Peter Scott, vice chancellor of Kingston University, believes it is essential to have more flexible structures and awards if more people are to be attracted into higher education.

"If you can get a qualification that is acceptable to the market place," he says, "and you can get it in two years rather than three years, especially at a time when student debt is increasing, then it might be quite attractive."

He has, however, two caveats. One is that students are still fixated on taking bachelor degrees, and the other is that employers are also quite conservative in their attitude to new qualifications.

Professor Alan Smithers of Liverpool University says that while foundation degrees were a good idea in principle he had some reservations.

"Is there going to be a real demand from employers for them?" he asks. "Much of the expansion of higher education is supply-side expansion - politicians thinking it would be good for more people to go to university. And in so far as these qualifications are going to be invented, what are they to consist of? And will they really open doors for young people?"

To cynics, who say that foundation degrees will inevitably mean higher education dumbing down, Robertson says if you want an inclusive higher education system you have to broaden its student base.

Responding to the old canard "more means worse", he says: "More means worse for whom? A degree is the greatest educational asset an individual possesses.

"More means worse for lecturers, more means worse to those who have had privileges of access, but more means better in terms of the national economy, more means better in terms of general exposure to learning for the greater number of people, more means better absolutely and more also means different.

"Once you create a climbing frame of opportunity in Britain - so people can begin life in a local college but graduate from a reputable university - that is something that has enormous benefits for social mobility and equality of opportunity.

"As well as the moral argument, this is an issue of economic efficiency. If other countries in the world are maximising the return from their human resources, why the bloody hell aren't we?"

fields.headline: Answer me this
fields.standfirst: The 'Colleges for Excellence and Innovation' initiative begs a lot of questions, says  John Brennan
fields.trailText: The 'Colleges for Excellence and Innovation' initiative begs a lot of questions, says John Brennan
fields.body:
David Blunkett has launched his vision of the future for further education colleges. At its heart is the aim that at least a half of them will become centres of excellence in a specialist area of vocational provision.

The new Learning and Skills Council will take the lead in identifying which colleges will benefit from the £100m investment over the next three years. It will draw on the assessment of regional and sectoral skill needs by Regional Development Agencies and National Training Organisations. Employers will be key partners, too, in the creation of centres of excellence.

But alongside the new drive to enhance colleges' contribution to national, regional and local skill needs, Colleges for Excellence and Innovation offers insights into government thinking about 16 to 19 education, and its relationship to adult provision. The proposals to establish three new sixth-form colleges, Hackney, Islington and Lambeth, signals a strong belief in the importance of dedicated centres for 16- to 19-year-olds, as the vehicle for tackling low levels of participation among school-leavers and for driving up standards of attainment.

The new initiative, launched at the Association of Colleges Annual conference, marks the beginnings, too, of the more planned approach to the development of provision envisaged for the new Learning and Skills Council. But what does this mean for colleges? For some the emphasis on specialisation might be seen as an erosion of their autonomy, or, worse, the demise of the comprehensive ideal of the tertiary college - although geographical and other considerations may mean little shift in overall college missions, in rural areas especially. Others will recognise that many colleges have a long tradition of specialising in some spheres of provision - especially those involving high cost facilities and high-level technical skills, often serving a regional market alongside a broad base of more general learning opportunities serving local needs. So, an increasing emphasis on specialisation may be a way of recreating a tertiary system in which the contribution of each institution forms part of an agreed local plan.

The emerging division between 16-19 and adult learning may, however, give considerable pause for thought. Other developments have pointed to an increasingly sharp differentiation between these two groups - not least the separate inspection arrangements through Ofsted and Adult Learning Inspectorate, and the lack of any counterpart for adult learners of Curriculum 2000.

The overwhelming majority of colleges with a strong stake in both 16-19 and adult learning know from long experience that the learning needs of adults and young people overlap and that in many areas of provision, logistics as much as educational theory dictate that under-and-over 19s learn together. So while the importance of creating learning opportunities attractive to school-leavers is understood, regard will need to be paid to practicalities.

There remain many questions unanswered by the DfEE statement. For example, the Learning and Skills Council is to lead in identifying the new centres for specialist provision, but nothing is said about how this is to be done. Will it, for example, be decided by some internal Learning and Skills Council review process, or will the providers in each local learning and skills council area have opportunities to influence thinking about the needs and how best they can be met. Will the new centres be built on existing strengths or will they be created anew? What will be the implications for specialist provision in colleges which are not selected for support? Will transport and other support be available for students who have to travel to the new specialist centres? Will modern information and communication technologies be used to facilitate remote access and perhaps partnerships between the new centres, other learning providers and employers? How far will employers - especially small and medium enterprises be prepared to support the new centres?

The government's initiative has opened up a major new agenda for the organisation of post-16 education and training - one which challenges the sector to think seriously about the mission of individual colleges and the part they wish to play in the wider Learning and Skills Council world now emerging.

 Dr John Brennan is director of Further Education Development at the Association of Colleges.
fields.bodyText: David Blunkett has launched his vision of the future for further education colleges. At its heart is the aim that at least a half of them will become centres of excellence in a specialist area of vocational provision. The new Learning and Skills Council will take the lead in identifying which colleges will benefit from the £100m investment over the next three years. It will draw on the assessment of regional and sectoral skill needs by Regional Development Agencies and National Training Organisations. Employers will be key partners, too, in the creation of centres of excellence. But alongside the new drive to enhance colleges' contribution to national, regional and local skill needs, Colleges for Excellence and Innovation offers insights into government thinking about 16 to 19 education, and its relationship to adult provision. The proposals to establish three new sixth-form colleges, Hackney, Islington and Lambeth, signals a strong belief in the importance of dedicated centres for 16- to 19-year-olds, as the vehicle for tackling low levels of participation among school-leavers and for driving up standards of attainment. The new initiative, launched at the Association of Colleges Annual conference, marks the beginnings, too, of the more planned approach to the development of provision envisaged for the new Learning and Skills Council. But what does this mean for colleges? For some the emphasis on specialisation might be seen as an erosion of their autonomy, or, worse, the demise of the comprehensive ideal of the tertiary college - although geographical and other considerations may mean little shift in overall college missions, in rural areas especially. Others will recognise that many colleges have a long tradition of specialising in some spheres of provision - especially those involving high cost facilities and high-level technical skills, often serving a regional market alongside a broad base of more general learning opportunities serving local needs. So, an increasing emphasis on specialisation may be a way of recreating a tertiary system in which the contribution of each institution forms part of an agreed local plan. The emerging division between 16-19 and adult learning may, however, give considerable pause for thought. Other developments have pointed to an increasingly sharp differentiation between these two groups - not least the separate inspection arrangements through Ofsted and Adult Learning Inspectorate, and the lack of any counterpart for adult learners of Curriculum 2000. The overwhelming majority of colleges with a strong stake in both 16-19 and adult learning know from long experience that the learning needs of adults and young people overlap and that in many areas of provision, logistics as much as educational theory dictate that under-and-over 19s learn together. So while the importance of creating learning opportunities attractive to school-leavers is understood, regard will need to be paid to practicalities. There remain many questions unanswered by the DfEE statement. For example, the Learning and Skills Council is to lead in identifying the new centres for specialist provision, but nothing is said about how this is to be done. Will it, for example, be decided by some internal Learning and Skills Council review process, or will the providers in each local learning and skills council area have opportunities to influence thinking about the needs and how best they can be met. Will the new centres be built on existing strengths or will they be created anew? What will be the implications for specialist provision in colleges which are not selected for support? Will transport and other support be available for students who have to travel to the new specialist centres? Will modern information and communication technologies be used to facilitate remote access and perhaps partnerships between the new centres, other learning providers and employers? How far will employers - especially small and medium enterprises be prepared to support the new centres? The government's initiative has opened up a major new agenda for the organisation of post-16 education and training - one which challenges the sector to think seriously about the mission of individual colleges and the part they wish to play in the wider Learning and Skills Council world now emerging.  Dr John Brennan is director of Further Education Development at the Association of Colleges.

fields.headline: Private affair
fields.trailText: British universities can and should embrace the enormous potential of e-learning for millions of students worldwide, but they risk losing out to the North American universities and the private sector
fields.body:
British universities can and should embrace the enormous potential of e-learning for millions of students worldwide, but they risk losing out to the North American universities and the private sector.

Demand for e-learning is growing rapidly, particularly from people in work who want to update their skills and acquire UK university qualifications. In addition, corporate universities and overseas universities upgrade what they offer on campus in a cost-effective way.

But surely many UK universities are already meeting that demand? Why is there a need for a national initiative? Unfortunately most UK e-learning programmes are under-resourced and under-scaled. Most academics are trying to bolt on these initiatives to already over-committed diaries, and few exploit the full potential of the technologies.

The economics of e-learning depend on scale and product quality: more quality offerings result in more registered students, which translates into higher revenues. On a large scale the return on initial investment can be very attractive for many subject areas. The e-University is needed to give impetus and focus to the initiatives already started - in medicine, law, finance and business management, to name but a few. It is also needed to inject extra resources so that universities can fully exploit the technologies and operate on a larger scale.

So why should the private sector be involved? Delivering a major e-learning initiative is complex. It requires both academic and business skills. The private sector partner will help deliver the technology platform, the global marketing of the courses and the commercial aspects of content procurement to match demand, and help resolve the complex intellectual property issues. Media, publishing and broadcasting companies all have relevant experience and are seeking new ways to participate in the digital revolution. Internet service providers are looking for new content with a valid revenue model - which e-learning has. Systems and software providers will help create hardware and software applications to support e-learning.

Why will the private sector want to be involved? Certainly, because it will put them at the forefront of e-learning and project them into a leading position in this rapidly growing global business. But also because this is a unique opportunity to form partnerships with the higher-education sector as a whole, to access the best content available from whatever university, to offer students qualifications from the best universities for the chosen subject. And finally because this is a profitable opportunity if the business plan is delivered successfully.

The e-University will need substantial start-up capital. The public sector will contribute part of this investment. The private sector partner (which may be a consortium) will also invest capital and earn a return linked to achievement of educational goals, output targets such as the number of courses and registered students, and financial targets.

Launching a global e-learning initiative is complex, expensive and risky. It will be more effective to address all the myriad challenges at the macro level, through the e-University, than for every university and college in the UK to attempt to produce their own solution. It will be more likely to succeed if it is undertaken as a partnership with the private sector. The potential is enormous, and someone needs to grasp the opportunity firmly. That is what the e-University intends to do.

 Details on the e-University project, including the proposed business model, are available on the Hefce web-site at: www.hefce.ac.uk under 'Partners/e-University'.

 Dr Keith Palmer is vice-chairman of NM Rothschild Corporate Finance and part-time professor at the University of Dundee Graduate Centre for Energy and Mining Law and Policy. He is also a member of the Hefce e-University Steering Group.

fields.headline: Clever business
fields.standfirst: Britain's e-University seeks big-business backers. But what's in it for them?  Donald MacLeod predicts major pickings from webucation
fields.trailText: Britain's e-University seeks big-business backers. But what's in it for them? Donald MacLeod predicts major pickings from webucation
fields.body:
Forget dot.coms. "Webucation" is going to be the really big business of this century. That is not just the view of a growing number of hopeful academics but of serious global capitalists who think it is worth investing millions in education via the internet.

Today Sir Brian Fender, head of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, is calling on private sector investors to take a stake in his £200m venture to set up a British e-University.

Last week Universitas 21, a network of UK and overseas universities, announced that it had rejected Rupert Murdoch as a global partner to deliver e-degrees and linked up with Thomson, the Canadian electronic publishing group in a multimillion pound agreement.

These are not purely altruistic ventures. Alan Gilbert, chair of U21, quotes estimates that the number of students in this global market will reach 160m by 2025. Even a small slice of that would mean handsome financial returns to the universities that can mobilise their resources and market their reputations - their brands - particularly in the burgeoning societies of Asia. Added to the number of new students will be the numbers of existing graduates who will have to keep honing their skills and updating their knowledge throughout their lives.

Education spending worldwide is estimated at $1.5 trillion, compared to the IT industry at $1.7 trillion, but it is expected to double in the next five years and double again in the five years after that. "Education will become the biggest industry in the world," believes Gilbert.

The buzzword in financial and web publications is no longer B2C (business to consumer) or B2B, but E2C and E2B. As e-learning entrepreneur Alexander Brigham, who is based in Phoenix, Arizona, predicts: "Education will be one of the few parts of the internet where the more you charge the greater will be the demand. Doesn't everyone want to go to Harvard?"

E-learning - webucation - is more than text-based distance learning. Thanks to two linked technological developments - interactive, multimedia learning packages and online student presentations, tutoring and academic support - the quality of e-learning is potentially high. It will soon be as good or better than one-to-one teaching, say enthusiasts.

But the start-up costs are huge. Tim O'Shea, Master of Birkbeck College London, one of the leading figures in the creation of the e-University, estimates that it takes 200 hours to produce one hour of online tuition. So the e-U is looking for private investors and the U21 institutions have teamed up with Thomson, which got out of newspapers to reposition itself as a provider of specialised information on the internet, to provide technology and investment and is spending $4bn acquiring education business.

U21, which includes Birmingham, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Nottingham and universities in China, Australia, New Zealand, North America and Europe, plans to start its first postgraduate courses next year and award degrees bearing the names of all 18 member universities. They have already agreed to recognise some of each others' qualifications in, for example, accountancy to make them internationally portable.

A rival group of Leeds, Manchester, Sheffield, Southampton, York and five US universities, calling themselves the World Universities Network, is working on e-learning courses.

Gilbert, the fast-talking vice-chancellor of Melbourne University, is evangelical about the possibilities of e-learning but sees it as a wake-up call to traditional institutions. "Universities are probably under the most severe threat in their 900-year history because there is a threat to their monopoly. For the first time non-universities are saying: 'We will offer awards and not bother with being accredited' and are competing with universities in the education market. They are able to do so because demand is greatly outstripping supply. Traditional universities are misguided if they are complacent."

In less colourful language, the report on the e-U by PricewaterhouseCoopers for the funding council said the venture would be risky, but it would be riskier for British universities to do nothing in the face of the looming competition from commercial, especially American, outfits.

What U21 has to offer is the reputation of well-established research universities which can pick and choose their campus-based students. A company, Pedagogica, has been set up to vet course quality and delivery. It is headed by Sir Stewart Sutherland, principal of Edinburgh University (and chief inspector of schools in England before Chris Woodhead).

Other prestigious institutions such as Oxford and the London School of Economics are working in other international consortia.

The e-U is different. As O'Shea, who chaired the e-University working group, explained: "Instead of an institution run by a consortium of leading universities, it has emerged as a shop window to the world for the whole of UK higher education. It will take course materials from any university or college in the country - provided they are excellent - and feed them to learners anywhere in the world (or indeed in Britain)."

There has been criticism of this approach, but Sir Brian is undeterred. He does not think e-learning can be left to piecemeal projects. "The evidence is that people do need initiatives such as this and some help to form effective collaborations. The e-University might turn out to be an exception - but I doubt it."

He admits: "Everybody is circling around outside until there have been substantive conversations about how their particular collaboration might react with the e-U model. It is a situation where people are bound to be guarded. Until they can see something rather more concrete they are going to be cautious."

To those who question what is in it for universities, especially those with international reputations, Sir Brian replies that not only will the proposed academic committee give a quality stamp, but it will also help market those sailing under the e-U flag and, crucially, help fund the massive costs of developing software and online learning materials. The private sector is interested, he is convinced.

Quality, not price, is the crucial factor in webucation and Sir Brian stresses that the quality assurance process by an academic committee will have to be rigorous. "The selection of the first programmes and universities will be important - they will be setting the standard for the e-U as it develops."

E-learning ventures will work best as collaborations across national boundaries - better able to embed themselves in the local culture, argues Gilbert, who feels the British e-U will not be U21's main competitor for this reason. "It would be stronger if it was less catholic and broad church." There was a danger of "brand confusion" because a national system was perceived as of variable quality.

Sir Brian's avuncular confidence in his baby is undimmed. "People will start to join, there isn't much worry about that - or about the e-University's success."

 For joint venture partners in e-University: www.hefce.ac.uk

webTitle: Give vice-chancellors a substantial pay rise

fields.headline: Double their money
fields.standfirst: The only way to safeguard the future of British universities is to give vice-chancellors a substantial pay rise, argues  Andrew Oswald (and no, he isn't one)
fields.trailText: The only way to safeguard the future of British universities is to give vice-chancellors a substantial pay rise, argues Andrew Oswald (and no, he isn't one)
fields.body:
At around £100,000 a year, university vice-chancellors in the UK are badly underpaid and this is hurting the quality of our universities. There, said it.

My rough calculations suggest vice-chancellors' salaries at our top institutions ought to be doubled, and those at middle-ranking universities raised by about 20-30%. This would improve the flow of talented candidates willing to do what has become a tough and unattractive job.

Before the letters come rolling in from Dr Aggrieved of Dreamworld, let's look at the evidence. First, we know the average chief executive of a reasonably sized British company earns about £700,000 a year. The job of a vice-chancellor is fairly close in kind to this. It would not make sense to pay as much as in the private commercial sector.

Such bosses often run larger organisations, have more job uncertainty than is true of vice-chancellors, and usually have to have more managerial talent (no offence to anyone) than is necessary for university heads. Yet this broad comparison makes it clear that Britain's universities are wildly out of line with what has become a normal executive-level wage packet.

"Ahh," comes the muffled shriek from the prostrate gentleman at the back of the common room, "but these British executives are greatly over-paid, so Victor Vain, our vice-chancellor, does not deserve any more largesse." Well, feel free to complain about the price of apples, too. But if you want tasty ones, they cost. And the same goes for professors.

Second, US college presidents get more than £300,000 a year in the top universities. The US market makes a natural and efficient (not to say probably prescient) standard of comparison. It is a fairly free market, so we can use it to estimate what practical sense might look like here. The US is nearly 50% richer, as a nation, than we are. We have to adjust down for that. Hence, if its top university people make around £300,000, the right price for ours would be about £200,000.

Third, there is a shortage of qualified vice-chancellors in Britain. Nobody is sure why this has happened, but an economist might conclude that the job has got worse. When life gets nastier, pay gets tastier.

Fourth, sharp evidence from all over the western world suggests wage inequality is rising through time. Our universities cannot close their eyes and say they refuse to adapt. If they try, market pressures will punish them.

The question as to why wage dispersion is rising is debated in the seminars in which I spend my life. A good bet is that, in the case of managers, the outside world has become more important. We live in a global marketplace, and all that. This means you need a good vice-chancellor even more now because one mistake could see your university shut down in 2025 because of competition from an e-university in Texas, or the like.

Fifth, the system for paying vice-chancellors has led to an inefficiently flat wage structure across different types of university. The bosses of our largest universities are paid no more, and occasionally less, than those of our smaller universities. This is daft.

There are arguments on the other side. Fairness is a word that may be on your lips. But analysing it is hard. On one hand, it's right that human beings prosper if they are in a world where inequities are not too great. It's palpably unjust that those born with lucky gifts should reap more riches than those born with handicaps. But on the other, the green-eyed monster is best resisted. We need talented people in these jobs.

Finally, there's one other thing that ensures fairness. You are free to apply for the job of vice-chancellor. I don't notice you queuing.

Latest salaries of a sample of US university presidents

President / University / Salary

Judith Rodin / Penn State / £468,647

L.Jay Olivia / New York / £464,412

William Brody / Johns Hopkins / £461,607

Richard Levin / Yale / £375,805

George Ruup / Columbia / £357,587

Harold Shapiro / Princeton / £326,108

Audrey Doberstein / Wilmington College Delaware / £266,667

Source: Chronicle of Higher Education

 Andrew Oswald is professor of economics at Warwick University. He is a specialist in labour economics and has held previous positions at Oxford, LSE, Dartmouth and Princeton.

fields.headline: Human resources
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: No sooner have I survived my first meeting of the governing body than another sheaf of photocopied paperwork from the school office lands on my doormat
fields.body:
No sooner have I survived my first meeting of the governing body than another sheaf of photocopied paperwork from the school office lands on my doormat. Since I had put up my hand for the curriculum development committee, this bundle contains a copy of the school development plan (SDP): a thick document of aims, targets and assessments for every subject.

I put this at least to one side, because an accompanying notice advises me that the curriculum development meeting is not for another fortnight. More urgent is the invitation to a workshop for governors on performance management training (yes, yes: PMT).

Since the school seems generally to make the assumption that most parents and certainly anyone prepared to be a governor cannot possibly have a life (or even paid employment that might exert some prior claim), two days is the standard notice period for most events. So it is with the PMT workshop: with a sigh, 5pm the day after the morrow goes in my diary.

When I arrive, dripping wet and in a mood nearly as foul as the weather, it proves, as ever, impossible to get a reply on the entryphone. Fortunately, school security is compromised by a passing cleaner and I make my way up to the staff room. A handful of fellow parent and partnership governors have made it already; I am greeted by a tall, floppy-haired man with pale eyes and a short reddish beard. He looks strikingly like Boris Becker, except that when he speaks it is in a modified northern accent. He bids me hello and introduces himself as "Jeff", invites me to sit in the semi-circle of chairs he has arranged around an overhead projector.

"Hello, my name is Jeff Mayhew, and I am an instructor with Rebus, a human resources services company in education. My job today is to take you through the concept of performance management and how it is intended to work in the context of your school."

He has this spiel down pat. I find myself switching off and wondering instead how someone like him ends up doing presentations for an outfit like Rebus. The possible biographical narratives seem a lot more interesting than the bullet-point paragraphs he has just illuminated on the projector.

Perhaps this is a day-job for an aspiring actor. I like this: Jeff dreams of playing Hamlet, but today he is soliloquising about new initiatives in pay structures.

"So do you all know what threshold payments are?" Jeff breaks the spell of my daydream by going into the interrogative.

"Well, you may have read earlier this year that David Blunkett decreed that teachers who had served a certain number of years were to receive a threshold payment, a lump sum of £2,000. The teachers' unions succeeded in holding up its introduction in the courts, so the DfEE had to delay implementation. But it is now about to come in. By the beginning of next year, you - the school governors - will be required to have held a performance review of your head-teacher and set his or her salary accordingly," explains Jeff, scrupulously skirting around the political issues.

It all sounds complicated and contentious: clearly, performance management is intended to shoe-horn into this vast public service leviathan a private-sector ethos of competitiveness and reward, introducing pay differentials and abolishing automatic length-of-service salary increments. But, as Jeff explains confidingly, much of what performance management replaces is similar to the existing system of teacher appraisal. The difference is that automatic pay increments for length of service have been abolished, which has upset the teachers' unions. But the good news is that the ceiling on teachers' earnings has also been removed, so that senior teachers can go on working the classroom without having, as in the past, to move into management in order to boost their salary. Fortunately for we governors, though, we have only to decide the salary of the head-teacher. Mr Richardson is answerable for the potentially divisive task of assessing the rest of the teaching staff.

Jeff has established a rapport with his audience. At the end, I swear, if there were about three more people in the room, he would have got a round of applause. Perhaps Jeff shouldn't stick to the day-job.

fields.headline: Millennium essay competition winners
fields.trailText: References abounded at Winfield House in London last Wednesday to the difficulty for the judges of the Millennium essay competition and the American people in choosing winners
fields.body:
References abounded at Winfield House in London last Wednesday to the difficulty for the judges of the Millennium essay competition and the American people in choosing winners. That such quips were shared by Philip Lader, US ambassador and David Blunkett reflects the shared history and language between the two countries that the competition aimed to exemplify, by providing a stimulus to explore the effects of the second world war on individuals and the world. The White House Millennium Council, Imperial War museum, National Literacy Trust, Historical Association and National Association for the Teaching of English all made invaluable contributions.

Sixteen finalists were selected:
David Bennett, Marie Durcan, James Etherington, Edward Fowler, Cate Franklin, Alexandra Hill, Abigail Hiscock, Magnus Mackay, Alexander Mills, Jenny Norris, Jonathan Perrin, Christopher Russell-Smith and Steven Turgoose all received computers.

The three winners are Christopher Hassan-Houghton, from Kelvin Hall school in Hull, Jordan Skittrall, from St Edmund's College in Hertfordshire and Jenny Steer from Stroud High in Gloucestershire. They will visit Washington DC.
