webTitle: Ministers offer air traffic deal forces new air sale offer

fields.headline: Ministers offer air traffic deal forces new air sale offer
fields.standfirst:
Three-month delay conceded after new Lords defeat preserve transport bill

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Three-month delay conceded after new Lords defeat preserve transport bill.
fields.body:
The government made a dramatic late concession last night after suffering a second defeat in the Lords over its plans to part-privatise the national air traffic control service (Nats).

In an effort to ensure the crucial transport bill - with its plans to revive the railways - is pushed through by the end of the parliamentary ses sion this week ministers offered to delay the controversial sale for three months.

The compromise came after Labour rebels joined Lib Dem and Tory peers to vote 132 to 125 for a Tory amendment for the sell-off to be deferred until after the general election, widely expected for May 3.

The vote means the bill will have to be rushed back to the Commons again, where ministers will today insert a new amendment proposing the bill be made law at the end of this week, but the Nats sale be postponed until the end of February.

Should the amendment not be accepted by peers, there still remains a risk the whole bill could be lost. Last night the transport minister, Lord MacDonald, said the measure was being "brought forward in a spirit of compromise" to enable more time to allay the fears of opponents of the sale.

He blamed the 100 remaining "hereditary peers" for the defeat. "The role is as a revising chamber: what it should not do is to try and frustrate the House of Commons," he told BBC 2's Newsnight.

As peers reflected backbench disquiet in the Commons over the sell-off, however, Lord Stoddart of Swindon - one of three Labour rebels who spoke against the government - stressed he was opposing the plans "with great regret" to ensure "this house isn't going to be a rubber stamp: it is going to give advice to the House of Commons".

Pointing out that the part-privatisation ran contrary to Labour's pre-election pledge, he added: "It's a strange thing to ask Labour peers to do, at this point in time, the exact opposite of what we were told before the election that we should do. Some of us do have brains.

"I have been in the Labour party for 54 years, and I joined it because I believed that public ownership had a place in our economy, particularly where public safety was involved."

Last night's air traffic control defeat followed another at the hands of the Lords earlier in the evening, when Tory and Lib Dem peers voted by 199 to 136, a majority of 63, to demand tax relief to political parties for donations of up to £500. The government will try to reverse this in the Commons tomorrow if the political parties, elections and referendums bill is to become law as planned by the end of this week.

The constitutional dispute looked set to widen today when Lady Jay, leader of the Lords and the shadow leader, Lord Strathclyde, meet to discuss for the third time the terms of reference of the proposed joint committee of both houses which will consider the next stage of Lords reforms.

Lord Strathclyde is insisting that a reformed second chamber should have a large elected element with full powers to act as a check on the Commons.

Lady Jay is insisting that the committee should look only at "parliamentary aspects" of a reformed second chamber, and focus on the relative powers of the Commons and Lords, especially the power of the Lords to block legislation.

The Conservatives believe the joint committee should also discuss the method of election of the second chamber. The Tories now favour a heavily elected second chamber with as much as 50% elected.

Without an overall majority in the Lords, ministers have suffered a string of defeats and made a series of concessions in an attempt to get their crowded legislation through before the Queen's speech opening the next session of parliament next week.

fields.headline: Money matters
fields.standfirst: Q:  What's the difference between a well-equipped school and a run-down one?  A:  A good Parent Teacher Association
fields.trailText: Q: What's the difference between a well-equipped school and a run-down one? A: A good Parent Teacher Association
fields.body:
"But I've never baked a cake in my life," I blurted out defensively. The chair of my children's school Parent Teacher Association fixed me with the determination that is the first requirement of any PTA chair. "You don't need to bake cakes," she said. "You work at home, don't you? You can write letters, make phone calls. Approach local companies for sponsorship, get gift vouchers for the fete."

And so I became the secretary of the PTA. I'm not the most dedicated member, but I turn up, write letters when I'm asked to and send out the committee minutes (eventually). That's the name of the game with the PTA: you do what you can. And you know it makes a difference.

In fact, PTAs in these days of tightened purse-strings are making more of a difference than ever. They refurbish classrooms and paint corridors: they organise the staging of the school play and overhaul the playground. They buy books and computers, pay for outings and fun days and make the mince pies for after the carol concert. Hardly a corner of school life, in fact, goes untouched by the PTA.

And that's not all. According to Margaret Morrissey of the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations, the role of the PTA is expanding. "They were first set up in the fifties to raise money for schools, and to give parents and teachers a chance to work together, and of course these elements remain crucial," she says. "But what we're finding now is that, through the PTA, parents are demanding a bigger role - they're telling schools, we've raised all this money for you, and now we'll decide how we want to spend it. So you get PTAs that invite teachers along to give presentations about their work, and you get PTA members who are extremely closely involved in the whole planning and carrying out of projects."

There's also, she says, a changing role for the PTA as a forum for parents' concerns. "You get schools where this isn't happening- where the school would rather not have a PTA than have a PTA that tells it ... how it wants the school to change. But other, more open, schools are embracing this role for the PTA - with more parents working, it can be difficult if they're not at the school gates every day but want to be involved. For them, the chance to team up with other parents and to share worries and concerns can be a useful one."

The nature of PTA fundraising is changing too - radically. More and more of us are phone-bashers and letter-writers. Because the more clued-up PTAs have realised that you can treble your income if you put your resources into chasing a grant or sponsorship.

The first rule to bear in mind is that you need to know your market and plan something that will work given the kind of school you are. After that, it's all a question of how much you need to raise ...

£200 - £500

Quiz nights are a good fundraiser in this price bracket - especially if you've got parents who are up for getting in a babysitter and having a night out. Charge for tickets, and have extra pay-as-you-play games on the night. The biggest headache is working out the questions in advance - but according to Judith Centofanti, chair of the Holy Ghost School PTA in Balham in south London, this needn't be too much of a challenge. "It's quite an enjoyable task really," she says. The only other things you need to organise, apart from the use of the school hall, are food and drink on the night, and a prize for the winning team - and this can be a token rather than an expensive item. Another big plus is you really can involve the teachers - absolutely insist there's a teachers' team. Llynis Griffin, outgoing chair of the PTA at John Beddoes comprehensive school in Presteigne, Powys, says secondary schools such as hers even include pupil teams on quiz night.

Raffle a big prize makes for a successful raffle, so get something special that's donated in return for publicity. Maybe a local cycle shop would donate a racing bike, or a toy shop might give a garden play house. If they won't donate, find someone who'll supply a prize at cost price in return for publicity.

Car boot sale if yours is a small school, try a table-top sale instead - same principle, but in the school hall and sellers hire tables at £5-£10 each.

Jar jamboree ask every family to fill an empty jam jar with something to sell - it could be sweets, herbs from the garden, home-made jam, bath salts - anything legal. Then sell the jars for £1 or £1.50 at a playground stall.

£500 - £1,000

An easy one in this category is a job week. Run it over half-term, and simply send children home with a letter and form asking parents to donate a suggested amount (eg 20p or 50p) for household tasks such as cleaning the car, making their own bed etc. Job week is usually welcomed by parents because it encourages the kids to take a bit of the strain, and though the individual amounts raised per child aren't great, it really does add up, even in a small school.

Other ideas: a concert or talent show . "Any kind of show in which as many of the children as possible are performing is a good idea - it's guaranteed to get the parents along," says Llynis Griffin. A promises auction - encourage parents with time, rather than money, to donate (eg a night's babysitting; a taxi service to and from a local restaurant for the evening), and parents with money, rather than time, to buy.

£1,000 - £5,000

A sponsored bounce is a relatively painless way to raise £2,000 or more. Hire a bouncy castle, or even a large trampoline, for a schoolday. Get teachers to bring their classes along and get the children to take turns bouncing - count how many bounces they do in a minute. Sponsor forms, and permission forms, will have already gone out to parents - and the cash just comes rolling in.

A 100 club (or a 200 club or even a 500 club if you're a big school). This is a lottery - parents buy a number and pay a set amount for it by standing order. There's a monthly draw with a cash prize, and the rest is profit.

£5,000 - £10,000

Many schools manage to raise several thousand pounds each year through their big, setpiece event such as a summer fete or Christmas bazaar. These events are, make no mistake, the hardest money the PTA makes. "You usually get a lot of people who will run a one-off thing like a stall or make the teas for an hour or whatever, and you need to have a big list of those people and to be prepared to call on them," says Delia Perry, chair for two years of the Honeywell Junior and Infant School PTA in Battersea in south London.

Most fetes and bazaars have a programme on which local companies can pay to advertise: but have you thought of getting sponsorship from larger companies to increase your takings? If you live in an area with a buoyant housing market, sound out estate agents: some will pay to supply balloons or awnings at the entrance, and to give out their publicity material. Some London schools have raised hundreds of pounds by getting 10-15 or more parents to agree to have the sponsor estate agent's board outside their house for the week of the fete - the board advertises the fete or says the agent "supports the fundraising work of such-and-such a school". When you're getting sponsors, think in terms of companies that will be looking to 30-something parents to buy their product.

£10,000 - £50,000

If you need this kind of money, think grants. The world can be your oyster - parents at Heathbrook School in south London raised £40,000 in just three months this year thanks to funds from bodies such as Walcot Endowed Charity, Sir Walter St John's Educational Charity and Bridge House Estates Trust Fund. The money has been used to overhaul the playground. The local council - in this case Lambeth - also boosted the funds by agreeing to match any money raised, again after an approach from the PTA.

"In approaching charities for funds our starting point was to put together a brochure about the school and the project we were trying to raise funds for," says Wendy Chandler, one of four key parents who worked to raise the money. "That really helped - it showed we were professional and that we were serious." Don't think you can't raise this sort of money if you're a small school - with around 350 pupils Heathbrook, a primary, is medium-sized and, says Chandler, size isn't important when it comes to fundraising.

"What matters is good communication between the school and the PTA, feeling everyone is pulling together and having a core group of parents prepared to take on the project and put the work in." Finding the right charity to give your school a grant is the biggest headache. "Which costs charities are able to help schools with is a huge grey area," says Jo Habib of the organisation Funder Finder. "Some take a strong line and feel provision of basic educational facilities is a state responsibility, but others will be open to looking at funding anything that's more than the books and pens." Find a charity that could help you using the FunderFinder software - it's too pricey to buy, but if you call FunderFinder on 0113 2433008 they'll point you in the direction of a library or organisation near you that has it. The website at www.funderfinder.org.uk has information you can download (in the Apply Yourselves package), which gives hints on how to write to trusts and what they're going to need to know about your project.

Chandler's advice is that, even before you start looking for a fund-giver, there are certain things you need to check out about your PTA.

To qualify for any grant, she says, you'll almost certainly need to be a registered charity, with a bank account and a constitution. Next step is to look carefully at a fund-giver's criteria before applying.

"You've got to fit what they're looking for, so do phone the administrator and talk it through. You'll find these people are quite approachable - what they're there for is to dish out funds, so they want to help all they can.

"Sometimes you need to be quite resourceful - a charity might not fund the buying of educational equipment per se, for example, but would fund an environmental project. Because our money was for a playground, we would then stress the environmental aspects - for other charities, we stressed the educational value or the fact that the children were involved in deciding what play equipment we bought."

Some of the forms Chandler and her PTA colleagues filled in took two days to complete, but not all grant-givers require as much paperwork. The Save and Prosper Educational Trust, which donates around £1m a year in grants of between £100 and £10,000, requires simply an initial letter. "It's really very simple, and we deliberately keep it like that so no one is put off applying," says the trust's administrator, Sharon Gormer. "The letters are reviewed regularly and our trust director visits organisations we think we might be able to help."

Like Chandler, she stresses the importance of tailoring an approach. "We can't fund building work, but we can fund equipment. So if someone wrote asking us to help pay for a new library, we'd have to say no, but if they wrote asking for help with buying the furniture inside, we might be able to say yes."

Chandler's advice is to find out what other projects a funder has given grants for, and possibly to speak to other PTAs that have been successful for tips. "Another thing is, don't try to do too much on your own. You're going to do best if you can work in a team - it is very time-consuming work, and it does sometimes seem a bit daunting. But it is possible - and we'd never have believed when we started out at Easter that we'd be putting together our new playground over the summer."

But it doesn't end with the go-ahead from the charity, of course: once the project is under way, the funding body will need to see carefully kept accounts including receipts for everything bought. You may also have to show the charity's representative around for one or more site visits.

Sponsor forms, and permission forms, will have already gone out to parents - and the cash just comes rolling in. A 100 club (or a 200 club or even a 500 club if you're a big school). This is a lottery - parents buy a number and pay a set amount for it by standing order. There's a monthly draw with a cash prize, and the rest is profit. £5,000 - £10,000 Many schools manage to raise several thousand pounds each year through their big, setpiece event such as a summer fete or Christmas bazaar. These events are, make no mistake, the hardest money the PTA makes. "You usually get a lot of people who will run a one-off thing like a stall or make the teas for an hour or whatever, and you need to have a big list of those people and to be prepared to call on them," says Delia Perry, chair for two years of the Honeywell Junior and Infant School PTA in Battersea in south London. Most fetes and bazaars have a programme on which local companies can pay to advertise: but have you thought of getting sponsorship from larger companies to increase your takings? If you live in an area with a buoyant housing market, sound out estate agents: some will pay to supply balloons or awnings at the entrance, and to give out their publicity material. Some London schools have raised hundreds of pounds by getting 10-15 or more parents to agree to have the sponsor estate agent's board outside their house for the week of the fete - the board advertises the fete or says the agent "supports the fundraising work of such-and-such a school". When you're getting sponsors, think in terms of companies that will be looking to 30-something parents to buy their product. £10,000 - £50,000 If you need this kind of money, think grants. The world can be your oyster - parents at Heathbrook School in south London raised £40,000 in just three months this year thanks to funds from bodies such as Walcot Endowed Charity, Sir Walter St John's Educational Charity and Bridge House Estates Trust Fund. The money has been used to overhaul the playground. The local council - in this case Lambeth - also boosted the funds by agreeing to match any money raised, again after an approach from the PTA. "In approaching charities for funds our starting point was to put together a brochure about the school and the project we were trying to raise funds for," says Wendy Chandler, one of four key parents who worked to raise the money. "That really helped - it showed we were professional and that we were serious." Don't think you can't raise this sort of money if you're a small school - with around 350 pupils Heathbrook, a primary, is medium-sized and, says Chandler, size isn't important when it comes to fundraising. "What matters is good communication between the school and the PTA, feeling everyone is pulling together and having a core group of parents prepared to take on the project and put the work in." Finding the right charity to give your school a grant is the biggest headache. "Which costs charities are able to help schools with is a huge grey area," says Jo Habib of the organisation Funder Finder. "Some take a strong line and feel provision of basic educational facilities is a state responsibility, but others will be open to looking at funding anything that's more than the books and pens." Find a charity that could help you using the FunderFinder software - it's too pricey to buy, but if you call FunderFinder on 0113 2433008 they'll point you in the direction of a library or organisation near you that has it. The website at www.funderfinder.org.uk has information you can download (in the Apply Yourselves package), which gives hints on how to write to trusts and what they're going to need to know about your project. Chandler's advice is that, even before you start looking for a fund-giver, there are certain things you need to check out about your PTA. To qualify for any grant, she says, you'll almost certainly need to be a registered charity, with a bank account and a constitution. Next step is to look carefully at a fund-giver's criteria before applying. "You've got to fit what they're looking for, so do phone the administrator and talk it through. You'll find these people are quite approachable - what they're there for is to dish out funds, so they want to help all they can. "Sometimes you need to be quite resourceful - a charity might not fund the buying of educational equipment per se, for example, but would fund an environmental project. Because our money was for a playground, we would then stress the environmental aspects - for other charities, we stressed the educational value or the fact that the children were involved in deciding what play equipment we bought." Some of the forms Chandler and her PTA colleagues filled in took two days to complete, but not all grant-givers require as much paperwork. The Save and Prosper Educational Trust, which donates around £1m a year in grants of between £100 and £10,000, requires simply an initial letter. "It's really very simple, and we deliberately keep it like that so no one is put off applying," says the trust's administrator, Sharon Gormer. "The letters are reviewed regularly and our trust director visits organisations we think we might be able to help." Like Chandler, she stresses the importance of tailoring an approach. So if someone wrote asking us to help pay for a new library, we'd have to say no, but if they wrote asking for help with buying the furniture inside, we might be able to say yes." Chandler's advice is to find out what other projects a funder has given grants for, and possibly to speak to other PTAs that have been successful for tips. "Another thing is, don't try to do too much on your own. You're going to do best if you can work in a team - it is very time-consuming work, and it does sometimes seem a bit daunting. But it is possible - and we'd never have believed when we started out at Easter that we'd be putting together our new playground over the summer." But it doesn't end with the go-ahead from the charity, of course: once the project is under way, the funding body will need to see carefully kept accounts including receipts for everything bought. You may also have to show the charity's representative around for one or more site visits.

webTitle: EU ministers want 'minimal' change at Nice summit

fields.headline: EU ministers want 'minimal' change at Nice summit
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Next week's European Union summit in Nice will produce only modest reforms, the European commission warned yesterday, confounding claims by the Conservatives that Tony Blair is preparing to surrender British sovereignty to a European "superstate".
fields.body:
Next week's European Union summit in Nice will produce only modest reforms, the European commission warned yesterday, confounding claims by the Conservatives that Tony Blair is preparing to surrender British sovereignty to a European "superstate".

As the chancellor, Gordon Brown, said Britain was "winning the argument" in Europe, his Tory shadow, Michael Portillo, accused the government of planning concessions on "a whole raft" of policies on which the national veto will be lost.

But Michel Barnier, the commissioner in charge of reform, said he was disappointed that member states were prepared to make only minimal changes, especially on the vexed veto question.

Mr Barnier, who took part in weekend talks on the new treaty, said gloomily: "It is very regrettable ... In Nice we will not have a major reform of the institutions."

He said he still hoped that "useful" reforms could be agreed. But his bleak assessment appeared to confirm British claims that Mr Blair would resist pressure on the veto and say that he stood firm.

Britain's "red lines" are on tax, social security, defence and treaty change. But 11 other member states also have their own no-go areas.

Britain is ready to drop its veto in favour of majority voting on transport policy, financial regulation, appointments to EU institutions, the court of justice, and structural funds. It could accept about half of the 50-odd items that the French are pushing.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said last night: "If Tony Blair wants to block an EU superstate, why is he prepared to give up the British veto in so many areas? Labour will say anything on the EU. Britain can't trust them."

Changes due to be agreed at the summit are supposed to prepare the EU's old decision-making machinery for the entry of up to 12 new members.

But changing the voting weights of governments, reducing the 20-strong commission, and abolishing vetoes are all proving extremely difficult.

Such issues fundamentally concern how much power individual governments have in EU policy making and how much political clout should be kept in the national capitals.

On vote re-weighting, the central issue is giving Germany, with 82m people, more votes than France, Britain and Italy, which all have about 59m. All four currently have 10 votes.

Mr Blair can count on the support of Ireland, Luxembourg and probably Sweden on tax. But with so much at stake, and under the principle that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed, the summit may go down to the wire.

At a meeting of finance ministers in Brussels, Mr Brown said that a deal reached yesterday on the withholding tax issue was a vindication of Britain's long-haul negotiating tactics and British engagement in the EU.

At the commission, Mr Barnier signalled trouble ahead on the charter of fundamental rights, which Eurosceptics regard as an embryonic EU constitution.

He said the fact that it was more or less agreed that the document would be a political declaration and not legally binding would not stop the commission pressing later for the charter to be given full legislative weight.

In a memorable, if unfortunate, comment Keith Vaz, the Foreign Office minister for Europe, quipped that the charter would have no more significance than a copy of the Beano.

Yesterday Mr Vaz was back on the offensive as the political temperature rose.

"The usual suspects are now asserting that Nice will lead to nothing other than the end of the UK as a viable nation state, and that other heads of government are bent on creating a federal superstate," he said. "Nothing could be further from the truth."

The issues at Nice were left over from the Amsterdam treaty of 1997, precisely because they were so difficult to agree.

With the risk that the EU cannot put its house fully in order before enlargement, the 12 candidate countries are worried that their entry will be further delayed.

fields.headline: Kerkorian sues DaimlerChrysler
fields.trailText: The secretive US investor Kirk Kerkorian last night sought to unwind the 1998 motor industry merger between Chrysler and Daimler Benz by lodging a $9bn lawsuit alleging fraud.
fields.body:
The secretive US investor Kirk Kerkorian last night sought to unwind the 1998 motor industry merger between Chrysler and Daimler Benz by lodging a $9bn lawsuit alleging fraud.

Mr Kerkorian's investment vehicle, Tracinda, filed a suit in the US district court in Delaware against DaimlerChrysler and senior executives including chairman and chief executive Jürgen Schrempp, alleging misrepresentation in the merger.

Tracinda says the merger should be unwound "so that Chrysler will once again be an independent corporation owned by Chrysler shareholders". Tracinda's lawyers said DaimlerChryler falsely presented the deal between the two companies as a "merger of equals" and accused the company of "fraudulently inducing the 1998 vote of Chrysler shareholders and knowingly deceiving the securities and exchange commission, Chrysler's board of directors, Tracinda and other Chrysler shareholders through false representations".

Tracinda, which was Chrysler's largest single shareholder at the time, said it would not have voted for the merger "had it known DaimlerBenz's true intention was to acquire and subjugate Chrysler, reduce it to division status and fire Chrysler's management".

Tracinda's $2bn damages claim includes an acquisition premium it claims was not paid on the grounds that the deal was a merger of equals. The firm also seeks $1bn in damages for the drop in value of the DaimlerChrysler shares exchanged for Tracinda's Chrysler stock and punitive damages of at least $6bn.

"Since the merger of Daimler and Chrysler in November 1998, the value of Tracinda's stock in the combined entity has fallen by more than half," said Tracinda's legal representative.

"This massive decline in shareholder value has coincided with Mr Schrempp's subjugation of Chrysler into a subordinate role and his purge of Chrysler's own long-time executives, which has demoralised Chrysler employees and dealers throughout North America."

Tracinda held 13.75% of Chrysler at the time of the merger agreement and now holds 4% of DaimlerChrysler stock. - AFX

webTitle: G2: Alix Sharkey on body art

fields.headline: Skin deep
fields.standfirst: As David Beckham bares yet another tattoo, Alix Sharkey decodes the language of body art
fields.trailText: As David Beckham bares yet another tattoo, Alix Sharkey decodes the language of body art.
fields.body:
Leonard Selby, the protagonist of Christopher Nolan's superb new film Memento, is an alienated individual with no short-term memory who sets out to avenge his wife's murder. In order to keep a record of clues he would otherwise forget, Lenny has "the facts" tattooed on his chest, arms and legs. His body becomes a walking notepad, a constant reminder of his raison d' tre.

As a commentary on the contemporary human condition, Memento is pertinent. Tattoos have never been so popular; in the US, an estimated one in seven people, or 39m Americans, have at least one. Here in Europe, tattoo parlours are flourishing as an ever-increasing number of young people go under the needle. Many are merely imitating their favourite stars. Indeed, it's probably easier to name the celebrities who don't have tattoos these days.

In the UK, Robbie Williams leads the high-profile body-art gang, with a Maori design on his left arm, a lion's head above the motto Born To Be Mild on the right, and a Celtic cross on one thigh. In tribute to wife Sadie Frost, Jude Law has a line from a Beatles song along his forearm: "You came along to turn on everyone Sexy Sadie."

At least four Spice Girls had themselves inked at LA's Sunset Strip tattoo parlour (Emma Bunton will live to regret having "Baby" emblazoned on her ass, believe me), while even professional virgin Britney Spears has an angel on her back and is rumoured to have had another, "more intimate" tattoo. And then, of course, there is David Beckham, whose tattoos are front-page news.

Over the centuries, tattoos have been marks of royalty, symbols of religious devotion, decorations for bravery, sexual lures and pledges of love. They have indicated membership of elites and gangs, and have served purposes varying from spiritual protection to the punishment of convicts and outcasts.

In this materialist age, however, tattoos have become a kind of self-branding. In a world in which we construct our identities through the products we consume, tattoos are like logos; graphic reminders of who we think we are and what we believe we are doing. In short, how we like to see ourselves.

The "casuals" of the mid-80s took this behaviour to its logical extreme, by having Fred Perry, Fila and Lacoste logos tattooed on their chests, under the actual logo on their polo shirts. They wanted to identify themselves completely with what they saw as the unimpeachable coolness of such brands.

Likewise, identification with an iconic image explains why Maradona has Che Guevara tattooed on one shoulder and Eric Cantona has a native American warrior-chief inked over his heart: both footballers see themselves as noble but rebellious anti-authoritarians, determined to overthrow the oppressor.

David Beckham, however, is a different kind of footballer with very different tattoos. Across his lower back is his son's name; his second, across both shoulders and down his spine, is a guardian angel. And now, to much media consternation, along the inside of his forearm is his wife Victoria's name - in Hindi script. Beckham explained he and his wife had discussed the idea and "agreed it would look a bit tacky if I just had 'Victoria' in English."

Once again, he's right on the money. Hindi script has an air of eastern mystery to most westerners, who associate anything Indian with some vague, New Age spirituality. Being both ethnic and mystic, it scores highly on the fashion register.

But Beckham's canny choice goes beyond the vagaries of style. In choosing Hindi, the Manchester United midfielder and England captain is distancing himself from the nationalist thugs who insult his wife and child when he plays for his country. Think about it: he's sticking two fingers up to every Union Jack-waving moron in the land.

Perhaps even smarter, this latest tattoo is insured against Vine Leaf Syndrome, the tattooist's traditional solution when a former lover's name becomes an awkward reminder of an imperfect past: cover it up or rework it with some thick, tattooed vine leaves.

While I pray every night that the Beckhams live happily ever after in wedded bliss, life is unpredictable and people change their minds all the time. Patsy Kensit recently had "Liam" changed into her son's name, Lennon, while Pamela Anderson had "Tommy" changed to "Mommy" when she and her drummer husband hit Splitsville. In choosing Hindi script, Beckham has cleverly insured against such future embarrassments. Unless, of course, his next wife is Indian.

webTitle: Soldiers' lawyer admits victims were unarmed

fields.headline: Soldiers' lawyer admits victims were unarmed
fields.standfirst:
Bloody Sunday inquiry
Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: A lawyer acting for soldiers who fired at civil rights marchers during Bloody Sunday in Derry said yesterday he accepted that none of the 13 killed and 14 injured was armed.
fields.body:
A lawyer acting for soldiers who fired at civil rights marchers during Bloody Sunday in Derry said yesterday he accepted that none of the 13 killed and 14 injured was armed.

The statement, by Edwin Glasgow QC, contradicts the findings of the 1972 inquiry into the shootings, when the then lord chief justice, Lord Widgery, concluded there was "strong evidence" that some of those killed or injured had been firing weapons or handling bombs.

Mr Glasgow was opening the case for 440 soldiers, who, he said, ranged from "teenage recruits to senior high ranking officers". Their involvement ranged from those "in the frontline, who fired live rounds which undoubtedly killed, to those who really did little more than observe some peripheral activity".

Mr Glasgow told the inquiry into the events of January 30 1972: "We will not contend ... that those individuals who have been identified were armed with lethal weapons. It follows, as has rightly been accepted for a long time, that innocent people were killed on Bloody Sunday".

His acceptance that none of those fired at by the soldiers was armed is at odds with claims made by lawyers representing other soldiers who link two identified casualties - Gerald Donaghey, who was killed, and Joseph Friel, who was injured - with weapons allegedly used on the day.

Asked by Mr Justice Toohey about the case of Gerald Donaghey - his body was photographed with nail bombs in the pocket, which his family insists were planted - Mr Glasgow said the teenager was no different from anyone else on the list of dead and wounded.

"I accept without hesitation or reservation that for an innocent person to lose his life, even one, or for his life to be lost to his family and to his community in horrifying circumstances is one of the greatest tragedies that can occur."

However, he added: "For an innocent person, even one, to be accused of murder or of conspiracy to murder, where what he was doing or attempting to do was nothing more or less than his duty in those same horrific circumstances, is almost equally abhorrent."

He described what the soldiers did as a "reaction to mob violence and sustained and physical serious attacks". Those soldiers who fired live rounds would say "without exception that they aimed and shot at, and only at, those who they believed to be using firearms or to be threatening lethal violence".

Mr Glasgow also claimed there were 34 more casualties who were never publicly acknowledged. These, he suggested, included gunmen and bombers attacking the soldiers.

The inquiry has not found any evidence of unaccounted for casualties.

Earlier, Mr Glasgow accused Martin McGuinness, Mid Ulster MP and Northern Ireland's education minister, of not having the "courage, integrity or respect" to cooperate with the inquiry.

He said the process of handing information to the inquiry had so far been "wholly and exceptionally" one-sided, with no statements from the leading republicans of that era, including Mr McGuinness.

Mr McGuinness issued a statement later saying Mr Glasgow's words were an attempt to deflect attention away from the weight of evidence that continued to be presented indicting the soldiers who opened fire on Bloody Sunday.

Mr McGuinness said he had had meetings with his solicitor to determine the most adequate way of presenting his evidence. "When that is decided I will inform the families."

Last week, the inquiry, chaired by Lord Saville, threatened to subpoena Ian Paisley, leader of the Democratic Unionist party, for refusing to cooperate with it.

webTitle: War hero Wallenberg was executed in Soviet gulag

fields.headline: War hero Wallenberg was executed in Soviet gulag
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A senior Russian official finally admitted yesterday that Stalin's secret police shot dead Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved tens of thousands of central European Jews from the gas chambers of Auschwitz in 1944 and 1945.
fields.body:
A senior Russian official finally admitted yesterday that Stalin's secret police shot dead Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved tens of thousands of central European Jews from the gas chambers of Auschwitz in 1944 and 1945.

Alexander Yakovlev, the liberal former communist who is in charge of the archives on Stalin's terror, said he was confident that President Vladimir Putin would soon "rehabilitate" Wallenberg as a victim of political repression, the Russian euphemism for the millions who died in Stalin's gulag or were executed by his NKVD, the precursor to the KGB.

"We no longer doubt that he was shot in the Lubyanka prison," Mr Yakovlev told the Interfax news agency.

Raoul Wallenberg, scion of the Wallenberg business dynasty, was posted to Budapest under diplomatic cover at the age of 32 in June 1944, a year before the end of the war, just as the members of the biggest remaining Jewish community in Europe were being de ported to their deaths at Auschwitz to the north in what is now Poland.

He saved at least 20,000, some say almost 100,000, of the 230,000 Jews remaining in the city when he arrived by giving them Swedish passports.

He disappeared into the clutches of the Red Army as it advanced on Hungary later in 1944. He was arrested by Soviet troops around the east Hungarian town of Debrecen in January 1945. Nothing was ever heard of him again. The Soviet version was that he was arrested by Red Army intelligence as an American spy. In 1957 Moscow said it had a medical note showing that Wallenberg died of a heart attack in the Lubyanka in 1947.

In October, Russian television located an elderly man in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv who said he had arrested Wallenberg in eastern Hungary in 1945.

For decades the Soviet authorities insisted that Wallenberg had died of a heart attack in 1947 in a Soviet prison, but speculation about his fate grew into a full-blown mystery as gulag inmates surfaced to report sightings of the Swede in Siberia into the 1950s.

Sweden has been pressing Moscow for decades for a proper investigation of the Wallenberg mystery and a joint Russian-Swedish commission was eventually established in 1997, the same year that Sergei Stepashin, Mr Putin's predecessor as prime minister and then justice minister, said that Wallenberg had probably been murdered by the NKVD.

Mr Yakovlev was the key aide to Mikhail Gorbachev in the late 1980s who masterminded and promoted the policy of glasnost or openness and media freedom which did much to prise open the secrets of the Great Terror and overturn the cover-ups of history.

He said yesterday that Wallenberg and his driver were detained in 1945 as prisoners of war and then convicted and executed on political grounds. For years Moscow maintained there was scant documentary evidence on Wallenberg's fate, but Mr Yakovlev said the experts working under him had collected evidence which had been forwarded to the military prosecutor's office for evaluation. He revealed that personal effects of Wallenberg had been turned over to Swedish officials.

A presidential decree was being prepared on the Wallenberg case, Mr Yakovlev said. "It will say that Wallenberg was a victim of Stalin's repression. We should finally put an end to this story which has taken on a serious international character and poisoned the atmosphere for a long time," he told Interfax.

He is in charge of a presidential commission investigating the Great Terror and rehabilitating its victims.

Mr Yakovlev said yesterday that Vladimir Kryuchkov, a former KGB chief who led the abortive communist putsch against Mikhail Gorbachev in 1991 that triggered the collapse of the Soviet Union, had known that Wallenberg was shot in the Lubyanka secret police headquarters in Moscow and had said so.

webTitle: Clinton hopes visit will revive Ulster talks

fields.headline: Clinton hopes visit will revive Ulster talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland peace process received a boost last night when the White House announced that Bill Clinton would pay a farewell visit to the province next month.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland peace process received a boost last night when the White House announced that Bill Clinton would pay a farewell visit to the province next month.

In one of his final overseas visits before relinquishing the presidency in January, Mr Clinton will spend three days in Britain and Ireland between December 12 and 14. The president is expected to turn on the Christmas lights in Belfast and to pay a visit to the scene of the 1998 Omagh bombing.

A White House spokesman said last night: "Building on the progress that has been achieved on implementing the Good Friday accord, the president hopes that this visit will help to overcome current difficulties on the path to peace."

Mr Clinton is not expected to fly into Belfast with a blueprint to clinch a deal between the Ulster Unionist Party and Sinn Fein over IRA disarmament. However, the British and Irish governments are hoping that his visit will help the negotiations to revive the peace process after the UUP leader, David Trimble, banned Sinn Fein from attending a cross-border ministerial council.

Mr Clinton spoke to both Gerry Adams and David Trimble in the final hours before the signing of the Good Friday agreement in 1998.

webTitle: Gore stakes all on final push

fields.headline: Gore stakes all on final push
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore threw everything into a legal, political and public relations offensive yesterday to keep his White House hopes from crumbling in the face of George W Bush's claims of victory in the US presidential contest after election officials in Florida declared him the winner in the decisive state.
fields.body:
Al Gore threw everything into a legal, political and public relations offensive yesterday to keep his White House hopes from crumbling in the face of George W Bush's claims of victory in the US presidential contest after election officials in Florida declared him the winner in the decisive state.

As the Texas governor began ostentatiously building a new Republican administration, Mr Gore was fighting on three fronts: challenging the election result in the Florida courts, rallying the Democratic party and taking his case to the public in a prime-time TV broadcast.

The odds against Mr Gore remained long. But the vice-president kept hammering home his belief that every vote cast in Florida on November 7 should be counted before the presidency is awarded.

His camp believes that in the three counties at issue the Democrats have been denied a net gain of more than 1,100 uncounted votes in Palm Beach and 750 in Miami-Dade, and that Mr Bush was wrongly credited with 51 votes in Nassau as part of his overall 537 majority.

If this is right, the uncounted votes would be more than enough to hand Florida, and the White House, to Mr Gore.

"What we're talking about involves many thousands of votes that have never been counted at all," he said in a televised phone conversation with his party's congressional leaders Tom Daschle and Dick Gephardt yesterday. The two leaders went to Florida to head a show of unity for Mr Gore. But in the meantime Andy Card, whom Mr Bush has named as his putative White House chief-of-staff, was pumping out the Republicans' message about their man: "He's getting ready to be a great president."

Clay Johnson, Mr Bush's Texas chief of staff, was named as executive director of the transition team, and Ari Fleischer as press spokesman.

To add to the appearance of momentum, the senate majority leader, Trent Lott, told committee chairmen to convene their members on January 4 to begin confirmation hearings on Bush cabinet nominees.

But the 80,000 square feet of government offices set aside in central Washington for the transition team stayed locked.

Federal officials from the General Services Agency said that the law required them to withhold the keys while the election outcome was in doubt.

The Republican vice-presidential nominee, Dick Cheney, said he was "disappointed" at this. The Bush campaign, he announced, would set up offices in Washington funded from private contributions.

"We feel it is our obligation to the American people to honour their votes by moving forward and assembling the administration they've chosen," he said.

An ABC television/Washington Post opinion poll suggested that the public, whose tolerance for the Florida impasse has been considerable, could now be moving in Mr Bush's direction. In the poll 56% said the Florida votes had been properly counted and 60% thought Mr Gore should now stand down.

But there was no sign of that happening yesterday. Mr Gore's lawyers went back to court yesterday in Tallahassee to challenge the certified results for the state which gave Mr Bush the victory there by 537 votes on Sunday night. Focussing on the counties of Miami-Dade, Nassau and Palm Beach, the Democrats want judges to order a count of up to 15,000 ballot papers that were not counted before Sunday's deadline.

"The vote totals reported in the election canvassing commission's certification of Nov 26 2000, are wrong," the Gore papers submitted to the court argued. The Gore team stressed that it was not seeking any more recounts, but want all the votes to be counted.

"If we ignore the votes that have been cast, where does that lead?" Mr Gore asked in his conversation with the congressional leaders.

He also told the New York Times that he wanted "the will of the American people" to be properly documented in a full count. But his efforts would not continue indefinitely; he was sure the Florida legal contests would be over before December 12.

fields.headline: Views split: he's out of line; she's a wimp
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: John Prescott yesterday mocked his French counterpart, Dominique Voynet, after she accused him of "deeply macho" behaviour when the climate change conference collapsed in the Hague at the weekend.
fields.body:
John Prescott yesterday mocked his French counterpart, Dominique Voynet, after she accused him of "deeply macho" behaviour when the climate change conference collapsed in the Hague at the weekend.

"I'm accused of being a macho man," the deputy prime minister joked in the Commons. "Moi? I must say the remark leaves me most gutted."

His sarcastic response amused MPs across the house. But they were divided on whether Ms Voynet was right to brand Mr Prescott a male chauvinist after he said she had got "cold feet" and was "too tired" in the final talks.

Jackie Ballard, Liberal Democrat MP for Taunton, welcomed Ms Voynet's attack on the deputy prime minister. "John Prescott is male chauvinism incarnate," she said. "His remarks about how Ms Voynet could not cope with the negotiations were incredibly offensive. I bet he would not have said [that] to a male minister. He is a bruiser and not a peacemaker."

Ms Ballard added that such negotiating sessions were a product of male dominated politics. "It is macho to stay up all night to push for a better deal in negotiations. It never works because when people are tired they are fractious. Those sort of negotiations are typical of male dominated institutions that are all about appearing to be being tough."

A senior woman Labour MP, who wanted to remain anonymous, said: "John Prescott is a male chauvinist pig. He is the worst in the cabinet. He has a chip on his shoulder which is agitated by successful women."

But Mr Prescott won strong support from a former Conservative minister who once reduced her male Belgian counterpart to tears during an all-night negotiating session. Gillian Shephard said that Ms Voynet had done a disservice to women by rounding on Mr Prescott for macho behaviour.

"I am sure John Prescott is macho, as I was when I reduced the Belgian agriculture minister to tears," Mrs Shephard said.

"The minister, who was chairing an EU agriculture meeting, wept after I gave him a dressing him down in the middle of the night for allowing the French and the Germans to usurp the negotiations. I told him, in French, that he should be ashamed and that I would call a halt to the negotia tions unless he stopped." The episode showed women were capable of punching just as hard as men during long bargaining sessions, she said.

"You use whatever tactics it takes in negotiations. If that means long sittings and back-breaking negotiations, then so be it. To use the feminist argument is not helpful to women or to the French."

Lorna Fitzsimons, the Labour MP for Rochdale, agreed. European negotiations were always tough going, she said, and "It is a cheap shot to accuse John Prescott of chauvinism when he was just trying to get the best deal".

fields.headline: The Prescott empire
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The sprawling department John Prescott invented embraces environment, the countryside, transport, regional policy, housing, planning, local government and urban affairs. Some say it is too unwieldy and unable to focus clearly on the issues of the day.
fields.body:
The sprawling department John Prescott invented embraces environment, the countryside, transport, regional policy, housing, planning, local government and urban affairs. Some say it is too unwieldy and unable to focus clearly on the issues of the day.

But Mr Prescott can point to some solid legislative achievements, from creating regional development agencies to protecting the countryside. However, he has been forced to make several notable u-turns, which have damaged his credibility.

Environment

Mr Prescott was widely acclaimed at the world climate change summit at Kyoto for being instrumental in brokering a deal committing countries to reduce carbon emissions to 1990 levels. But he misread the signals at the disastrous Hague summit, which was supposed to follow up Kyoto with a treaty; several EU governments have been forced by green parties to adopt a much tougher environment agenda. Mr Prescott saw the prospect of a compromise agreement with the United States as better than having no deal.

On the rural front Mr Prescott has made solid progress. A white paper, setting out the case for more affordable housing in the countryside, multi-million pound backing for small towns, and a reform of agricultural support, will be published today. Legislation just approved boosts wildlife protection and gives greater access to the countryside.

Housing

Again a partial success. Mr Prescott has pushed through new planning guidelines forcing developers to consider recycled or 'brownfield' land ahead of greenfield sites.

Earlier this year he steered an effective middle course between competing demands in the south-east. A government advisory panel suggested the building of 70,000 homes annually to meet demand; local councils wanted 33,000. Prescott has gone for 43,000 houses.

Transport

Mr Prescott's big problem area. A 10-year transport plan unveiled last July included an extra £60bn for the country's collapsing rail system, but it also involved an extra £59bn for roads, seen by the environmental lobby as a monumental u-turn and a reversal of Mr Prescott's much-vaunted 'green agenda'.

To make matters worse, it is now far far from clear whether the train operating companies and Railtrack can provide a crucial contribution to the £60bn rail revival package as passenger numbers fall amid the current rail chaos.

Cities

A partial success. Soon after taking office Mr Prescott appointed the architect Lord Rogers to lead a high-powered task force which called for an 'urban renaissance' backed with billions of pounds of extra cash and tax incentives. Two weeks ago Lord Rogers complained that crucial elements of his task force report were missing in Mr Prescott's urban white paper. Prescott admitted he had been thwarted by the Treasury in his battle to create an equal VAT regime between new homes and house conversions - new houses are zero rated while conversions attract the full 17.5%.

Regions

Mr Prescott drove through legislation to create eight regional development agencies. Budgets will almost double to £1.7bn over the next three years.

Local government

Mr Prescott has clashed with the local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, over town hall reform. She has strongly pushed Downing Street's agenda for elected mayors; Mr Prescott opposes the idea. He lost the battle.

webTitle: Business: Microsoft says trial infected with error

fields.headline: Microsoft says trial infected with error
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Microsoft yesterday accused the US government and a senior judge of misunderstanding the law in the latest round of the legal battle for its survival.
fields.body:
Microsoft yesterday accused the US government and a senior judge of misunderstanding the law in the latest round of the legal battle for its survival.

In a filing to the US court of appeals, the Seattle-based company argued that it had not broken any anti-monopoly laws, in spite of a ruling by a US district court to the contrary. The company rejected the entire basis of last year's ruling that it had abused its monopoly position by stifling competition.

The 150-page brief states: "The entire proceeding was infected with error. Revealing a profound misunderstanding of the anti-trust laws, the district court condemned Microsoft's competitive response to the growth of the internet."

The US government and 19 US states which brought the case had successfully argued that Microsoft abused its stranglehold over the software industry by preventing competition from newcomers such as Netscape.

Microsoft accused the government and the lower court of trying to create new law by failing to recognise the dynamics of a successful business.

It then criticised the handling of the case by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who agreed with most of the government's arguments.

"The district judge's violations of the code of conduct are emblematic of the manner in which he conducted the entire case - employing improper procedures and changing the rules of the game, always to Microsoft's detriment," said the company.

Few analysts were surprised at Microsoft's combative approach yesterday. Judge Jackson himself had castigated the company and senior executives for their failure during the trial hearings to accept any wrongdoing.

The government is expected to file its response in January with the appeals court not expected to reach a decision until early summer. The case could then be taken to the US supreme court.

fields.headline: Prescott the 'macho man' refuses to back down
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: A beleaguered John Prescott last night refused to back down over angry European accusations that he behaved like an "inveterate macho man" at last week's climate change conference in the Hague - and warned his critics they may have to restart the negotiations from scratch next year with a much tougher US administration.
fields.byline: Jon Henley in Paris and Michael White
fields.body:
A beleaguered John Prescott last night refused to back down over angry European accusations that he behaved like an "inveterate macho man" at last week's climate change conference in the Hague - and warned his critics they may have to restart the negotiations from scratch next year with a much tougher US administration.

With Dominique Voynet, the French environment minister, yesterday unleashing a ferocious attack on Britain's deputy prime minister, Mr Prescott stood accused of sexism and small-mindedness in blaming her for the collapse of UN talks on environnmental reforms to slow climate change.

In an article for today's Guardian, Ms Voynet says: "He has blamed me for the failure of the conference; he could have justified such an attitude through founded arguments. But, for lack of any, he adopted the mood of machismo. According to John Prescott, a woman is necessarily incompetent and unable to physically bear such a negotiation. Compared to the stakes we are facing, this is laughable."

Last night Mr Prescott pledged continuing cooperation with his Green counterpart in Paris - "my phone is always there" - but joked his way out of the controversy by telling MPs: "A macho man ? Moi? I must say the remark leaves me most gutted. I did what I thought was best. We came close to an agreement. It was time that ran out for us."

The underlying reality last night was that Mr Prescott was caught in crossfire between Europe and the US - dubbed "the biggest polluter on the planet" - for playing the familiar British role as bridge-builder across the Atlantic.

Upping the stakes in a highly undiplomatic cross-channel slanging match - which coincides with tensions over the BSE issue and next month's EU summit in Nice - Ms Voynet had used an appearance on France's most popular morning radio show to deliver a personal putdown.

"John Prescott's statement is unacceptable, both in terms of what he said and how he said it," she said. "It was pathetic."

The survivor of a political culture at least as male-dominated as Britain's, she said Mr Prescott had "revealed himself to be deeply macho". Her voice laced with sarcasm, she added: "Of course, a woman is bound to be tired, scared and not able to understand things."

Despite Tony Blair's scheduled pre-summit dinner with President Jacques Chirac on Thursday, Downing St backed their man. Officials lavishly praised deputy prime minister's energetic three-year record of trying to curb envi ronmentally damaging emissions, notably by the US from whom - Mr Prescott told MPs yesterday - he had won valuable last-minute concessions.

They may not be on the table when talks resume in Bonn next May with what is likely to be a Republican-controlled administration, Mr Prescott admitted.

On Sunday, Mr Prescott said he was "gutted" and suggested Ms Voynet had not been up to pushing through a deal on cutting emissions of greenhouse gases.

"She got cold feet, felt she could not explain it, said she was exhausted and tired and could not understand the detail and then refused to accept it," he explained. "That is how the deal fell."

After other EU ministers and MEPs backed Ms Voynet and were supported in turn by Greenpeace and other green activists in Britain and Europe, Mr Prescott struck a conciliatory note when he reported to the Commons.

"I have worked and negotiated with Dominique Voynet for three years now. Her commitment to securing an agreement is as passionate as mine. We will both work together to ensure that agreement is reached." But he insisted he had nothing to apologise for.

It was Ms Voynet, a Green minister in Lionel Jospin's coalition, who had described herself as "tired," he repeated. Nor had he stormed out of the two-week summit, as reported. It ended when his last-minute attempt to broker a deal between the EU and the intransigent US delegation failed early on Saturday.

After three weekends away Mr Prescott admitted he had wanted to go home. But the talks were over and other ministers had left first. His Conservative shadow, Archie Norman, accused him of failing to understand the "subtleties" of the EU negotiating position and of letting down Britain's EU partners.

webTitle: Business: Pres.net follows in Santa's sleigh tracks

fields.headline: Pres.net follows in Santa's sleigh tracks
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: General Trading Company in London and Germany's Kaufhof are among retailers backing an initiative to give Father Christmas a helping hand through the internet.
fields.body:
General Trading Company in London and Germany's Kaufhof are among retailers backing an initiative to give Father Christmas a helping hand through the internet.

Pres.net, a worldwide gift service site, allows people to use the web to order goods from shops in the country where the present is to be delivered. The company, which says it has partnerships with top stores in many countries, says this cuts out the need for shipping.

"The idea for the company is like Interflora, with more potential and more imagination", Nik Nicholas, executive director of pres.net said.

Pres.net hopes to have stores in 17 countries on its site in time for Christmas and access to stores in 30 countries soon after. Partners include Brown Thomas in Dublin and Pres.net hopes to sign with Selfridges in time for Valentine's day.

Countries covered include Portugal, Singapore, Mexico and Korea, and the company is working to cover Switzerland, Israel and the US.

Pres.net, which is funded privately, aims to be profitable and to have shops from all major cities on board by the end of next year.

The company charges stores commission of about 4% for every order. Products must cost the same on the site as in the store, but partners can charge for wrapping and delivery.

Marketing, Mr Nicholas said, is mainly done by or in the individual stores. "People are basically being introduced to pres.net by a brand they know. Everyone knows who the shops are and the shops will tell everyone who we are."

Pres.net is also advertising in the Middle East, Far East and Europe in the run-up to Christmas.

fields.headline: Euro Wars
fields.standfirst:
The French minister hits back, as an anti-Europe tone breaks out again in Britain

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The French minister hits back, as an anti-Europe tone breaks out again in Britain. Dominique Voynet and Ros Coward write.
fields.body:
Dear John...

John Prescott blames me for the failure of the Hague conference. He could have used reasoned arguments. But, for lack of any, he adopted a standard macho attitude. According to Prescott, a woman is necessarily incompetent and can't physically last the course in such a negotiation. Such an argument is laughable compared with the stakes we face. What I care about is for us to be able to get on with implementing the Kyoto protocol and effectively reduce greenhouse gas emissions. It is an emergency.

The EU has been the group of countries most determined to find an agreement about how to implement the protocol while preserving its environmental integrity. We have indicated the main requirements: a genuine compliance system, ie a system of controls and penalties; action to combat loopholes, especially "carbon sinks"; supplementarity, ie priority given to national measures for combating the greenhouse effect, and support for developing countries so that they can join this battle.

We knew that not only the US, but also Japan and Canada, would have to be persuaded to face up to their responsibilities. The EU had constantly reaffirmed that it was ready for dialogue, and eventually for compromise, as long as it would lead to an effective cut in carbon emissions.

As president of the EU environment council, I went to the Hague to fight for this European position, prepared and decided by the 15 states. I went there convinced that it was right, and hoping that, given the demands of public opinion, the US and its partners would join with us in our determination to effectively combat the greenhouse effect. I also went there hoping that the EU would remain united and ready to fight, and would act with all its force, without any weakness from members.

In the final 36 hours we got from the US and its partners their agreement, for the first time, to enter a genuine and intense negotiation on all the issues. We led them to better understanding of our point of view. We convinced them of the necessity to take this into account. We remained firm over our objectives but willing to negotiate.

During the night, we managed to draw up the framework of a compliance regime acceptable to everyone. We brought closer together our points of view on supplementarity. But the US's requirements on carbon sinks would have reduced the very modest commitments to cut emissions made in Kyoto. The 15 EU states decided by an overwhelming majority not to accept such a bad compromise - particularly because the developing countries had not been party to it.

Of course we all lament that it was not possible to reach a fair agreement in the Hague. But it was not a useless conference. We advanced further during those 36 hours than during the three previous years; a compromise is feasible. For that we need the EU to remain strong, united and firm. I'd like to think that is what John Prescott was thinking when he went home. I am determined to keep working in this way over the coming weeks.

• Dominique Voynet is the French environment minister

Ros Coward writes:

The trashing of Dominique Voynet, France's environment minister, by Prescott and sections of the British press was astonishing. She was said to head a team of "French wreckers" who "sandbagged" Prescott. Or she was "too tired" to hammer out details of a compromise at the Hague implying she'd behaved "irrationally" before. What would you expect; French, a woman and an environmentalist - she might just as well have a couple of horns and a forked tail.

There were more obvious candidates for this diabolic role. The American negotiator Frank Loy went on Radio 4 to assert he would do nothing to "jeopardise the American lifestyle" and that the third world's best interests were served by America's growing - albeit polluting - economy.

But choosing Voynet as chief bogey-woman says much about the sorry state of British political culture. Days ago, Blair ranted about the British media's anti-Europeanism. Now he supports a deputy spouting sexist, chauvinistic and inaccurate nonsense.

In fact 15 European nations, of which Voynet was the chair, viewed the final compromise with the Americans as entirely dubious. This united refusal may prove a turning point in European political culture. In spite of Eurosceptic fantasies, Europe rarely acts as a political superstate. Individual countries are often divided by sectional interests. This time, even doubters like Denmark acted in concert for long-term well being. None was prepared to be bullied into accepting the indefensible.

Europe is growing more confident in resisting American imperialism and the idea that the interests of multinationals are the same as the interests of the world. This new political landscape won't melt away. There's a widespread perception that people are not in control of their own lives.

In the UK, though, this discontent has for the most part been harnessed to anti-European feelings which, after 20 years of press propaganda, are fertile ground. Fuel protesters are typical: European companies have unfair advantages; Europe interferes unnecessarily in their activities. But scratch the surface and there's something else. At a recent New Statesman meeting it was clear that the farmers at least had common ground with environmentalists. They were naive to imagine cheap fuel was the answer, but what they were actually concerned about was the loss of viable rural economy, the loss of local distinctiveness and the destruction of the countryside.

This is not to fall into a glib pro- Europeanism. On many occasions, the EU promotes multinationals' interests or acts like a small-scale global economy overriding local concerns. But on domestic emissions and the need for national and international action, European countries are way ahead. They have already done much, and know there's much more needed. Their new-found unity at the Hague in rejecting American imperialism could be the beginning of a new Europe.

fields.headline: Israel shifts to live bullets
fields.standfirst:
Assassinations and gunfire into mobs take rising Arab toll

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli troops are making increasing use of live ammunition against Palestinian protesters, according to an internal United Nations report obtained by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Israeli troops are making increasing use of live ammunition against Palestinian protesters, according to an internal United Nations report obtained by the Guardian.

Live fire now exceeds rubber-coated steel bullets, it says, and this has driven up casualties during the past two months of communal conflict in Israel and the Palestinian territories.

The finding has emerged from a study of Palestinian deaths and injuries by the policy unit of the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees (UNRWA). It has charted a steady rise in injuries from live fire since October 1, three days after the start of the Palestinian uprising, and a parallel decline in the use of rubber-coated bullets.

Since November 15 - the anniversary of a symbolic declaration of Palestinian independence which saw 10 Arabs shot dead by Israeli forces in the West Bank and Gaza - the use of live fire has exceeded rubber bullets. Last week, 70%-80% of all Palestinian injuries were caused by live bullets, the report says.

The study's other findings are in line with reports from international human rights organisations which document Israeli troops targetting the head and upper body, a policy blamed for the casualty figures: more than 280 dead in two months, and nearly 9,000 injured, almost all Palestinian.

The UNRWA report, which is based on statistics provided by the Palestinian Red Crescent Society, also notes the many children among the dead - 28% aged below 16.

The graph also indicates that on several days there was no use of rubber bullets before a resort to live ammunition.

Last week, the journalist Amira Hass published a chilling account of a day in the life of an Israeli sharpshooter in the Ha'aretz newspaper. The high velocity bullets used by the Israeli snipers break up inside the body.

"Every day before we go out they define the principles for opening fire," the sniper told Ha'aretz. "This also changes from place to place." Commanders loosened restrictions after a Palestinian mob hacked and burned two Israeli reservists to death in Ramallah on October 12, the man said.

"After the lynch, for example, the orders for opening fire were far more lenient than they had been the day before."

The unnamed sniper added: "Every time, after there is a serious incident, it's political, you can feel it."

But he also said that commanders often held back trigger-happy conscripts, and were terrified of shooting children after the outpouring of condemnation of the killing of Mohammed al-Durreh, a Gaza boy shot dead in his father's arms in front of TV cameras. "You don't shoot at a child who is 12 or younger," he told Ha'aretz. "Twelve and up is allowed. He is not a child any more, he is already after his bar mitzvah."

The UN made its findings available on the day when George Mitchell, a former US senator who was a key mediator in the Northern Ireland accord, formally started work on a fact-finding commission looking into the violence. He is to submit his report in March.

The UN human rights chief, Mary Robinson, yesterday spoke out in favour of an international monitoring body for the region - a demand Israel categorically rejects.

"The thrust of the [UNRWA] report is urgently calling international attention to the bleak human rights situation in occupied territories," Ms Robinson said in Geneva yesterday. She called for "measures to be taken to reduce the terrible violence".

Israeli army officials argue that soldiers have been forced to use live fire by Arab gunmen who hide among crowds of civilians and children.

Earlier this month, an army legal expert, Colonel Daniel Reisner, said: "The current situation has more of a semblance of war than of peace," and "as a result, we are also applying the principles applicable to warfare."

According to him, the main change of strategy has been to target and assassinate men Israel accuses of leading militias that have attacked its soldiers and settlers.

fields.headline: After the deluge, a heatwave
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: After the gales that turned seaside caravans into matchwood and the torrential rain that caused floods, Britain faces a further outbreak of freak weather: a heatwave.
fields.body:
After the gales that turned seaside caravans into matchwood and the torrential rain that caused floods, Britain faces a further outbreak of freak weather: a heatwave.

The country may have just suffered the wettest autumn since records began almost 300 years ago, but weather forecasters were predicting that temperatures today could reach an almost unprecedented 17C (63F) in some parts.

The last time November 28 was that warm was in 1979, but many parts of the country will see some rain, while the long term forecast for the rest of the month remains unsettled.

According to the Met Office, a band of warm air from the Azores will cause today's mini-heatwave

A forecaster predicted that the north Kent coast and parts of East Anglia are most likely to experience the highest temperatures. Temperatures in London, which average around 9C at this time of year, are expected to rise to 15C. The unseasonal temperatures will bring some relief for thousands of people still clearing up after the worst floods in living memory.

An average of 18.11 inches of rain has fallen across England and Wales this autumn - 77% more than usual - beating the previous record of 17.94 inches set in 1852.

fields.headline: I2S halts flotations until hostility ends
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Neville Buch, exhibitions organiser turned chairman of dot.com incubator firm I2S, yesterday called a halt to floating fledgling businesses until investor aversion to technology shares eases.
fields.body:
Neville Buch, exhibitions organiser turned chairman of dot.com incubator firm I2S, yesterday called a halt to floating fledgling businesses until investor aversion to technology shares eases.

Mr Buch warned that there had been a significant change in attitude towards some sectors of the new economy and spoke of a return to a more traditional assessment of investments.

As a result, "the possibilities of securing exits by stock market flotation are limited".

I2S has stakes in two quoted companies: Getmapping.com, which provides aerial photos to businesses customers, and i-Onyx, a Hong Kong-listed technology investment fund.

Despite counting the Queen among its shareholders, Getmapping has not found favour on the stock exchange. I2S has seen its stake in Getmapping, bought at £2 a share, fall to 51.5p yesterday.

Mr Buch said i-Oynx had spent recent months assembling a technical and investment team and its share price had risen about HK$0.37 since I2S bought its stake at HK$1.

The incubator firm also has a stake in Sit-up.com, the interactive television company which is starting a string of niche channels, the first of which, auction channel bid-up.tv, is on Sky Digital.

It also has an interest in Eighteen Global, a golfing website backed by Nick Faldo and Ernie Els.

Mr Buch, who founded the Blenheim exhibitions group before selling it to United News and Media for £600m in 1996, said: "While the companies have not met their targets to date, we are confident that by adhering to their original strategy and by capitalising on what is now effectively a dominant position they will realise significant value from their content."

Shares in I2S remained unchanged at 65p yesterday.

Mr Buch warned that there had been a significant change in attitude towards some sectors of the new economy and spoke of a return to a more traditional assessment of investments.
