fields.headline: Failed Norman conquest aids Prescott's French war
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Mr Macho Man, John Prescott, scourge of the Frogs, unreconstructed male chauvinist cochon, came to the Commons yesterday to give his version of the weekend debacle at the Hague talks on global warming.
fields.body:
Mr Macho Man, John Prescott, scourge of the Frogs, unreconstructed male chauvinist cochon, came to the Commons yesterday to give his version of the weekend debacle at the Hague talks on global warming.

Given the list of disasters that have attended the deputy prime minister's recent efforts, including the train chaos, the air traffic privatisation nonsense, his urgent desire to shaft Ken Livingstone even if it means the end of all public transport in London apart from a couple of one-man buses, and now this slanging match with his French opposite number, he came over yesterday with a modicum of dignity.

And compared to Archie Norman, the Tories' environment spokesman , he emerged as a world statesman, a man of experience, wisdom and stature.

It didn't help that Mr Norman's response had been written out - before he even heard Mr Prescott's statement - in the form of Japanese haikus, or possibly extracts from the more obscure works of TS Eliot.

"He set high expectations for the Hague talks/

And he has himself said/

In the vernacular of the professional footballer/

That he was 'gutted' by this breakdown.

In the room the women come and go/

Talking of Michaelangelo ..."

(No, Eliot made the last bit up, but the whole thing has a fine, melancholy rhythm.)

I particularly liked the line about the "vernacular of the professional footballer", which has a great "The Spice Girls are a popular beat combo, m'lud" ring to it.

"Or does the prime minister's renowned disdain for matters environmental" - WS Gilbert would have been proud of that line - "Mean he doesn't want to be involved/

And that the deputy prime minister was hung out to dry?" he asked, in the vernacular of the professional washerwoman.

"And to dismiss French anxieties as 'getting cold feet'?" he continued, in the vernacular of the professional sock salesman.

"Isn't the final indignity/

That the secretary of state for Northern Ireland/

Is now briefing that he wants his job,/

The man he held up to the world/

As a crab in a jar ?"

The metaphysical poets would have relished that line: "I am but a crab in a jar/

Held up to the world/

Lift me with thy hand, oh Lord/

Cover me with the soothing balm of thy mayonnaise ..."

He ended with what sounded like an extract from Robert Browning, How They Brought the Bad News from the Hague to Westminster, perhaps.

"And wasn't yesterday's collapse/

Just the final collapse/

Of the credibility of a failed deputy prime minister?"

The failed deputy prime minister himself made a desperate attempt to make his peace with the French. "To be fair to the French government," he said at one point, and a chorus of Tories yelled "Why? Why?" He even praised Dominique Voynet, the environment minister whose commitment to a pact restraining global warming was "as passionate as mine". Yes, he admitted genially, he had said she was tired - not his judgment, but hers. "She constantly said that she was too tired ... I don't blame her, these were very complex negotiations ..."

At this point he teetered, perhaps on the brink of saying something catastrophic, such as "for a woman's brain to cope with", but he recovered: "To be fair, most ministers were tired after 36 hours of negotiations ..." and sank back in his seat, like a weary crab falling back to the bottom of the jar.

webTitle: Tattooists own goal leaves Beckham a marked man

fields.headline: Tattooists own goal leaves Beckham a marked man
fields.trailText: It was meant as a very public statement of love and affection. But last night David Beckham was left with a face as red as his Manchester United shirt after it emerged that a tattoo on his arm bearing his wife Victoria's name in Hindi has been misspelt.
fields.body:
It was meant as a very public statement of love and affection. But last night David Beckham was left with a face as red as his Manchester United shirt after it emerged that a tattoo on his arm bearing his wife Victoria's name in Hindi has been misspelt.

The letter H was incorrectly included, leaving his wife's name reading as VIHCTORIA.

Hindi experts in Britain spotted the mistake yesterday after Beckham was photographed wearing a T-shirt showing off the misspelt tattoo, done in Hindi because he liked the look of the language.

Padmesh Gupta, president of the United Kingdom Hindi committee and editor of Purvai, a Hindi language magazine said: "Whoever wrote this tattoo is clearly not a Hindi expert. There is no H in Victoria when it is written in Hindi."

A spokesman for the Hindi department at the Indian High Commission in central London said: "Victoria is a name that we are used to writing in Hindi because of Queen Victoria. I can assure you that there is no H in Victoria.

"But the tattoo is quite artistic and it is good that Hindi is getting this sort of publicity."

Beckham's agents appeared bemused yesterday over the spelling and the word Hindi itself. A spokeswoman for Outside Organisation, which looks after Beckham's non-footballing interests, said with authority: "You have to understand that there is a difference between Hindi and Hindu. The tattoo has been checked by a Hindu expert. It's not as if David Beckham just walked into a tattoo parlour and got it done. It was carefully designed."

When told that Hindi is a language and Hindu a religion, the spokeswoman insisted: "We know the tattoo is spelt correctly."

A spokeswoman for SFX, which looks after Beckham's football interests, said: "Oh dear, I'll have to tell David there's a mistake on his arm next time he telephones in."

webTitle: Caught in a climate of change...

fields.headline: Caught in a climate of change...
fields.standfirst:
Prescott faces a winter of discontent as French minister's 'macho' attack may prove a problem too far

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Prescott faces a winter of discontent as French minister's 'macho' attack may prove a problem too far.
fields.body:
John Prescott does not want to be remembered as the man who failed, as he might put it, to save the bloody world. The deputy prime minister's intemperate outburst, blaming "exhausted" Dominique Voynet's "cold feet" for the collapsed climate change talks, was borne out of a deep personal frustration.

He knows he might not get another chance to strike a deal that would make a difference, because his tenure as secretary of state of the environment, transport and regions is likely to end in the first reshuffle after the election, if Labour is re-elected.

The French environment minister's dismissal of one of Britain's most senior politicians as a male chauvinist pig, "an inveterate macho man", threatens to feature prominently in Mr Prescott's political obituary.

He has attempted to make a virtue of an unspun man-of-the-people image, appealing to that sizeable chunk of the public who still prefer colourful politicians over Millbank androids.

But Mme Voynet's riposte will strike a chord with a worryingly large number of women MPs, and a fair few men. There were murmurings about his sexist behaviour a few weeks ago when he branded Tory MP Anne McIntosh a "twit", Mr Prescott later insisting it was because she was a twit and nothing to do with her being a woman.

When he was caught driving a few hundred yards at a Labour conference after preaching the virtues of public transport, he blamed the trip on the need to protect wife Pauline's hair do from the Bournemouth weather. And when he confronted Chumbawumba's Dunbert Nobacon after the band member drenched him with a bucket of water at the Brit awards, Mr Prescott insisted he had been anxious to protect "the women".

Friends insist he is not sexist other than of the "old school" type, opening doors for women and letting them slam for men.

Certainly he shows little sign of acknowledging the offence he caused with his attack on Mme Voynet, trying to shrug it off in the Commons yesterday. A great tribalist, part of his anomosity may have been motivated by the fact she is a Green party minister - a political grouping Mr Prescott is unable to take seriously.

Bruiser

Mr Prescott does not plan to freewheel to the election and DETR officials maintain he is serious about attempting to salvage the climate talks before playing what is expected to be a prominent role in Labour's campaign. The risk is he will be less of an asset than in 1997.

Famous for his blunt speaking, Mr Prescott's image is of a thick-skinned political bruiser, who gives as good as he gets. Yet those closest to him see a more vulnerable, sensitive side of a secondary modern pupil anxious to prove he earned his place at the cabinet table.

"You [the public and media] never see the real John Prescott," said a government ally recently. "He is brilliant behind the scenes and will not duck an issue in public. That is why he gets such a bad press."

What is undoubtedly true, however, is the former union negotiator's failure to land that deal in the Hague can be added to a growing list of problems that refuse to leave his in-tray. The rail system is in crisis with the network in worse shape than when Labour won power, while the much-vaunted integrated transport plan has yet to be delivered.

Mr Prescott delivered one of the great hostages to fortune when he declared: "I will have failed if in five years there are not more people using public transport and far fewer journeys by car."

He has not passed his own test and risks being remembered as the Labour left-winger who attempted to privatise air traffic control and the London tube while refusing to take a public stake in the railway despite widespread support for at least partial renationalisation.

Some policy successes have been enjoyed by Mr Prescott, such as delivering eight regional development agencies and driving forward some key recommendations from the urban taskforce led by Lord Rogers.

He is also considered to talk sense about climate change and traditional Labour supporters recognise he played an important role in curbing the wilder excesses of the new Labour apparatchiks.

He cannot be said, however, to be one of the cabinet's stars. There is some truth in the jibe that John Prescott is the deputy prime minister but the prime minister's deputy is Mr Brown or Alastair Campbell or even Peter Mandelson. He is regularly consulted by Mr Blair but has fallen out with Downing Street advisers, and friends admit his influence is waning.

During the early days of the government it promised to be so different as Al Gore heaped praise on Mr Prescott for delivering the Kyoto limits on greenhouse gases. Catalyst, the centre-left think tank, rated him the most effective minister in an audit of the government's first year, applauding Mr Prescott's verve.

Some ministerial colleagues chart his decline to Mr Prescott's inability to get his transport bill included in Labour's second queen's speech, requiring him to wait until this year.

Mr Prescott has claimed he is the victim of snobbish abuse, particularly over his brushes with the English language, and has enjoyed some public sympathy. Mme Voynet's criticism cannot be so easily dismissed and may be seen as evidence that Mr Prescott, a politician who likes to present himself as in touch with ordinary people, is increasingly out of touch.

webTitle: Arts: The ICA's Aernout Mik exhibition

fields.headline: Like a pop festival on the Somme
fields.standfirst: At first Adrian Searle was bored rigid by Aernout Mik's three strange installations at the ICA. By the time he left, he was comparing him to Rembrandt
fields.trailText: At first Adrian Searle was bored rigid by Aernout Mik's three strange installations at the ICA. By the time he left, he was comparing him to Rembrandt.
fields.body:
There's a screen at the end of a corridor built through one of the ICA's upper galleries. On it, a couple of girls are hanging around in a room filled with a pop band's gear, a foldaway bed, and a coffeepot on a stove. They wander in and out of frame, in and out of focus. Bored, they bounce a volleyball around, and occasionally one of them leaves the room for a minute.

Christ, this is dull, I think - typical ICA balls-achingly boring stuff. My mind wanders: oh dear, oh dearie me, the critic's lot. One of the girls is just sitting there, mouth open, immobile. Bounce, bounce, bounce goes the ball. The sound quality's good - that's one thing you can say. And the door opening and closing, it could almost be in the next room. And is it me, or do I smell coffee? Hang on - it is in the next room: this is live, and happening just over the wall from where I'm leaning.

The camera is slowly zooming in and out, focusing on a life-size head stuck to the wall. Now the head fills the screen. It looks like a slightly inane, blue-eyed, dyed-blonde Dutchman - a football star maybe, or a Netherlandish Jean-Paul Gaultier lookalike. Definitely a denizen of one of those Amsterdam dope bars. Here he comes again.

The girls next door, it turns out, are students from Central St Martins art college in London, co-opted into this stultifying drama. I guess their servitude in this installation, Sliding Room, isn't much different from being in college - hanging around all day in a little studio cubicle, waiting not for Godot, but for a tutor who never comes, and who probably wouldn't be worth talking to if he did.

One begins to think of all this in terms of a behavioural experiment, except for that damned head stuck to the wall. His slack-mouthed, blank countenance mimics the boredom of the scene. He, too, appears mesmerised by the dullness of it. Why, you ask, why?

Welcome to the world according to Dutch artist Aernout Mik. It is a place where people hang around doing odd things, or almost nothing at all, for a very long time, and in what we might call challenging circumstances. I first saw Mik's work - and was confused, amused and alarmed at it - in the Dutch pavilion at the Venice Biennale five years ago.

In one video, a bunch of pugnacious old guys were milling about, having a senior citizens' punch-up in a kitchen. In another, a sullen group lounged around in a white space, connected to fat hosepipes that gurgled and spouted and leaked blue goo through their clothing. They had an air of normality, unperturbed by their situation.

Mik's 3 Crowds, an exhibition of three works (two of which have been specially made for the space), is the first decent exhibition of new work at the ICA for a very long time. A second two-screen video, Piñata, shows a white room where a group of middle-aged people are smashing things up.

There's soil on the floor, and they're hacking away at a lot of chunky, pink-painted polystyrene blocks. The task is endless, as more blocks get hurled on-screen whenever it looks like their job might be done. A lot of chairs need smashing to bits, too, and a couple of people are wrenching a perfectly serviceable baby-buggy apart with their bare hands. A man with his shirt off, a sort of amateur Hercules, wields the back of a dining-room chair, going at the polystyrene chunks like a biblical hero with an ass's jaw as his only weapon.

The women, on the other hand, are more diligent and concentrated, hacking those chunks of plastic down into little chips. Then a whole lot of earth falls from above, in a great whooshing cloud of dust, as though someone had just emptied a giant bag of garden peat into the room. No one seems to notice. Their labour is never done. Bring on more chairs.

A work called Lumber fills the downstairs gallery. You walk in through a chest-high corridor, to a central space where an array of screens show disconnected views of a crowd, outdoors in the mud. Mats on the floor encourage you to sit, as though among them. Along the way, one passes a rubber disc set flush with the wall. Connected to an air pump, it flexes in and out, as though the wall itself were breathing. I don't know what this means. It must mean something.

The people lounge about on besmirched blankets, on bits of polythene and on opened-up cardboard boxes. Some have thought to bring inflatable mattresses. Here's a yellow beach parasol, wearing a tide-line of mud. Bright colours - a gaudy poncho, a red blanket - make this brown and grey world look worse.

The sun comes out, more as an insult than as a promise, because it soon goes in again. It is coming on to rain now. The cameras scan the crowds, the little groups on their mud allotments. Everything is caked in mud, clogged in mud, slowly sinking into the mire. Feet squelch past, through the rubbish and scummy puddles. Someone in a wheelchair churns slowly by.

You have to be really keen, drunk or stoned to stay here: it is like a pop festival on the Somme. A truly horrible scene, this Europe after the rain. The camera lingers. There's a baby-stroller; here's a couple of sorry-looking dogs, making the best of it. Some of the people are trying to sunbathe or to sleep, and to ignore their circumstances. Others are sitting up, clapping to an unseen band playing on a stage miles away. We neither see the band nor hear it: the footage is silent. In fact, these bog people are the main attraction.

You come out feeling queasy, a bit sea-sick, after spending time among them. It could be the sway and pitch of the camera, the disjointedness of the multiple projections. But what eventually strikes you, staring at your on-screen fellows, is the peculiarity of their movements. They appear at times almost to levitate, or to lift themselves up from their blankets with an unnatural slowness, and without seeming to prop themselves up. It is as if the mud, instead of sucking them down, were rejecting them. At first you don't notice this. Only later did I learn that there were people hidden in holes under the mud, pushing upwards from below. And that the footage was not shot at some Dutch popfest, but staged by Mik.

What we have been watching are exercises in entropy - worlds running out of energy, things breaking down, returning to the earth. It strikes me that this is a very Low Countries obsession: think of the work of Belgian sculptor Thierry de Cordier, or the early, mud-coloured, big-booted works of Van Gogh.

I recall the earthiness of Beuys, born in the north German flatlands near the Dutch border; and of Dutch sculptor Mark Manders, his root-like figures, attenuated, parsnip-like golems. Yet placing Mik's work is not so easy. He uses video, a projected record of a performance in a constructed space, but the place where you watch it is also staged - another set. His work can be read as a meditation on sculpture - on mass, form, liquidity, inertia, the interaction of people and things.

It is also intensely choreographed. Unlike, say, American artist Anne Hamilton and the performers in her tableaux, Mik does not treat people as living props, or merely as bodies. There's a psychology at work here. His works remind me, too, of the sculptural situations and routines in Pina Bausch's dance works: her use of the stage as more than a container, and of objects as more than things.

Mik re-invigorates the different media his work touches. Best of all, leaving the ICA, you begin to see the world his way, something that only good art does. Leave a Rembrandt show (and there's another Dutch artist whose work meditates on entropy - on bodies, time, earth and death) and everyone has Rembrandt wrinkles.

After Mik, the shoppers on Piccadilly walk in slow time, picking at inexplicable presentations of rags in stagey clothes shops, maundering about in that weird shopping light, blundering and transfixed, at once mesmerised and lost. They wander in and out, going nowhere. Entropy and rain are in the air, and the whole world feels like an installation.

 Aernout Mik: 3 Crowds is at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, London SW1 (020-7930 3647), until January 7.

I guess their servitude in this installation, Sliding Room, isn't much different from being in college - hanging around all day in a little studio cubicle, waiting not for Godot, but for a tutor who never comes, and who probably wouldn't be worth talking to if he did. One begins to think of all this in terms of a behavioural experiment, except for that damned head stuck to the wall. His slack-mouthed, blank countenance mimics the boredom of the scene. He, too, appears mesmerised by the dullness of it. Why, you ask, why? Welcome to the world according to Dutch artist Aernout Mik. It is a place where people hang around doing odd things, or almost nothing at all, for a very long time, and in what we might call challenging circumstances. I first saw Mik's work - and was confused, amused and alarmed at it - in the Dutch pavilion at the Venice Biennale five years ago. In one video, a bunch of pugnacious old guys were milling about, having a senior citizens' punch-up in a kitchen. In another, a sullen group lounged around in a white space, connected to fat hosepipes that gurgled and spouted and leaked blue goo through their clothing. They had an air of normality, unperturbed by their situation. Mik's 3 Crowds, an exhibition of three works (two of which have been specially made for the space), is the first decent exhibition of new work at the ICA for a very long time. A second two-screen video, Piñata, shows a white room where a group of middle-aged people are smashing things up. There's soil on the floor, and they're hacking away at a lot of chunky, pink-painted polystyrene blocks. The task is endless, as more blocks get hurled on-screen whenever it looks like their job might be done. A lot of chairs need smashing to bits, too, and a couple of people are wrenching a perfectly serviceable baby-buggy apart with their bare hands. A man with his shirt off, a sort of amateur Hercules, wields the back of a dining-room chair, going at the polystyrene chunks like a biblical hero with an ass's jaw as his only weapon. The women, on the other hand, are more diligent and concentrated, hacking those chunks of plastic down into little chips. Then a whole lot of earth falls from above, in a great whooshing cloud of dust, as though someone had just emptied a giant bag of garden peat into the room. No one seems to notice. Their labour is never done. Bring on more chairs. A work called Lumber fills the downstairs gallery. You walk in through a chest-high corridor, to a central space where an array of screens show disconnected views of a crowd, outdoors in the mud. Mats on the floor encourage you to sit, as though among them. Along the way, one passes a rubber disc set flush with the wall. Connected to an air pump, it flexes in and out, as though the wall itself were breathing. I don't know what this means. It must mean something. The people lounge about on besmirched blankets, on bits of polythene and on opened-up cardboard boxes. Some have thought to bring inflatable mattresses. Here's a yellow beach parasol, wearing a tide-line of mud. Bright colours - a gaudy poncho, a red blanket - make this brown and grey world look worse. The sun comes out, more as an insult than as a promise, because it soon goes in again. It is coming on to rain now. The cameras scan the crowds, the little groups on their mud allotments. Everything is caked in mud, clogged in mud, slowly sinking into the mire. Feet squelch past, through the rubbish and scummy puddles. Someone in a wheelchair churns slowly by. You have to be really keen, drunk or stoned to stay here: it is like a pop festival on the Somme. A truly horrible scene, this Europe after the rain. The camera lingers. There's a baby-stroller; here's a couple of sorry-looking dogs, making the best of it. Some of the people are trying to sunbathe or to sleep, and to ignore their circumstances. Others are sitting up, clapping to an unseen band playing on a stage miles away. We neither see the band nor hear it: the footage is silent. In fact, these bog people are the main attraction. You come out feeling queasy, a bit sea-sick, after spending time among them. It could be the sway and pitch of the camera, the disjointedness of the multiple projections. But what eventually strikes you, staring at your on-screen fellows, is the peculiarity of their movements. They appear at times almost to levitate, or to lift themselves up from their blankets with an unnatural slowness, and without seeming to prop themselves up. It is as if the mud, instead of sucking them down, were rejecting them. At first you don't notice this. Only later did I learn that there were people hidden in holes under the mud, pushing upwards from below. And that the footage was not shot at some Dutch popfest, but staged by Mik. What we have been watching are exercises in entropy - worlds running out of energy, things breaking down, returning to the earth. It strikes me that this is a very Low Countries obsession: think of the work of Belgian sculptor Thierry de Cordier, or the early, mud-coloured, big-booted works of Van Gogh. I recall the earthiness of Beuys, born in the north German flatlands near the Dutch border; and of Dutch sculptor Mark Manders, his root-like figures, attenuated, parsnip-like golems. Yet placing Mik's work is not so easy. He uses video, a projected record of a performance in a constructed space, but the place where you watch it is also staged - another set. His work can be read as a meditation on sculpture - on mass, form, liquidity, inertia, the interaction of people and things. It is also intensely choreographed. Unlike, say, American artist Anne Hamilton and the performers in her tableaux, Mik does not treat people as living props, or merely as bodies. There's a psychology at work here. His works remind me, too, of the sculptural situations and routines in Pina Bausch's dance works: her use of the stage as more than a container, and of objects as more than things. Mik re-invigorates the different media his work touches. Best of all, leaving the ICA, you begin to see the world his way, something that only good art does. Leave a Rembrandt show (and there's another Dutch artist whose work meditates on entropy - on bodies, time, earth and death) and everyone has Rembrandt wrinkles. After Mik, the shoppers on Piccadilly walk in slow time, picking at inexplicable presentations of rags in stagey clothes shops, maundering about in that weird shopping light, blundering and transfixed, at once mesmerised and lost. They wander in and out, going nowhere. Entropy and rain are in the air, and the whole world feels like an installation.  Aernout Mik: 3 Crowds is at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, London SW1 (020-7930 3647), until January 7.

webTitle: Business: CBI wants more from Blair

fields.headline: CBI wants more from Blair
fields.trailText: The CBI last night put the government on pre-election probation as the party of business by demanding a package of measures to cut taxes and regulations.
fields.body:
The CBI last night put the government on pre-election probation as the party of business by demanding a package of measures to cut taxes and regulations.

Digby Jones, CBI director general, awarded ministers top marks for achieving macro-economic stability but assailed them for their "ignorance and misunderstanding" of industry's needs and "flawed and inept" imposition of burdensome regulations.

Mr Jones nevertheless welcomed as "an important shift in the right direction" the prime minister's announcement of a package of "business friendly" initiatives including more than 20 to be enshrined in the regulatory reform bill, due to figure in next week's Queen's speech.

The CBI also joined forces with other business lobbies in hailing government plans to make it more difficult for employees to pursue "vexatious" or "weak" infair dismissal claims.

Tony Blair's announcement came at a Downing Street meeting with entrepreneurs designed to convince them that the government is committed to reforming outdated and unnecessary regulation.

But, in advance of tonight's CBI manufacturing dinner in Birmingham, Mr Jones insisted that Labour had increased taxes on business by £5bn a year and imposed a £12.3bn burden on companies through employment legislation alone.

Labour - or any other political party - would win the business vote at the next general election by proving it understood further rules and taxes acted as a disincentive to investment - and long-term economic success needed a flourishing manufacturing base.

The CBI specifically wants Labour to drop its plans for paid parental leave and the legal right to part-time work for mothers returning to employment.

It wants the chancellor to use his March Budget to extend research and development tax credits to all companies, and to ease implementation of the climate change levy or energy tax for manufacturing firms.

"The levy in its present form is threatening the very sector which contributes £150bn a year to the economy and employs 15% of the workforce," Mr Jones said.

The government had earlier laid plans for enabling tribunals to strike out ill-founded claims for unfair dismissal, raising the deposit on pursuing a weak case from £150 to £500 and increasing allowable costs for unreasonable behaviour from £500 to £10,000.

Although John Edmonds, leader of the GMB union, condemned the plans as "an absolute disgrace", other union leaders said the bulk of weak cases were pursued by non-union members and the changes were a spur for employers to recognise unions.

webTitle: Kostunica asks Nato to control rebels

fields.headline: Kostunica asks Nato to control rebels
fields.standfirst:
Ethnic Albanian guerrillas dig in despite troop buildup and Yugoslav president's urgent plea for peacekeepers to calm rising tensions

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Ethnic Albanian guerrillas dig in despite troop buildup and Yugoslav president's urgent plea for peacekeepers to calm rising tensions.
fields.body:
President Vojislav Kostunica made an emotional plea to UN and Nato leaders yesterday to stop ethnic Albanian gunmen killing Serb policemen, or risk the region being set ablaze.

The Yugoslav leader, accompanied by his army chief of staff, General Nebojsa Pavkovic, and the Serbianstate security chief, Rade Markovic, travelled to Bujanovic in the south-eastern Kosovo-Serbian buffer zone to try to stop the already tense situation spiralling out of control.

In letters to Nato secretar,y general, George Robertson and the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, Mr Kostunica pressed for "concrete deeds, not supportive words", saying that Serbia was sticking to its side of a security bargain for the zone which had tied its hands.

The Albanian guerrilla group's commander, Shefqet Musliu, appeared in defiant mood, despite the increase in Yugoslav troops in the region and news that the Serbian ceasefire had been extended until Friday.

Speaking from his headquarters in Dobrosin, half a mile from the boundary with Kosovo, he said he did not have faith in the Serbs keeping their word.

"We are happy to keep the ceasefire but, as we all know from Kosovo, lots of KLA fighters were betrayed in ceasefires," he said. "We are keeping our eyes open and we are in our positions, and I say that if a Serb even gets with in 200 to 300 metres we will open fire."

He spoke in an office, alongside two of his deputies. All three had beards, and wore khaki uniform with gold, red and black badges on their sleeves embroidered with the letters UCPMB, the initials of the Preshevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac Liberation Army which seized a key Serbian police checkpoint last week.

The group wants to unite three Albanian-speaking municipalities with those in Serbia with Kosovo. The three towns were part of the province until 1957, when they were made part of Serbia.

The group point to a referendum held in 1992 in which 97% of Albanians voted for independence from Serbia.

Mr Musliu said he would prefer to settle the issue at the negotiating table. "We do not want to be killed, or see our women and children die."

But he doubted that the Serbs wouldl agree to their demands. In the meantime, he said, they would fight to control the region. "How long it will take I don't know. It's possible that some of us commanders will not be here to see it happen, but somebody will."

As many as 200 cars carrying up to 800 refugees entered Kosovo yesterday through one border checkpoint manned by American troops of the Nato-led peacekeeping force, K-For, a spokesman for the UNHCR said.

News of the ceasefire extension failed to stem the influx, however.

Outside Dobrosin there was an air of panic as rumours spread that 20 Yugoslav tanks had been brought up to the frontline.

"While we've been sitting in the warm, they've been fortifying their positions," said a guard dressed in black fatigues with initials PU on an armband, the standard uniform of the Kosovo Liberation Army's military police.

Small numbers of guerrillas could be seen scattered along the muddy track that leads from Dobrosin to Konculj, the rebels' latest conquest.

Most of them were lightly armed with Kalashnikov semi-automatic rifles. Dugouts and new trenches lined the hills.

Back on the Kosovan side of the boundary, American and Russian troops were busy checking a line of cars trying to enter the province.

Nearby, the UNHCR was monitoring events. Peter Dick, an American field-officer with the refugee agency, said that at the moment the majority of refugees are being housed with relatives.

If the Serbs launched an offensive, he said, the number of refugees would rise sharply. Public buildings had already been identified in he added.

fields.headline: Soviets shot war hero Wallenberg
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A Russian committee set up to rehabilitate the victims of Soviet repression believes that the Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg was executed in the notorious Lubyanka prison, Interfax news agency reported yesterday.
fields.body:
A Russian committee set up to rehabilitate the victims of Soviet repression believes that the Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg was executed in the notorious Lubyanka prison, Interfax news agency reported yesterday.

The statement contradicted the traditional Soviet line on Wallenberg, who helped thousands of Jews flee the Holocaust and disappeared in 1945 in Budapest after Soviet troops arrested him.

In 1957 the Soviets said they had a doctor's note from 1947 showing that Wallenberg had died of a heart attack that year at the age of 34 in the Lubyanka, headquarters of the NKVD secret police.

A Russian-Swedish committee has been set up to investigate what exactly happened to Wallenberg after his arrest.

"Now we have no doubts he was shot in the Lubyanka," Interfax quoted Alexander Yakovlev, head of the Presidential Commission on the Rehabilitation of Victims of Political Repression, as saying.

He said he expected the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, to issue a decree rehabilitating Wallenberg.

"[The decree will say that] Wallenberg was a victim of Stalin's repression."

Mr Yakovlev said that some of Wallenberg's possessions had been handed over to Swedish officials. A Swedish member of the joint commission said Stockholm had seen no official documents confirming Moscow's intention to rehabilitate Wallenberg, but it backed the idea.

"Of course this is something that we welcome," Jan Lundvik, a Swedish foreign ministry official, said.

"It is an admission of the previous mistake that once was made. The mistake was to arrest him and then also to apparently put him to death since he is now being rehabilitated as a victim of repression."

Wallenberg, a member of Sweden's most powerful industrial family, was sent to Budapest as a diplomat on a secret mission. The original Soviet version said that Wallenberg, regarded as a hero for his efforts to rescue Jews in Hungary from almost certain death in Nazi camps, was arrested as a spy in 1945 in the Hungarian town of Debrecen.

He was never heard of again, but there has always been a suspicion that he was executed. Reuters

webTitle: Business: Corus and Vauxhall feel pinch

fields.headline: Corus and Vauxhall feel pinch
fields.trailText: British industry is shutting down plants and laying off staff temporarily to cope with declining orders.
fields.body:
British industry is shutting down plants and laying off staff temporarily to cope with declining orders.

Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, has closed two blast furnaces making 40,000 tonnes of iron a week at Llanwern, Gwent, and Scunthorpe, Lincolnshire, while it waits for a pick-up in demand.

There are fears in south Wales that the group's latest moves could presage further cuts in capacity, with the entire Llanwern plant, employing some 3,000 people, under renewed threat of closure.

Vauxhall confirmed it will extend the Christmas shutdown of its Luton car plant from one to four weeks because of falling orders for its Vectra models and deteriorating trading conditions, partly caused by the strength of sterling.

Chairman Nick Reilly said, that the next few months would be difficult. The Luton staff will, under the group's flexibility agreement, have to pay back the hours when demand is restored.

webTitle: Business: Cammel workers launch liner's midsection into limbo

fields.headline: Tug of war
fields.standfirst: Cammel workers launch liner's midsection into limbo
fields.trailText: Cammell Laird workers yesterday launched the 26,000-ton midsection of the Italian cruise ship Costa Classica on the Mersey from the company's Birkenhead yard.
fields.body:
Cammell Laird workers yesterday launched the 26,000-ton midsection of the Italian cruise ship Costa Classica on the Mersey from the company's Birkenhead yard.

But the 45-metre section will stay in Cammell's wet basin until resolution of a legal dispute between the company and the ship's owner, Costa Crociere, over the £51m contract.

The Italians last week forced the captain of the Costa Classica to turn around off the coast of Spain and head home for Genoa, claiming that the British yard had breached its contract through substantial delays and failing to complete the top decks of the section.

Cammell, which rejects the Italian cruise line's claim for arbitration, is to hold talks with union officials later this week about the possibility of hundreds of lay-offs among the 1,000-strong workforce.

The AEEU union, which has accused the Italians of "commercial piracy", said it sided with Cammell and would do all it could to help resolve the unwarranted dispute.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Immelt follows Welch at GE
fields.body:
Immelt follows Welch at GE

General Electric, the world's biggest company, yesterday named Jeffrey Immelt, head of its medical systems division, to succeed Jack Welch as its chairman and chief executive.

The 44-year-old Mr Immelt beat off two fellow executives at the American industrial, financial services and broadcasting conglomerate to be chosen to take the helm at the start of 2002.

Mr Immelt, who has been at GE for 18 years, will come under pressure to emulate his predecessor - often cited as the most-admired business leader in the world - and institute a series of radical changes.

Old Lady under fire from Unifi

The Bank of England is being sued over the sacking of six staff who refused to sign "inferior" contracts. Finance union Unifi accused the bank of failing to follow legal procedures over the way it terminated the employment of the workers, who included secretaries and analysts.

The five women and one man complained that the new contracts cut holidays, axed staff mortgages and reduced other benefits. The union claimed that most of the 1,800 staff who signed new contracts only agreed because they feared losing their jobs.

Unifi is taking the case to an employment tribunal. The six who earned between £18,000 and £30,000 a year, are also planning unfair dismissal cases.

Biotech firm cuts losses

A sharp increase in income from joint ventures with big drugs companies helped Cambridge Antibody Technology cut its annual losses by 60% to £5.15m before tax.

The biotechnology firm specialises in tie-ups in which it provides human antibodies as targets for pharmaceutical groups' research. Its revenue jumped from £1.8m to £10.1m.

The company confirmed plans for an imminent listing on the US Nasdaq market but denied suggestions that it was planning a big fund-raising. This sent the shares up 385p to £31, following a fall from £42 since the beginning of the month.

PPR dismisses LVMH overture

French luxury goods group LVMH proposed a ceasefire yesterday in its battle with retailer PPR, which snatched control of Gucci from under its nose last year.

But the overture was quickly dismissed by PPR as little more than legal posturing and a thinly veiled attempt to break its alliance with Gucci.

LVMH has been seeking to sever the ties between PPR and Gucci by legally contesting the manner in which PPR won a 42% stake in the Florentine fashion house last year.

That increase cut LVMH's 34% stake to 20.6% and left some €1.8bn of LVMH capital tied up in a non-strategic stake that gave it no seat on Gucci's board.

fields.headline: Cazenove to float in 2002
fields.standfirst: Last of old-style City partnerships heads for the market
fields.trailText: Cazenove, the blue-blood broking firm, is to bring down the curtain on 177 years of history by ending its partnership structure and seeking a £1.5bn flotation on the London Stock Exchange.
fields.body:
Cazenove, the blue-blood broking firm, is to bring down the curtain on 177 years of history by ending its partnership structure and seeking a £1.5bn flotation on the London Stock Exchange.

The move ends the unlimited liability of the 80-strong partnership, one of the last major ones to survive the 1986 Big Bang.

For the first time a value will be put on the stakes held by partners in the highly regarded firm. These could be worth on average as much as £18m each.

Ahead of the flotation in 2002 of a minority stake, Cazenove plans to sell 10% of the firm to outside investors next year. Under the new structure, all 1,170 employees, from the frock-coated doormen in the discreet wood-panelled head office in the shadow of the Bank of England to the top corporate financiers, will be offered shares in the business.

As a result of the change, Cazenove hopes to have a "flexible compensation currency" to make it easier to attract and retain key staff at a time when share stakes are an increasingly common way of being paid in the City.

Mark Loveday, the senior partner of Cazenove, said it would put an end to the system whereby partners' "homes, braces and shirts" were at risk through the unlimited nature of the partnership.

It will make it easier, too, for the firm to raise money. Many rivals had said that without this Cazenove's growth could be inhibited.

Mr Loveday was greeted with applause from the firm's staff last night as he announced the decision, was taken unanimously at a secret partners' meeting over the weekend following a six-month review of the business. He also named 42 new partners yesterday.

Mr Loveday, who is to retire after the partnership structure is eradicated next year, described the move as "evolution not revolution".

The change follows an unprecedented wave of mergers and acquisitions among leading financial firms, in cluding one of its former neighbours in the City, Flemings, which was sold to Chase Manhattan this year.

But David Mayhew, a Cazenove partner who is to become chairman, insisted that this had not forced the partnership to follow suit.

Instead, he said, the firm saw opportunities for Cazenove to benefit from of the race among its rivals to become global organisations.

Cazenove, which acts as broker to half of the 100 biggest companies in the country, including Bank of Scotland and Glaxo Wellcome, has stood out in the City by holding on to the past.

Its head office has a tiny, gold-handled entrance in a narrow street, in contrast to its competitors which have built vast new impersonal officers. It too has now called in the office builders.

Rivals said last night that the biggest challenge for Cazenove would be retaining the firm's atmosphere after following the route taken by Goldman Sachs a year ago when it floated on the New York stock exchange.

Not all partners in Cazenove have equal stakes, so it will be difficult to calculate the stakes owned by each of the partners, who will not take any of their money out of the firm. Two new non-executive directors from outside the firm are to be appointed to the board.

Going public: A very private banker

David Mayhew is a City legend, a respected name and face in the boardrooms of many leading companies. Over two decades, the slim, immaculately presented, pinstripe-suited figure has won Cazenove a role in as many as 50% of takeovers and mergers.

Yet Mr Mayhew first found prominence in the mid-1980s when he was arrested and charged in connection with the Guinness share support scheme. All charges were later dropped against Mr Mayhew and his reputation for assiduous advice remained intact.

His style is to be discreet, keeping a behind-the-scenes profile not just for himself but for Cazenove too. That news did not leak out when more than 100 partners and new partners learned over the weekend of plans for a stock market flotation is testimony to the firm's reputation for secrecy.

Rivals' predictions of Mr Mayhew's impending retirement were wide of the mark. He is to become chairman of the new look Cazenove, which he was pains to describe yesterday as the opposite of becoming a global investment bank.

"We're selling advice," Mr Mayhew said. "The model everyone else is following is to have the biggest balance sheet and sell the most products. We're going in the other direction."

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with ... Hayley Cropper
fields.trailText: Getting personal with ... Hayley Cropper
fields.body:
Full name: Julie Claire Hesmondhalgh

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and if so, why?

No, but I was known as "Hesy" throughout school.

Have you ever lied about your age and if so, why?

When I was 19, I replied to a lonely hearts ad saying I was 27 as he was much older.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Big-arsed leftie with unlimited access to showbiz parties.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

I stole a strawberry Chubba Chup from Rita's cabin.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

Gave a lift on a rainy day for two Man U fans and I don't even support them.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Sue Nichols, who plays Audrey - always a nice word to say about everybody.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've worked with?

NL. When I was a cleaner in Knightsbridge.

Has a critic ever made you cry?

Garry Bushell, he hates me and Hayley.

What would you advertise without a fee?

Amnesty International and Cadbury's.

What would you never advertise?

McDonalds, banks and Stage Coach.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?

Garry Bushell, guilt and random drunken memories from the evening before.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

Driving my camper van down country lanes singing to Billy Bragg's The Internationale at the top of my voice.

 40 Years On Coronation Street, tonight, 9.30pm, ITV.

fields.headline: Sisters in arms
fields.trailText: Daylight Robbery | Private Lives Of The Pharaohs | The Royle Family | Human Remains
fields.body:
The new series of Daylight Robbery (ITV) began with an American-style resumé of what had happened in the first series, in which Kathy Lawrence (Michelle Collins) and her gang of Essex housewives launched into a new career of armed robbery to pay off those troublesome household bills. There were lots of armed policemen running around in kevlar flak jackets shouting at people, as Michelle scarpered with the loot in a light aeroplane and Emily Woof's Paula outsmarted the pursuing Filth by hailing a taxi. Easy!

In series two, it's a year later, Michelle is living in Florida with a suitcase full of stolen banknotes, and Paula is pretending to be an East European refugee called Anya working as an au pair for Harriet Howell (Beth Goodard). While anything resembling "realism" had obviously been banned from the set of series one, the new one takes implausibility to impressive new extremes, with only Harriet's cancer diagnosis striking a discordant note of private anguish.

In particular, the Florida sequences felt as though they had been shot for an entirely unconnected production for a US network, with their tourist-bureau landscape shots in sun-drenched primary colours, accompanied by ham-fisted backing music.

No doubt the idea was to aim for export sales in the US, but the story line about murderous drug dealers was knee-jerk cliché of the most idiotic kind, and scenes of Michelle cavorting on a palm-fringed beach in the sunset with boyfriend Chris, to the schlocktastic strains of The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face, were straight out of French and Saunders. But you never know, maybe American programme buyers will mistake it for a new series of Absolutely Fabulous.

Private Lives Of The Pharaohs (Channel 4) threatened to be another attempt to conjure sensational revelations from the distant past (usually involving orgies, cannibalism and lost tribes), in a desperate effort to make archaeology dumb and lurid enough for mass consumption. But it turned into something altogether weightier.

Egyptologists have long puzzled over the significance of the blue lotus flower depicted in numerous tomb paintings. The flower clearly had symbolic or ritualistic significance, and experts surmised that it had some connection with both sex and rebirth in the afterlife. But only recently has a squad of Manchester-based scientists got around to laying full-scale forensic siege to the issue.

At first they thought the lotus might have narcotic properties, but after much mucking about with spectroscopes and test tubes, and comparing ancient lotus samples with flowers plucked from Stapeley water garden in Cheshire, they found that Essence of Lotus has viagra-like attributes, enhancing sexual vigour and promoting general good health.

Although this was moderately interesting, where the film scored was in using this discovery as leverage for a wider investigation of the lives of the ancient Egyptians. The scientists only had a single mummy from the Manchester Museum to work with, this being the embalmed carcass of a so-called "temple chantress", but examination of tissue samples provided evidence of a daunting litany of debilitating health problems.

The luckless chantress had suffered from intestinal worms, a lung condition called "sand pneumoconiosis", a degenerative disease of the joints, a fractured vertebrae and a slipped disc, and a dose of bilharzia, a parasitic disease carried by water snails. Since she was from a privileged class, likely to have enjoyed better health than the proletariat, life for the ancient Egyptian workers was probably sordid, painful and brief. If the Valley of the Kings was in reality a vale of tears, no wonder the life-enhancing properties of the blue lotus accorded it sacred status.

The Royle Family (BBC1) ended its run with the christening of Baby David, celebrated with a family booze-up from hell. Smartly observed though it may have been, the endless parade of ignorance and gormlessness, mixed in with cringe-evoking sentimentality, was enough to induce vomiting after 15 minutes. Interesting to compare it with Human Remains (BBC2), in which Rob Brydon and Julia Davis enacted the Beckett-like desolation of the home life of Stephen and 'shell in suburban Wales. Treading deftly along the fault lines between stupidity, bigotry and failed expectations, it offered two pokes in the eye for every belly laugh.

fields.headline: CJD review over German blood
fields.standfirst: Special report: BSE
fields.trailText: Experts on the safety of medicines will consider within weeks whether they should ban blood products from Germany after its discovery of BSE in cattle and the announcement of a suspected victim of the related human disease.
fields.byline: James Meikle and Tony Paterson  in Berlin
fields.body:
Experts on the safety of medicines will consider within weeks whether they should ban blood products from Germany after its discovery of BSE in cattle and the announcement of a suspected victim of the related human disease.

Clotting factors to treat haemophiliacs are among such products used in Britain although the Department of Health last night admitted it did not know the extent of the potential problem.

Meanwhile, ministers will wait until the end of the week, when British food standards officials have returned from meeting their counterparts in Paris, before determining whether to ban beef imports from France where there has been a steep rise in BSE cases and mounting concerns over beef safety.

The health department has based policies for using vaccines and other injected material on countries being free of BSE and variant CJD. Most plasma supplied through the manufacturing arm of the national blood service, BPL, is imported from the US.

However, NHS trusts can use other licensed sources, including blood products from Germany. A centre treating haemophiliacs at the Royal Victoria infirmary in Newcastle confirmed last night it was among those using supplies, although there would be a review in January.

Patients and their families who have campaigned for all haemophiliacs to be given synthetic, laboratory-produced blood, instead of human-derived products, said the latest news from Germany "is psychologically very damaging for people who have to continue to inject this material."

Members of Haemophilia North demanded action from the centre, whose medical director, Mike Laker, said: "Logic would suggest there must come a time when all existing haemophiliacs are going to receive recombinant (laboratory produced) material."

There is already a huge row over policy in England, where most health authorities are only offering the alternative to children and newly diagnosed haemophiliacs. But ministers now appear ready to follow the example of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, where a switch for all patients has been agreed.

A health department spokesman said sourcing of blood products was kept under constant review. "As the BSE epidemic spreads and cases emerge, clearly we need to ensure blood products are sourced from places that are BSE and vCJD-free."

The NHS has already introduced controls on blood donations here, including the filtering out of white blood cells, because of the theoretical risk of BSE-like infection being spread through transfusions.

It is now considering banning anyone who has ever received a transfusion in Britain from giving blood and a growing list of countries, including Germany, is refusing to accept blood donations from citizens who lived in Britain between 1980 and 1996, the period in which the risk to exposure to BSE here was highest.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Under African Skies | File on 4
fields.body:
Fela Anikulapo Kuti was a hugely popular Nigerian singer who died of AIDS three years ago. His band, which played at a Lagos venue dubbed The Shrine by Kuti, included his 27 wives. For years the singer used this popularity to attack the blatant corruption of successive governments. The authorities responded with harassment and repression. Now, as Robin Denselow reports in Under African Skies (1.30pm, Radio 4), Kuti's son Femi is trying to follow in his father's footsteps.

Allan Urry looks at the repeated failures of children's social services in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). He cites two, admittedly extreme, cases. A 13-year-old girl, taken into local authority care, eventually admitted to case workers that she regularly operated as a prostitute. She was found to have four varieties of venereal disease and is now dead. A boy, aged 15, also supposedly in care, was later found battered to death near his local authority home.

fields.headline: Pop stars hail Bowie's influence
fields.trailText: He became one of the most subversive icons of his generation and now the senior statesman of rock, David Bowie, has been named as the artist who has most influenced today's music stars.
fields.body:
He became one of the most subversive icons of his generation and now the senior statesman of rock, David Bowie, has been named as the artist who has most influenced today's music stars.

Born David Jones in a south London suburb, the 53-year-old star, who recorded his first solo album 37 years ago, was voted as the most influential artist by more than 100 pop stars interviewed in the latest edition of New Musical Express magazine.

With his androgynous appearance, south London accent and fluid sexuality, Bowie was at the forefront of 1970s youth culture. Credited with having influenced several pop genres, including punk and glam-rock, his 1972 album and tour about an androgynous space-rock messiah, The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars, sparked a huge following that he continues to enjoy.

NME interviewers asked today's generation of stars which band or artist made them pick up a guitar or write their first lyrics. Stars who voted for Bowie included Brett Anderson from Suede, Brian Molko from Placebo, Ed O'Brien from Radiohead, and Marilyn Manson.

Radiohead was second in the NME list with the Beatles taking third position.

Bono, lead singer of U2 whose chart career spans two decades, nominated Radiohead because of their new live show and the lead singer's voice.

The grandfathers of hip-hop, Public Enemy, took fourth place in the survey. Miles Davis, Kraftwerk and the Sex Pistols took fifth, sixth and seventh place respectively.

American rapper Eminem, famed as much for his violent, homophobic and sexist persona as his music, took eighth position.

His nominators included Shaun Ryder of Black Grape and formerly the hit 1980s band, Happy Mondays.

Stars such as Stevie Wonder, Bob Dylan and The Velvet Underground made the top 20. Spice girl Victoria Beckham said that she nominated Wonder, who took 11th place, because she had grown up listening to his music.

The top 10

1 David Bowie 2 Radiohead 3 The Beatles 4 Public Enemy 5 Miles Davis 6 Kraftwerk 7 Sex Pistols 8 Eminem 9 Nick Drake 10 The Smiths

webTitle: Gore pins last hope on judges

fields.headline: Gore pins last hope on judges
fields.standfirst:
Democrats launch series of challenges

Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore launched a three-pronged legal challenge in Tallahassee yesterday to the election results certified in Florida on Sunday night, which gave victory in the presidential race to his Republican rival, George W Bush.
fields.body:
Al Gore launched a three-pronged legal challenge in Tallahassee yesterday to the election results certified in Florida on Sunday night, which gave victory in the presidential race to his Republican rival, George W Bush.

The thrust of his argument is that many votes have still not been counted properly and that more than 10,000 votes have not been counted at all.

Effectively, the challenges are as follows:

In Miami-Dade county the Gore team seeks the completion of the manual recount which was stopped, in the words of the legal summary of the action, "after a mob intimidated the canvassing board to reverse a decision - made just hours earlier - to complete the count".

This is a reference to Republican supporters who protested noisily in the counting building and, say the Democrats, affected the canvassing board's judgment.

There are also about 10,000 ballots that were not counted because the machine in Miami-Dade could not read them. The action seeks to have these votes counted. In addition, the suit seeks to include at least the 368 votes that were counted in a partial recount which showed a net gain for Mr Gore of 156 votes.

 In Nassau county the canvassing board rejected a machine recount which gave an extra 51 votes to Mr Gore. He is now seeking to have those votes included.
 In Palm Beach county the Gore team seeks a judicial review of the ballots because it does not believe that the canvassing board "determined the voter's intent".

The Democrats suggest that up to 2,000 ballots were improperly rejected by the board, and say that they could give Mr Gore a net gain of between 300 and 600 votes. Hundreds of indented ballots were not counted, they allege. They will also challenge the decision by the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, not to allow the hand recount votes.

At the heart of the action, as Democrat lawyers explained at the weekend, is a belief that many votes that were intended for the vice-president have still not been counted.

Once Miami-Dade decided not to continue hand-counting, Mr Gore's team knew that it would have an uphill battle. The team decided at that stage that it would pursue the legal challenges and has tried to prepare the US public for this.

The complaint has been filed in Leon county circuit court. The plaintiffs are listed as Al Gore, Joe Lieberman, Mr Gore's running mate, and the Florida Democratic party. The defendants are the canvassing boards of Miami-Dade, Nassau and Palm Beach, George W Bush, his running mate, Dick Cheney, and Katherine Harris.

A separate legal action was launched by voters in Seminole county, where Republican officials had filled in the identification numbers missing on 4,700 absentee ballots. If the ID numbers had been missing, the votes would have been discarded. Individual voters have filed suit alleging that this is illegal.

According to a Gore spokesman, the vice-president's team will not join this action, even though most of the votes that would be dismissed would be Republican. It is felt in the Gore camp that, since the Democrats are arguing that every intended vote should count, it would be hypocritical to challenge on a technicality votes that were clearly stated. However, a strict legal ruling could still throw out the votes, putting Mr Gore ahead.

The case was transferred yesterday to the state court in Tallahassee which is handling other challenges, a court official said.

The Bush team is continuing with a US supreme court case due to be heard on Friday. This will seek to rule out all hand recounts that have taken place, thus confirming a Bush victory. Defeat for Mr Bush here would have a damaging effect on his credibility but might not affect the result.

fields.headline: What the papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: Atlanta Journal and Constitution,  Boston Globe,  San Francisco Chronicle
fields.body:
Atlanta Journal and Constitution

We know that this is history we are living through. The possibility that a candidate who got most votes might end up losing this race was more than enough to make it notable.

The fact that the election may ride on 400 to 500 votes out of almost 6m cast in Florida, and more than 100m nation wide, took the situation to another level. But we should be concerned about just what kind of history we're making. There will be people on both sides who look back on their rhetoric and behaviour during this period with a lot of regret. Or at least there should be.

Boston Globe

Katherine Harris's decision to certify the Florida presidential vote with only partial recounts did not close the entangled case of the 2000 election.

Harris appeared to be acting within her rights when she denied a request from Palm Beach county to extend the deadline for the hand recount until 9am today. But to deny all of the Palm Beach manual recounts flies in the face of the ruling, which blocked her authority to precipitously certify the vote in the first place.This regrettable act only adds to the grounds upon which the Gore campaign will be contesting the certification.

San Francisco Chronicle

The US supreme court will not be hearing arguments about the hand counts in Florida until Friday. The legal war that neither candidate professes to want, but both continue to escalate, has not run its course.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bomb under car defused
fields.body:
Bomb under car defused

A booby-trap bomb containing two pounds of commercial explosive, found under a car, was defused by army bomb experts in Drumshane, Co Fermanagh yesterday. The RUC said it did not know why the target had been chosen.

Police inspector on theft charge

Inspector Neil O'Byrne, 40, of Cleveland police, appeared before Teesside magistrates yesterday charged with theft, forgery and breaching the Data Protection Act. He was bailed until January 24.

Depression link to deprivation

A three-year study has revealed that half of all depression among GPs' patients is linked to how rundown the surrounding area is. Researchers at the University of Southampton studied nearly 18,500 patients across Hampshire.

Footballer arrested

The Coventry City footballer Carlton Palmer, 34, was arrested at his home in Sheffield early yesterday after failing a drink-drive breath test, police said yesterday. He was later released on bail until January 31.

Pay deals edge over 3%

Pay settlements in the three months to October took average awards over 3% for the first time since January 1999, said the pay analysts Industrial Relations Services.

Divorce 'better for children'

Bickering parents should end an unhappy marriage for the sake of the children, according to a survey for Bella magazine. The study of 1,000 people revealed that 64% believed divorce was better for children than living in misery.

Soccer manager in court

The trial of former Southampton manager David Jones on charges of assault and indecency against boys in a Merseyside care home was adjourned yesterday at Liverpool crown court. Jones, 44, pleaded not guilty.

Murdered girl's mother 'positive'

Sara Payne, mother of murdered schoolgirl Sarah, said yesterday she was "very positive" after the discovery of scraps of clothing thought to belong to the eight-year-old were found in a hedgerow near to where her body was found at Pulborough, West Sussex.

Menstrual link to migraine

Women migraine sufferers have double the chance of an attack during the first two days of their menstrual cycle, an American study revealed yesterday.

Hovercraft for museum

Two hovercraft which plied the Channel for 33 years, the Princess Anne and the Princess Margaret, are going to the Hovercraft Museum at Gosport after attempts to sell them failed.

webTitle: Peering from behind Bush, Al looks like a loser

fields.headline: Peering from behind Bush, Al looks like a loser
fields.standfirst:
Weary public wants an end to election strife

Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: As the Gore campaign went to court yesterday in an attempt to overturn George W Bush's victory certification in Florida, it faced a parallel and equally important battle for public opinion on a playing field which was tilting increasingly against the vice-president.
fields.body:
As the Gore campaign went to court yesterday in an attempt to overturn George W Bush's victory certification in Florida, it faced a parallel and equally important battle for public opinion on a playing field which was tilting increasingly against the vice-president.

Senior Democrats insisted that Sunday night's formal certification by Katherine Harris, Florida's Republican secretary of state, did not cement Governor Bush's status as president-elect.

But most analysts agreed that the Gore team faced the tough task of warding off a sense of inevitability gathering around the idea of a Bush administration.

A snap poll conducted by ABC News and the Washington Post found that 60% of those asked thought Mr Gore should stand down, including 26% of his own supporters.

As sports analogies abounded, even Democrats were conceding that it was one thing to argue with the umpire but quite another to carry on quarrelling once the umpire had passed judgment.

Meanwhile the Bush camp was striving to deepen the sense of finality underlying Ms Harris's pronouncement without appearing too presumptious. For the first time since the vote, campaign officials talked openly about preparations for the White House, although they avoided using the phrase "president-elect".

Despite this note of caution, Democratic party support for the vice-president's legal efforts appears to have been galvanised by Republican behaviour.

Orchestrated raucous protests in Miami-Dade county were described by one Democrat official as "brownshirt tactics".

Even before Mr Bush made his television appearance, Mr Gore's staff telephoned executives of television networks and major newspapers urging them to avoid portraying Mr Bush as the country's 43rd president-in-waiting.

Their effort succeeded, for headline writers largely avoided annointing Mr Bush as the winner, focusing instead on Friday's supreme court hearing on the election as the next critical bout in a continuing struggle.

Time and Newsweek portrayed both candidates on their covers, albeit with Mr Bush in the foreground and the vice-president peering over his shoulder.

Opinion articles in the principal newspapers reflected the uphill task now facing Mr Gore. While pro-Republican columnists roundly condemned the vice-president, normally staunch Democrats offered only tepid defences.

Ironically, the Bush campaign team's decision last week to appeal to the supreme court may buy the Gore camp a few more days of public patience, while the vice-president's lawyers scramble for votes in the Florida counties.

"He had better find a court somewhere that will allow those votes ... to be counted pretty quickly," Bob Herbert, a liberal commentator for the New York Times, warned.

"Because time is running out for Mr Gore."

webTitle: Brain surgery on hold due to lack of nurses

fields.headline: Brain surgery on hold due to lack of nurses
fields.trailText: A hospital which has been forced to cancel "routine" brain operations said its predicament reflected a national shortage of nurses.
fields.body:
A hospital which has been forced to cancel "routine" brain operations said its predicament reflected a national shortage of nurses.

Nine of the 41 staff in the neurosurgical unit at Derriford Hospital in Plymouth are away through sickness, training or maternity leave, leaving eight of 19 beds closed so remaining staff can concentrate on those needing emergency care.

Patients who require routine surgery, mainly for spinal conditions, have been told their operations have been put on hold until February.

Even six patients who need emergency treatment, including two with tumours and one threatened with paralysis, must wait as immediate life-threatening conditions take priority.

Consultant neurosurgeon James Palmer said the decision was not taken lightly. "The national shortage of specially trained nurses means that it is extremely difficult to recruit the number we need to keep the unit fully staffed.

"There are no quick fixes, so we had to take the decision to close some beds in the interest of patient safety. We felt our duty was to provide a safe but limited service, rather than compromise patients."

Acting director of operations John Yarnold said: "We are under-resourced but this is a national problem. I apologise to all those who have had their operations put on hold."

Two agency nurses are due to join the unit next month and they will be joined by three of the unit's own staff returning from absence, allowing three ward beds to reopen.

The hospital trust said people needing life-saving surgery would still be operated on and it hoped that many of the more routine cases would be dealt with before February.

Derriford is currently short of about 90 nurses and has been trying to lure potential staff with free weekend breaks in a city hotel, including a job interview.

webTitle: Councils given 6.7% funding rise, with strings attached

fields.headline: Councils given 6.7% funding rise, with strings attached
fields.trailText: Ministers yesterday increased town hall funding in England next year by over twice the level of inflation in an attempt to improve specific local services such as education and social care.
fields.body:
Ministers yesterday increased town hall funding in England next year by over twice the level of inflation in an attempt to improve specific local services such as education and social care.

But the 6.7% rise, giving English councils £44 bn from next April is tied to cash going to specific areas for the first time, rather than a lump sum going into one large pot. While the Labour-led Local Government Association cautiously welcomed the £2.8bn rise, Liberal Democrats said the annual settlement would lead to Whitehall exerting increasing control over town halls.

Adrian Sanders, the Lib Dems' local government spokesman, said £8.3bn alone would be tied up in specific grants, "removing choice from local people and elected rep resentatives by stealth". But the local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, told MPs that the increase would boost the quality of life of people across the country. "This means extra resources to help councils deliver better services - everything from education, social services and policing through to libraries, parks and transport."

While the government retained reserved powers to cap council spending she did not expect to have to take that option. "We expect councils to behave responsibly - they need to take into account this represents a substantial increase, way above inflation for local services."

To ensure that specific councils did not lose major government support because of a decreasing population or other factors, a new system for calculating local need would be introduced. This will involve setting a floor and a ceiling on grant increases for councils with education and social services responsibilities. The floor will ensure that such town halls got at least 3.2% more grants next year, with a ceiling set at 6.5%. The minister also revealed that the health secretary, Alan Milburn, would shortly announce £100m for social services.

The Tory local government spokesman, Nigel Waterson, accused the government of taxation by stealth, claiming that over the last three years council tax had increased by 23%, equal to £150 on the average band D property.

Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association, said tying specific increases to individual services would mean Whitehall exerting an overbearing pressure on local councils.

fields.headline: Psychiatrist 'preyed on women patients'
fields.trailText: A retired consultant psychiatrist was accused yesterday of preying on vulnerable women, raping and indecently assaulting them after they were referred to him with depression, after family bereavements or for psychiatric assessment.
fields.body:
A retired consultant psychiatrist was accused yesterday of preying on vulnerable women, raping and indecently assaulting them after they were referred to him with depression, after family bereavements or for psychiatric assessment.

William Kerr, 75, from York, frightened his victims into silence for years, Leeds crown court was told, by telling them that they were mental patients whose word would never be believed against his.

The consultant is suffering from brain damage and was found unfit to plead by a previous jury.

The hearing is a "finding of fact" trial, a relatively unusual legal process to decide, in the absence of a plea, whether he committed the four rapes and 15 indecent assaults that have been alleged.

Paul Worsley QC, prosecuting, said that the consultant, who retired 13 years ago, had deliberately taken advantage of the "helplessness and hopelessness" of a large number of women in acute distress.

He had chosen his victims from both NHS and private hospitals in York, Harrogate and Ripon, assessing their vulnerability before selecting targets.

"Over 20 years, he sadly abused the trust placed in him as a consultant psychiatrist," said Mr Worsley.

"He would see a woman patient on his own in his room. He would talk about sex being at the root of their problems. He would touch them. He would expose himself to them and invite them to touch his penis.

"On some occasions he even required them to have sexual intercourse with him, the doctor. They were women with their own problems. They were vulnerable. They trusted him completely and in his room they did as he demanded. Afterwards they felt unclean, ashamed, humiliated."

The court heard that some women had told their GPs, but the doctors did nothing because they thought their patients "unreliable".

Mr Worsley added that the victims were frightened of Kerr's legal and medical networking powers.

He said: "They felt if they complained about Dr Kerr he might speak to other psychiatrists and no one would ever treat them and in some cases, for those who were profoundly depressed that he would have them locked up in a mental hospital. Such was the remarkable hold that Dr Kerr exerted over his women patients.

"Each thought they were the only victim. They did not realise that over the years he had abused many, many women for his sexual gratification."

The jury of seven men and five women was told that the doctor's reign of terror had only been broken when a woman went to the police after seeing the consultant af ter an interval of six years and suffering a second sexual assault.

Other patients came forward during an inquiry by North Yorkshire health authority and others made statements after publicity about the affair, including an analysis in the Guardian.

They included Kerr's first alleged victim, who is now 50, who saw the consultant in 1969 because she wanted an abortion.

Mr Worsley said that the doctor told her to lie on a couch and close her eyes. When she opened them, he was standing by her naked and she was forced to commit a sex act.

Kerr denied any sexual misconduct or inappropriate behaviour during interviews with police after his arrest in August 1997.

Lawyers for the consultant have lodged an application under the Human Rights Act that the proceedings are in breach of his human rights.

The hearing continues.
