Lawyers for the consultant have lodged an application under the Human Rights Act that the proceedings are in breach of his human rights. The hearing continues.

webTitle: Liverpool photographer's heritage to be immortalised on home ground

fields.headline: Liverpool photographer's heritage to be immortalised on home ground
fields.trailText: The National Trust is to acquire the home, negatives and old bicycle of an internationally-admired Liverpool photographer.
fields.body:
The National Trust is to acquire the home, negatives and old bicycle of an internationally-admired Liverpool photographer.

The move means that the life's work of Edward Fitzmaurice Chambré Hardman will be preserved in the city where he ran a photographic studio for 40 years.

Hardman spent much of his time taking portraits of babies, brides and actors who performed at the Liverpool Playhouse, including Ivor Novello and Dame Beryl Bainbridge.

But out of hours he would take pictures of the Liverpool cityscape and with his wife Margaret would travel to Scotland and Ireland to produce landscapes now hailed as masterpieces of the pictorialist school.

His picture of the aircraft carrier Ark Royal rising like a ghost above the terraces of Birkenhead has become a classic.

When Hardman died in 1988, his home in a beautiful Georgian house in the city centre was found to be full of ephemera including wartime tins of baked beans, ancient contraceptives, vintage frocks and a touching series of love letters as well as business archives. He left the house and its contents to a trust which has since struggled to find cash to conserve 120,000 negatives and glass plates and to open a museum.

Earlier this year, the Hardman trust announced defeat and prompted outrage in Liverpool when it said it would hand over the negatives to the National Museum of Photography, Film and Television in Bradford. Now the National Trust has agreed to take on the house, studio and collections if the Hardman trust formally agrees to hand them over next month.

It will invest £500,000 if a bid for £760,000 from the heritage lottery fund is successful. The house should be open to the public within five years.

"Thanks to Liverpool city council's generous offer to store and care for the photographic collection, Hardman's work will remain in the city and there will be public access to it," said Keith Halstead, the National Trust's area manager for Merseyside.

The deal was welcomed by Roger Prideaux, chairman of the Hardman trust. "It achieves all the things we wanted to achieve when we set out but couldn't manage because we did not have strong financial partners."

fields.headline: Care UK mental health move pays off
fields.trailText: Care UK said yesterday it expected to cash in on the growing cost to local authorities of running homes for people with mental health problems.
fields.body:
Care UK said yesterday it expected to cash in on the growing cost to local authorities of running homes for people with mental health problems.

The healthcare group, which reported a 21% rise in profits during the year to September, said last year's decision to set up a separate mental health division had justified the investment.

Chief executive Richard Clough said the division had grown from managing one home to 13 in the past year. Its first nursing unit for adults with enduring mental illness had been complemented by a unit in Coventry offering a dependency rehabilitation service for adults discharged from secure forensic facilities.

"Working in partnership with the NHS trust, who provide clinical expertise, the unit has been an undoubted success," Mr Clough said. "A similar service will open in Hackney in the new year."

The division was considering the acquisition of further homes and holding discussions with public sector authorities about four new schemes for the care of people with severe and enduring mental illness.

Care UK's chairman, John Nash, said the group's strategy of working in partnership with the public sector had been consistently successful. "We are now ideally placed to expand further as the government involves the private sector in its drive to satisfy modern healthcare demands," he said.

Contracted income, excluding inflation, rose from £175m to £215m last year and three major contracts still to come on stream would add a further £140m, he said.

Care UK concentrates on running and upgrading homes for public sector authorities under contract. Last year its capital investment topped £10m.

Pre-tax profits before goodwill rose from £6.26m to £7.57m. The board is proposing to lift the full year dividend by 16.7% to 2.1p a share.

fields.headline: Lazio sword hangs over Eriksson
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson may take up his post as England manager as early as next week, if Lazio's run of bad form continues.
fields.byline: Paddy Agnew in Rome and Martin Thorpe
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson may take up his post as England manager as early as next week, if Lazio's run of bad form continues.

Despite public backing from Lazio's president Sergio Cragnotti, sources close to the club suggest that if Lazio lose to Leeds in the Stadio Olimpico on Tuesday night, Eriksson's career with the club will be over. Even a draw may not be enough to save him.

Having lost 1-0 away to Anderlecht on Wednesday, Lazio were beaten 2-0 at Parma in Serie A on Sunday, prompting fans on the Curva Nord to hold up a banner reading "Eriksson Go". Sunday's defeat was the team's fourth of the season, adding to the pressures that Eriksson brought on himself by pledging his future allegiance elsewhere.

The Swede defended himself with his usual dignity on Sunday night. "I've never thought of resigning and I'm not going to," he said. "Lazio's problems are elsewhere. I'm not the problem and that banner from the fans leaves me indifferent."

Cragnotti added that the banner was the work of "unstable fans who are incorrigible".

The fact that Leeds could hold Eriksson's future in their hands is an irony. The Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale was on the FA's head-hunting panel that chose Eriksson for the England job. Now, he could be instrumental in getting his man here early. That would certainly end the speculation about what is going to happen for England's friendly with Spain at Villa Park in February.

It was originally intended that the Swede would see out his contract with the Roman club before taking up his post as England manager in June.

Should Lazio terminate Eriksson's contract they would have a ready-made caretaker replacement in their former coach Dino Zoff, who resigned as national team manager following Euro 2000 after he was criticised by the Milan president Silvio Berlusconi and returned to Lazio in an administrative role.

Roberto Mancini, the 35-year-old former Sampdoria and Italy striker who is being groomed by Eriksson to be his successor, may not be thought of as quite ready for the top job, having only recently retired from playing. Alternative targets, such as Marcello Lippi, recently fired as Internazionale coach, and Alberto Zaccheroni, under pressure at Milan, may not be as readily available.

Yesterday the FA played down reports that Peter Taylor would refuse to take charge of the England team for the game against Spain if Eriksson picked the team in preparation for the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March.

Taylor was reported as saying at the weekend: "If I have the title of team manager for that game I would have to have the main input into the team. I will have to have a word about it if that is the plan."

Taylor is due in Italy this week to meet Eriksson for the first time and discuss strategy for the match. Eriksson's right-hand man, Tord Grip, who has been monitoring England's players in the Premiership, will also be present.

The FA remains confident that some time this week it will be able to confirm that Taylor and Manchester United's No2 Steve McClaren will take charge of the England side for the game against Spain. The pair led England in their last match, a 1-0 friendly defeat by Italy in Turin.

fields.headline: On the web -  Law constitutions
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor picks the best sites on political law
fields.body:
Legal education

Aimed at: teachers

Keep up to date with developments in law teaching at the Centre's site, which is aimed principally at university lecturers but is also helpful for teachers at secondary level.

Court service

Aimed at: A-level pupils and teachers

All the Court of Appeal's judgments are posted on this site, together with daily court listings and (in the Forms and Leaflets section) a guide to the workings of each type of court and issues such as divorce law, young witnesses, probate and making a claim.

Anatomy of a murder

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

With its "Rockin Supreme Court Cases" and glossary for the baffled, this exploration of the US criminal justice system will not appeal to everyone. But it leads younger students through a murder trial in compelling style and, if it were applied to English law, would be an invaluable resource.

UK justice web links

Aimed at: teachers and KS3 onwards

An exhaustive collection of links pertaining to every aspect of British justice - lobbying groups, quangos, criminologists, prisons, courts and security services.

Police forces

Aimed at: KS1-4

Many local police forces have web pages for children - usually about drugs, the Highway Code and personal safety - and these can be a useful practical introduction to the law for younger children.

Comparative constitutions

Aimed at: A-level students and teachers

If you want to compare the constitution of one country with another, this page links to dozens of examples.

Lord Chancellor

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

The Lord Chancellor is responsible for "securing the efficient administration of justice in England and Wales". His site has helpful guides to legal aid, magistrate's courts and the role of judges and QCs. The new Human Rights Act is covered at: http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk

The British Council

Aimed at: teachers

Part of the British Council's brief is to extend awareness of UK law to other countries. In so doing it explains the way our law relates to various issues in clear language - notably gender equality and justice and rights. The directory of links is also extremely useful.

Virtual supreme court

Aimed at: teachers

Another example of an imaginative US educational resource. Unlikely to be relevant to your course and aimed at undergraduates, Penn University's site is nonetheless an indication of what can be achieved on the web.

You can find more law sites at www.educationunlimited.co.uk/netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Hawksley Workman
fields.standfirst:
Hawksley Workman
12 Bar Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Hawksley Workman
12 Bar Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
I keep waiting for the tap dancing to begin. Hawksley Workman may be an accomplished guitarist singing picturesque songs of open roads and inner passions, but his reputation as an all-singing, all-tap-dancing Canadian precedes him. After all, you don't see much vaudeville these days. But he has obviously left his dancing shoes at home. So we have to be content to watch him shake a leg and strike a pose instead.

Workman, with his waistcoat and flowery necktie, is a strange combination of wild-west hustler and Oscar Wilde, his gait and movements those of a dandy, his voice by turns Tim Buckley and David Bowie. And his in-between-songs patter has the deferential crowd wondering whether to be charmed or simply amused.

"I brought my guitar in on a camel," Workman announces in one of his surreal diatribes, to scattered giggles and an awkward silence as the worthy ponder his words for hidden meaning. "You mean you've got the hump with it?" a brave soul asks. With his target in sight, Workman raises an eyebrow. "Hey, I guess we could put the spotlight around."

Not that that's likely. It's clear he's out to grab and maintain our attention, even though he sings with his eyes tightly shut. Stop Joking Around is a blues number from the debut album For Him and the Girls that showcases Workman's voice as it glides one moment, screams the next, in a fit of vocal gymnastics that would send Mariah Carey crying back to her singing teacher. But rather than trilling for trilling's sake, Workman uses his amazing range as a tool to complement the raw sounds of his guitar, his odd little noises enhancing the chords. With each screech and squeak, he moves his body, like a doll that cries when you press its stomach. There's a fey flick of the wrist as he reaches a high note, while a controlled kick marks a pause in the proceedings, before the intricate guitar parts start again. Wiping the sweat away from his eyes becomes a protracted, graceful interlude.

It's a charismatic and endearing performance, but one that detracts from the simple loveliness of the songs. Workman doesn't seem to be able to decide whether or not he wants to be a stylish mime artist or a lovelorn musician, and in trying to be both he leaves us confused, his eccentricity unique but uncomfortable.

When he stops putting on a show and gets down to singing, it's easy to get lost in the moment, as Workman's passion and attachment for his songs shines blindingly from him. Safe and Sound, with its romantic intentions and waltzy rhythm, is warm and poetic, while Don't Be Crushed is the perfect airport goodbye to the one you love.

As Workman holds a pitch-perfect high note for an inordinately long time, I start to fear for the glass in my hand and feel thankful he didn't break into a Fred Astaire dance routine after all.

 Further performances at the 12 Bar Club, London WC2 (020-7916 6989), on Thursday and December 7.

fields.headline: COE / Harnoncourt
fields.standfirst:
COE/ Harnoncourt
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
COE/ Harnoncourt
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Dvorak is one of Nikolaus Harnoncourt's recent enthusiasms. His voracious appetite for new fields to explore has carried him ever further from his beginnings as a pioneering interpreter of baroque and classical repertory and deeper and deeper into the 19th century. Brahms and Bruckner have already been tackled; now he has begun to record the Dvorak symphonies and symphonic poems, and the first half of his glorious concert with the Chamber Orchestra of Europe was devoted to the set of Slavonic Dances, Op 46.

These enduringly popular pieces could have been an unprepossessing start - there is the ever-present danger of over-familiarity, and anyone who has played in a youth orchestra is almost certainly to have learned at least one of them. But from the opening bars of the first dance, the whirling C major Furiant, it was clear that Harnoncourt was going to sweep away all traces of routine - the COE's playing sparkled, the rhythms had a insistent energy, the orchestral colours were vivid. With each movement there was the renewed sense of discovery, whether in the delicate woodwind and string tracery of the E minor second dance, the burnished, mahogany beginning of the fourth, or the stabbing accentuation that lifted each of the faster numbers on to a far higher plane than that of a mere orchestral lollipop. These were interpretations of the most extraordinary re-creative kind.

If after that the Pastoral Symphony seemed less exceptional, it was only because Harnoncourt's Beethoven is much more of a known quantity - he has, after all, recorded a complete cycle of the symphonies with the COE. But still in every movement there was something fresh and revealing - the subtle contrast between vibrato and non-vibrato in the strings' chording, and the supple layering of opening Allegro; the assault on the scherzo that was less Beethoven's "Merry Gathering in the Country" than a harking back to the world of Sturm und Drang; the broad, hymn-like paragraphs of the finale - and all was fabulously played.

fields.headline: Judith Weir's Indian odyssey
fields.standfirst:
Judith Weir/ Future Perfect
Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Judith Weir/ Future Perfect
Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Tabla and harp as the new drum'n'bass? Composer Judith Weir has become particularly fond of the combination of late, and while this beguiling east-west combination is unlikely to cut it as the latest club sensation, it makes a powerful case for cross-cultural collaboration.

Billed as a journey across time and continents, Future Perfect has its origins in a journey across Birmingham. The work is the outcome of a three-year association between Weir, the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group and acclaimed traditional storyteller, Vayu Naidu. Having witnessed Naidu in action, floating an improvised narrative across the pulsing undercurrent of tabla master Sarvar Sabri, Weir became fascinated by the possibilities of a western composer writing for an Indian storyteller and percussionist.

Given that neither Naidu's tales nor Sabri's tabla parts are committed to paper, it was clear that if the collaboration was to come about they would have to invent the means of achieving it. Weir, Sabri and the western musicians listened time and again to Naidu's tales until the overall dynamic had entered the bloodstream, and the musical architecture become fluid enough to follow a narrative that might never be told the same way twice.

Future Perfect, presented as a Contemporary Music Network tour, stands poised at that point on the silk route where oriental fluidity meets western formal design. Faced with such apparently incompatible elements, Weir's solution has been to disregard the distinction between eastern and western instruments, and to fashion an economically-scaled tone-poem through which Naidu extemporises her story like an extended, verbal cadenza.

This is intoxicating stuff, especially when offered intimately beneath atmospheric lighting and a beautiful, burnished, applique canopy created by local schoolchildren.

The programme is also something of a personal triumph for Birmingham Contemporary Music Group's cellist, Ulrich Heinen, whose detuning and dexterous technique emulates the glides and drone of the surbahar. Heinen's cross-continental virtuosity is employed to best advantage in the opening item, a mesmerising raga by Imrat Kahn, notated for solo cello and tabla. A sublime assimilation of the best of east and west.

 At the Dean Close School, Cheltenham (01242 227979), on Thursday, the Richard Attenborough Centre, Leicester (0116 252 2455), on Saturday, then touring.

Having witnessed Naidu in action, floating an improvised narrative across the pulsing undercurrent of tabla master Sarvar Sabri, Weir became fascinated by the possibilities of a western composer writing for an Indian storyteller and percussionist. Given that neither Naidu's tales nor Sabri's tabla parts are committed to paper, it was clear that if the collaboration was to come about they would have to invent the means of achieving it. Weir, Sabri and the western musicians listened time and again to Naidu's tales until the overall dynamic had entered the bloodstream, and the musical architecture become fluid enough to follow a narrative that might never be told the same way twice. Future Perfect, presented as a Contemporary Music Network tour, stands poised at that point on the silk route where oriental fluidity meets western formal design. Faced with such apparently incompatible elements, Weir's solution has been to disregard the distinction between eastern and western instruments, and to fashion an economically-scaled tone-poem through which Naidu extemporises her story like an extended, verbal cadenza. This is intoxicating stuff, especially when offered intimately beneath atmospheric lighting and a beautiful, burnished, applique canopy created by local schoolchildren. The programme is also something of a personal triumph for Birmingham Contemporary Music Group's cellist, Ulrich Heinen, whose detuning and dexterous technique emulates the glides and drone of the surbahar. Heinen's cross-continental virtuosity is employed to best advantage in the opening item, a mesmerising raga by Imrat Kahn, notated for solo cello and tabla. A sublime assimilation of the best of east and west.  At the Dean Close School, Cheltenham (01242 227979), on Thursday, the Richard Attenborough Centre, Leicester (0116 252 2455), on Saturday, then touring.

fields.headline: Clint Eastwood's boy lives up to the hype
fields.standfirst:
Kyle Eastwood
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Kyle Eastwood
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
There's something in the diffidence of Kyle Eastwood's playing that suggests that his famous father has been a mixed blessing. Being jazz-loving Clint's bass-playing son (and sharing both his father's physiognomy and dislike of superfluous chat), Eastwood has found the doors of the world's jazz clubs swinging open for him.

But he knows that if the impact of his name on the box office is substantial, the downside is that starstruck audiences will watch but not listen, and jazz audiences will listen and complain about the hype.

Doubts about these things might well contribute to young Eastwood's curious combination of a withdrawn and retiring sound (as if he's not sure he wants you to hear him) with a bass technique of formidable agility and lyricism - and, for that matter, his band's tendency to sound as if it's practising in a college rehearsal room until it eventually wakes up to where it really is.

At the Pizza Express, against a noisy audience in the early stages, they delivered Sonny Rollins's bop classic Oleo as if they didn't expect anybody to take much note of it, and then a mellow Eastwood original that began in reflective mood and quickly wound up to a mid-tempo swinger.

A subtle Eastwood solo intro, focused on delicate melodic dances very high on the fingerboard, then opened out into an emphatic feature suggestive of a McCoy Tyner band, but even by the fourth tune - a crisp account of Tom Waits's I Beg Your Pardon - the atmosphere of hesitant shyness hadn't yet receded.

But then it did on an original from Eastwood and his pianist Jon Regen, the North African-tinged Marrakesh. The percussive McCoy Tyner flavour that frequently surfaced in the show was a powerful characteristic here, but saxophonist Joel Frahm sounded far less rehearsed on soprano than he had on tenor, the ensemble interplay jumped a couple of notches, and a confident eagerness entered the performance.

Thelonious Monk's We See, played in double-tempo, found drummer Sunny Jain skimming along, and Joel Frahm was by now delivering a sax line that had a volatile life and destiny of its own.

Frahm's quirkily catchy original Paint the Fence completed the recovery, by which time the audience was hooked on the music and not just on how young Kyle's cheekbones caught the light.

webTitle: Business: Banks lose small business vote

fields.headline: Banks lose small business vote
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Small businesses' perception of their banks worsened dramatically this year for the first time since 1992, a worrying trend for the leading banks as the competition commission investigates small business banking.
fields.body:
Small businesses' perception of their banks worsened dramatically this year for the first time since 1992, a worrying trend for the leading banks as the competition commission investigates small business banking.

The drop in performance shown in the report by the Forum of Private Businesses was acknowledged by the banks' representative body yesterday as "very concerning".

The forum blamed the fall in service on restructuring within the banks and the handling of inquiries at centralised call centres.

More than 1,300 small businesses told the forum that their banks offered them a less reliable and less efficient service, and that they found it more difficult to gain access to their loan officers. Compared with two years ago, more businesses were considering changing their banks, which have in the past been able to rely on the inertia of their customers.

The performance registered in the survey has fallen back to 1996 levels. The forum suggested that banks should "benchmark" the impact of internal changes and any slowdown in the economy on small business.

"If bank restructuring has reduced their ability to support smaller firms when pressures on liquidity and working capital increase, then the implications in the event of an economic downturn could also be severe in terms of business closures," the forum said.

The survey findings come at a time when the small business banking market is being scrutinised by the competition commission.

After its acquisition of NatWest, Royal Bank of Scotland has a share of more than 30% of all accounts with small businesses.

HSBC, Barclays, Lloyds TSB, and other Scottish banks such as Bank of Scotland and Clydesdale have cornered much of the remainder of the market. Allied Irish Bank, with a small market share, registered a higher performance than the others.

Andy Brenan, director of customer relations at the British Bankers' Association, said that many of the problems for the banks could be to do with their "perception" of the customers.

fields.headline: Soft-shoe shuffle at the Theatre Royal
fields.standfirst:
Phoenix
Theatre Royal, York
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Phoenix
Theatre Royal, York
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Over the last 19 years Leeds-based Phoenix has led the way for black British dance. But like its fabulous namesake, the company has self-ignited and risen from the flames in several incarnations.

In the beginning there was the all-male line-up. Then came Phoenix Plus, with women brought in to enrich the mix. Home-grown dancers have come and gone recently and now Phoenix is preening its plumage with performers from Finland, Russia, Madagascar, Zimbabwe, South Africa and Jamaica.

This retrospective show, 19: Rewind & Come Again, gets its title from the Jamaican dance-hall slang for encore. It features dance bites from eight of the company's best-loved works, plus three new offerings, intercut with sharp video collagesfrom film-maker Jenson Grant and words from writers Tyrone Huggins and Sol B River.

Action comes thick and fast, dashing down memory lane with Bebe Miller's witty urban slant on the Highland fling, Spartan Reels (1992), spanking fresh and full of girl-power attitude, contrasting hugely with Pamela Johnson's elegant human architecture in Subject of the City (1991), a construction site of difficult balances and inverted bodies demanding great control and timing. Other old friends included Shapiro and Smith's hysterical romp Family (1992), with its wild acrobatics centred on a big yellow armchair. We have canoodling teenagers torpedoing wildly over it, and an insomniac Hugh Davis - the remaining Leeds dancer - desperately trying to get comfortable in it, edgily hunching, stretching and defying gravity.

The three new pieces created by artistic director Thea Nerissa Barnes and choreographer Andile Sotiya illustrate the inherent Phoenix vocabulary: Jamaican club moves, jazz and modern expressionism.

Hot to trot and fired up with catcalls, three couples show out in Brawta, Jamaican slang for a little extra. We're down at the dance-hall and it's a free-for-all as they let rip to the rap. This funky battle for dance supremacy is full of loose gyrations and peacock struts, each contender slipping on a black coat before they go for it. Raw and fun, it captures what early Phoenix was all about.

Barnes recalls the 1940s with snoods and soft-shoe shuffle in Key Club, a homage to the company's jazz heritage. The six dancers cut a rug with swinging jive and nifty footwork to the hopping sounds of Frisco Frog. In contrast, the horror of lynchings in the deep South is all too evident in Strange Fruit, a powerful solo for Sotiya, danced to Nina Simone's harrowing version of the song.

Gary Lambert's duet, Longevity (1990), was especially poignant in the hands of Tiia Ourila and Bawren Tavaziva. As the words of Martin Luther King's "I have a dream" oration punch out, they dance seamlessly, free at last.

fields.headline: The Tennis Show
fields.standfirst:
The Tennis Show
The Museum Of, London
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
The Tennis Show
The Museum Of, London
Rating: *
fields.body:
After creating a bit of a stir at this year's Edinburgh festival with the Andes air-crash show, The Ballad of Bobby Francois, the performance collective Shunt come down to earth with a bang. The Tennis Show is no more than a jolly jape with all the hallmarks of a student prank.

The real pity is that a company that has already proved itself capable of completely altering and unsettling audiences' perceptions by transforming spaces, should make so little of the Museum Of, one of the most intriguing performance venues in London.

Things begin promisingly enough with men and women being separated and herded into different rooms. In ours, two women, naked but for stuck-on moustaches, offered to sign autographs. A man wanders in and is expelled from the room. A figure swings from a rope ladder. The atmosphere is languid, as if this is a summer house party back in the 1920s. The women wander around and sit on two pristine white toilets. The music is jaunty: "This is not a game. Win, win, win." The audience waits for something to happen and I wonder idly whether the men are having a better time.

Then it's time for a nip of vodka and a journey through the clubhouse. On the other side, the men and women are reunited but forced to sit on benches on either side of a long, narrow, clay tennis court. Strangely the trampled earth makes you think of trenches. The surrounding netting is topped by barbed wire.

What follows is the rapid fire of balls thudding on to the empty court from a ball machine. A male and female umpire squabble. Linesmen and lineswomen Tippex in the white lines. But gradually the court markings and the net disappear. Only the calls continue. "Foot fault. Second service. Out." It is as if some strange ritual is being played out.

Eventually all that is left is the space that is now filled only by a young couple picnicking. They are obviously at the start of their relationship, at that golden moment when attraction and friendship turn to love. You wonder if everything else you have witnessed was the playing out of this relationship to its bitter end. The tennis match as the battle of the sexes, the death of love. All I know is that this brief scene of human emotion is a welcome injection of warmth into a performance that is otherwise extremely icy in more ways than one. The hot-water bottles provided for the audience are a nice touch.

The evening is never sufficiently interesting either theatrically or intellectually to hold your attention, and there is more to be learned about rules, ritual, transgression, the will to win and hating the person on the other side of the net, from a real tennis match.

 Until December 10. Box office: 020-7739 0990.
